fields.headline: Ronaldo injury fears eased
fields.trailText: Fears for the future of Ronaldo, the greatest player of his generation, were eased last night after an immediate operation in Paris went "perfectly" according to an Internazionale spokeswoman.
fields.body:
Fears for the future of Ronaldo, the greatest player of his generation, were eased last night after an immediate operation in Paris went "perfectly" according to an Internazionale spokeswoman.

She added that Inter's £17m Brazil striker should be playing again in seven or eight months after surgery lasting more than two hours in which doctors completely rebuilt the torn tendon in his right kneecap. But there will still be fears for Ronaldo, given that this latest surgery was to remedy precisely the same damage for which he had an operation five months ago.

Last night's surgery came less than 24 hours after a deathly hush settled on Rome's Olympic Stadium as it became clear that the Inter striker had again suffered a serious injury, only seven minutes into his long-awaited comeback.

That immediate sensation as he crashed, unchallenged, to the ground in agony was confirmed yesterday when the Paris-based surgeon Professor Gérard Saillant, who operated on him last November, examined the 23-year-old and decided at once that further surgery was necessary.

Ronaldo, who had been flown to the French capital on the Inter president Massimo Moratti's private jet, would not comment as he walked into the Pitie Salpetriere hospital on crutches, surrounded by security guards.

But as word spread of his latest setback during Inter's 2-1 defeat by Lazio, many questioned whether the former world player of the year would ever recover his greatness.

After pre-operative tests on Ronaldo yesterday, Inter announced they were "already sure" the latest injury would not end his career. Nevertheless there must be grave doubts as to effective he will now be. This latest cruel blow comes at the end of two dismal years in which he has rarely been out of the sick bay, having been plagued with knee tendon problems which flared up during the France 98 World Cup finals.

Even on Wednesday night the consoling presence of Moratti, who rushed to the dressing room after Ronaldo was carried off, could not stop him crying in pain and frustration.

Perhaps the combination of childhood poverty and the effects of constant top-level football on his teenage development has left Ronaldo lopsided, an athlete with a Ferrari turbo engine mounted on a Fiat 500 chassis which simply cannot bear the pressure.

Perhaps that is why yesterday's operation is the third carried out on his right knee, after last November's and one in the Netherlands in February 1996.

webTitle: Arcadia axes 3,500 jobs in fight for survival

fields.headline: Arcadia axes 3,500 jobs in fight for survival
fields.trailText: The UK's second biggest clothing retailer, the struggling Arcadia group, is to close down 400 high-street shops, axe its Principles for Men chain and cut 3,500 jobs in a fight for survival.
fields.body:
The UK's second biggest clothing retailer, the struggling Arcadia group, is to close down 400 high-street shops, axe its Principles for Men chain and cut 3,500 jobs in a fight for survival.

The company disclosed it had lost £60.8m in the last six months, including £52m of one-off costs, compared to a £23m profit over the same period last year.

Arcadia, which operates 15 separate high-street brands including Top Shop, Burton, Wallis, Dorothy Perkins, Miss Selfridge and Warehouse, has just been forced into a complicated refinancing with its 13 banks, led by HSBC, after it came close to breaching its banking covenants.

Its shares have underperformed the FTSE by 70% in the past year and slumped from 450p to less than 50p in the last two years. The group, which has 2,000 outlets and a £2bn annual turnover, is now valued at £85m with net debt of £217m.

Yesterday chief executive John Hoerner insisted that the group has been a victim of circumstances - price deflation, savage discounting, a downturn in the overall clothing market, a glut of retail space and an escalating rent bill for high street sites. He said clothing prices had declined 15% last year and while Arcadia's chains had matched the declining prices and held the group's 10.5% market share, it was being crippled by its rent bill.

His response is a new strategy, dubbed BrandMax, which will cost £90m to implement but should produce annual cost savings of £160m - including £88m in rent costs alone.

The plan will signal the demise of the Principles for Men brand, which operates 99 stand-alone stores and 53 concessions in department stores. The Principles for Women chain is also being "taken out of the mainstream", with the closure of 85 sites, leaving just 58 stand-alone outlets. Some 50 TopMan shops will also shut down and the brand will only exist alongside TopShop womenswear outlets, with 22 new such side-by-side stores planned.

More than 40 Miss Selfridge outlets will also be closed down and there will be a big shake-up of Dorothy Perkins and Burton stores to more side-by-side outlets. The group's space devoted to menswear will also be reduced

The Arcadia chief executive insisted he had "not considered resigning" and he was given a vote of confidence by chairman Adam Broadbent.

But analysts said the group's woes would "go on and on" and one described the shares, which closed down 1.5p at 48.5p, as "one for the brave".

fields.headline: A bad day for bananas
fields.standfirst: Our employment tribunal lawyer encounters a customer keeps coming back
fields.trailText: There aren't many repeat customers in the tribunal business. Apart from the sad serial-case souls for whom the tribunal system is a sort of outcropping of social services - somewhere to go for a bit of rather rough and unsatisfactory group therapy.
fields.body:
There aren't many repeat customers in the tribunal business. Apart from the sad serial-case souls for whom the tribunal system is a sort of outcropping of social services - somewhere to go for a bit of rather rough and unsatisfactory group therapy.

And Dave. Dave is my only non-corporate repeat customer. Not that Dave and I have ever got near a tribunal together. Dave likes to come along for a conference in Chambers about once a year with his solicitor to discuss whether his employer's latest bad doings might entitle him to resign and claim that he has been unfairly dismissed.

This year Dave came in February to see whether he might be able to resign yet. The catalogue of hardships this year:
 Christmas bonus frozen at last year's level;
 Delay in Dave's overtime payments being processed;
 Failure to investigate Dave's complaint about safety gloves being too tight.

Me: This isn't going to do it, Dave. I mean all these things are really too minor.
Dave: Fair enough.
Me: But you know, Dave, this is the third time you've come to see me. I get the feeling you really hate this job. Have you thought of just looking for something else and leaving?

Silence. Evidently Dave feels the only way he can leave the job with honour is if he is driven out.

So I was surprised when Dave's solicitor sent me papers again this week. Dave had been sacked for allegedly throwing a banana at his supervisor in the works canteen during a disagreement about safety gloves.

Or that was the supervisor's story. Dave's statement said that after a frustrating exchange with his supervisor, he turned to leave, tossing his banana at the coffe machine "in disgust", whereupon it must have bounced back (several feet) and struck the supervisor in the chest.

How bouncy are bananas? I decided to conduct a controlled experiment in the office with a carefully chosen pair of contrasting bananas. Lobbing a banana in a sort of underhand but hard fashion at the wall caused it to slide down the wall catching a cup of cold coffee in its descent and tipping the coffee over onto Dave's papers.

So I cleared the desk. No matter how hard I threw banana 1, a mature yellowish black specimen, it didn't bounce. It just thunked to the floor and sat there. Only when I sort of frisbeed it at the doorframe could I persuade it to make contact with the leg of my roommate who was just entering the room. Unfortunately, it had developed a side seam by then and disgorged some of its contents onto roommate's trousers.

So I switched to banana 2, a springier greener banana. I had to let my roommate do the throwing to make up for the snail trail on his trousers. Still no bounce.

I rang Dave's solicitor.

Me: I've been looking at the merits of Dave's case.
Solicitor: Have you been bouncing bananas too?
Me: Yeah, but they don't really, do they?
Solicitor: No, but Dave wants to come in to see you and prove that they do.

I couldn't talk them out of it. Besides Dave's union seem perfectly happy to pay for him to come and bounce bananas in Chambers. And I know what will happen. When we've all failed to bounce a variety of bananas off a variety of surfaces, I'll turn to Dave and explain why his case is not very strong.

And he'll say: Fair enough.

fields.headline: BP Amoco under pressure
fields.standfirst: Small investors demand rethink on top pay and Arctic drilling
fields.trailText: BP Amoco was forced on to the back foot at its annual meeting yesterday when a surprisingly large contingent of small shareholders attacked it over green issues and executive pay.
fields.body:
BP Amoco was forced on to the back foot at its annual meeting yesterday when a surprisingly large contingent of small shareholders attacked it over green issues and executive pay.

Environmentalists claimed a moral victory after 13.5% of proxy votes were cast in favour of a resolution calling on the oil major to halt its Alaskan Northstar development and abandon any future plans to drill in the Arctic.

Campaigners argued that the money should be channelled instead into renewable energy projects - a move which was soundly rejected by the BP board both before and after the voting figures were released.

Simon Billenness, a spokesman for Trillium Asset Management, one of the proposers of the motion, said it was a very high level of support given that it was a first time motion. "I think BP will be forced to change direction as it represents a defeat for them," he insisted.

But a company spokesman said it would be ridiculous to change policy since 86.5% had voted against the resolution.

Sir John Browne, chief executive, told the meeting that the plans for Northstar were supported by local communities, insisted that there were no plans at present to drill in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, and added that the company was already the leading proponent of solar energy.

On executive pay, a steady stream of pensioner shareholders attacked proposed changes to the BP executive pay scheme contained in one of the other resolutions.

One woman said: "You are already drawing levels of pay that you can't spend. It's all absurd." She argued that the board should set an example to other big companies by halting ever-bigger pay increases.

Peter Sutherland, the chairman, defended Sir John's £1.4m salary and a new performance-related pay scheme. Shareholders would not thank them if they lost top talent to competitors because payscales were not right. He said that BP Amoco had completed another year of "historic and momentous progress."

BP Amoco said last night it had now received clearance for the merger with Atlantic Richfield from the Federal Trade Commission. Sir John said: "We are very pleased to have received FTC approval. We will now rapidly implement the plans we have to integrate our operations worldwide. We intend to move quickly to deliver the significant value of this union to the shareholders of the new group."

The news came shortly after ExxonMobil confirmed it had agreed to buy Arco's Alaskan assets. The US giant had earlier begun legal action against BP Amoco in a bid to stop it selling Arco's stake in the Prudhoe Bay oil and gas field to Phillips.

webTitle: Brink resigns from World Online after irate investors go to law

fields.headline: Brink resigns from World Online after irate investors go to law
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Nina Brink, chairwoman of the pan-European internet group World Online, resigned yesterday amid growing anger from institutions about her controversial sale of shares shortly before the company's flotation.
fields.body:
Nina Brink, chairwoman of the pan-European internet group World Online, resigned yesterday amid growing anger from institutions about her controversial sale of shares shortly before the company's flotation.

Ms Brink quit just hours after a Dutch private shareholders' lobby, VEB, launched legal action against the company and its advisers, claiming the prospectus for the flotation gave "incorrect, incomplete and unclear information".

World Online insisted that Ms Brink's departure was her own decision.

The Rotterdam-based company said: "After careful consideration and at her own request, Nina Brink is resigning with immediate effect as chairwoman and member of the management board."

Ms Brink, 46, founded the web portal four years ago and has become one of the Netherlands' best known business personalities.

When the company joined the Amsterdam stock market last month, it was valued at €12bn (£7bn). But the shares plunged from their initial price of €43 when it emerged that a US investment company, Baystar Capital, had sold more than 6% of the company on the first day of trading.

Shareholders were furious when they discovered that Ms Brink had transferred two-thirds of her 9% stake to Baystar in late December at a price of €6.04 a share.

She was accused of undermining confidence in the company and some said her actions had contributed to the recent overall plunge in technology stocks.

Ms Brink sought to defuse the row two weeks ago by apologising. In a statement, she said: "I would like to express my profound regret about the commotion in the market. My sale was made for entirely personal reasons to secure the financial future of my family."

However, this failed to satisfy investors, who felt she had behaved inappropriately in avoiding the usual "lock-up" arrangements which prevent immediate sales by founding shareholders.

Ms Brink has gone on holiday. Colleagues said she was ill and exhausted by the criticism.

At a press conference to announce its action, VEB said in vestors had lost more than $1.5bn in the first two weeks after World Online's flotation, although the organisation did not specify how much it was claiming in damages.

World Online and its advisers, ABN Amro and Goldman Sachs, insisted that the transaction was above board, pointing out that it was mentioned on page 99 of the flotation prospectus. A World Online spokeswoman said the company's lawyers were looking at the claim "confidently".

A spokesman for Goldman Sachs said: "We believe we acted properly. We do not believe there is any merit in these allegations. We will challenge this action vigorously."

ABN Amro said it could see "no reason whatsoever" for a court case.

Ms Brink's responsibilities will be taken on by the group's British chief executive Simon Duffy. He joined World Online last year, after a spell as finance director of the music group EMI.

World Online's shares edged up to €18.85 yesterday - still less than half their initial €43 flotation price.

fields.headline: Promenade poetry
fields.standfirst:
The Hunting of the Snark
The Museum of... , London
***
fields.trailText: The 1998 Guardian International Theatre award was scooped by writer/director Dylan Ritson and he proves that the faith was justified with this most novel of London debuts.
fields.body:
The 1998 Guardian International Theatre award was scooped by writer/director Dylan Ritson and he proves that the faith was justified with this most novel of London debuts.

Ritson's play and production, a fleshing out of Lewis Carroll's nonsense poem, are overlong and the relentless wordplay can get wearing. But there is real imagination at work here, and the eerie, derelict upper floors of the museum are cunningly used for this promenade.

Having assembled his strange and unreliable crew of a ballerina, a baker, a banker, a barrister, a beaver and others, the Bellman takes us on an epic journey in search of the Snark. In Ritson's hands the mock-heroic nonsense poem becomes an eccentric marvel in which the visual conceits match the absurdity of both his and Carroll's language. The cleverness of the production is the way it gradually seduces you with the logic of its madness so the audience becomes almost as one with the protagonists as we are led deeper and deeper into the heart of the building. Eventually we are all quite lost too in the tangle of trees and Ruth Barrett's beautiful, itchy score.

Ritson holds back on offering some emotional payoff just a little too long, but the final half hour - a cross between the final damned days of Scott's doomed South Pole trek and Fitzcarraldo - has all the sense of loss and hallucinatory strangeness of a nightmare.

When Carroll was asked whether the poem was an allegory, a political satire, or contained a hidden moral he answered, "I don't know". But Ritson knows very well that it is about the foolishness of human desires, how we chase dreams and the way all our lives are a fantastical quest.

 To April 29. Box office: 0171- 960 4242.

fields.headline: Divine right to be cruel
fields.standfirst:
Richard II
Gainsborough Studios, London
***
fields.trailText:
Richard II
Gainsborough Studios, London
***
fields.body:
At the moment, we have an embarrassment of Richards. At Stratford-on-Avon there is a nakedly political, modern dress production. Now at the old Gainsborough Studios in Shoreditch, east London, Ralph Fiennes gives an unequivocal star performance in a traditional, pyramidal Almeida Theatre production.

The space is astonishing. One feels as if one is in an aircraft hangar. At one end of it sits a wide stage which designer Paul Brown has turned into an image of a disintegrating medieval England. The floor is a grassy carpet implying the demi-paradise that once was. But the rear brick wall is dominated by a huge central fissure which both suggests schismatic disintegration and allows for extravagantly regal entrances.

And Fiennes himself certainly gives us a Richard swathed in kingship. This is not the artist-king created by Frank Benson exactly 100 years ago. Fiennes's Richard is a mercurial autocrat. Entering enthroned to the sound of Te Deums, he soon reveals the flawed being underneath the ceremony. He sticks his tongue out at the corrective John of Gaunt, seizes his lands with arbitrary zeal and skips off to the Irish wars as if going to a fashion parade.

Within the parameters of Jonathan Kent's production, it is a fine performance. Fiennes has a stained glass profile, a resonant voice and a mordant irony. If the lyricism of Richard's downfall is underplayed, Fiennes compensates with a mocking humour. He is at his best in the deposition scene where he exaggeratedly cocks an ear as he cries: "God Save The King" and hugs the crown to his chest as if it were a favourite toy. Stripped of monarchy's protective divinity, this Richard becomes poignantly aware of his own wastefulness and other people's cunning.

What I miss in Kent's production is much sense of the play's politics. We are magnetised by Richard. But Linus Roache's stolidly impassive Bolingbroke gives us no hint of a man who turns injustice into opportunity. And amongst the anonymous Shakespearean nobles only two performances stand out. fields.headline: BT carves itself up
fields.standfirst:
Shareholder pressure prompts revamp

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: British Telecommunications finally bowed to shareholder pressure yesterday and announced a corporate shake-up that will see it reorganise into six main divisions, with Yell, its online directory service, the first to be spun off in a separate listing.
fields.body:
British Telecommunications finally bowed to shareholder pressure yesterday and announced a corporate shake-up that will see it reorganise into six main divisions, with Yell, its online directory service, the first to be spun off in a separate listing.

The move was met with mixed enthusiasm by investors who boosted BT's share price 44p to £11.33, anticipating that more divisions would eventually be listed in their own right.

Bill Cockburn, group managing director of BT UK, responsible for the company's domestic strategy, became a victim in the shake-up. He announced he would be retiring from the board.

Some analysts had hoped for a more aggressive response from BT on its international investments and for the sale of BT Cellnet.

"The breakdown of the new structure fully reveals the weakness of BT's position," said Charterhouse Securities analyst Alex Maby. "Without an announcement about a flotation of BT Cellnet, these plans are unlikely to result in a major stimulation to BT's share price."

Sir Peter Bonfield, BT's chief executive, denied yesterday's announcement was a case of "rearranging the deckchairs on the Titanic". He also denied that his position would be at risk in the restructuring.

"This is an offensive move that we have been planning for quite some time," he said.

The move would also allow investors to better value the group. Sir Peter denied that the changes would mean him retiring early. "I am not expecting this reorganisation to have any effect on my position."

BT intends to split its fixed-line business into wholesale, at which Paul Reynolds will become managing director, and retail, which has yet to have a managing director appointed.

Sir Peter argued that splitting off fixed line, BT's biggest business, would allow the company to compete more effectively and deal with changes in the regulatory environment.

The mobile business will come under the umbrella of BT Wireless. BT Openworld will combine online services with interactive television for the mass market.

The corporate and wholesale broadband services of BT will come under a new division, to be called Ignite. BT intends to inject £4bn over three years into its broadband services.

The final division, Yell, is expected to see a part of the unit floated by the year end giving it a value of £3bn-£6bn, according to analysts.

BT also said would look to mop up stakes in some of its international investments, spending £1.2bn yesterday to buy the remainder of Telfort, its Netherlands fixed and mobile operation.

BT has been forced to address its structure after a dismal third-quarter result, announced in February, which saw investors wipe £14bn off its market value in one day.

Analysts noted that the pre-tax profits were much worse than expected, slumping from £595m to £453m. The accepted wisdom was that fierce competition in BT's fixed-line business had affected the company's profitability.

BT has also had to respond to its competitors, such as Telefonica, which have doubled their valuations by hiving off parts of their business.

Telefonica floated its mobile business, while Deutsche Telekom is spinning off its internet arm, T-Online, and France Telecom and Swisscom are considering similar listings.

The telecommunications watchdog, Oftel, welcomed BT's restructure.

"The proposals by BT are a significant step to create a structure where there will be greater transparency," the regulator said.

webTitle: Biotech firm's curry plant pill helps arthritic dogs

fields.headline: Biotech firm's curry plant pill helps arthritic dogs
fields.trailText: Relief could be on the way for dogs suffering from arthritis, thanks to a new medicine derived from an Indian curry plant by biotech firm Phytopharm.
fields.body:
Relief could be on the way for dogs suffering from arthritis, thanks to a new medicine derived from an Indian curry plant by biotech firm Phytopharm.

Phytopharm yesterday bought 10% of a pharmaceuticals factory in Bangalore which will manufacture 15m doses of the product, P54, in preparation for launch next year.

Chief executive Richard Dixey said canine arthritis was an enormous problem: "The companion-animal market is enormous. This kind of thing causes great distress."

Phytopharm has established a plantation in western India to grow hundreds of acres of curcuma - the shrub that produces the spice turmeric.

Oil from the roots of curcuma will be taken to the factory in Bangalore, mixed with fluids from another plant and made into a capsule.

Mr Dixey said: "We are planning on growing 100 tonnes of curcuma an acre. You would be surprised - dogs can soon chew their way through several million capsules."

Phytopharm cited a recent survey showing that a fifth of all adult dogs in the US showed some symptoms. Initial signs tend to be weariness, and problems putting weight on each paw. In more advanced cases, dogs can suffer from a complete loss of joint function.

Mr Dixey estimates the market is worth $250m (£160m) annually and believes P45 has potential for human conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis and irritable bowel disorder.

webTitle: Dresdner trio quit as third bank re-enters the fray

fields.headline: Dresdner trio quit as third bank re-enters the fray
fields.trailText: Three Dresdner bank board members resigned yesterday, the latest casualties of the embarrassing collapse in the German bank's planned merger with its rival Deutsche Bank.
fields.body:
Three Dresdner bank board members resigned yesterday, the latest casualties of the embarrassing collapse in the German bank's planned merger with its rival Deutsche Bank.

Their resignations came as German bank Commerzbank appeared to open the doors to talks with Dresdner. Commerzbank which held talks with Dresdner earlier in the year, said: "We are open to talking with Dresdner about possible co-operation though we are not in talks at the moment."

The departure of Gerd Häusler, Ernst-Moritz Lipp and Andreas Bezold from the Dresdner board was regarded as a significant step towards its investment banking arm, Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, achieving more autonomy.

Kleinwort, which has suffered 125 defections since the aborted merger was announced last month, will now be represented on the Dresdner board by just one banker, Leonhard Fischer, the 37-year-old head of global markets, equities and asset management. Mr Häusler was the management board chairman of Kleinwort.

Speculation that senior bankers would push for a partial flotation subsided yesterday as it emerged that Dresdner had set aside a guaranteed bonus pool for the coming year.

Rows over Kleinwort were at the root of the break down in the merger which would have created one of the world's largest banks. Dresdner said yesterday that the latest three resignation from its board were for "personal reasons".

fields.headline: Barrett breaks his silence
fields.standfirst: Torrent of bad publicity forces Barclays' chief executive to explain pay package
fields.trailText: Matt Barrett, the multi-millionaire chief executive of Barclays bank, is to break his silence over his controversial performance related-pay deal to explain the complex performance scheme under which he stands to get a payout up to £30m.
fields.body:
Matt Barrett, the multi-millionaire chief executive of Barclays bank, is to break his silence over his controversial performance related-pay deal to explain the complex performance scheme under which he stands to get a payout up to £30m.

Mr Barrett, who took on the £850,000-a-year role last October, plans to write to his 55,000 staff after being stung by a torrent of negative publicity. The criticism was sparked by 171 branch closures as details of the executive's pay package were revealed and adverts claiming it was a "big bank" ran on television.

Mr Barrett, already a wealthy man after running the Bank of Montreal, is on an annual package of approximately £6m. As part of the deal he will receive £15,000 a year to pay for outside advice on his tax, by-passing Barclays' own tax advice unit. Mr Barrett is clarifying his pay just days before he faces scrutiny by a panel of influential MPs.

The bank admitted yesterday that the terms of the incentive share option plan - which will be put to share holders for approval later this month - had caused confusion, but insisted that this had not been its aim. Instead, it heralded the ground-breaking scheme as the model for other top management pay.

Defending the structure of the deal Cathy Turner, executive compensation director at the bank, said: "It is one of the most robust performance-led plans on the market and it should be put forward as a model for other companies. "It is purposefully penal when performance is poor: there is 50% probability of zero payout".

For the first time yesterday, the bank admitted that, hypothetically, Mr Barrett could receive a £30m payout in three years time when scheme runs its course. But Ms Turner said: "£30m will only happen if the share price reaches £180". The bank's shares were trading yesterday at under £17. It was more likely that the maximum payout would be in the region of £5.5m after three years.

This payout would be made under one of the possible scenarios constructed by the bank yesterday to try to explain the terms of the proposed plan. For £5.5m to be achieved, the bank's market capitalisation would have to more than double yesterday's figure of £25bn within the next three years. "Barclays would have to be absolutely wonderful. This is where I want them to be aiming," said Ms Turner.

Around 500 staff will join the incentive share option plan which judges performance on two criteria: economic profit - the bank's profit after taking out shareholder funds - and its share performance relative to a peer group of 11 other companies.

Mr Barrett has a set a target to double economic profit over four years. Only 15 directors, including Mr Barrett, will be catapulted in the second portion of the scheme which could quadruple the award if the bank is best performing share in three years.

Countering claims that the bank would award options worth 200% of salary and bonus, Ms Turner insisted that the bank's remuneration committee would be more likely to make awards between 100% and 150% of salary. These would be based on the basic £850,000 salary, not including any annual bonus pay.

fields.headline: A special rapport
fields.standfirst:
London Philharmonic/ Bernard Haitink
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
London Philharmonic/ Bernard Haitink
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.body:
Before he was lured away to the illusory delights of working at the Royal Opera House, Bernard Haitink was principal conductor of the London Philharmonic for 12 years. Though he now appears as a guest with most of London's orchestras there is a still a special rapport between him and the LPO players, though in Wednesday's concert it took a little while for that to manifest. A few smudged chords in Schumann's Manfred Overture suggested that Haitink's unfussy beat wasn't transmitting as cleanly as it should have done, though much else about the performance was perfectly lucid, especially in the air that he gave to the orchestral textures and the unmistakable dramatic pointing of the whole work, which is as much a miniature symphonic poem as it is a concert overture.

Wagner's Wesendonk Lieder, though, had no uncertainties. With Haitink due to conduct a new production of Tristan und Isolde next season at Covent Garden, the songs provided a foretaste of his approach - a bit cool but emphasising the seamless lyricism of each number. Perhaps his lack of outright passion in the music was intended to match the delivery of his soloist, for though Petra Lang (who will sing Brangaene in the ROH Tristan) has a cast-iron technique, admirable diction and smooth, potentially sumptuous tone, there was something too forthright, rather take-it-or-leave-it, about the way in which she presented these sometimes ecstatic texts.

The symphony was Shostakovich's 10th, which Haitink has always conducted with the right degree of theatricality. The LPO acquitted themselves well in the scherzo, and provided the first movement with a good depth of tone, even if the string sound didn't always glisten. In Haitink's performances the symphonic lines through Tchaikovsky and through Mahler that come together in Shostakovich are remarkably fused, and his care with details, like the piccolo snapping out the DSCH motto at the end of the Allegretto, or the eloquent phrasing of the oboe solo that begins the finale, is a constant fascination. There are more tumultuous interpreters, those who emphasise the work's tragic dimension more insistently, but few who bring all elements together into a more satisfying shape.

webTitle: United force fans to foot the bill for Keane

fields.headline: United force fans to foot the bill for Keane
fields.trailText: Manchester United's supporters discovered the true cost of keeping Roy Keane at Old Trafford yesterday when they were told they would have to pay a heavy price for his new £52,000-a-week contract.
fields.body:
Manchester United's supporters discovered the true cost of keeping Roy Keane at Old Trafford yesterday when they were told they would have to pay a heavy price for his new £52,000-a-week contract.

The champions have announced they are raising season-ticket prices by up to £2 a match next season because of the resulting financial burden.

In a letter to existing season-ticket holders, the United secretary Ken Merrett says: "We are sure supporters will recognise the importance we place on staying competitive, not only in the transfer market but in our endeavours to retain our existing players.

"There was a huge collective sigh of relief when Roy Keane agreed a new contract... making this commitment to Roy, the directors believe they are also making a commitment to supporters.

"United fans have grown accustomed to the best. It is our duty to ensure we remain in a position to provide the best."

But there was condemnation from the Independent Manchester United Supporters' Association. "It smacks of the club being spiteful," said their spokesman Andy Walsh.

"The supporters made a lot of demands that Roy should be offered improved terms and this is the club's response. Are they going to do this every time a player is awarded a better contract?

"Next season United will have another 11,000 seats and the extra capacity will bring with it extra revenue. The bottom line is that United have the resources to reward the supporters for their loyalty but have chosen not to."

webTitle: Punter Claridge and Petit are fined

fields.headline: Punter Claridge and Petit are fined
fields.trailText: The Portsmouth striker Steve Claridge provided the light relief yesterday as the Football Association dealt with English football's own betting mini-scandal, while Emmanuel Petit avoided a ban that would have removed him from Arsenal's Uefa Cup campaign when he was fined for making obscene gestures to abusive Aston Villa fans.
fields.body:
The Portsmouth striker Steve Claridge provided the light relief yesterday as the Football Association dealt with English football's own betting mini-scandal, while Emmanuel Petit avoided a ban that would have removed him from Arsenal's Uefa Cup campaign when he was fined for making obscene gestures to abusive Aston Villa fans.

Claridge was fined £900 for misconduct in backing his side when they beat Barnsley 3-0 at Fratton Park on January 29. "It's quite fair - pretty much what was won on the bet. I had a fair hearing and everything is fine," he said after yesterday's meeting in London. "There will be no more bets."

The FA spokesman Steve Double explained when Claridge was charged: "Players, managers and directors have to realise that even betting on their own team to win is a breach of football's rules.

"Players and officials have access to information which those outside the game do not. Use of such information to place bets could be regarded as a form of insider trading."

The Arsenal midfielder Petit was fined £5,000 after being caught on camera aiming an obscene gesture at fans at Villa Park when substituted in the 1-1 draw on March 5.

The Frenchman claimed he had been racially abused by some fans and. with the FA deciding to crack down on abusive fans, the spokesman Double said: "The commission took into account the level of abuse he faced and, as a result of this hearing, and indeed other incidents brought to our attention this season, we are compiling a report to send to the Association of Chief Police Officers.

"We are asking them to take stronger action against fans who abuse players either racially or on the grounds of their nationality."

The Highbury manager Arsène Wenger gave Petit's heavy fine a mixed welcome. "I am satisfied that I have the player available and not suspended, but on the other hand I had hoped he would not be fined. But you should always keep control in that kind of situation. [The abuse] was especially aggressive against him on that day."

The West Bromwich Albion manager Gary Megson has asked for a personal hearing in the FA misconduct charge brought after he was ordered from the dug-out by the referee Graham Poll during his side's 2-0 defeat at Portsmouth on March 21. Megson had disputed the 26th minute penalty from which Portsmouth scored.

The Frenchman claimed he had been racially abused by some fans and. with the FA deciding to crack down on abusive fans, the spokesman Double said: "The commission took into account the level of abuse he faced and, as a result of this hearing, and indeed other incidents brought to our attention this season, we are compiling a report to send to the Association of Chief Police Officers. "We are asking them to take stronger action against fans who abuse players either racially or on the grounds of their nationality." "I am satisfied that I have the player available and not suspended, but on the other hand I had hoped he would not be fined. But you should always keep control in that kind of situation. [The abuse] was especially aggressive against him on that day." The West Bromwich Albion manager Gary Megson has asked for a personal hearing in the FA misconduct charge brought after he was ordered from the dug-out by the referee Graham Poll during his side's 2-0 defeat at Portsmouth on March 21. Megson had disputed the 26th minute penalty from which Portsmouth scored.

fields.headline: Ronaldo's comeback ends in tears
fields.trailText: Ronaldo's long-awaited return from injury lasted just seven minutes last night before he was carried off in tears after reinjuring his right knee in Internazionale's Italian Cup final first leg in Rome against Lazio.
fields.body:
Ronaldo's long-awaited return from injury lasted just seven minutes last night before he was carried off in tears after reinjuring his right knee in Internazionale's Italian Cup final first leg in Rome against Lazio.

The Brazilian striker had come on as a substitute in the 59th minute after recovering from a torn right knee ligament which required surgery and a five-month lay-off.

The Arsenal striker Nwankwo Kanu, Chelsea's full- back Celestine Babayaro and Colchester's defender Efetobore Sodje have been included in Nigeria's 18-man squad to play Eritrea in the World Cup qualifier in Lagos on Saturday week. But South Africa's coach Trott Moloto has omitted the Leeds captain Lucas Radebe from his squad for the second leg of the World Cup qualifier against Lesotho on the same day.

The Arsenal captain Tony Adams is on course to face Leeds on Sunday after coming through 45 minutes of a friendly against Norwich yesterday. It was his first game since the Uefa Cup quarter- final second leg on March 23.

 Arsenal qualified for the FA Youth Cup final after a 1-1 draw in front of a crowd of 14,023 at Middlesbrough saw them through 2-1 on aggregate.

The Gunners will meet Coventry, who earlier this week reached the final for the second successive season after knocking out Southampton.

Arsenal went behind to a Jeremy Robinson goal but hit back through Irish Under-21 star Graham Barrett after 29 minutes.

webTitle: Ligament injury rules Rafael out for season

fields.headline: Ligament injury rules Rafael out for season
fields.trailText: The Celtic defender Rafael has been ruled for the rest of the season after damaging knee ligaments in training.
fields.body:
The Celtic defender Rafael has been ruled for the rest of the season after damaging knee ligaments in training.

The Brazilian defender was signed by the former head coach John Barnes in December for £4.8m from Gremio, but needed an appendix operation only weeks after joining the club.

Celtic's interim manager Kenny Dalglish said: "Rafael injured his knee in training today, which, following a scan, has shown some ligament damage which will certainly mean, regrettably, that he will be out for the season."

The 27-year-old defender has been capped seven times by Brazil but has not played a competitive game since the end of November.

Guus Hiddink has emerged as the strongest candidate yet for the vacant head coach's position at Celtic, according to reports.

The former Holland coach is currently working in Spain with Real Betis, but is believed to be out of contract at the end of the season. Hiddink, who succeeded Dick Advocaat - now manager of Rangers - as national coach in December 1994, has also been in charge of PSV Eindhoven, Fenerbahce, Valencia and Real Madrid.

According to the Scotsman, Celtic's chief executive Allan MacDonald has left for Spain for talks with him.

However, Hiddink's agent, Jose Luis Catalan, insisted he knew nothing about an approach for his client from Celtic, although he refused to rule out a possible move in the summer.

webTitle: Business as usual as Proteas power to victory

fields.headline: Business as usual as Proteas power to victory
fields.standfirst:
Australia 240-9
South Africa 241-4
South Africa win by six wickets
fields.trailText:
Australia 240-9
South Africa 241-4
South Africa win by six wickets.
fields.body:
If the Australia team were expecting South African cricket fans to turn on their own in the wake of the Cronje affair, they were sadly mistaken. When the teams walked on to the field at Kingsmead for the anthems before the first game of this three-match series there was respectful quiet for Advance Australia Fair and the familiar mumbles of English speakers trying to get their tongues round Xhosa words during Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika.

The only player implicated in wrongdoing taking part was Herschelle Gibbs and he mum bled along with everyone else, in an apparent trance. But once he took the field it was a different matter. After Mark Waugh had fallen lbw to Shaun Pollock without scoring, Gibbs spectacularly ran out Matthew Hayden to reduce Australia to 12 for two.

If there had been any doubters in the crowd they were silenced by this piece of prehensile fielding. In fact, anybody unaware of the happenings of the past week would have assumed that it was business as usual here.

Business as usual being a crowd of some 8,000 at the start of play, swelling to double that number as the offices and schools emptied in late afternoon. A balmy autumn day here is about as good as it gets and the girls were there in their bikinis, the boys in their bermuda shorts, mums and dads finding room on the grass banks to barbecue the evening meal.

The usual plethora of hand-made banners was conspicuous by its absence, although one young woman defiantly waved a sheet saying, "We still love you Hansie".

Cronje was scarcely missed in the first 25 overs as Australian wickets fell willy-nilly, leaving them perilously placed at 118 for seven. The chief architect of the collapse was Makhaya Ntini, who disposed of Steve Waugh and Michael Bevan. He added the former Gloucestershire all-rounder Andrew Symonds to his list of scalps, and the crowd became truly animated for the first time. Not because Symonds was out but because the next man in was Shane Warne. The man South Africans love to hate was booed to the wicket and cheered all the way back to the pavilion when Ntini had him caught behind for a duck.

The catch was the fifth to disappear into the gloves of Mark Boucher and he had a chance to set a world record when, inexplicably, he dropped a dolly.

In the event Australia reached 240 for nine. The architect of the revival was Damien Martyn, who was run out off the final ball for 74 made from 91 deliveries.

However Martyn's efforts proved in vain and in the end it was Australia who looked as if their minds were on other things as South Africa won by six wickets with two overs to spare with a thoroughly professional performance.

A third-wicket stand of 129 between Gary Kirsten and Jacques Kallis set the platform and when Kallis fell for 61, Jonty Rhodes produced a perfect cameo knock of 46 not out from 40 balls to seal the match.

Kirsten was out just before the end for 97, made from 126 balls with eight boundaries. It was left to Lance Klusener to hit the winning boundary from the last ball of the 48th over and the full house went into raptures, proclaiming that there is life and cricket after Cronje.

The next match is in Cape Town tomorrow.

fields.headline: McCarthy gambles on new blood
fields.trailText: The Republic of Ireland manager Mick McCarthy has named three uncapped players in his squad for the friendly against Greece at Lansdowne Road on April 26.
fields.body:
The Republic of Ireland manager Mick McCarthy has named three uncapped players in his squad for the friendly against Greece at Lansdowne Road on April 26.

The Leeds midfielder Stephen McPhail, the Everton defender Richard Dunne and Fulham's wing-back Steve Finnan have been included in the 22-man squad, and McCarthy indicated that all three are likely to take the field.

"Dunne will get his chance as he has been playing consistently well for Everton and has improved no end this season," McCarthy said. "Stephen McPhail has shown great vision for Leeds and has great ability on the ball."

Paul McKnight, meanwhile, has been included in Northern Ireland's squad for the game against Hungary the same day, just a week after joining St Mirren from Rangers.

fields.headline: The best Limo scene
fields.standfirst: Three Kings
fields.trailText: Three Kings
fields.body:
Kuwait, 1991. Having fallen in with a band of Iraqi dissidents, US troops Archie Gates (George Clooney), Chief Elgin (Ice Cube) and Conrad Vig (Spike Jonze) discover a fleet of Lexuses and BMWs in a desert bunker. Gates turns to the dissidents' leader, who grins broadly in his direction.

"Listen, we use these cars to fight Saddam's soldiers."

The dissident leader keeps grinning. Elgin frowns.

"What's so funny?"

"Cannot take."

"What do you mean, cannot take? We kicked Saddam's ass. We definitely take."

"We", announces Gates, "are the United States Army."

Their impromptu interpreter, Amir Abdullah (Cliff Curtis) butts in.

"You're three guys with a bunch of civilians and no Humvee."

The dissident leader interrupts.

"Money! Have no money!"

In Iraqi, he begins talking to Amir who, in turn, translates for Gates.

"The American Army is huge. It has planes and tanks. We have nothing."

"Listen to me," Gates exclaims. "We will rise up together."

He grabs Elgin and Amir by the hand.

"George Bush wants you to stand up for yourself! To fight for freedom!"

The three men parade around the room, their fists in the air.

"God bless America! And God bless a free Iraq!"

Soon the room is filled with whoops of insurrection. Beaming, Gates turns back to the dissident leader.

"What do you say, my friend?"

"Cannot take."

Gates's smile fades.

"OK. I guess we'll buy 'em."

See also: This Is Spinal Tap, The King Of New York

Don't see also: Who's That Girl?

Pointless trivia: George Clooney's father Nick was a local TV newscaster in Cincinnati.

webTitle: Ministers demand council action to revive estates aid poorest estates

fields.headline: Ministers demand council action to revive estates aid poorest estates
fields.standfirst: Cash penalties if town hall services fail to improve
fields.trailText: Councils and other public agencies could face tough Whitehall penalties if they fail to improve conditions for people on England's poorest housing estates.
fields.body:
Councils and other public agencies could face tough Whitehall penalties if they fail to improve conditions for people on England's poorest housing estates.

Ministers are planning a sophisticated system of poverty monitoring linked to national efficiency guidelines which will force authorities to improve services like housing and health, before the government pumps in extra cash.

The move will be tied to a new monitoring system under which Government statisticians will compare the performance of town halls - in areas from refuse collection to council house and road maintenance - in many of England's 3,000 poorest neighbourhoods.

John Prescott's Department of the Environment is hoping the tough system, tied to a new network of local partnerships involving councils, business and other agencies, will persuade the Treasury to approve a multi-billion pound urban regeneration programme in the forthcoming comprehensive spending review for the next three years.

The initiative will be seen by local government as further evidence of Whitehall tightening its grip on town halls, with councils relegated to a secondary role in reviving run-down estates and inner city ghettos. It was pushed to the top of the government's urban agenda yesterday with the publication of the social exclusion unit's national strategy for neighbourhood renewal, which pulled together the work of 18 Whitehall policy action teams which have been investigating England's poorest communities.

The local government and regeneration minister, Hilary Armstrong, made clear she strongly backs one key recommendation that important services in deprived areas should be set "explicit performance targets". Money to improve the areas would be based on performance.

While local government would be given an important role in the new partnerships covering areas of up to 4,000 houses - probably overseen by a public-private sector board - ministers are keen that other local stakeholders, particularly tenants and residents, should play a key role.

The Local Government Association last night called on ministers to develop alternative public service agreements with town halls, rather than imposing Whitehall programmes. It said this would "escape the over-rigid prescription of central government initiatives". Much of the government's emphasis will also be placed on expanding the £800m new deal for communities programme from 17 pilot projects on some of the poorest estates to seven new areas. Mr Prescott claimed that government policies were already having some effect in "tackling the cycle of deprivation that has blighted many of the country's poorest areas for decades".

Unemployment on the poorest estates is six times above the national average. Mr Prescott acknowledged that 40%of teenagers between 16 and 18 were "outside education and work", partly because industry had collapsed in 20 of the biggest cities which had lost half a million jobs in 20 years alone.

Yesterday's social exclusion report speaks of many neighbourhoods, largely concentrated in the midlands and the north, being "devastated" by mass unemployment and becoming almost entirely dependent on state benefits

It calls for more joined-up programmes on the ground to replace a string of sometimes disparate Whitehall initiatives and suggests a network of neighbourhood wardens, or estate managers, to reassure tenants and help reduce crime.

fields.headline: Brimson criticised over Wisden prank
fields.trailText: Leicestershire spinner Matthew Brimson has been criticised after apparently exposing himself in a team photograph featured in the new edition of the Wisden Cricketers' Almanack.
fields.body:
Leicestershire spinner Matthew Brimson has been criticised after apparently exposing himself in a team photograph featured in the new edition of the Wisden Cricketers' Almanack.

Matthew Engel, editor of Wisden 2000, was not amused by Brimson and described his action as "an insult to supporters".

Engel said: "I think if you are going to pull this kind of stunt, you need to be a more competent professional sportsman than Matthew Brimson - and, frankly, more impressively arrayed.

"Even when we increased the size of the picture, after being tipped off today, we couldn't be certain that we had seen what we thought we had seen.

"If everyone's right, I think it's a very poor comment on Leicestershire County Cricket Club and professional cricketers in general. It's the supporters who have been insulted, not Wisden."

A statement from Leicestershire said: "We have had a meeting with Matthew Brimson and we have accepted his explanation that it is simply not in his character to do anything that would cause offence.

"Matthew Brimson wishes to apologise to anyone who may have misinterpreted the published photograph."

webTitle: Mandela tells Britain to stop playing world's policeman

fields.headline: Mandela tells Britain to stop playing world's policeman
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela, on his first visit to the UK since he retired as president of South Africa last June, accused Britain and the United States of encouraging international chaos by playing "policeman of the world".
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela, on his first visit to the UK since he retired as president of South Africa last June, accused Britain and the United States of encouraging international chaos by playing "policeman of the world".

Mr Mandela said the two countries had ridden roughshod over the United Nations by launching military actions against Iraq and Kosovo.

"Tony Blair is a young man I like very much," he said on a private visit to Britain and Ireland last week. "But I am resentful about the type of thing that America and Britain are doing. They want to be the policemen of the world, and I'm sorry that Britain has joined the US in this regard.

"It's a totally wrong attitude. They must persuade those countries like China or Russia who threaten to veto their decisions at the UN. They must sit down and talk to them. They can't just ignore them and start their own actions. The message they're sending is that any country which fears a veto [from the UN] can take unilateral action. That means they're introducing chaos into international affairs - that any country can take a decision which it wants."

Such disregard for international conventions was more dangerous to world peace than anything happening in Africa, Mr Mandela said.

"Africa hasn't got the capacity to create such destruction of innocent civilians as the Western powers have. We have no bombs in the proper sense of the word, except one or two countries, and we have no weapons [of mass destruction], such as the West has. What they are doing is far more serious than what is happening in Africa - especially the US and Britain. It is proper for me to say that."

Mr Mandela even suggested there was a racist motive behind Washington's neglect of the UN: "The US did not do this when the secretary general of the UN was white. They are doing it now, ignoring the UN under Kofi Annan. And there are many people who are whispering that it is because the secretary general is black. That perception is disturbing."

Mr Mandela was reluctant to criticise the Zimbabwean president, Robert Mugabe, who he said had been unfairly represented in the media.

"The South African press, unfortunately, are so hostile to Mugabe that they are prepared to say things which we know are not true about him. Simply because he lost the referendum [on extending his powers] they think he is going to lose the election.

"The fact that he has lost the referendum may be a blessing in disguise for him. Because Mugabe is a strategic thinker, he's a very capable man. If I have to express an opinion, he is likely to retain power."

webTitle: Business as usual as Proteas power to victory

fields.headline: Business as usual as Proteas power to victory
fields.standfirst:
Australia 240-9
South Africa 241-4
South Africa win by six wickets
fields.trailText:
Australia 240-9
South Africa 241-4
South Africa win by six wickets.
fields.body:
If the Australia team were expecting South African cricket fans to turn on their own in the wake of the Cronje affair, they were sadly mistaken. When the teams walked on to the field at Kingsmead for the anthems before the first game of this three-match series there was respectful quiet for Advance Australia Fair and the familiar mumbles of English speakers trying to get their tongues round Xhosa words during Nkosi Sikelel' iAfrika.

The only player implicated in wrongdoing taking part was Herschelle Gibbs and he mum bled along with everyone else, in an apparent trance. But once he took the field it was a different matter. After Mark Waugh had fallen lbw to Shaun Pollock without scoring, Gibbs spectacularly ran out Matthew Hayden to reduce Australia to 12 for two.

If there had been any doubters in the crowd they were silenced by this piece of prehensile fielding. In fact, anybody unaware of the happenings of the past week would have assumed that it was business as usual here.

Business as usual being a crowd of some 8,000 at the start of play, swelling to double that number as the offices and schools emptied in late afternoon. A balmy autumn day here is about as good as it gets and the girls were there in their bikinis, the boys in their bermuda shorts, mums and dads finding room on the grass banks to barbecue the evening meal.

The usual plethora of hand-made banners was conspicuous by its absence, although one young woman defiantly waved a sheet saying, "We still love you Hansie".

Cronje was scarcely missed in the first 25 overs as Australian wickets fell willy-nilly, leaving them perilously placed at 118 for seven. The chief architect of the collapse was Makhaya Ntini, who disposed of Steve Waugh and Michael Bevan. He added the former Gloucestershire all-rounder Andrew Symonds to his list of scalps, and the crowd became truly animated for the first time. Not because Symonds was out but because the next man in was Shane Warne. The man South Africans love to hate was booed to the wicket and cheered all the way back to the pavilion when Ntini had him caught behind for a duck.

The catch was the fifth to disappear into the gloves of Mark Boucher and he had a chance to set a world record when, inexplicably, he dropped a dolly.

In the event Australia reached 240 for nine. The architect of the revival was Damien Martyn, who was run out off the final ball for 74 made from 91 deliveries.

However Martyn's efforts proved in vain and in the end it was Australia who looked as if their minds were on other things as South Africa won by six wickets with two overs to spare with a thoroughly professional performance.

A third-wicket stand of 129 between Gary Kirsten and Jacques Kallis set the platform and when Kallis fell for 61, Jonty Rhodes produced a perfect cameo knock of 46 not out from 40 balls to seal the match.

Kirsten was out just before the end for 97, made from 126 balls with eight boundaries. It was left to Lance Klusener to hit the winning boundary from the last ball of the 48th over and the full house went into raptures, proclaiming that there is life and cricket after Cronje.

The next match is in Cape Town tomorrow.

fields.headline: 'People's war' sparks violence in Nepal
fields.standfirst: Thousands killed as indisciplined police battle Maoist rebels in remote rural areas
fields.trailText: A brutal guerrilla insurgency and scores of extra-judicial killings by police are undermining the once peaceful reputation of Nepal.
fields.body:
A brutal guerrilla insurgency and scores of extra-judicial killings by police are undermining the once peaceful reputation of Nepal.

A so-called "people's war" against the kingdom's 10-year-old multi-party democracy is being waged in the western region by a Maoist faction of the Communist party, which claims to control several districts. The government's latest figures put the death toll at 1,216 but most people believe that the figure is more than 3,000.

Last week the Maoists called a strike, paralysing the nation and leaving the streets of Kathmandu empty and its businesses closed. The government drafted in 7,000 police to the city, and foreign embassies warned tourists to stay close to their hotels.

Nine police were killed last week, eight of them in the remote village of Taksera, when 200 guerrillas attacked a police post. Evidence is growing that the police are carrying out scores of extra-judicial killings in retaliation for guerrilla attacks. The number of deaths could run into hundreds.

One of the worst incidents took place in February when 15 police died as Maoists blew up the police post at Ghartigaun village in Rolpa. Two days later 30 police, acting on a tip-off that guerrillas were hiding nearby, arrived in Kumcheri village in the neighbouring Rukum district. Rebels hiding in jungle outside the village opened fire, killing one policeman.

A rapid response unit set up by the police to deal with the insurgency arrived in the region by helicopter and immediately began burning houses and barns in villages with paraffin looted from local shops. Fifteen villagers, five of them supporters of the ruling Nepali Congress party, were then shot by police as Maoist sympathisers.

"It was cold-blooded murder," says Krishna Pahadi, a human rights worker based in Kathmandu who travelled to the area. "The police pulled them from their houses, stood them in a line and shot them. The police are claiming they were killed in an exchange of fire. The reality is that the police wanted to take revenge."

For their part, police said initially that those killed had been wearing uniforms and carrying rifles.

The government promised a report on the killings within two weeks, but since Krishna Prasad Bhattarai was replaced as prime minister by a hardliner, Girija Prasad Koirala, last month, it has not been published.

The new interior minister, Govinda Ray Joshi, said: "We don't accept that there are extra-judicial killings in Nepal." Saying that the report had been delivered and would be published "in due course", he added: "If the police have made any mistakes, then we'll take it very seriously. The police were excited, and maybe that's why that incident happened."

Human rights activists believe that the police have stopped operating within the law. "They are doing this kind of thing in a systematic fashion," says Pahadi. "And the government refuses to take action against the police. The politicians believe they can't get re-elected without the help of the police."

In early February the United Nations and Amnesty International released reports heavily criticising the police and Nepal's recent human rights record. The issue will be raised by the British Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, when he visits Nepal this month.

Nepal holds a number of political activists without charge, and there is evidence that police in remote districts have killed detainees before abandoning their posts. Three bodies were recently discovered at Simrudu police station, close to where the 15 villagers were murdered. Fearing Maoist reprisals, the police abandoned the station. Last week local people reported that three bodies had been found buried inside the building.

Two were sisters, Sita Pun, 13, and Sirjana Pun, 16, who had been detained in August at what police said was a Maoist meeting. Villagers accused the police of raping the sisters and killing them before quitting the post. The body of Satya Deva Sharma, also held without charge, was found in an abandoned police post in Salyan district.

Despite regular reassurances that legislation passed in 1996 to set up a National Human Rights Commission would be acted on, the government still has to name its first members. Rights activists believe that the gov ernment is stalling to allow security forces a free hand in dealing with the Maoist insurgency.

The rebel group is part of the London-based Revolutionary Internationalist Committee, and has links with Peru's Shining Path and Maoist groups in India. The rebels either make their own weapons or steal guns from the police. The leaders are believed to be hiding in India, where key party workers are trained in insurgency techniques. The Observer

webTitle: Elian relatives to meet father in private

fields.headline: Elian relatives to meet father in private
fields.standfirst:
The US attorney general has announced a meeting between Elian Gonzalez's exiled relatives and the Cuban boy's father before any handover of the child.
More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: The US attorney general has announced a meeting between Elian Gonzalez's exiled relatives and the Cuban boy's father before any handover of the child.
fields.body:
The US attorney general, Janet Reno, announced a meeting today between Elian Gonzalez's father and exiled Cuban relatives who are refusing to relinquish custody of the six-year-old Cuban.

In a dramatic change of tack ahead of a 2pm (1800 GMT) deadline for the handover of Elian at a Miami airport, Ms Reno said she had accepted a request from Elian's relatives, led by his great-uncle, Lazaro Gonzalez, for a private meeting with the boy's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez.

Ms Reno said the state would "stand aside" as Elian's relatives were flown to Washington "at no expense to themselves" to meet Juan Miguel Gonzalez, who has been awarded custody of his son by the US authorities. The meeting would occur before any handover of Elian to his father.

Ms Reno expressed hope that the Miami relatives could work out an 11th-hour solution. If they did not, she said, the government would take action in a "reasonable, measured way".

The move followed mounting tension outside the exiled relatives' house in Miami, where the boy is staying. The relatives, backed by the Cuban-American community, have fiercely opposed the US government-sanctioned attempts of Elian's father to be reunited with his son. They have refused to relinquish custody of the boy they have looked after since Elian's mother drowned off the Florida coast after fleeing Cuba nearly five months ago.

Earlier today, they released a home video recording, on which Elian tells his father he does not wish to return to Cuba.

"Papa, I don't want to go to Cuba. I want to stay here," said the boy, on a video aired on ABC's Good Morning America TV programme.

ABC said it was unclear whether the boy, shown sitting cross-legged on a bed and chewing gum, had been coaxed by the relatives about what to say on the video.

After failing to reach an agreement with the family during a meeting lasting more than two hours last night, which was attended by the Cuban boy, Ms Reno had earlier ordered them to bring him to the Opa-locka airport outside Miami at 2pm.

"We will not turn this child over - not in Opa-locka, not in any 'locka'," Lazaro Gonzalez said this morning. "They will have to take this child from me by force."

Ms Reno did not specify what would happen if the family failed to agree to relinquish Elian, but government sources have said the justice department was prepared to send US marshals and immigration agents into the house to take the boy.

By engineering a meeting between Elian's relatives and his father in which Elian's custody can be decided, the US government hopes to avoid an confrontational endgame in which it used force to take Elian from the Cuban community in Miami.

webTitle: The mob descends from Gt Snoring

fields.headline: The mob descends from Gt Snoring
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The Commons was under siege yesterday from a crowd of 2,000 clutching a vast petition. The crush at the entrance was so great that Nicholas Winterton MP told a hushed House that the police had lost control, and it had taken him five minutes to gain access. Oooohs rang round the chamber; the Speaker expressed her outrage and promised to report   the matter to the serjeant-at-arms; artists were commissioned to commemorate the scene - Nicholas Winterton Saved From The Mob.
fields.body:
The Commons was under siege yesterday from a crowd of 2,000 clutching a vast petition. The crush at the entrance was so great that Nicholas Winterton MP told a hushed House that the police had lost control, and it had taken him five minutes to gain access. Oooohs rang round the chamber; the Speaker expressed her outrage and promised to report the matter to the serjeant-at-arms; artists were commissioned to commemorate the scene - Nicholas Winterton Saved From The Mob.

The mob in question were not crazed revolutionaries, but a small army of sub-postmasters demanding government protection from the harsh winds of commercial change sweeping through rural Britain. And that, despite Mr Winterton's narrow escape, suited the Conservatives nicely. As icons of old England go, the rural sub-post office will serve very well, the perfect symbol of counter-revolution.

The future of sub-post offices was the subject of the Opposition's supply-day motion. The dour Angela Browning, who clutches the despatch box for grim life as if she feels someone (John Redwood?) might grab it if she lets go, led for the mob. Mrs Browning is not much given to coups de theatre, but she produced one here, tossing a birthday card at trade secretary Stephen Byers, who is 47 today. The National Federation of Sub-Postmasters has promised to deliver another 18,000. (As protests go, sending someone a birthday card rates rather low on the revolutionary scale.)

At Question Time, Mr Hague took up the day's great issue. "We had a policy to save post offices, you have a policy to close them down." The Prime Minister looked uncomfortable and immersed himself in statistics in an effort to prove that the rate of closure had been even higher under the Tories.

The lovable grey-haired spinsters running sub-post offices in Great Snoring had to face the "challenge of modernisation", said Mr Blair. The Tories jeered and made curious digging motions, which irritated the Speaker. "Save our post offices," barked Mr Hague for the sleepy folk of Great Snoring, who are very happy with their 1950s realities.

It was a day for symbols. The RUC was receiving the George Cross for standing up to 35 years of murder and mayhem, and Mr Hague suggested that this was not the moment to strip it of its title. Mr Blair gave a quiet, thoughtful response that recognised the contribution of the force but said it had to become more inclusive - another institution that had to face the challenge of modernisation. Mr Hague looked statesmanlike; the Ulster Unionists suppressed their derision; the House was pleasingly peaceful. It was an auspicious start for the UK Noise Association, launched yesterday at the Commons to reduce decibel levels.

Earlier in the day, Mr Blair had finally appeared on a platform with Frank Dobson (never mind that the mayoral train had already left the station). Questions had been asked about the Prime Minister's devotion to the Dobson cause, but for 28 minutes they were together on stage at the Glaziers Hall in South wark, hymning the praises of the public-private partnership as the solution to London's transport woes.

Frank sat beneath his tasteful logo (isn't Frank a magazine for the discerning thirtysomething woman?), while Mr Blair blazed forth from the lectern. Norris would privatise; Livingstone would saddle London with a debt mountain; only Frank - "I've worked with this guy for 20 years, he's a man you can trust" - had the answer to the great question: how to get all the escalators working on the London Underground. Then they were off, to take the Jubilee line (with a posse of photographers) to Westminster. Great Snoring's sub-post office can expect a visit any day now.

webTitle: Wisden editor not impressed by Brimson stunt

fields.headline: Wisden editor not impressed by Brimson stunt
fields.trailText: Responding to Matthew Brimson's shenanigans in the Leicestershire team photograph on page 657 of the 2000 Wisden Cricketers' Almanack, the editor Matthew Engel said: "I think if you are going to pull this kind of stunt, you need to be a more competent professional sportsman than Matthew Brimson - and, frankly, more impressively arrayed.
fields.body:
Responding to Matthew Brimson's shenanigans in the Leicestershire team photograph on page 657 of the 2000 Wisden Cricketers' Almanack, the editor Matthew Engel said: "I think if you are going to pull this kind of stunt, you need to be a more competent professional sportsman than Matthew Brimson - and, frankly, more impressively arrayed.

"Even when we increased the size of the picture, after being tipped off today, we couldn't be certain that we'd seen what we thought we'd seen.

"If everyone's right, I think it's a very poor comment on Leicestershire County Cricket Club and professional cricketers in general. It's the supporters who have been insulted, not Wisden."

Leicestershire were quick to respond, and released a statement saying: "We have had a meeting with Matthew Brimson and we have accepted his explanation that it is simply not in his character to do anything that would cause offence.

"Matthew Brimson wishes to apologise to anyone who may have misinterpreted the published photograph."

Quite how the photo could have been misinterpreted is another matter.

webTitle: Three held as police say race attack bogus

fields.headline: Three held as police say race attack bogus
fields.trailText:
Detectives investigating an alleged racist attack in which a 17-year-old youth claimed he was set on fire by a racist gang
   in Berinsfield, Oxfordshire, said last night the attack never took place.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating an alleged racist attack in which a 17-year-old youth claimed he was set on fire by a racist gang in Berinsfield, Oxfordshire, said last night the attack never took place.

Chris Barton, 17, a mixed race youth, said four white men had sprayed him with petrol then set fire to him with lighters after racially taunting him in the early hours of last Friday morning. He suffered superficial burns to his face and hands.

Last night, however, a Thames Valley police spokesman said they were now of the opinion a racist attack never occurred.

"Thames Valley Police treated the case seriously and committed a large number of detectives and one of their four senior investigating officers," the spokesman said.

"All the detectives worked in a highly professional manner and for long hours and are now of the opinion that a racist attack never occurred."
