webTitle: Yard offers help to couple who have suffered 2,000 racist attacks

fields.headline: Yard offers help to couple who have suffered 2,000 racist attacks
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard's racial and violent crime task force has stepped in to help Lancaster race hate victims Mal Hussein and Linda Livingstone who continue to suffer a nine-year campaign by racist council tenants well known to the local police, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Scotland Yard's racial and violent crime task force has stepped in to help Lancaster race hate victims Mal Hussein and Linda Livingstone who continue to suffer a nine-year campaign by racist council tenants well known to the local police, it emerged yesterday.

The head of the task force, deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve, responded to a request by Lancashire police and sent his staff officer, detective Inspector Howard Gosling, to Lancaster on Tuesday to meet the mixed race couple.

He met them again yesterday when he attended a local conference on tackling racial harassment. He was accompanied by Mike Franklin, vice chairman of the independent advisory group set up last year to monitor the task force.

It also emerged that senior Lancaster police officers were briefed last February in London by the task force on practices adopted by Scotland Yard following the Stephen Lawrence inquiry.

These include a proactive prosecution policy involving injunctions and intelligence gathering and sharing with the local authority.

Mr Franklin said he and DI Gosling were concerned that local officers had still not informed Mr Hussein about the London briefing.

He also criticised other statutory and voluntary agencies for failing the couple. But he singled out the local authority and Lancaster police for "colluding with the majority of tenants" on Ryelands estate where Mr Hussein and Ms Livingstone have owned a corner shop and upstairs flat since 1991.

The couple, he said, were regarded by the local authorities as "the problem not the victims". And the two local Labour MPs, Hilton Dawson and Geraldine Smith, appeared "very defensive" about the record of the Labour group who controlled the local council when the worst attacks occurred between 1991 and 1997.

During the first six years the shop was regularly firebombed on Mr Hussein's birthday. He was also shot at twice and, said Mr Franklin, the police failed to properly investigate the incidents.

Mr Hussein,45, believes he was maliciously prosecuted by the police in 1991 for defending himself against two thugs trying to violently extort money from his newly-opened shop. The Pakistani-born shopkeeper was banned from his home and Lancaster city until his acquittal a year later. Since then he has documented over 2,000 racist attacks and brought more than 40 successful prosecutions against offenders.

There has, however, been no let up in the psychological and physical violence. Official council figures record that last year 37 of the 79 racial incidents recorded by the police in Lancaster related to the couple.

Last July Lancashire police apologised unreservedly to Mr Hussein for its "damning" and repeated failure since 1991 to investigate the racist attacks.

The apology followed an operational review by the Lancaster police which has never been shown to the couple in full.

The local police authority also called for a report from chief constable Pauline Clare last year. This, too, has not been disclosed.

A group of local lay advisers is reviewing Lancaster police's 12-point action plan. And an investigating officer has been appointed to identify and address any disciplinary offences in consultation with the local police authority.

During the conference, Mr Hussein criticised the action plan for still failing to support him as a repeat victim.

A scheme was launched last November by the National Assembly Against Racism to raise at least £120,000 to buy the property from the couple through a share issue that would allow then to rebuild their lives and relationship elsewhere.

Dr Richard Stone, an adviser to the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, believes there is a "conspiracy" not to take Mr Hussein seriously. Whether this is motivated by racism, corruption and a desire to cover up past mistakes will only be established by setting up a "truth commission" in Lancaster, he said.

Mr Hussein said he was pleased by Scotland Yard's involvement. This follows a meeting last week in London with Nelson Mandela.

Next week Mr Hussein will send a critical report to the home secretary, Jack Straw, who called for it when they met earlier this month in Blackburn.

Mr Hussein will ask the home secretary for an independent public inquiry. He is already taking the government to the European court of human rights for the failure of the city council to protect him and Ms Livingstone.

fields.headline: Palace guard
fields.standfirst:
Whether Royal employees have ever been covered by anti-race discrimination laws is a mysteryRace issues in the UK: special report
The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: A mysterious royal issue is due to be discussed today. The Queen employs 667 staff. The Liberal Democrat Simon Hughes wants to make her subject to anti-race discrimination law like everyone else, by proposing an amendment to the government's Race Relations Bill.
fields.body:
A mysterious royal issue is due to be discussed today. The Queen employs 667 staff. The Liberal Democrat Simon Hughes wants to make her subject to anti-race discrimination law like everyone else, by proposing an amendment to the government's Race Relations Bill.

He is merely trying to restore an earlier situation. Recently released documents at the Public Record Office confirm that the Queen had been included in the original Race Relations Act of 1968. This was in force until superseded by a new law in the mid-70s which did not include the monarch.

Why is the Queen no longer covered and why is the government not taking the opportunity of the new Bill to bring her within race relations law? I put these questions and something rather curious occurred. The Palace spokesman, helpful in other respects, would not accept that the 1968 Act had ever applied to the Queen, even after taking legal advice.

The Home Office at the first and the second time of asking were even more emphatic that the Act had not covered the Queen.

It seems these enquiries touched a sensitive spot: for to admit that the Queen had come within the 1968 Act is an implicit criticism of the present situation where she is outside the law.

It took two weeks to extract a final answer: a minimal and misleading reply, telling me that it was "a fine point", whether the Queen had ever been covered by 1968 Act.

Yet the Home Office documents now open to the public turn out to be abundantly clear. In a memo to his cabinet colleagues, dated March 21 1968, the then Home Secretary, James Callaghan, wrote, "the fact that the Crown is to be bound in the Bill will mean that the Queen will be bound in her private capacity." (ie as an employer. Her public capacity in constitutional jargon means the Crown as government).

This memo followed a meeting two days previously, on March 19 between Palace officials and Home Office civil servants. One Palace official was apparently nervous about the matter, mentioning that they would not deal with outside bodies like the Race Relations Board. (At the time the Palace would only deal via the then Ministry of Labour, with the union which represented the staff )

Other objections from the Palace may have been put in correspondence with the Home Office: we do not know, for the half-dozen such letters seem to have been removed from the files available to the public.

The next move in anti-discrimination legislation was Labour's Sex Discrimination Act of 1975. The top jobs of the Queen's household had always been filled by men. But the government only has the final say on legislation affecting the monarchy if it is prepared to insist on its point of view, as occurred in 1968. This time the Queen was not covered by the law.

The Sex Discrimination Act mentioned that government ministers and departments would be covered; but the Queen was exempt because of her "Crown immunity". An obscure constitutional convention states that only if legislation states that "the Crown" as a whole is subject to the law, or that it contains some other formulation that clearly includes the Queen, is she subject to an Act of Parliament. The Home Office under Roy Jenkins deliberately avoided any such wording in 1975, as internal documents make clear.

The subsequent 1976 Race Relations Act then fell into step with the Sex Discrimination Act. It no longer included the Queen as an employer.

Crown immunity as applied to the Queen is an outdated notion. It derives from the time that the monarch was the true ruler of the country. It was used by the Queen, with Treasury approval, to avoid paying income tax until 1993. The Queen now pays tax, but only "voluntarily" so preserving Crown immunity. However, she did not volunteer to pay inheritance tax on any of her private wealth which passes to the next monarch.

The Queen has had an extremely poor record on the equal opportunities front, although there are at last some signs that the Household are beginning to address the issue with a new director of personnel.

One young Asian woman is serving a 12-month secondment in the Palace's coordination and research unit. She follows another Asian woman who has completed her year in the same unit a couple of years ago. These appointments, the Palace maintain, have senior "members of the household" status and are thought to be the first non-white people at this level since 1959 when a Ghanaian press officer spent two months at the Palace, ahead of her visit to west Africa. He was the last recruit from the black Commonwealth to be a courtier. ITN's Trevor MacDonald back in 1992 thought it would not be long till there was another such appointment, but he has not been proved correct.

The UN can find its leader from a black, African commonwealth country but apologists for the Queen suggest she has been unable to find anyone suitable for her court from a similar source.

 Phillip Hall is the author of Royal Fortune: tax money and the monarchy (Bloomsbury).

Comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Grant and Firth to star in Bridget Jones adaptation

fields.headline: Grant and Firth to star in Bridget Jones adaptation
fields.trailText: Ending weeks of speculation, British actors Hugh Grant and Colin Firth have been confirmed to co-star in the forthcoming adaptation of Bridget Jones' Diary, alongside Renee Zellweger as the eponymous sad singleton
fields.body:
Ending weeks of speculation, British actors Hugh Grant and Colin Firth have been confirmed to co-star in the forthcoming adaptation of Bridget Jones' Diary, alongside American actress Renee Zellweger, who will play the eponymous sad singleton.

Firth, who played supporting roles in The English Patient and Shakespeare in Love, will play Mark Darcy, the romantic lead opposite Zellweger, with Grant the good for nothing Daniel, who beds our heroine, and unceremoniously dumps her for someone thinner and blonder. Firth's casting is a case of life imitating art, and its irony will not be lost of the millions of Bridget Jones fans, who will know that Colin Firth's portrayal of Mr Darcy in the 1995 BBC adaptation of Pride and Prejudice, fuels numerous fantasies for Bridget Jones.

Zellweger is perhaps best known as Tom Cruise's love interest in the 1996 hit Jerry Maguire.

Diary, produced by Working Title Films and helmed by first time director Sharon Maguire, starts shooting later this month, financed by Universal Pictures and Canal Plus.

fields.headline: A net too far?
fields.trailText: Thursday, 4.15pm: Can you really say what you want online? Across the world, the internet is suddenly facing a onslaught from individuals and organisations fighting back against online material which, they think, is illegal. Neil McIntosh explains
fields.body:
Can you really say what you want online? Across the world, the internet is suddenly facing a onslaught from individuals and organisations fighting back against online material which, they think, is illegal. More and more are trying to prove the internet is not above the law.

For long enough, "netizens" have bragged the internet simply cannot be gagged. One wit, quoted in Wired magazine in 1995, compared the internet's attitude to censorship to its in-built capacity to cope with damage caused by nuclear strikes. "The internet interprets censorship as damage, and routes around it," he said.

But already this month there have been three major attempts to clamp down on what can be published online. The right to completely free speech online has never come under greater attack - not just in the US, but in Europe as well.

The most recent challenge was launched yesterday in a San Francisco court, where Daniel Curzon Brown, a professor of English, is pursuing a lawsuit against the operators of a website. The site in question, teacherreview.com, contains vehement criticism of the professor posted by his students. He says the attacks are "evil" and that he is now "depressed and afraid" because of them.

But it is not just in the US where online freedom of speech is being challenged. Europe is also seeing a rash of court cases where material published online is being challenged under national law.

The Paris-based International League against Racism and Anti-Semitism (LICRA) is taking internet portal Yahoo! to court over Nazi memorabilia being sold on one of the websites it hosts.

Although Yahoo! is not directly responsible for the content, LICRA demanded on Tuesday that Yahoo! take steps to prevent the sales in France, where it is illegal to exhibit or sell objects with racist themes. A hearing has been set for May 15.

Meanwhile, in the UK, internet service providers are still worrying over the repercussions of Dr Lawrence Godfrey's successful action against Demon Internet, which means that in the UK internet service providers can be held liable as publishers for the information stored on their servers, including newsgroup postings and web pages created by subscribers.

Can the internet ride out this onslaught? For now, it can: controversial websites will flee the more heavily regulated countries for servers located abroad, run under more lenient regimes. But the real problems could come if run-of-the-mill e-commerce and information sites decide the risks of being sued are too high in the US or UK, and decide to move elsewhere.

For the UK, the situation could be further complicated by the regulation of investigative powers bill now going through parliament, which would hand the security services sweeping new powers to intercept encrypted communications.

All this could persuade entrepreneurs and service providers to move their servers to less heavily regulated countries, saving themselves the worry of lawsuits over content they do not control.

And, once again, the internet will have neatly routed round the problem - and dealt a hefty blow to the e-economies of the countries they have abandoned.

webTitle: BNFL dirty tricks revealed in memos

fields.headline: BNFL dirty tricks revealed in memos
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: British Nuclear Fuels was involved in a series of dirty tricks campaigns to unsettle and mislead MPs in England and Ireland and even plotted to undermine a government minister, according to secret memorandums obtained by the Guardian and the Channel 4 Dispatches programme.
fields.body:
British Nuclear Fuels was involved in a series of dirty tricks campaigns to unsettle and mislead MPs in England and Ireland and even plotted to undermine a government minister, according to secret memorandums obtained by the Guardian and the Channel 4 Dispatches programme.

The company was able to dictate the wording of a letter sent to an Irish MP who asked Tony Blair to consider the closure of Sellafield, and planned to use backbench Labour MPs "to stuff" the environment minister Michael Meacher's proposal for a public inquiry into the discharges of nuclear waste into the Irish sea.

It also targeted an MP it called "aggressive and old Labour", Rudi Vis, who ran a successful campaign to stop trains carrying dangerous spent waste from parking overnight at the back of homes in Cricklewood, north London.

Other documents reveal collusion between the Department of Trade and Industry and BNFL over the handling of safety measures, including "burying" from public scrutiny a plan to increase by 33% the speed of trains carrying spent waste.

The disclosures could not come at a worse time for the company and the DTI. BNFL is already at risk of losing millions of pounds of export orders for falsifying safety records for reprocessed nuclear fuel exported to Japan. The government has had to put on hold plans to part privatise the company before the next election.

The memos call into question the authority of trade secretary, Stephen Byers, over the actions of his civil servants at the DTI.

The authority over the DTI in 1997 of Margaret Beckett, the former president of the board of trade and now leader of the house, is also questioned. The documents show that Geoffrey Robinson, then paymaster general, was holding private meetings with top officials at BNFL to discuss privatisation within months of Labour's victory.

The former Tory trade secretary, John Redwood, who questioned the running of BNFL, said last night: "Once again Byers does not seem to be in control of his department. MPs are entitled to receive a proper and considered reply from ministers and it looks like John Battle [the former energy minister] when he was at the DTI had the wool pulled over his eyes, when he replied to the Irish MP on behalf of the prime minister.

"As for plots involving ministers it seems that Michael Meacher, a decent and fair-minded old Labour minister, is being set up by a DTI-sponsored company.

"The DTI seems to be targeting the complainant and not the issue."

Labour MPs were yesterday alarmed at the disclosures. One of the MPs who was to be targeted "to stuff" Mr Meacher, Christine Russell, Labour MP for Chester, told the Guardian: "I am absolutely shocked that they should ever think of such a thing."

Mr Vis, the MP for Finchley and Golders Green, had been sent anonymously a number of memos showing that BNFL privately regarded him as an "aggressive MP", but he was still shocked at the company's tactics. BNFL was planning to enlist prominent Jewish figures in his constituency in its campaign to undermine him.

Though BNFL was successful in replying to Mildred Fox, the Irish MP, the ploys to undermine Mr Meacher and Mr Vis failed. BNFL did not raise with Cheshire MPs its plan to get them to lobby against Mr Meacher, and Mr Vis won his battle to stop the waste trains parking in Cricklewood.

The DTI yesterday defended its role in allowing BNFL to word replies to MPs: "Mr Battle's reply drew on material provided by BNFL ... The DTI consults BNFL, seeks it advice on the issues raised and takes account of that advice in responding."

"As for plots involving ministers it seems that Michael Meacher, a decent and fair-minded old Labour minister, is being set up by a DTI-sponsored company. "The DTI seems to be targeting the complainant and not the issue." Labour MPs were yesterday alarmed at the disclosures. webTitle: How BNFL deployed its dirty tricks arsenal

fields.headline: How BNFL deployed its dirty tricks arsenal
fields.standfirst:
Techniques of deception: Irish campaigner fobbed off; Government minister discredited; Vital information buried

Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: A large number of internal documents have been leaked from British Nuclear Fuels Ltd revealing that the public relations department was involved in a series of "dirty tricks" in dealing with hostile ministers and MPs in Ireland and the UK. They also reveal that BNFL has buried important safety information - with the knowledge of the Department of Trade and Industry - on the running of nuclear waste trains.
fields.body:
A large number of internal documents have been leaked from British Nuclear Fuels Ltd revealing that the public relations department was involved in a series of "dirty tricks" in dealing with hostile ministers and MPs in Ireland and the UK. They also reveal that BNFL has buried important safety information - with the knowledge of the Department of Trade and Industry - on the running of nuclear waste trains.

Case one

An official reply to an Irish MP who had written to Tony Blair calling for Sellafield to be closed down was secretly scripted from documents prepared by British Nuclear Fuels.

The MP, Mildred Fox, who represents Wicklow, was not told that the government response telling her that her fears were "unfounded" had lifted a paragraph from BNFL's publicity, the very people she was criticising. She thought she was getting a considered reply from John Battle, then junior energy minister at the Department of Trade and Industry.

Nor did she know that BNFL had advised Whitehall that, as "one of a handful of independent MPs", she did not merit a reply from the prime minister or a secretary of state.

Ms Fox has been vocal in the campaign against Sellafield, which has discharged radioactive waste into the Irish Sea for many years.

The Irish government and campaigners have been pressing for Sellafield to be shut, as they object to the radioactive contamination of their shores and the possibility of a nuclear accident spreading fallout over their country.

In the same month Mr Blair became prime minister, Ms Fox wrote to him congratulating him on his landslide victory. She went on "to express my concern with the nuclear facility at Sellafield and would respectfully request that steps be taken to close this plant, as I feel it is a threat to public safety and quality of life".

Her letter was passed to the trade department for a reply - and then on to BNFL.

In a memo obtained by the Channel 4 programme Dispatches, a BNFL manager wrote to department officials on June 11 1997, saying: "In reply to an Irish [MP], we believe that it is important to be assertive and not to be appearing to justify or apologise for the UK nuclear industry."

BNFL suggested that, since Ms Fox was an independent MP, "the reply should come from a more junior minister" than the trade and industry secretary, then Margaret Beckett.

BNFL sent to the department a draft reply, which was included almost verbatim in the letter eventually sent to Ms Fox in the name of Mr Battle.

An entire paragraph in the letter on the operation of BNFL was written by BNFL.

In addition, Mr Battle's letter included a paragraph taken wholesale from a BNFL brochure. Ms Fox told Dispatches: "I find it very offensive and condescending. You can get technical information [from BNFL] but you don't advise a minister on how to reply to a particular race of people ... it just shows the lack of regard they have for the concerns of Irish people."

A spokesman for the DTI said: "Though Mr Battle's reply drew on material provided by BNFL, it had been amended to omit references to safety standards acheived at Sellafield."

Case two

An extraordinary proposal to "stuff Michael Meacher" is revealed in a leaked memo from the company, whereby Labour backbench MPs worried about job losses at a BNFL subsidiary were to be urged to lobby against the environment minister's plans for a public inquiry into discharges into the sea at Sellafield

The memo is one of a series written by BNFL's public relations department, deal ing with handling "old Labour" backbench MPs complaining about the company's activities.

Another involved persuading influential Jewish community leaders to try and modify a stance taken by Labour backbencher Rudi Vis, MP for Finchley and Golders Green, against plans to store spent waste trains in sidings outside homes in Cricklewood, north London.

The memo on Mr Meacher, written on August 14 1997, came as the then BNFL chairman, Sir John Guinness, was under pressure from Cheshire MPs over plans to hive off work at the Capenhurst nuclear facility in advance of the part-privatisation of the company. The plan was to cut jobs by allowing a management buyout - which subsequently went ahead - of a subsidary called Deva, which makes nuclear flasks.

The memo, written by Rupert Wilcox-Baker, the company's public relations director, says: "Christine Russell [MP for Chester] has asked for a meeting with Guinness and all the local MPs which has been accepted but no date fixed ... my radical suggestion is that we meet Russell and the other MPs and say we made a mistake on Deva and announce we con tinue to support it. Then we ask them, as a body with the other constituency MPs, to stuff Meacher and the public inquiry. Cheap trade off?"

Ms Russell confirmed yesterday that a meeting did go ahead but she had no recollection of such a proposal being put to her and the other MPs. Instead BNFL went ahead with the management buy-out, and Mr Meacher won his case for an inquiry by the environment agency into the discharges. "I am absolutely shocked that they should ever think of such a thing," she told the Guardian.

On Mr Vis, who has successfully campaigned to keep spent waste trains from being stored at Cricklewood, a memo to Sir John Guinness proposed a way of undermining his campaign.

Written in March last year, it read: "We have had a number of meetings with Rudi Vis and he has made it very clear that he is determined to get us out of Cricklewood and to stop us transporting spent fuel. Andrew Miller's [Labour MP for Ellesmere Port] insight into Vis's rationale is interesting but I suspect what he is seeing is a hangover from Vis's old Labour background. He is a long-standing member of CND and has stated privately to us his ab horrence of all things nuclear ..." It goes on: "Regarding the suggestion that we try and get a senior Jewish figure on side, I have some doubts ... whilst Rudi Vis is not himself Jewish, his father helped Jewish families during the last war in Alkmaar, Holland, where Vis was born in 1941.

"With that in mind and the make-up of his constituency, the Jewish influence will be strong. I would propose that we ensure that this section of the local community is fully represented in the dialogue process."

Case three

BNFL staff deliberately "buried" vital information about the dangers of trains which carry highly radioactive waste hundreds of miles across Britain, the internal papers revealed.

Officials at the Department of Trade and Industry were told by BNFL that the information was being hidden from the public.

Nuclear waste was regularly transported each week by rail to Sellafield from various different power stations. The cargo travelled through densely populated areas, on the same lines as passenger trains.

Last year BNFL proposed that the speed of the trains should be increased from 45 mph to 60 mph.

BNFL, in consultation with the DTI, drew up a public statement in case the media and campaigners started to ask questions about the speeds of the trains.

In a secret memo to the DTI in April last year a BNFL manager wrote that the original draft statement had been reworked to "reflect your comments".

The only hint of the faster speed appeared in the middle of the public statement in a sentence which stated that "over time there will be some operational differences" to the trains.

A spokesman for BNFL told the Guardian: "BNFL did propose last year to increase the speed of the trains to 60mph and do have the power under current regulations for carrying hazardous waste to do so. But we have decided at the moment to keep the trains running at 45mph."

A DTI spokesman said: "The wording in the BNFL memo and the use of the word "buried" is clearly poor and unfortunate but obviously was BNFL's responsibility. Any change [in the speed of the trains] would only be made in the light of regulatory and ministerial agreement and would be made public."

Another secret memo shows that the DTI encouraged BNFL to keep quiet about its failure to comply with reporting requirements on accidents and other hazardous incidents.

In June 1997 BNFL and the DTI were concerned about pressure from the Health and Safety Executive and the Environment Agency to improve the existing agreement.

webTitle: How much can you pay for...

fields.headline: How much can you pay for...
fields.standfirst: ...a computer mouse?
fields.trailText: ...a computer mouse?
fields.body:
Asprey & Garrard, the Queen's jewellers, is offering a sterling silver computer mouse for £850. For an extra £100, you can buy the millennium bug edition featuring a small silver insect with large teeth sitting beside the gilt click button. Both plug straight into your Mac or PC, the standard mouse with a plain black wire and the bug version with a lilac wire, the millennium colour, apparently. For maximum effect, use the millennium bug mouse while wearing Asprey's sterling silver millennium bug cufflinks featuring the same insect gnawing a pair of miniature floppy disks. These will set you back £95.

If you still haven't spent enough, for a further £495, you can buy a matching silver case for your own disks. This will hold two floppies at a time. Because it's silver, Asprey warns that it may get scratched at the bottom of your briefcase, but a good polish will bring it back to form. To order a silver mouse, call Asprey on 0171 493 6767. Alternatively, ring PC World where for the same price you can buy two desk-top computers and a printer.

fields.headline: Cybershopping: gardening
fields.standfirst: Shopping Unlimited
fields.trailText: Worse than gardening has to be pushing a trolley round rows of bedding plants. So skip that and go to one of the new gardening destinations online.
fields.body:
Worse than gardening has to be pushing a trolley round rows of bedding plants. So skip that and go to one of the new gardening destinations online. www.e-garden.co.uk claims to be the UK's largest gardening website, and has signed up some of the nation's top experts to provide tips. If visitors can't find the answer to a problem, they can get advice from the e-garden team. The online catalogue is easy to browse, with clear images and information about the best times and conditions in which to plant. The site has more than 2,000 products (most of which, the company says, are 15-20% cheaper than in garden centres) including shrubs, gardening tools and cut fresh flowers. There is also a reassuring "no quibbles e-guarantee" of a refund or replacement on all unsuitable goods.

The creators of gardening portal - or "horticultural channel" - www.thegardenline.com, hope it will become the prime online gardening and horticulture service, accessible via the net, public information kiosks and possibly WAP-enabled phones. The site launched this month and is set for completion by the end of May. As well as a gardening and horticultural products from some big names in garden retail, a facility is being set up to enable specialist sellers to create their own websites.

fields.headline: Dial 020 for chaos
fields.standfirst: More than 15m phone numbers will change next week, yet few of us know what the new codes are. If you're not careful, you may call north Africa rather than north London, warns  Oliver Burkeman
fields.trailText: More than 15m phone numbers will change next week, yet few of us know what the new codes are. If you're not careful, you may call north Africa rather than north London.
fields.body:
1. Inner London (0171) xxx xxxx becomes (020) 7xxx xxxx

2. Outer London (0181) xxx xxxx becomes (020) 8xxx xxxx

3. Cardiff (01222) xxxxxx becomes (029) 20xx xxxx

4. Coventry (01203) xxxxxx becomes (024) 76xx xxxx

5. Northern Ireland (028) plus one of 37 new local number prefixes, making all local numbers eight digits

6. Portsmouth (01705) xxxxxx becomes (023) 92xx xxxx

7. Southampton (01703) xxxxxx becomes (023) 80xx xxxx

You don't need a degree in organisational psychology to detect the distinct smell of panic that has been emanating from the offices of The Big Number in recent weeks. Fifteen million telephone users will be affected by next week's sweeping numbering changes, but according to The Big Number, the telecommunications industry-backed campaign charged with drumming the switch into the British psyche, few have any idea what they mean.

Even according to its own recent survey, only 7% of people questioned in the affected areas - London, Cardiff, Coventry, Northern Ireland, Portsmouth and Southampton - could correctly describe how their area codes and local numbers would change on April 22. In outer London, the figure was 5%; in Northern Ireland - where the changes are nightmarishly complex - it was a dismal 3%.

As a result, the people at The Big Number have been indulging in some comically desperate attempts to ram home the message. In February, the campaign website warned "would-be Romeos" of devastating consequences if they didn't get the hang of their new three-digit (02x) area codes and eight-digit local numbers: "You may be chatting up the best-looking woman in the whole club - but blow it all by giving out your old number." (Actually, she'll get an error message and soon figure out your new one, but who can begrudge the beleaguered awareness-raiser a little poetic licence?)

By last week things were getting serious. Computer software, fax machines, auto-dialling security alarms and phone memory banks would need reprogramming, we were warned; even more importantly, "dog and cat owners should check pet collars carry the right telephone number."

"Because this is a change to people's numbers as well as their code, it's been more difficult for them to get their minds around it," explains Howard Sandom, campaign manager at The Big Number. "We know people only internalise the information at the last minute, but what they have to understand is that on April 22, their existing local number stops working and" - this is the nub - "they have to start using the eight-digit local numbers."

If domestic customers are confused, business users have been hassled by the switch for months. Stories abound of companies - even telephone companies - which spent thousands redesigning stationery and vehicle liveries on the assumption that London's new codes are 0207 and 0208. In fact, the single new London code is 020; the 7 and 8 are part of the numbers, and need to be dialled even when calling locally.

In a heartwarming display of corporate unity, the Big Number's £20m advertising campaign is funded by the industry under the name All The Phone Companies Together; its centrepiece is a "number change machine" allowing users to enter their old number and discover the new one. This is accessible via the campaign's website (www.numberchange.org) and a free helpline (0808 2242000), which is far easier to get through to, and certainly far more helpful, than telephoning any of the companies individually.

But even as they seek to draw attention to the switchover, the telephone operators are making furious efforts to distance themselves from responsibility for it: BT's mailshots point the finger at Oftel, the regulator which initiated the move. This should not come as much of a surprise: next Saturday's change represents the latest instalment in a sequence of adjustments that arguably ought never to have been required in the first place.

There have been only seven major changes to numbering in Britain since the telephone was introduced in 1879, but three of them have happened in the past decade. Critics accuse Oftel of having caved in too readily to requests for more capacity, and of monumental lack of foresight in 1995, when area codes gained a 1. The obvious excuse - that it had only just taken over responsibility for numbering from BT, and had to act fast to create new capacity - looks a little flimsy in the light of its claim then that no more changes would be required in the foreseeable future.

But this is the unforeseen future, a world of proliferating mobile numbers, data lines and domestic faxes, and it's making some people uncomfortable. "There's nothing worse than a funny-sounding noise on the line and the impression given to the customer that a business has gone bust," says Stephen Alambritis, of the Federation of Small Businesses. The FSB estimates most small businesses will incur costs of anything from £100 to £2,000 in redesigning letterheads, shopfronts and vans, assuming that they even know about the change.

Then there are foreign suppliers and customers to be alerted, software to be reconfigured and directory entries to be amended, and Microsoft Office's nasty habit of interpreting "02" as the international dialling code for Egypt (a "patch" is available at www.microsoft.co.uk). And, as Alambritis points out, it hardly helps that directory enquiries has made no apparent effort to give out the new numbers or warn of their imminent arrival. "In 1995, the impression was given that that was it, the industry had got its act together," he says. "The problem is all the chopping and changing at a time when issues like this need to be sorted out on a once and for all basis."

Sandom is phlegmatic. "We have to be mature enough to take this on the chin. The explosive growth of telecom in the past three to five years has caught everyone by surprise: even the most optimistic forecasters couldn't have seen how much the data and mobile networks would grow. We're introducing a system we believe will be robust for a long time to come, with a system of order we think people will welcome."

The simultaneous introduction of other uniform prefixes - 07 for mobiles and pagers, 08 for free and local rate calls, 09 for premium services - will, he says, create a "family of numbers" and imbue the numbering system with the perfect logic it's lacked since three-letter exchange names were abolished in the 1960s.

None of this will matter, of course, when the day finally dawns that numbers aren't needed at all. Some mobile phones can already make calls on the basis of spoken names; there's no theoretical reason why we shouldn't abandon strings of digits altogether, just as few people learn the complex sequence of numbers by which a website is technically identified. "There'll come a time when we'll generally be talking to our computers and telephones," Peter Cochrane, BT's pathologically optimistic chief technologist, has predicted.

And not everyone is dreading the change. "With all the stationery that will need redesigning, printers should be in for a boom time," says Alambritis.

 The new local numbers come into operation on Saturday April 22. Website: www.numberchange.org Helpline: 0808 2242000

In a heartwarming display of corporate unity, the Big Number's £20m advertising campaign is funded by the industry under the name All The Phone Companies Together; its centrepiece is a "number change machine" allowing users to enter their old number and discover the new one. This is accessible via the campaign's website (www.numberchange.org) and a free helpline (0808 2242000), which is far easier to get through to, and certainly far more helpful, than telephoning any of the companies individually. But even as they seek to draw attention to the switchover, the telephone operators are making furious efforts to distance themselves from responsibility for it: BT's mailshots point the finger at Oftel, the regulator which initiated the move. This should not come as much of a surprise: next Saturday's change represents the latest instalment in a sequence of adjustments that arguably ought never to have been required in the first place. There have been only seven major changes to numbering in Britain since the telephone was introduced in 1879, but three of them have happened in the past decade. Critics accuse Oftel of having caved in too readily to requests for more capacity, and of monumental lack of foresight in 1995, when area codes gained a 1. The obvious excuse - that it had only just taken over responsibility for numbering from BT, and had to act fast to create new capacity - looks a little flimsy in the light of its claim then that no more changes would be required in the foreseeable future. But this is the unforeseen future, a world of proliferating mobile numbers, data lines and domestic faxes, and it's making some people uncomfortable. "There's nothing worse than a funny-sounding noise on the line and the impression given to the customer that a business has gone bust," says Stephen Alambritis, of the Federation of Small Businesses. The FSB estimates most small businesses will incur costs of anything from £100 to £2,000 in redesigning letterheads, shopfronts and vans, assuming that they even know about the change. Then there are foreign suppliers and customers to be alerted, software to be reconfigured and directory entries to be amended, and Microsoft Office's nasty habit of interpreting "02" as the international dialling code for Egypt (a "patch" is available at www.microsoft.co.uk). And, as Alambritis points out, it hardly helps that directory enquiries has made no apparent effort to give out the new numbers or warn of their imminent arrival. "In 1995, the impression was given that that was it, the industry had got its act together," he says. "The problem is all the chopping and changing at a time when issues like this need to be sorted out on a once and for all basis." Sandom is phlegmatic. "We have to be mature enough to take this on the chin. The explosive growth of telecom in the past three to five years has caught everyone by surprise: even the most optimistic forecasters couldn't have seen how much the data and mobile networks would grow. We're introducing a system we believe will be robust for a long time to come, with a system of order we think people will welcome." The simultaneous introduction of other uniform prefixes - 07 for mobiles and pagers, 08 for free and local rate calls, 09 for premium services - will, he says, create a "family of numbers" and imbue the numbering system with the perfect logic it's lacked since three-letter exchange names were abolished in the 1960s. None of this will matter, of course, when the day finally dawns that numbers aren't needed at all. Some mobile phones can already make calls on the basis of spoken names; there's no theoretical reason why we shouldn't abandon strings of digits altogether, just as few people learn the complex sequence of numbers by which a website is technically identified. "There'll come a time when we'll generally be talking to our computers and telephones," Peter Cochrane, BT's pathologically optimistic chief technologist, has predicted. And not everyone is dreading the change. "With all the stationery that will need redesigning, printers should be in for a boom time," says Alambritis.  The new local numbers come into operation on Saturday April 22. fields.headline: Ken will win despite himself
fields.standfirst: Even his gaffes can't stop him now, says Livingstone biographer John Carvel
fields.trailText: Even his gaffes can't stop him now, says Livingstone biographer John Carvel
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone has not been running the smartest of campaigns of late in his bid to become London mayor.

He could be reasonably confident that he commanded the hearts of a majority of voters, but not yet sure that he had won their heads.

A conventional campaign manager would have advised him to spend all his time reassuring people that there would be no economic price to pay for having him as their effervescent, independent voice.

But Livingstone is his own campaign manager and he is not conventional. That is both the reason for his appeal and the reason why he makes what other politicians would regard as mistakes.

Whatever the truth of the matter, it was not clever of him to say that global capitalism kills more people each year than Hitler. That will not have gained any votes - and will probably have lost some - for a candidate wanting to run an international trading city that needs to woo global capitalists. Neither was the handling of his extra-parliamentary income entirely deft.

But today's ICM poll for the Evening Standard suggests he is escaping punishment for tactical errors. It puts his share of the vote at 49% - well down on the 68% recorded by the Guardian's poll on March 6, the day he announced his candidacy, and the 61% that he registered in the last Evening Standard poll nearly a month ago.

The drop was inevitable because, for Livingstone, those early figures were too good to be true. They may have reflected Londoners' irritation with the stitch-up that denied Livingstone the Labour candidacy more than their opinion about his fitness for office.

As polling day approaches, voters become more concerned about the future and less about the circumstances in which candidates were selected. Livingstone's good fortune is that his loss of support over the last five weeks has not produced a strong rival. None of his votes leeched to Frank Dobson, the official Labour candidate, whose cause is starting to look hopeless. Dobson's share fell by 1%. Other candidates gained.

The result is a three-way race for second place, with Stephen Norris for the Conservatives on 16%, Dobson on 15% and Susan Kramer for the Liberal Democrats on 12%.

Unless one of them emerges quickly as the clear challenger to front-runner Livingstone, he looks to have the election in the bag. If he does not get 50% on the first ballot, the contest will be decided on second-preference votes. But how, on these figures, does an anti-Livingstone supporter of Dobson, Norris or Kramer choose a second preference?

So Livingstone may be making mistakes. But they are not half as bad as those made by Tony Blair, architect of Labour's mayoral fiasco. For him the nightmare gets worse.

 John Carvel is author of Turn Again Livingstone, Profile Books £6.99.

webTitle: Livingstone's lead tumbles in new poll

fields.headline: Livingstone's lead tumbles in new poll
fields.standfirst: The frontrunner in London's mayoral election has seen his support fall by 12 points - but he is still 33 points ahead of his nearest rival.
fields.trailText: The support for the London mayoral favourite, Ken Livingstone, has fallen 12 points to 49%, but the former Labour MP still commands a 33-point lead over his rivals, according to a new poll published today.
fields.body:
The support for the London mayoral favourite, Ken Livingstone, has fallen 12 points to 49%, but the former Labour MP still commands a 33-point lead over his rivals, according to a new poll published today.

Labour's Frank Dobson also lost support since the previous Evening Standard poll last month, sliding into third place with just 15%. "As the seriousness of the campaign and the seriousness of the mayor's job becomes more widely known, I will do better," Mr Dobson insisted.

The prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, argued that little significance should be attached to Mr Dobson's rating. "Polls are polls, that's his Mr Blair's view of them," he said.

Support for the Conservative candidate, Steven Norris, has risen three points to 16%, and the Liberal Democrat candidate, Susan Kramer, rose four to 12%, according to the poll.

An ICM poll for the Guardian carried out immediately after Mr Livingstone declared his independent campaign last month gave him 68%, a 55-point lead.

Today's ICM poll was carried out after Mr Livingstone told the NME that capitalism had killed more people than Hitler.

In a radio debate with the other main mayoral candidates today, Mr Livingstone moved to quell unease in the City by arguing that it was the United States, and not the City of London, which was primarily responsible for third world debt and the inequities of the capitalist system.

"No one makes money in the City out of the international debt crisis," he told BBC Radio 2's Jimmy Young Show.

"I see no reason why we continue to have a system where America dominates the IMF and the World Bank and WTO [World Trade Organisation], rigging the whole system not just for their own benefit but causing huge mayhem in the third world."

Meanwhile, Ms Kramer launched her manifesto today, claiming "the momentum is with us" as she draws "within spitting distance" of Mr Norris and Mr Dobson.

Ms Kramer predicted she could come second to Mr Livingstone in the first round, after which she could win the ballot on the strength of picking up more second preference votes, to be redistributed from losing candidates to the top two if no one wins 50% in the first poll.

In her manifesto, the former banker said her three priorities for London were rescuing public transport, reducing crime and revitalising local communities.

She promised no privatisation of the tube and an increase in policing, as well as a system of community banks to raise funds in impoverished parts of the capital.

"I will raise the billions of pounds needed for transport, not by selling off parts of the tube, but by raising revenue bonds, a system that has been shown to work for transport projects worldwide," she said.

fields.headline: Gibson blockbuster baits the censors
fields.trailText: The makers of the new Mel Gibson blockbuster, The Patriot, are already anticipating trouble with the American film censors over a solitary scene featuring two children killing a British soldier
fields.body:
The makers of the new Mel Gibson blockbuster, The Patriot are already anticipating trouble with the American film censors over a solitary scene featuring two children killing a British soldier. Directed by Roland Emmerich, the film has been tipped as one of the summer's big movies, but insiders are concerned that an 'R' rating could seriously impede its box-office appeal.

The Patriot is a movie in the same Brit-bashing vein as Gibson's Oscar-winning Braveheart. But where Braveheart celebrated the Scots fight against their English oppressors, The Patriot stars Mel as a hardy pioneer battling with the British army during the American War of Independence. One scene follows the adventures of two brothers (aged 12 and 13) as they stalk and eventually gun down a British soldier. For a nation still reeling from a spate of Columbine-style tragedies, the scene seems guaranteed to cause controversy.

Even if The Patriot is threatened with the expected R-rating, director Emmerich has vowed that he will not cut the film. Meanwhile producer Dean Devlin has been defending the scene to USA Today. "I don't think anyone's cheering these children shooting their guns," he argues. "I don't think children seeing it are going to want to shoot guns from looking at it... If the only kind of violence our children see is heroic violence, I think that's really dangerous. We felt it was important to show that it's horrifying."

fields.headline: Too much, too young
fields.standfirst: Sean Ingle believes that being the most promising player in the world has taken its toll on Ronaldo
fields.trailText: Just seven days ago, Ronaldo flashed his once-familiar buck-toothed grin at the world's press. "I'm going through a magic moment," he told them after his son Ronald's birth. "I'm back playing, I have a son. Life is wonderful!"
fields.body:
Just seven days ago, Ronaldo flashed his once-familiar buck-toothed grin at the world's press. "I'm going through a magic moment," he told them after his son Ronald's birth. "I'm back playing, I have a son. Life is wonderful!"

At last, Ronaldo seemed genuinely happy. All the injuries and frustrations that had tormented him since the 1998 World Cup Final were evaporating before our eyes. The world's greatest footballer was ready to return.

Last night he made his comeback. But just seven minutes after replacing Roberto Baggio in the first leg of the Italian Cup final against Lazio, he was lying on the ground, his face contorted in agony, clutching the same right knee that had caused him problems all season.

And as he woke this morning every newspaper from London to Lahore was asking the same question: after being stretchered off yet again, is Ronaldo's career finished?

Of course it's too early to say. But one thing that can't be disputed is that in football - like life itself - you often reap what you sow. And the fact is that Ronaldo's injury woes are a direct result of playing too much football, too young.

A look at his career shows that football is pretty much all he's being doing ever since he was spotted at fourteen by Brazilian legend Jairzinho.

At seventeen he was playing in the Brazilian First Division for Cruzeiro Belo Horizonte, scoring a phenomenal 58 goals in an equally phenomenal 60 games during the 1993/1994 season.

After that he moved to Europe, where neither the goals - nor the rate of games, slackened. At PSV (56 league matches, 55 goals) and Barcelona (37 league matches, 34 goals) Ronaldo's innate ability to glide past an awkward challenge coupled with his sheer physical power helped him smash goal-scoring record after goal-scoring record. Even at Inter, his record of 54 goals in 90 games is more prolific than most.

But all those matches, coupled with the myriad must-attend Brazilian friendlies and photo-shoots organised by Nike - who were desperate to get every last ounce of publicity out of the money they'd spent sponsoring him - have taken their toil on both Ronaldo's physical and psychological state.

Perhaps the only surprise about his collapse before the 1998 World Cup final was that it didn't happen sooner. For most footballers a long-time injury is now part of the job, along with the flash cars and fast women. More matches inevitably bring more injuries.

In 1998 when Fifa banned the tackle from behind, they called it the Van Basten law, in memory of the great Dutch striker who had his career criminally shortened by injury.

Recently the world's governing body announced plans for a world football calender to allow players a break from the stresses of the game. Let's just hope - if it's ever introduced - they won't have to call it the Ronaldo law, in memory of a brilliant Brazilian whose career never fulfilled what it had promised.

webTitle: Embattled Mugabe confronted by rule of law

fields.headline: Embattled Mugabe confronted by rule of law
fields.standfirst: President Robert Mugabe's remaining obstacle to absolute power is Zimbabwe's independent judiciary, writes Guardian foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall
fields.trailText: The order issued today by Zimbabwe's high court instructing police to halt a spate of farm invasions by supporters of the ruling Zanu-PF party has placed the country's independent judiciary in direct confrontation with the government of President Robert Mugabe.
fields.body:
The order issued today by Zimbabwe's high court instructing police to halt a spate of farm invasions by supporters of the ruling Zanu-PF party has placed the country's independent judiciary in direct confrontation with the government of President Robert Mugabe.

An earlier high court ruling ordering the eviction of more than 50,000 squatters, who have occupied several hundred white-owned farms amid increasing violence, had been challenged by the police commissioner and the attorney-general, Patrick Chinamasa. They maintained that the order was unenforceable and if attempted, could lead to widespread bloodshed.

Earlier this week Mr Chinamasa went further, telling Judge Moses Chinhengo that the farm invasions were essentially a political matter, part of the "unfinished business" of Zimbabwe's liberation war against Ian Smith's illegal white-minority regime.

Mr Justice Chinhengo rejected those arguments today, saying he saw no reason to reverse the previous court order. "The rule of law must be upheld," he said.

The ruling is the latest in a series of blows suffered by Mr Mugabe's regime. Last year, it lost funding from the IMF and World Bank after a row over its economic management and its involvement in the Congo war. In February, it lost a national referendum on a new constitution. Since then, the United States has cut bilateral aid, South African banks have suspended commercial credit, Zimbabwe's foreign reserves have been exhausted and the country has been hit by serious fuel and energy shortages.

Mr Mugabe has also become engaged in a war of words with Britain, the country's former colonial power, which he claims is trying to influence forthcoming general elections. But facing his biggest-ever challenge from the multiracial Movement for Democratic Change, Mr Mugabe has postponed the elections, originally due this month, and has refused so far to set a new date.

This week's dissolution of parliament, coupled with the government's control of much of the media and its suppression of opposition demonstrations, means that the judiciary is the only remaining obstacle to unchallenged rule by Mr Mugabe.

The big question now is whether Mr Mugabe's government will accept the court order. It made no immediate comment after the ruling.

On recent form, it seems unlikely to comply. If it does not, then farmers and other groups are likely to return to court, arguing that Mr Chinamasa and the police commissioner, Augustine Chihuri, are in prima facie contempt of court. Mr Justice Chinhengo yesterday imposed no penalties on the government, other than costs, for ignoring the earlier ruling. If its defiance continues, however, he may be forced to put the government in the dock.

Mr Mugabe has repeatedly expressed his support for the farm occupations, and has increased the tension by telling white Zimbabweans that they should leave the country if they are not prepared to give up their land. To back down now would be seen as another, big personal humiliation.

But the alternative - ignoring the law, defying the high court, and perhaps preventing further court proceeedings - would be even more damaging, confirming the view of many Zimbabweans that Mr Mugabe has become an autocrat and that the country is heading for anarchy and a possible new civil war.

All this makes it more necessary than ever that a British plan to appoint an independent regional mediator to tackle some of these issues is implemented.

webTitle: NHS under fire for 'allowing older patients to die'

fields.headline: NHS under fire for 'allowing older patients to die'
fields.standfirst: 13 April, 2.30pm: The health service has defended itself against accusations from Age Concern that a shortage of beds has led some hospitals to allow older patients to die.
fields.trailText: 13 April, 2.30pm: The health service has defended itself against accusations from Age Concern that a shortage of beds has led some hospitals to allow older patients to die.
fields.body:
The NHS today found itself on the defensive again amid accusations that some British hospitals are allowing elderly patients to die because of a shortage of beds.

The latest salvo against the embattled health service came from Age Concern, which accused doctors of ignoring national guidelines on the resuscitation of older people. The charity said that some elderly patients had found "not for resuscitation" written on their medical notes without their knowledge.

"The evidence we have received about 'not for resuscitation' points to a disregard of the national guidelines," said Sally Greencross, the director of Age Concern.

The Department of Health said that such reports should be checked on a case-by-case basis, but it stopped short of launching a full-scale investigation. Sheila Adam, deputy chief medical officer at the NHS, said: "These individual cases ... obviously do raise concerns and should be fully investigated." She said her department would publish a blueprint on medical services for the elderly next year.

"There are principles which should be followed," Dr Adam said. "The patients' wishes should be taken into account where they are known, and where appropriate so should the relatives' views."

The case of an elderly cancer-sufferer was the latest embarrassment for the NHS. Jill Baker, 67, described her horror at discovering that doctors treating her in hospital had decided not to resuscitate her - without seeking her permission to let her die. She only found out after she left hospital that the comment "inappropriate for resuscitation" had been written on her notes.

She said she was "written off" by a doctor who never even met her - but she is still alive and enjoying good quality of life more than nine months later. Mrs Baker, from Portsmouth, who has stomach cancer, was admitted to a ward in the city's St Mary's hospital last July after a tube used in her chemotherapy treatment became infected and she developed septicaemia.

She eventually discharged herself because she was unhappy with her care and demanded to see her hospital notes. A doctor had written on top of the records: "In view of the underlying diagnosis (cancer), in the event of cardiac arrest or stroke, resuscitation would be inappropriate." The note also said: "Do not ring 555" - the hospital number for the resuscitation team.

Mrs Baker said: "When I read this I was absolutely horrified. They were going to let me die. My husband broke down in tears. I am a founder member of the NHS - I have paid for it from the very beginning - but my husband has now said he would rather sell everything we own and go to private healthcare than let me go in to that ward again."

His move came after a barrage of criticism of the NHS, from the shortage of beds to the lack of funding for talking care of the elderly. But the International Monetary Fund has criticised Mr Brown for going on a spending spree that risks bringing in its wake higher interest rates.

webTitle: Anthony Hopkins renounces UK for US

fields.headline: Anthony Hopkins renounces UK for US
fields.trailText: Anthony Hopkins is now officially an American citizen. The Welsh-born actor effectively renounced his British passport in a quiet ceremony in Los Angeles last night presided over by Judge Margaret Morrow. John Travolta and Steven Spielberg were among several celebrity buddies in attendance to welcome the 62-year-old actor into the American way of life.
fields.body:
Anthony Hopkins is now officially an American citizen. The Welsh-born actor effectively renounced his British passport in a quiet ceremony in Los Angeles last night presided over by Judge Margaret Morrow. John Travolta and Steven Spielberg were among several celebrity buddies in attendance to welcome the 62-year-old actor into the American way of life.

Hopkins has been a US resident for several years now and makes the majority of his movies for American studios. He is currently preparing to reprise his Oscar-winning role as Hannibal Lecter in the Ridley Scott picture Hannibal. "He has been here a long time and it seemed like the right thing to do," explained his spokeswoman Catherine Olim.

An issue yet to be clarified is that of Hopkins's title. Sir Anthony was knighted by Queen Elizabeth in 1993, but part of the US pledge of allegiance called upon him to read the line, "I further renounce the title of nobility to which I have heretofore belonged."

Some experts claim that Hopkins may still be referred to as "Sir Anthony" when he visits the land of his birth. In America, by contrast, he has become plain old Tony once again.

fields.headline: BMW sell-off 'secret and incompetent'
fields.standfirst:
BMW accused but government exonerated by MPs' report
Latest trade and industry select committee publications
fields.trailText: MPs today accused BMW of "excessive secrecy and incompetence" in its attempted sale of Rover, and criticised the government for its failure to anticipate the "chaotic and incomplete" break-up of the car manufacturer.
fields.body:
MPs today accused BMW of "excessive secrecy and incompetence" in its attempted sale of Rover, and criticised the government for its failure to anticipate the "chaotic and incomplete" break-up of the car manufacturer.

A new report by the Commons trade and industry select committee found BMW had lacked "any coherent disengagement strategy, or any plan for communicating the decisions".

"BMW should be criticised for the manner of its disposal of Rover on grounds of incompetence and excessive secrecy," the report said.

The committee's report also defended trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers' handling of the crisis, finding that allegations from Tory leader William Hague that Mr Byers doctored a BMW statement on March 30 "have not been substantiated".

"Given the assurances from the most senior managers of BMW in the UK and in Munich, it is hard to see how the secretary of state could have anticipated the decisions of March 16," said the Labour-dominated committee."

Chairman Martin O'Neill MP told a Commons press conference that the committee did not believe Mr Byers was guilty "of anything" and Conservative committee members John Butterfill and Tony Baldry said there was more of a "cock-up than a conspiracy" over the statements.

But the report questioned whether Mr Byers could have better anticipated BMW's decision, saying that Mr Byers was given "some advance indication" of BMW's plans when he met Rover boss Walter Samann on March 10, and that his officials had allegedly been similarly warned on 23 February.

"We do however detect some failure in the government's intelligence-gathering mechanism in recent weeks," they concluded.

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB, said: "The Department of Trade and Industry really dropped the ball on this one. It is high time the DTI was restructured and given a new remit. Its job from now on must be to ensure the defence and promotion of British industry at home and abroad. We must never see a situation akin to Longbridge again."

John Redwood, former Conservative shadow trade secretary, said: "Labour wanted a whitewash but the report is a greywash. It's no good Stephen Byers trying to blame his officials for his abject failure with BMW-Rover. He's either been incompetent or misled everybody.

"We still need to know why he said in the summer of last year that the large grant he was offering would secure the future of Longbridge and why he then told me in the House of Commons that the grant was a 'red herring', not big enough to make any difference."

"Given the assurances from the most senior managers of BMW in the UK and in Munich, it is hard to see how the secretary of state could have anticipated the decisions of March 16," said the Labour-dominated committee.

Downing Street said the report provided strong backing for Mr Byers.

Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman, said: "We have been clear throughout that the prime minister thinks Stephen Byers handled it [the Rover situation] extremely well.

"The pressure has been on Stephen Byers; we have insisted throughout that the version he has been giving has been right, and consistent, and we do feel that this report vindicates him."

The MPs' report also said that prospects for Longbridge were "bleak", adding that any rescue would only partially preserve the plant's manufacturing capacity.

Following last night's meeting at No 10 between the prime minister, Mr Byers and members of the society of motor manufacturers and traders, Mr Campbell said that the government was "well aware" of the wider motor industry's current concerns, but held out little prospect of any moves to lower the value of the pound.

"Don't imagine that they all came in and said everything was all doom and gloom - the economic fundamentals are strong," he said.

"On the strength of the pound, our position hasn't changed."

fields.headline: Online soap operas
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about episodic entertainment on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about episodic entertainment on the net
fields.body:
1. Today sees the launch of Online Caroline, the latest attempt to persuade soap fans to transfer their addiction from TV screen to computer screen.

2. Freeserve's Caroline is set on a fictional personal homepage. You register and are soon bombarded with emails from Caroline, who tells you: "I live with David - although he's expressed his deep love for me by buggering off to Africa for work. Back in a week or so, he says." In his absence, you are encouraged to befriend her.

3. It's faintly pervy stuff, and should be an obvious hit with anoraks-cum-macs, who can already fill their boots with the one genre whose current TV boom follows its the proliferation on the web - docusoaps.

4.You can follow the drama of people's real lives via hundreds of personal webcams, from the leerily contrived to the shockingly banal.

5. There are also hundreds more orthodox fictional soap operas, including Covington Bay ("Love. Lust. Mystery. Intrigue. Danger. Desire.") and Schuyler Falls ("Jonnie Adair is the Bartender at Boondoggles"). Both are American, and you've got a lot of episodes to catch up on.

6. There is exotica and good old-fashioned English action, albeit from an American perspective.

7. Some are simply serial stories; others are vaguely interactive, a bit like those non-linear ("choose your adventure" to you and me) novels which enjoyed a brief heyday in the 1980s.

8. But the finest online soap by far is from the fens, the aptly named Cauliflower Drove.

9. It had the citizens of Ely enthralled for 100 episodes after the shocking murder of farmer Reg Dixon and rise of yokel hero Yaxley Farcett, who bears an uncanny resemblance to Ewan McGregor.

10. TV soap script-writers are unlikely to be quaking in their boots. The big hitting soap sites are still those of the nation's great TV dramas, and the future of interactive soap operas is likely to be on digital TV screens rather than the old-fashioned PC.

fields.headline: The poverty gap
fields.standfirst: The reputation of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, has been tarnished by new official figures which show that the poverty gap in Britain is widening and criticism from the International Monetary Fund, which says that his latest budget could stoke inflation. Derek Brown explains
fields.trailText: The reputation of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, has been tarnished by new official figures, which show that the poverty gap in Britain is widening, and criticism from the International Monetary Fund, which says that his latest budget could stoke inflation.
fields.body:
What is the poverty gap, and why is it widening?
The rich are getting richer and the poor are getting poorer. The best-off people in Britain are taking their biggest share of national income since 1988, when inequality peaked at the height of the Thatcher boom.

Who says so?
The Office for National Statistics. It says that in the financial year 1998-99, the top 10% of households had a gross average income of £65,500. That is 31 times the income of the bottom 10%, who had an income of just £2,100.

Don't taxes and benefits iron out the difference?
Partly. After taxes and benefits are taken into account, the ratio between the top and bottom tenths falls to 6:1. That represents an average household income of £44,800 for the richest, compared with just under £8,000 for the poorest.

So Labour policies are working to reduce inequality?
Embarrassingly for the government, no. The new figures show that even after taxes and benefits are taken into account, the top 20% of earners are scoffing 45% of the national income cake - up 2% since Labour took office. At the same time, the lowest-earning 20% saw their share dwindle from 7% to 6%. In 1978, the last full year of the last Labour government, the poorest 20% had 10% of national income.

How has the government responded?
The Treasury says that the latest figures are already out of date, and do not take into account the chancellor's favourite innovations, such as the working families tax credit, the minimum wage, the new 10% income tax band and the cut in the basic rate to 22%.

So ministers are not worried?
Behind the dry metallic sound of clashing statistics, there is rising concern - some commentators say incipient panic - about the impact of such figures on the party's support in Labour's traditional heartlands.

What about the seats which Labour captured from the Tories in the 1997 general election?
Voters in those marginal constituencies may be less concerned about the poverty gap than about the latest criticism from the IMF. Senior officials rebuked the chancellor yesterday for stoking inflationary pressure and risking higher exchange and interest rates with the higher spending figures in his latest Budget.

Is that embarrassing for Mr Brown?
Highly. He has staked his reputation - and a possible future bid for Number 10 - on rigorous fiscal prudence. The Treasury is said to be seething with fury about the IMF comments.

fields.headline: Eating his own words
fields.trailText: To conclude his address at cricket awards dinner in 1998, the speaker chose to recite the poem that had given him especial inspiration. He declaimed it in impressive style, the lines learnt off by heart, delivered from the heart.
fields.body:
To conclude his address at cricket awards dinner in 1998, the speaker chose to recite the poem that had given him especial inspiration. He declaimed it in impressive style, the lines learnt off by heart, delivered from the heart.

Hansie Cronje's choice of poem was hardly original, but Kipling's "If" has, for all its praise and vilification in roughly equal measure, guided tens of thousands. Somehow, the poem - which lays down conditions for the transition of an ordinary individual to revered Manhood - was dead right for Cronje: a straightforward, honest, upright poem for a straightforward, honest, upright Man, revered by almost all the cricketing world.

It might stick in the craw for others to speak of their personal philosophy, but here was a cricketer who apparently abided by his espoused principles.

Reflecting on the poem in the sickly light cast by recent events is now an uncomfortable business. In the first verse, Kipling sends down one of many challenging deliveries: "If you can wait but not be tired by waiting, Or being lied about, don't deal in lies..." Middle stump, Hansie, given those hasty early denials.

A couple of lines later: "If you can dream - and not make dreams your master..." By accepting a first downpayment of $10,000-15,000, Cronje had surely made his judgement subservient to fantasies of greater rewards. And in the last verse: "If you can talk with crowds and keep your virtue..." Cronje could - he was good with the media - but just how virtuous was he?

But it is a sequence in the middle of the poem that is particularly telling: "If you can... watch the things you gave your life to, broken, And stoop and build 'em up with worn-out tools..." Should Cronje, who has arguably done more to break the game than any other individual, be allowed to build it up? Should he continue to play a role in cricket?

A sense of justice says he should not. Though he himself never made claim to be especially honourable, he was universally seen as such. And when such people fall, they fall further, causing greater harm to those around them. The damage the Cronje affair has done is so great that it seems wrong that the perpetrator should ever profit again from the game.

And yet it is another Cronje - Cronje the good guy - that is desperately needed if the game is to be built up again. He had a golden touch with people, young and old. As Wisden reported in 1996, after Cronje's season at Leicestershire: "even an old hand like [James] Whitaker found inspiration in him."

Cricket has lost twice over.

Hugh Chevallier is managing editor of Wisden Cricketers' Almanack

fields.headline: Wedding site woos M&S executives
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Two more senior Marks & Spencers executives have quit the high street and moved into online retailing.
fields.body:
Two more senior Marks & Spencers executives have quit the high street and moved into online retailing.

James Benfield, a highly-rated former marketing director, and Peter Marsh, who oversaw the latest revamp of M&S's lingerie business, have joined wedding website Confetti.co.uk.

The moves come two weeks after Nigel Robertson and Roger Whiteside, quit as heads of M&S's food division to join online grocer LM Solutions. Their departures coincided with the appointment of former finance director Christopher Littmoden, as chief operating officer of Freecom.net.

Mr Benfield, 50, had spent 30 years at M&S before being ousted at the end of last year. He was responsible for developing M&S's e-commerce and customer relations strategies. He becomes executive chairman of Confetti.

Mr Marsh, who revamped M&S's crucial lingerie division by bringing in Agent Provocateur to spice up the retailer's staid image, will be commercial director.

Andrew Doe, Confetti's chief executive, said: "James and Peter will further strengthen our existing team." The company recently raised $12m of new finance.

M&S itself recently invested in online lingerie company Splendour.com.
