fields.headline: Not just a pretty page
fields.standfirst: If companies want the public to do business with them online, they have to produce websites that do more than look flashy.  Jane Dudman talks to four design gurus
fields.trailText: If companies want the public to do business with them online, they have to produce websites that do more than look flashy. Jane Dudman talks to four design gurus
fields.body:
Usability expert Jakob Nielsen has a precise way to measure how the web has made companies take good design seriously: money.

When Guardian Online interviewed him in December, he was charging companies $10,000 a day to tell them what was wrong with their web sites. Now, he charges $20,000 a day.

The explanation for this exponential rise in interest is simple. If e-commerce is to work, web sites have to be easy to use. That's a common-sense message, but the path to online selling is littered with abandoned virtual shopping trolleys.

And Nielsen has a warning for those who still scorn his lean, mean approach to web design. He has formulated his own version of Moore's Law, the theory first articulated by the founder of Intel, which says the power of computers doubles every 18 months.

"Nielsen's law says user bandwidth goes up 50% a year," he explains. "By this reckoning, it will be at least five years before a standard web page responds at less than a second, which is what most people find pleasant to use."

Web design is big business. Dot.coms are realising that to turn browsers into shoppers, they have to make the customers' progress from front page to checkout as painless as possible.

But what are the big secrets? Earlier this month, Online sat down with four of the world's foremost net design gurus, who had gathered in London for the Design For Usability conference.

Their CVs are impressive. Jakob Nielsen is behind the Alertbox website which reviews web design. He worked at Bell Research Labs and Sun Microsystems and co-founded the Nielsen Norman group.

His consultancy partner is Don Norman (see www.jnd.org), the ex-Apple usability expert who wrote the book The Design of Everyday Things.

Professor Ben Shneiderman, is head of the University of Maryland's Human-Computer Interaction Laboratory and was one of the earliest pro ponents of hypertext linking. Brenda Laurel specialises in the cultural contexts in which websites are used, and helped Purple Moon produce a range of computer games for girls.

Online: Usability matters?

Ben: I'm banging on the desk saying it's time to get angry about the quality of user interfaces. As people become more dependent on this technology, their expectations have risen and I do not think the manufacturers have met that challenge.

Jakob: Our field is now attracting so much attention. But there is still a need to communicate to people that it is not their fault when things are difficult.

Ben: In practical environments, it is still a struggle to get companies to address this respectfully.

Brenda: When you work with web design companies in San Francisco, you end up with a bunch of twenty-somethings who have their own cultural peculiarities, including obscurity for its own sake. You give those guys a website for a banking institution and they screw it up, because they are designing for themselves.

Ben: You'll find the same thing anywhere: Silicon Valley, London.

Jakob: It is their job to create interesting websites and they get all too enthusiastic about that, as opposed to just the plain and simple thing that the customer wants to do. Customers only want to be in this website for one minute, not 20.

Brenda: I often get calls from people saying: "I need to be first to market, I launch in three weeks, is this site usable?" That is the rule, not the exception. And what do I say to them? I say: "Write me a cheque; I won't be taking stock."

Don: I agree. If I'm frustrated [on a website], I go to a competitor. Then it's much easier to make the usability argument because companies really are sensitive to it. United Airlines, Schwab, a whole bunch of companies, you can see them improve week by week.

Ben: United was my "bad guy" example for years. They had this globe of the world with eight obscure buttons that went nowhere. Now there are 65 or 70 links on that front page.

Brenda: Except you still can't get refunds online.

Don: Well, that's a different issue. But it's a very important one, because to get a website to work, you also have to get the backend of the company to work right. That is where we have to work hard, because what we're really arguing for is the end experience the user has. But people often think what we're doing is merely making the screen easy to read.

Online: But it's not the only factor?

Don: Jakob strongly criticises websites that are not lean and mean. That's very laudable but not necessarily appropriate for all websites. I say usability is always secondary. You go to get something done; you want the usability simply not to get in the way.

Brenda: Audiences are diverse and we need to understand their lives and their cultural context. So if I were doing a site around personal finance, for example, for women I might want to organise it around life issues like aging parents or children, whereas it is more likely that a man is going to be an aficionado of investment as a mastery issue, as a game.

Ben: Men are more risktaking and women risk-averse in those kinds of situations?

Brenda: Sure. That doesn't mean the whole site is going to be that way, because it could have exactly the same functionality, but coming at it through a different set of concerns and processes.

Don: I suspect I might often prefer the female website. The point is that I don't appreciate it being labelled male or female.

Ben: Let me give you an example of how subtle these differences are. The [US] National Cancer Institute has a site where at the top you choose doctor or patient and learn about all these various cancers.

The patient descriptions are very thorough, they're serious stuff; and the doctor side has reference to the literature, particular medications, dosages and so on. That sounds like a good differentiation, but what happens is that after the more knowledgeable patients have read their page, they want to see what's on the doctor's page. And the doctor wants to see what their patients are getting.

So the new redesign starts with the cancer descriptions. Then you choose patient or health professional, but you can easily go and see both. Let the user choose. Make it easy for the users to get what they want. Don't make images and mystical machines that magically figure out how users are going to behave and what they should have. Give users control. Controllable, predictable, comprehensible, that's my mantra.

Online: Are talking webpages and voice recognition the answer?

Jakob: It's the Star Trek fallacy. Voice is a great user interface to show on a TV show. However, in the real world, voice has a lot of downsides as a user interface because it is, by definition, not visible.

Ben: Exactly. Why use something that is slower and more error-prone than a visual interface? Let's not undermine the great efforts that have gone into this technology. It works remarkably well. It's just not very useful.

The airforce has spent 30 years and several billion dollars trying to make voice interaction work so why doesn't it work? Because when you're pulling 6Gs and you say "Fire" and it says "please repeat", you're not gonna use this thing ever again. Literally.

Jakob: That is the cute answer. What is the real answer?

Ben: The deep answer is that the cognitive load of voice interfaces is greater than hand/eye co-ordination. Speaking requires your short-term memory, whereas hand/eye co-ordination is parallel processed in other parts of your brain.

Jakob: We have to design from the reality not from what makes the best demos. Three-dimensional fly-throughs on the internet also make really good demos. But the more three-dimensional it is, the more you get lost. The general point being that any technology like 3D or voice is neither completely useless nor the solution to all our interface problems.

webTitle: Jury retires in Kenneth Noye motorway killing case

fields.headline: Jury retires in Kenneth Noye motorway killing case
fields.trailText:
The Old Bailey jury trying motorway killer Kenneth Noye retired today to consider its verdict. 
Mr Noye, 52, from Sevenoaks, Kent, has denied murdering Stephen Cameron during a road rage
incident on the M25 Swanley interchange on May 19, 1996.
fields.body:
The Old Bailey jury trying motorway killer Kenneth Noye retired today to consider its verdict. Mr Noye, 52, from Sevenoaks, Kent, has denied murdering Stephen Cameron during a road rage incident on the M25 Swanley interchange on May 19, 1996.

Prosecution allege he stabbed the 21-year-old in anger "and maybe pride" when he found he was not winning in the fight. Mr Cameron, from Swanley, Kent, was stabbed in the heart and liver.

Before he sent the jury out, Lord Justice Latham told them that the core of the case was the question of self-defence.

"Might Mr Noye have been acting in self-defence when he used the knife?

"Or do you think when he got out the knife it was to confront Stephen Cameron or even up the odds so he did not leave the scene a beaten man?

"But even if you conclude he may have believed he needed to defend himself, you still have to consider the very important question of whether the use of the knife was really out of all proportion to the incident."

The judge warned the jury that the alternative verdict of manslaughter was "not there as some easy, simple way of coming to a compromise if there are different views among you.

"You can only bring in a verdict of manslaughter if you are genuinely satisfied there was unlawful violence but that there was not the requisite intent - or that he was provoked."

webTitle: Robert Flaherty: Nanook of the North

fields.headline: Robert Flaherty: Nanook of the North
fields.trailText: When released, it got rave reviews and no one called it a documentary. It simply seemed to be in a class by itself. It still is. Flaherty was never again to achieve such lack of self-consciousness and purity of style
fields.body:
We have become so accustomed to television documentaries in which someone famous travels to a distant part of the world to view its inhabitants in their natural state that we have quite forgotten where it all originated. One of the fountainheads was Robert Flaherty, an American from Michigan who was as much the great Victorian romantic as any Englishman born in the late-19th century.

Flaherty was a pioneer of the documentary, and one of those whose work sparked many of the continuing arguments about truth and falsehood within the genre. His style is now often patronised as naïve and schematic. But if you look at Nanook of the North you can see where so much else has come from.

The filming of an Eskimo community took place over almost two years on the eastern shore of Hudson Bay, and Flaherty's goal was complete authenticity. He wielded his gyroscope camera himself, carrying into his harsh surroundings enough equipment to process and develop the film and show it to the Eskimos. Nanook and his family were real, but the film is not a straightforward recording of their everyday life: they amiably enacted some of it for Flaherty's cameras. But so honest and instinctive was their playing that it was undoubtedly truth of a sort.

The background comes to the fore, photographed in black and white with consummate dramatic skill. Though the film has no conventional plot, it tells a coherent story through its extraordinary images. It hints at that old cliche about the noble savage being pushed towards a civilisation that will destroy him. But it does so with a rare feeling for a timeless landscape and a way of life that had remained unchanged for centuries.

The building of the igloo is perhaps the most famous and fascinating episode. It is taken step by step, without the explanation that might render it more mundane today, though the way translucent blocks of ice are used as windows could hardly seem humdrum in any hands. But again Flaherty "cheated", since he had an igloo constructed to twice the normal size, with half of it cut away to provide more light for his camera.

When the film was released, it got rave reviews and no one called it a documentary. It simply seemed to be in a class by itself. It still is. Flaherty was never again to achieve such lack of self-consciousness and purity of style, though films like Moana, about the Samoan lifestyle, Man of Aran and Louisiana Story contained extraordinary sequences.

Flaherty had what was once called "an innocent eye", which tried to discover "the elemental truths that all men share". He was patrician, eccentric, obdurate and had the eye of a painter - the attributes of many good film-makers. He believed that if Eskimos could tame nature, then the rest of us could tame our more advanced civilisation. Perversely, Nanook of the North was made for a fur-trading firm. Perversely also, it was Nanook rather than the film-maker who became an instant celebrity.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Lacking in liaison

A number of readers have been threatened with legal action for sums they don't owe. Ewan Deas of Wrexham paid by direct debit to telecoms company Euphony until he lost his credit card. Other direct debits were automatically transferred to his new card, but not Euphony's. He received two letters asking him to pay up within a week, but the following day found his service had been suspended. Over the next two months, he sent his new card details to the company four times and filled in two mandates. The only result was a letter warning that his service would be suspended (which it already had been), then a notice of legal proceedings from a debt collection agency which accused him of "ignoring all our attempts to resolve this debt". But when his credit card bill arrived Deas found Euphony had helped itself to the outstanding sum 11 days before the debt collectors wrote to him - in fact, it had debited it twice, refunding one payment four days later.

"You'll have to write in," says Liz ("we're not allowed to give out surnames") from Euphony. Consumer complies and learns that Deas's service was terminated prematurely "due to a manual termination requested following information received from his credit card company". Euphony says his account was automatically transferred to the debt collection agency while his payment was processed, and the agency sent two threatening letters before Euphony discovered the mistake. It promises liaison between the finance department and collection agency will be "upgraded" and apologises for its "less than acceptable" service.

British Gas blunder

K. Newport of Devon is the second reader in a month to be threatened with court over a British Gas bill she didn't owe. In June 1996 she moved out of rented accommodation and settled a final bill with British Gas. In April 1997 she was told she owed £184.96 for gas used at the property. She sent evidence to prove she was paid-up and no longer lived there. Last November, she received a letter from a debt collection agency stating she owed £299.19, and a month later she was told court proceedings were being started. Last month, British Gas told her two of the outstanding payments had been paid - by the tenant who succeeded her - but legal proceedings could not be stopped.

 British Gas blames its computers. "At the time [Mrs Newport] vacated the property, we were implementing a new billing system and it is possible the details of [her] change in tenancy were not updated." One glance at the records at Consumer's request establishes Newport owes nothing and court action is being halted.

The Eye with no vision

Wendy Varley was meanwhile empathising with the reader who tried to book tickets on the London Eye. Varley spent 10 minutes on the automated ticket line. A recorded voice said tickets couldn't be posted and advised her to collect them five days later. No reference number was given. She arrived eight days later to be told there was a week's delay and no, she couldn't cancel and buy tickets there and then. Two weeks later her payment still hadn't gone through and she was unable to speak to a human on the automated line. "If phone bookings are taking two weeks to process, presumably people are turning up on the day of their ride unable to collect tickets and with no proof that they've booked."

 British Airways which runs the wheel says it has doubled the number of phone lines to cope with demand and is looking at "other distribution methods".

 Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 0171-713 4731, send a fax on 0171-239 9933, or email us at consumer@theguardian.com.

fields.headline: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Star Wars to be shot on digital; Vinnie Jones quits the UK; Spike Jonze seeks cameo in Hannibal; Ron Howard may direct next Cruise movie; Clare Kilner to helm adolescent spy film
fields.body:
 Always one to keep up to speed with new technology, George Lucas has announced that the next Star Wars picture will be shot on digital. When production gets underway in Australia this June, the film supremo plans to shoot the majority of the story's live action portions on a series of six high-definition camcorders. The benefits of digital production are obvious: keener sound, cleaner picture, easy to edit. But many feel that digital is an inherently colder and less enticing medium than good old-fashioned celluloid. After testing the new camcorders, Lucas begs to differ. "The tests have convinced me that the familiar look and feel of motion picture film are fully present in the digital 24p system," he claims. "The picture quality between the two is indistinguishable on the large screen."

 Vinnie Jones is quitting England for a home in the Hollywood hills. According to the Sun, the former soccer hardman will up-sticks to an $8,000-a-month Beverly Hills mansion next door to a home owned by tennis star Pete Sampras. Jones, 35, won decent reviews for his role in Guy Ritchie's hit picture Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels and is currently acting in Snatch, co-starring Brad Pitt and also directed by Ritchie. His move Stateside signals an attempt to break big in Hollywood.

Casting couch

 Spike Jonze may have bagged a cameo in the Silence of the Lambs sequel, according to whispered gossip on the US website Dark Horizons. Rumour has it that the Being John Malkovich director has been spotted in conversation with Hannibal director Ridley Scott at Paramount studios and that the film's makers are hastily trying to find a part for him. Jonze, who co-starred in the acclaimed war flick Three Kings, is currently developing Benjamin Button, his second film as a director.

 Ron Howard is in final negotiations to direct the Universal drama A Beautiful Mind, with Tom Cruise likely to star. The film will be based on Sylvia Nassar's book about John Forbes Nash Jr, a Pulitzer-Prize winning maths genius who was also a paranoid schizophrenic. In fact, Forbes was also homosexual: an element acknowledged in the book but apparently airbrushed out in Akiva Goldsman's screenplay, which even shoe-horns in a female love-interest. Ron Howard (the Happy Days graduate who went on to become one of America's most bankable directors) has just completed work on How the Grinch Stole Christmas, starring Jim Carrey.

 The MTV films division of Paramount Pictures has snapped up British director Clare Kilner to helm an American-set comedy Spy Girl, about a perky adolescent trained in espionage by her CIA-agent dad. Kilner cut her teeth directing episodes of EastEnders. Her debut picture, Janice Beard 45wpm, is released in the UK next month.
fields.bodyText:  Always one to keep up to speed with new technology, George Lucas has announced that the next Star Wars picture will be shot on digital. When production gets underway in Australia this June, the film supremo plans to shoot the majority of the story's live action portions on a series of six high-definition camcorders. The benefits of digital production are obvious: keener sound, cleaner picture, easy to edit. But many feel that digital is an inherently colder and less enticing medium than good old-fashioned celluloid. After testing the new camcorders, Lucas begs to differ. "The tests have convinced me that the familiar look and feel of motion picture film are fully present in the digital 24p system," he claims. "The picture quality between the two is indistinguishable on the large screen."  Vinnie Jones is quitting England for a home in the Hollywood hills. According to the Sun, the former soccer hardman will up-sticks to an $8,000-a-month Beverly Hills mansion next door to a home owned by tennis star Pete Sampras. Jones, 35, won decent reviews for his role in Guy Ritchie's hit picture Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels and is currently acting in Snatch, co-starring Brad Pitt and also directed by Ritchie. His move Stateside signals an attempt to break big in Hollywood. Casting couch  Spike Jonze may have bagged a cameo in the Silence of the Lambs sequel, according to whispered gossip on the US website Dark Horizons. Rumour has it that the Being John Malkovich director has been spotted in conversation with Hannibal director Ridley Scott at Paramount studios and that the film's makers are hastily trying to find a part for him. Jonze, who co-starred in the acclaimed war flick Three Kings, is currently developing Benjamin Button, his second film as a director.  Ron Howard is in final negotiations to direct the Universal drama A Beautiful Mind, with Tom Cruise likely to star. The film will be based on Sylvia Nassar's book about John Forbes Nash Jr, a Pulitzer-Prize winning maths genius who was also a paranoid schizophrenic. In fact, Forbes was also homosexual: an element acknowledged in the book but apparently airbrushed out in Akiva Goldsman's screenplay, which even shoe-horns in a female love-interest. fields.trailText: The Mirror
fields.body:
The Mirror

Robbie Fowler and Steve McManaman could be on their way to Elland Road this summer. David O'Leary has long been an admirer of Fowler - and believes that now Emile Heskey has joined Liverpool, Gerald Houllier might sell him. O'Leary is also believed to have watched McManaman on Wednesday evening in Real's Copa del Ray clash with Espanyol - and hopes that if he can persuade Fowler to join Leeds, his old mate McManaman could be tempted to follow.

Manchester United have placed Marseille's brilliant young play-maker Stephane Dalmat on their summer shopping list. The 21 year-old will cost £7m - but United face stiff competition from Leeds and Inter Milan.

Daily Mail

Gerald Houiller has resisted a £3m bid for Titi Camara from Rangers, and is insisting the striker is not for sale. Houllier said: "I have told him that his place is here with us at Anfield. I don't care if other clubs fancy him, he is staying at Liverpool."

Sir Alex Ferguson is assessing the form of another goalkeeper - this time it's Borussia Dortmund's Jens Lehmann. Apparently Ferguson watched the 30 year-old keeper in action earlier this month, and could make a £3m bid this summer.

The Sun

George Graham is lining up a bid for Wimbledon's Ben Thatcher. The left-back will leave Selhurst Park this summer if Spurs meet the £5m asking price.

fields.headline: Cricket for comrades
fields.trailText: Ian Aitken In the light of events, it seems much more likely that the Russian mafia would be running world cricket by now - hardly an improvement on Mr Cronje's Indian bookies.
fields.body:
Brooding on the state of world cricket in the dismal light of the Cronje affair, and contemplating where the greatest of all games can go now, a memory of my long-dead father came unexpectedly to mind. Once a professional revolutionary as well as a Marxist scholar, he was also a very Scottish Scot, so he hardly fitted the traditional image of a flannelled fool.

Yet he loved the game with no less passion than any of the straw-hatted chumps who parade their MCC ties in the pavilion at Lord's. Thanks to a war wound which removed two fingers from his right hand, he had to abandon a promising career as a fast-medium bowler. But his enthusiasm was such that he managed to develop a weird spinning action with the stumps of his missing fingers. The jagged bits of bone which stuck out seemed to give him extra purchase on the ball, so that he could turn it like an early version of Shane Warne. Or so my memory fondly tells me.

Such was his belief in cricket as a civilising influence that he - with me in faithful tow - set out towards the end of the second world war to teach the complexities of the game to Italian PoWs lodging in an open camp on Royston Heath, Hertfordshire. These bemused but utterly delightful young Latins would try desperately to follow his instructions as he carefully placed his field before bowling his crafty fizzers at me.

In fact, he had surprising success with several of the "prisoners". Most of them learned to catch the ball quite competently, and a few managed to throw it fairly straight. One or two even mastered the elements of batsmanship, although none really got the hang of the odd business of bowling the ball rather than chucking it - a difficulty they share with some world-renowned players today.

With steady progress being made, my father had begun to think about forming a team of what the locals called, with genuine affection, "our Eye-ties". He had visions of arranging fixtures with the local RAF station and (wildest of his ambitions) the nearby USAF base. But it was not to be. One night, shortly after D-day, the Italians were bussed out of Royston, to be replaced by a long column of dejected Germans. The camp gates clanged shut again, and the fun was over.

My father often wondered what might have happened if he had had a bit longer to complete his course of instruction with the Italians. He liked to think that they might have gone home and spread the gospel of leather and willow among their sun-kissed villages. And who knows, but for those Germans they might by now be playing World Cup cricket, just as they do in the Six Nations Rugby Championship.

Disappointments of this sort were not new to my ever-optimistic father. As I have said, he was a professional revolutionary, and he learned his rather specialised trade at the Marx-Engels Institute in Moscow, dubbed by the tabloids as the "school for spies". Early in his stay, he noticed that some of the American students were trying to teach baseball to their Russian hosts. This acted like... well, like a red rag to a bull. For my father thought baseball was little better than a girls' game played with a hard ball. The revolution, he decided, deserved better - ie cricket.

Being a man of action, he sent home to Communist party headquarters in Covent Garden to request an urgent shipment of cricket balls, bats, pads and gloves, plus six stumps and four bails. Goodness knows what the stern apparatchiks of King Street thought of this bizarre request, but - amazingly - they did as they were asked. So a large parcel was dispatched to Moscow, to be delivered eventually to my father by a clearly puzzled policeman.

On opening the parcel, my father found everything he had asked for. But there was just one snag. The balls had been slit open, the pads and gloves had been emptied of their stuffing, the stumps and bats had been sawn in half. Clearly, the ever suspicious NKVD imagined that these strange artifacts might be the tools of counter-revolution.

So ended my father's first attempt at being one of the world's few Marxist ambassadors of cricket - in failure, just like his Italian enterprise was to be 20 years later. But the mind boggles at what might have happened if he had succeeded in Moscow. He liked to imagine that it might have had a civilising influence on the Stalinists. In the light of events, it seems much more likely that the Russian mafia would be running world cricket by now - hardly an improvement on Mr Cronje's Indian bookies.

webTitle: Britain's Olympic success, and six and out

fields.headline: Britain's Olympic success, and six and out
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing queries? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Who won the gold and silver medals for cricket at the 1900 Olympic Games? asks Mark from Harrogate
fields.body:
Who won the gold and silver medals for cricket at the 1900 Olympic Games? asks Mark from Harrogate

Great Britain, represented by a team called the Devon and Somerset County Wanderers, beat "France" (a combined XI from the Albion and Standard Athletic clubs, and mostly English expatriates) in the one and only Olympic final, played in Vincennes, near Paris, in August 1900. That means that Britain are the reigning Olympic cricket champions! The British team batted first and made 117 (FW Cuming 38) and 145 (A Bowerman 59, CBK Beachcroft 54): France only managed 78 and 26 (Montague Toller 7-10). The International Olympic Committee has only skimpy details of most of the players in the match, and would appreciate any biographical details of those involved.

If the batsman hooks the ball for four (or six) but loses his balance and falls on his wicket, what would the result be? asks Imran Farooq from Lahore

The result would be that the batsman would be out, hit wicket. It happened to Roy Fredericks, the West Indian opener, in the first World Cup final at Lord's in 1975. He played a magnificent hook shot to Dennis Lillee, but his foot slipped and he broke the stumps. Fredericks was out, even though the ball sailed out of the ground.

Can you give me any stats for Billy Ibadulla of Pakistan? asks Pete Ingham

Khalid "Billy" Ibadulla was a useful allrounder who played for Warwickshire from 1954 to 1972. He also played and coached in Lahore (Pakistan), Tasmania (Australia) and Otago (New Zealand), and later became a first-class umpire. He made a dramatic Test debut, scoring 166 for Pakistan v Australia at Karachi in 1964-65 and putting on 249 for the first wicket with another debutant, Abdul Kadir (a wicketkeeper, not the legspinner with a similar name). He also played in the Tests in England in 1967, but probably because he was based here that was the extent of his Test career: four matches, 253 runs at 31.62, and one wicket. In 4216 first-class matches he scored 17,039 runs at 27.30, with 22 centuries, and took 462 wickets at 30.87.

Who returned the best bowling figures for England in one-day internationals during the recent tour of South Africa? asks Phil Lawrence

It was Mark Ealham, who took 5 for 15 against Zimbabwe at Kimberley in the fifth match of the recent one-day tournament. All his victims were lbw, which is an overall ODI record.

My partner has been given a small bat commemorating MCC's tour of East Africa in 1959. I can't make out all the names, but I can recognise Freddie Brown, Jack Bailey, Charles Robins and Billy Griffith. Who were the other players, and what happened on the tour? asks Mike Taylor

It is an MCC tour of East Africa, but it was in the winter of 1957-58, not 1959 (MCC did make a tour in 1959, but it was to North America, not East Africa - and of the players you mention only Bailey went on that trip). The full team was FR Brown (captain), SC Griffith (player/manager), JA Bailey, GW Cook, GHG Doggart, ACD Ingleby-Mackenzie, CJM Kenny, PE Richardson, RVC Robins, DRW Silk, MJK Smith, JJ Warr and WR Watkins. They played five two-day matches and four one-day games. In all they won three, lost one and drew five. Two centuries were scored - by Peter Richardson and Hubert Doggart, both Test players.

How do the flipper and the zooter work? asks Chulaka Perera

We've been asked this before, but it was a long time ago, so here goes again. The flipper is a difficult-to-bowl delivery which is squeezed out under the wrist, with an action rather like that used to click the fingers. When it's bowled properly, the ball hurries on to the batsman, who can be beaten by the unexpected pace. Shane Warne has often dismissed Daryll Cullinan with this ball. Warne claims to have invented the 'zooter', so we asked Mark Ray, the Australian journalist who helped write Warne's autobiography, how you bowl it. He said: "It's difficult to explain without drawings ... but basically the zooter comes out of the front of the hand, with the fingers running across it sideways, like a legbreak - but the ball is propelled more by the palm. It's not unlike a knuckle ball, but not as slow. The zooter does very little in the air or off the pitch - which is part of the point. It's not flatter like the flipper, which is under-spun - the zooter sort of wobbles down." So now we know!

Who was Sonny Ramadhin's famous bowling partner in cricket and a calypso? asks Jane Herford

The calypso, which celebrated West Indies' first Test win in England (at Lord's in 1950) spoke of "Those two little pals of mine, Ramadhin and Valentine." Alf Valentine was a left-arm spinner who, like Ramadhin, had played only two first-class matches before the tour started. Both were surprise selections - but they dominated the tour. In the four Tests Valentine took 33 wickets and Ramadhin 26, and in the tour overall Valentine claimed 123 first-class wickets and Ramadhin 135. In the new (May) edition of "Wisden Cricket Monthly" there is a long article by Frank Keating looking back on that 1950 tour, containing a fabulous photograph of Valentine which I had never seen before.

Where can you find cricket stats on the net? asks Alan

You can find updated records elsewhere on this site (www.wisden.com). Cricinfo (www.cricket.org) has an extensive archive of records and past scorecards, while the Indian site www.khel.com has a handy feature where you can work out combinations of statistics for players against particular countries or between certain dates. There are lots of other cricket internet sites as well: just search for "cricket" and see what happens!

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: Drink 'was not the cause' of writer's death

fields.headline: Drink 'was not the cause' of writer's death
fields.standfirst: Books unlimited
fields.trailText: Eugene O'Neill, the Nobel prize-winning American dramatist, did not have Parkinson's disease brought on by heavy drinking in the final years of his life as many have assumed. He suffered instead from an unusual neurological disease that left his mind intact while slowly destroying his ability to write, walk, and eventually talk.
fields.body:
Eugene O'Neill, the Nobel prize-winning American dramatist, did not have Parkinson's disease brought on by heavy drinking in the final years of his life as many have assumed. He suffered instead from an unusual neurological disease that left his mind intact while slowly destroying his ability to write, walk, and eventually talk.

The truth about O'Neill's decline has been revealed nearly half a century after his death, in 1953, by two doctors who conducted an autopsy at the request of the writer's wife. Carlotta O'Neill asked them to do it, she said afterwards, "because I wanted to know what in the name of God was the matter with this man I had nursed so long".

At the time, the family asked for confidentiality. Recently, O'Neill's grandchildren gave permission to the doctors to reveal what they found, which they have done in the New England Journal of Medicine.

When O'Neill, author of Long Day's Journey Into Night, was 15, he and his older brother Jamie began drinking, smoking and frequenting brothels in New York, where Eugene contracted syphilis, although he was treated and did not relapse.

But he did not throw off alcohol so easily. From 1910-12, when he was in his early 20s, he became a "tormented, drunken drop-out from his first year at Princeton", who drank heavily and socialised only with sailors and down and outs, say Bruce Price and EP Richardson, the Massachusetts-based doctors who did the autopsy and researched the writer's medical history.

He pulled himself out of his despair and set himself to become a playwright. He suffered "numerous depressive episodes", often in conjunction with completion of a play or its production, which might have coexisted with binge drinking leading to blackouts.

But in the last 25 years of his life he did not drink to excess and in the last eight he did not touch alcohol.

In May 1941, he first noted in his diary that he was having trouble controlling a pencil while writing. He was soon diagnosed with Parkinson's disease. From 1942, he mentioned Parkinson's increasingly in his diaries. By May 1943, he had been forced to stop writing diaries because of the uncontrollable shaking of his hands.

Many forms of treatment were tried without benefit. "The combination of bromide and chloral hydrate at times induced delirium, with disorientation, hallucinations and agitation," the authors write. O'Neill was given daily barbiturates for anxiety.

The immediate cause of death was pneumonia, but the autopsy revealed no evidence of Parkinson's disease.

Although chronic alcoholism can cause such changes in the brain, say the doctors, they do not think O'Neill's drinking was to blame.

From 1942, he mentioned Parkinson's increasingly in his diaries. By May 1943, he had been forced to stop writing diaries because of the uncontrollable shaking of his hands. Many forms of treatment were tried without benefit. "The combination of bromide and chloral hydrate at times induced delirium, with disorientation, hallucinations and agitation," the authors write. O'Neill was given daily barbiturates for anxiety. The immediate cause of death was pneumonia, but the autopsy revealed no evidence of Parkinson's disease. Although chronic alcoholism can cause such changes in the brain, say the doctors, they do not think O'Neill's drinking was to blame.

webTitle: O'Leary spoils the effect for under-siege Leeds

fields.headline: O'Leary spoils the effect for under-siege Leeds
fields.standfirst: The Leeds boss has fashioned an attractive team, but his interview techniques are less beguiling.
fields.trailText: The Leeds boss has fashioned an attractive team, but his interview techniques are less beguiling.
fields.body:
It might seem unkind to kick a man when he's as down as David O'Leary is, but here goes anyway.

O'Leary has garnered a lot of praise this season for the way his Leeds team has played, at least until the end of February. For many commentators, the fact that they are mostly young, mostly English and not Manchester United makes them all the more attractive as potential title contenders.

But as the results and the off-field events have gone against him, O'Leary has begun to spoil the effect. Possibly as a result of watching too much Gordon Strachan and Martin O'Neill on television, he has cultivated an exaggerated sarcasm directed at the "experts", who purport to know the game better than he does.

As far back as the opening day of the season, after a 0-0 draw with Derby, O'Leary commented: "The television experts have said to me, 'you must know you need a striker'. Believe me, I am only the manager and I know I need a striker."

"The experts are never wrong," he added, in case anyone had missed the point, when Alan Smith scored the winner against Sheffield Wednesday in October, after Leeds fans had called for him to be substituted.

O'Leary warmed to the theme again after his team beat Southampton in November. "I'm only the manager, so what do I know?" he said. "It is a sad trait of the British character that some 'experts' want to build us up and then knock us down." (They do things differently in Ireland apparently.)

In the past few months, O'Leary has had to cope with more serious business than the alleged failings of his forward line, namely the fact that several of his players are facing serious criminal charges, and then the deaths of two Leeds fans in Istanbul.

While disdain for outside comment on the affairs of the club may be fair enough (if tiresome when carried to extremes), it fits less well when the issues involved concern serious injury and death. O'Leary's comment that the assault charges had been "blown up out of all proportion" was particularly crass considering the racial sensitivities of the case.

But perhaps even more unedifying was his response in an interview on Match of the Day to the dismal events in Istanbul. After the 1-0 defeat at Aston Villa, O'Leary was again at pains to castigate the "experts" for expressing their opinions on the implications for the tie with Galatasaray.

"Lots of experts and some people who haven't got a clue have had plenty to say," he said. "I'm only the manager and I was only there so it would be wrong for me to say, because all the experts are coming out and having great opinions."

The gist seems to be that it is none of anyone else's business. O'Leary may well believe that people involved in the game are the only ones who can have a worthwhile opinion about football. It's rubbish, of course, but it's pretty harmless rubbish.

What is truly damaging is the idea that events such as those in a Leeds nightclub and the streets of Istanbul are not the legitimate subject of comment from outsiders. If O'Leary is beginning to feel he is under siege, his own tendency to pull up the drawbridge at the first sign of trouble is surely partly responsible.

webTitle: American Psycho soundtrack in hot water

fields.headline: American Psycho soundtrack in hot water
fields.trailText: Forget the furore surrounding American Psycho, the movie (that was so last month). The latest controversy concerns the film's soundtrack album, which has been yanked from retailers just a day before it was due to go onto the shelves
fields.body:
Forget the furore surrounding American Psycho, the movie. The latest controversy concerns the film's soundtrack album, which has been yanked from retailers just a day before it was due to go onto the shelves. The cause of this untimely withdrawal? Step forward Mr Huey Lewis, who has objected to the inclusion in the album of one of his better known songs.

The eponymous American psycho, it transpires, is a big fan of Huey Lewis and the News, a synthetic AOR combo who flourished for a time in the mid 1980s, and one of the key scenes in the movie shows Patrick Bateman's yuppie serial-killer hacking a victim to death while Huey's 1985 hit Hip to be Square plays as an accompaniment. But while Huey was happy enough to allow a portion of his song to feature in the movie, he is less than happy over its appearance on the soundtrack album. Last week, the album's distributors - Koch Records - were forced to recall some 100,000 copies of the American Psycho soundtrack which will now be destroyed.

Insiders suspect that the ageing popster has finally twigged that Mary Harron's movie has painted his musical oeuvre in the worst possible light - depicting it as a bland lifestyle accessory for the average eighties psycho-sexual murderer. "As a result of the violent nature of the film, Huey Lewis's management decided not to give the soundtrack clearance," explained Koch Records president Bob Frank.

But this theory is disputed by Huey Lewis and the News manager Bob Brown, who claims that Huey hasn't even seen the film. The problem, says Brown, is purely contractual. "We knew nothing about a soundtrack album," he insists. "They just went ahead and put the cut on there. I think what they're trying to do is drum up publicity for themselves."

These are not the first wrangles that American Psycho's makers have faced over the film's music. Just before filming began, Whitney Houston refused to allow the use of her stentorian soul tune, The Greatest Love of All, which now plays in the film in an easy-listening orchestrated version. The revised soundtrack album will still feature Phil Collins (another Patrick Bateman favourite) along with a few hipper numbers from the likes of New Order, The Cure and Eric B and Rakim. With Huey gone, the album is growing less square by the minute.

fields.headline: Obituary: John Sladek
fields.standfirst: Science fiction writer with a wry line in humour
fields.trailText: The most creative period of the author John Sladek, who has died aged 62 of hereditary lung disease, coincided with his time in England from the mid-1960s to 1986. A London vantage point seemed to offer new perspectives on his midwestern origin.
fields.body:
The most creative period of the author John Sladek, who has died aged 62 of hereditary lung disease, coincided with his time in England from the mid-1960s to 1986. A London vantage point seemed to offer new perspectives on his midwestern origin; repeatedly he used the metaphors of science fiction to create black satire and blacker farce about the United States, especially the midwest. In 1982 he mentioned plans to set a book in Albania but ruefully admitted: "It'll probably come out looking exactly like the American midwest."

Sladek entered Britain's SF scene during the New Wave upheaval, when Michael Moorcock gleefully outraged traditionalists by encouraging avant-garde experiments in New Worlds magazine. This was a good home for an author whose influences were William Gaddis and Joseph Heller rather than Isaac Asimov and Robert Heinlein; who loved wordplay, ciphers and surrealism (one collection is titled Keep The Giraffe Burning); and who endured repeated comparisons with Kurt Vonnegut. What he shared with Vonnegut was extravagant humour overlaying a sometimes cheerful, sometimes chilly pessimism: Sladek was funnier, though, and arguably more grown-up.

His favourite mirrors of fallible humanity were robots and artificial intelligences, often more sympathetic than his absurdly tic-ridden, trend-obsessed, culture-programmed human characters. The Reproductive System (1968) overruns America with little grey boxes that eat technology and spawn more boxes. The hapless hero of The Müller-Fokker Effect (1970) is converted to computer tape and put to bizarre uses; this novel's embarrassing-to-say title was a deliberate perversity. Sladek's finest work, Roderick, Or The Education Of A Young Machine (1980-83) offers an extended, Candide-like exploration of our follies as seen by a robot innocent.

Conversely, the antihero of Tik-Tok (1983) is an engagingly amoral mechanism whose defective "Asimov circuits" allow him to murder his way to the top, eventually becoming US vice-president. Tik-Tok won the British SF Association Award. By the time of Bugs (1989), Sladek was back in Minnesota, earning his living as a technical writer. Although the inevitable robot appears, Bugs focuses - surely autobiographically - on the disori entation and anomie of an English immigrant writer working for a cybernetics firm in yet another comic-inferno refraction of America.

Serial killers stalk, prime-time TV is filled with the presidential sanity hearings, and menus offer Spaghetti Pinocchio: "A meld of robust pesto that segues with a quietly poshified generosity of pine nuts webbed in a spunky cloudlet of homely pasta that does not noble it up unduly..."

Besides SF, Sladek restlessly explored other genres. He collaborated with his friend Thomas M Disch on the thriller Black Alice (1968), darkly satirising US race issues, and on a spoof Gothic novel by-lined Cassandra Knye; Sladek also wrote a solo "Knye" Gothic. His enthusiasm for conscious artificiality of plot resulted in two polished impossible-crime novels in the "Golden Age" detective mode, Black Aura (1974) and Invisible Green (1977).

Urged by Moorcock to document the irrational byways of modern thought, Sladek produced the useful and funny The New Apocrypha: A Guide to Strange Sciences and Occult Beliefs (1973). The realisation that pseudoscience could be highly profitable was all too tempting: as James Vogh he published Arachne Rising (1977), laboriously justifying a "long suppressed" 13th zodiac sign, Arachne the Spider. One of the invented case studies is of Cassandra Knye. Eventually he summarised this project as "a gigantic waste of time".

Sladek was a brilliant maverick author who claimed to read very little SF - Disch and Philip K Dick excepted - but nevertheless parodied it with wicked skill, and found his melancholy comedies best appreciated by the broad-church SF audience. He deserved a far wider readership.

Though cheerful and conversationally hilarious to the end, he knew that death was coming sooner rather than later. He also knew he was not forgotten: five Sladek books are scheduled for British re-issue in the near future.

He is survived by his first wife Pamela Sladek (divorced 1986) and their daughter, and by his second wife Sandra Gunter (married 1994).

 John Thomas Sladek, author, born December 15 1937; died March 10 2000

fields.headline: Instant classic
fields.standfirst: The director has been replaced, there's no time to rehearse and the cast are knee-deep in snow. Is this any way to treat a much-loved masterpiece?  Bibi van der Zee visits the set of Anna Karenina
fields.trailText: The director has been replaced, there's no time to rehearse and the cast are knee-deep in snow. Is this any way to treat a much-loved masterpiece? Bibi van der Zee visits the set of Anna Karenina
fields.body:
The British actors are provided with umbrellas and hot-water bottles, while the Polish extras are left to fend for themselves. "They're used to the cold," says one crew member, running between Warsaw's Palace on the Water and someone's trailer.

The cast and crew of Channel 4's Anna Karenina have been stationed in the Polish capital's Lazienki Park for two weeks now. A week ago there was a foot of snow filling the pathways and balconies of the 17 palaces that are poised around the grounds. Now it's just rain, and grey skies and banks of sodden autumn leaves, with all those long skirts trailing in the mud. Inside the palace they're filming a scene from near the beginning of Tolstoy's novel.

Peach-coloured paper lanterns warm the air as Anna dances with Count Vronsky, laughing and flirting. In the background young Kitty, who has turned down a marriage offer because she believes Vronsky will propose to her soon, is heartbroken; it will be several hundred pages - or a good few episodes - before she can find love.

Soon Anna will leave her husband for the count, setting in motion the events that make up one of the world's greatest tales of passion: their affair, the falling away of their love, and Anna's suicide beneath the wheels of a train at Obiralovka station. But for now, David Blair, who has never directed a costume drama before, is hunched behind the camera. His fingers are shoved deep into his hair and his face is screwed up in agonised concentration as he waits for the Polish extras to begin the mazurka again. Anna and Vronsky pause in the centre of the floor.

It looks gorgeous. But the tough pace of filming is taking its toll on everyone, and the change of director has left nerves twanging. Harry Bradbeer, the original director, was removed because Channel 4 were unhappy with the rushes; Blair, his replacement, has come straight from making a film with Colin Firth and admits that he hasn't read the book and is still finding his way.

One of the actors has a pregnant wife who is suffering from terrible morning sickness. Dougie Henshall, who plays Levin, the man spurned by Kitty, shouts at me for suggesting that Anna Karenina might not work on television. Helen McCrory, the actress playing Anna, gets very drunk with me on the last night of my visit and fixates on the idea that I find Anna unsympathetic. "But why?" she keeps asking anxiously. "Why are you doubting us so much?" She is determined to prove that Anna was wronged by society, and is clearly upset by the suggestion that Anna may have overreacted slightly to Vronsky going out for the day. In fact, all the actors look exhausted and are smoking heavily; any suggestion that they may have taken on more than they can handle gets a robust denial.

It's an extremely ambitious project. Gub Neal, head of drama at Channel 4, appears to have a vision for his department that is unlike anything it has done before. He came from BBC2 (where he had a hand in commissioning Gormenghast) and has brought us Queer as Folk, Dockers and Longitude. Longitude didn't go down that well, or Gormenghast.

As the BBC has proved dozens of times, Jane Austen, with her tightly focused stories, works perfectly on television. Other writers often just don't translate. And there's a double danger with Anna Karenina: not only does the book have its undisputed classic status, there's the great reputation of the Garbo film of 1935. Kevin McKidd (Vronsky) says that loads of his friends have urged him, "Don't fuck it up - that's my favourite book." Brilliant, he says. Just the kind of support you need.

'I read the novel after I got the part of Anna," says Helen McCrory. "I'd read War and Peace and Tolstoy's diaries but I'd never read Anna Karenina because I'd always had this image of it as this rather sentimental piece of work. Women running around deciding who they want to marry bores me stiff." But this is to be a "modern, contemporary take on Anna", and Channel 4 seems to be aiming to shatter some preconceptions with its casting. Like most of the British cast, McCrory is not an obvious choice for her role - she's not staggeringly gorgeous in the way you expect Anna to be. One crew member describes McCrory as "not beautiful but mesmerising"; she has the sort of indefinable quality that makes the barman knock things over as he goes to light her cigarettes.

Similarly, blond, granite-faced McKidd is an interesting choice for Vronsky, about whom we have so many romantic notions. (In fact, Tolstoy mentions that "Vronsky was beginning to get prematurely bald".) Best known for Trainspotting (he played naive, vulnerable Tommy) and for Small Faces (as psychopathic gang-leader Malky Johnson) he can currently be seen in Mike Leigh's Topsy-Turvy. "Some of the Polish extras just come up and stare at me," he says, when asked what he thinks of the casting. "It's like they're trying to work out what I'm doing playing Vronsky. It's quite intimidating, really, but I know I'm not the world's handsomest man. Around here, this book is a national treasure."

The former director hangs over the proceedings a little, though Stephen Dillane, who plays Karenin, is the only one to express genuine regret: he thought Bradbeer had some exciting ideas about the way he wanted to present the story. Mark Strong, playing Oblonsky, is not so positive. "Style was superseding content. You can't just do a general wash of people when you're doing plot-driven drama. You have to be specific, you can't just rely on people to know the plot."

The lack of time is clearly worrying people: McKidd has been spoiled by Mike Leigh, who spends months in preparation, and he clearly yearns for rehearsal time. "In telly there are always really tight schedules," he says. "You just have to do what you can and hope it will work."

McCrory is utterly committed to her character but clearly petrified that she's not getting it across and says she feels huge pressure. "You really don't know as an actor if it's good or rubbish till you've seen the rushes," she says nervously.

As one cast member says: "A change of director, too many producers, not enough time. It doesn't bode well." The cast are deeply committed but nervy - as is their director.

The ballroom scene is nearly ready, and the musicians have got into their gallery. Blair has managed to take McCrory to one side during lunch to chat about something that's worrying her. (He gobbles his food in four minutes flat, fielding questions from three people, then goes straight back to the set.) McKidd is outside having a crafty cigarette, while the costume designer stitches until the very last minute. Blair wanders around, has a few words with cast members, then calls, "Action!"

As we watch the monitor over his shoulder, the ballroom is suddenly transported into another century, and the camera flies, like a bird, around the room and through the dancers. Anna has purple pansies stitched into her hair, Vronsky's emerald uniform glints with decorations, Kitty's lips part in shock as she sees them laughing, dancing, talking, and for a moment, it is magic. And then someone trips over, and Blair shouts, "Cut!" And the whole thing starts again.

 Anna Karenina begins on Channel 4 at 9pm on May 9.

Best known for Trainspotting (he played naive, vulnerable Tommy) and for Small Faces (as psychopathic gang-leader Malky Johnson) he can currently be seen in Mike Leigh's Topsy-Turvy. "Some of the Polish extras just come up and stare at me," he says, when asked what he thinks of the casting. "It's like they're trying to work out what I'm doing playing Vronsky. It's quite intimidating, really, but I know I'm not the world's handsomest man. Around here, this book is a national treasure." The former director hangs over the proceedings a little, though Stephen Dillane, who plays Karenin, is the only one to express genuine regret: he thought Bradbeer had some exciting ideas about the way he wanted to present the story. Mark Strong, playing Oblonsky, is not so positive. "Style was superseding content. You can't just do a general wash of people when you're doing plot-driven drama. You have to be specific, you can't just rely on people to know the plot." The lack of time is clearly worrying people: McKidd has been spoiled by Mike Leigh, who spends months in preparation, and he clearly yearns for rehearsal time. "In telly there are always really tight schedules," he says. "You just have to do what you can and hope it will work." McCrory is utterly committed to her character but clearly petrified that she's not getting it across and says she feels huge pressure. "You really don't know as an actor if it's good or rubbish till you've seen the rushes," she says nervously. As one cast member says: "A change of director, too many producers, not enough time. It doesn't bode well." The cast are deeply committed but nervy - as is their director. The ballroom scene is nearly ready, and the musicians have got into their gallery. Blair has managed to take McCrory to one side during lunch to chat about something that's worrying her. (He gobbles his food in four minutes flat, fielding questions from three people, then goes straight back to the set.) McKidd is outside having a crafty cigarette, while the costume designer stitches until the very last minute. Blair wanders around, has a few words with cast members, then calls, "Action!" As we watch the monitor over his shoulder, the ballroom is suddenly transported into another century, and the camera flies, like a bird, around the room and through the dancers. Anna has purple pansies stitched into her hair, Vronsky's emerald uniform glints with decorations, Kitty's lips part in shock as she sees them laughing, dancing, talking, and for a moment, it is magic. And then someone trips over, and Blair shouts, "Cut!" And the whole thing starts again.  Anna Karenina begins on Channel 4 at 9pm on May 9.

webTitle: Zimbabwe court rules police must evict squatters

fields.headline: Zimbabwe court rules police must evict squatters
fields.standfirst: A high court judge in Harare has said police were legally obliged to remove 60,000 black war veterans from an estimated 1,000 farms, mostly owned by white people.
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's high court today ruled that police must evict black squatters from white farmers' lands.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's high court today ruled that police must evict black squatters from white farmers' lands.

"There is no basis for me to interfere with the judgment ... of March 17. I dismiss the application with costs," Judge Moses Chinhengo told a packed Harare courtroom.

The judge did not explain his ruling, saying he had not had enough time to deal with all the issues raised during a police application on Monday to overturn the order for the eviction of farm squatters.

The Commercial Farmers Union won the eviction order last month, but police chiefs refused to enforce it.

Zimbabwe's attorney general, Patrick Chinamasa, asking for the ruling to be overturned, claimed that police did not have the resources to evict 60,000 veterans of the 1970s liberation war from an estimated 1,000 mainly white-owned farms - and that trying to do so could trigger a civil war.

Meanwhile, Zimbabwean farmers reported that attacks on white-owned farms had intensified overnight as President Robert Mugabe urged the world to keep "cool" and insisted the land occupations were not an "anti-white" campaign.

Farm support groups reported a sharp increase in acts of intimidation and land invasions by squatters overnight in the Karoi area, about 95 miles west of the capital Harare.

Mr Mugabe, in Havana for the Group of 77 summit, laid the blame for Zimbabwe's current troubles on Britain's Labour government. He insisted that without aid from London, there would not be full compensation for affected farmers.

"I say people must be cool," Mr Mugabe said. "It is not a fight against whites as such; it is a fight against a particular section of the whites who have land."

"What they [the squatters] have done is merely stage a demonstration - a peaceful demonstration in most cases, because they have not been guilty of any acts of violence," Mr Mugabe said, although he acknowledged that some farmers had been assaulted after resisting occupation.

The veterans of the war against white minority rule in the former Rhodesia invaded the farms immediately after voters rejected in a referendum a new constitution that would have allowed the government to take over the land without paying compensation.

The defeat was the biggest blow to Mr Mugabe in 20 years in power, and indicated a drop in support for his ruling Zanu-PF party, which faces elections within three months.

The black war-veterans are demanding land that they say was stolen from their ancestors and have vowed to continue their campaign.

Political observers see the re-emergence of the issue of land redistribution as a crude way for Mr Mugabe to drum up popular support, diverting attention from an economy hit by fuel shortages, mounting debts and unemployment of close to 50%.

webTitle: Reno flies in for talks on Elian

fields.headline: Reno flies in for talks on Elian
fields.standfirst: More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: The US attorney general, Janet Reno, arrived in Miami last                                                                  night in a last-ditch attempt to resolve the dispute over the                                                                  future of Elian Gonzalez, the six-year-old Cuban boy at the                                                                  centre of a fiercely ideological tussle between Havana and                                                                  Florida-based Cuban exiles.
fields.body:
The US attorney general, Janet Reno, arrived in Miami last night in a last-ditch attempt to resolve the dispute over the future of Elian Gonzalez, the six-year-old Cuban boy at the centre of a fiercely ideological tussle between Havana and Florida-based Cuban exiles.

Elian's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, who arrived in the US last week to collect his son, called on the justice department to order his Miami relatives to return Elian to him today, after an attempt to set up a meeting in Washington between members of the divided family broke down in confusion.

The department said the order would not be issued unless Ms Reno failed to persuade the relatives to hand the child over voluntarily.

Myron Marlin, a department spokesman, said Ms Reno - a former Miami prosecutor- hoped to use her personal contacts in the city to act as an intermediary.

"She's planning to work out a resolution, trying to meet with the parties concerned to seek a cooperative settlement," he said.

"She wants to do anything possible to resolve this. She realises it's a tall order but believes she may be the one who can do it."

Armando Gutierrez, a spokesman for the Miami relatives, called her trip "a good sign".

Ms Reno's visit at least temporarily postponed a letter the government had planned to send to the Miami relatives yesterday telling them where and when to relinquish custody of Elian. "The timing of the letter is now in Reno's hands," Mr Marlin said.

It was learned that the latest draft of the letter called for the transfer to occur at 9am today at Opa-locka airport outside Miami. The transfer could also be moved back to tomorrow.

Government officials said that if no voluntary agreement could be reached, the Miami relatives who have been looking after the boy since he was shipwrecked off Florida in November would be instructed to hand him over to Juan Miguel Gonzalez.

Meanwhile rumours spread in Miami that government agents would try to storm the house where the boy has been staying and return him to his father.

The boy's great uncle whisked him to the home of a sympathetic Roman Catholic nun, Jeanne O'Laughlin.

Sister O'Laughlin, who is president of Barry Catholic University, said she had offered her house as a refuge from the tensions swirling around the Miami relatives' home in Little Havana. She said they were beginning to accept that they would have hand Elian over.

"I think that the family is becoming more reconciled and facing what perhaps could be pain," she said. "It is my hope and prayer that as the child becomes reacquainted with his father, that there will be peace in the family."

A meeting in Washington between the father and the relatives was cancelled on Tuesday night when Elian's great uncle, Lazaro Gonzalez, declared that it was "a trap" and said that Elian had refused to go. He claimed that the boy had even torn up a picture of his father.

Cuban exile leaders who negotiated the meeting on behalf of the relatives denied that they had agreed to Elian being handed over, as his father and the justice department have requested.

Juan Miguel Gonzalez, who has been waiting in the Washington suburbs for the past week to be reunited with his son, broke off talks yesterday and asked Ms Reno to order the relatives to surrender Elian today.

Yesterday lawyers representing Lazaro Gonzalez arrived at Sister McLaughlin's Miami home to discuss their next steps. Earlier they said the relatives were prepared to have a meeting with Juan Miguel Gonzalez, but not on the condition that they had to hand Elian over at that meeting.

They said if the justice department sent a letter ordering Elian's surrender they would seek a court injunction to stop it. In that case, justice department officials said, they might seek a court order to enforce their ruling.

fields.headline: Elian moved as talks founder
fields.standfirst:
Courts may be asked to rule on justice department order as parties back away from meeting

More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: Elian Gonzalez's father called on the US justice department to order his son's Miami relatives to hand him over today, after negotiations on the six-year-old Cuban boy's future broke down in confusion.
fields.body:
Elian Gonzalez's father called on the US justice department to order his son's Miami relatives to hand him over today, after negotiations on the six-year-old Cuban boy's future broke down in confusion.

A justice department official said that the order would be issued if no voluntary agreement could be reached between the father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, and the relatives who have been looking after the boy in the US since he was shipwrecked off Florida in November.

As the deadline approached rumours spread in Miami that government agents would try to storm the house where the boy has been staying and return him to his father. The boy's great uncle whisked him away to the home of a sympathetic Catholic nun, Jeanne O'Laughlin.

A meeting in Washington between the father and the relatives was cancelled on Tuesday night when Elian's great uncle Lazaro Gonzalez declared that it was "a trap" and said that Elian had refused to go. He claimed that the boy had even torn up a picture of his father.

Cuban exile leaders who negotiated the meeting on behalf of the relatives denied that they had agreed to Elian being handed over, as his father and the justice department have requested.

Juan Miguel Gonzalez, who has been waiting in the Washington suburbs for the past week to be reunited with his son, broke off talks yesterday and asked the attorney general, Janet Reno, to send a letter to the relatives drafted earlier in the week ordering them to surrender custody of Elian today.

Joan Brown Campbell, the former general secretary of the National Council of Churches, who has been arguing Juan Miguel Gonzalez's case, told journalists: "Last night was an enormous discouragement for him when he agreed he would meet the family and then, as you all know, throughout the night things kept changing. And he is going to simply ask now for the attorney general issue the court order and that the boy be returned to him immediately."

A government official confirmed that the justice depart ment had drafted a letter to Lazaro Gonzalez instructing him to transfer Elian to his father at Opa Locka airport, near Miami.

Ms Reno withheld the letter in the hope of a negotiated agreement in the Gonzalez family.

She was planning to travel to Miami later yesterday.

Justice department officials said that another of Elian's US-based uncles, Manolo Gonzalez, who has advocated his re turn to his father, might escort the boy to Washington if Juan Miguel Gonzalez refused to go to Miami.

Yesterday lawyers representing Lazaro Gonzalez arrived at Sister McLaughlin's Miami home to discuss their next steps. Earlier they had said the relatives were prepared to have a meeting with Juan Miguel Gonzalez, but not on the condition that they had to hand Elian over at that meeting.

They said if the justice department sent a letter ordering Elian's surrender, they would seek a court injunction preventing the boy's transfer. In that case, justice department officials said they might seek a court order to enforce their ruling.

They said they would consider sending immigration officials to remove Elian from Miami's Little Havana as a last resort.

Elian was found floating at sea on a car inner tube after the boat carrying him from Cuba sank, drowning his mother and 10 other would-be migrants. He quickly became a political totem on both sides of the Florida strait. His cause has been embraced by rightwing Cuban exile groups in Miami, to whom he has provided a emotive banner for rallying grassroots support, which had been waning as memories faded of Fidel Castro's 1959 revolution and the exodus it triggered.

Dr Castro has portrayed the case as a battle of wills between his regime and its capitalist foes in the US.

fields.headline: Moacir Barbosa
fields.standfirst: Goalkeeper who made a mistake his nation never forgave or forgot
fields.trailText: In the late 1940s Moacir Barbosa, who has died of a heart attack aged 79, was arguably the best goalkeeper in the world. Yet he became synonymous with the most famous error in Brazilian football history.
fields.body:
In the late 1940s Moacir Barbosa, who has died of a heart attack aged 79, was arguably the best goalkeeper in the world. Yet he became synonymous with the most famous error in Brazilian football history.

The date is still etched on the country's collective consciousness: July 16, 1950. Brazil were playing Uruguay in the World Cup final. Rio de Janeiro's grand Maracanã stadium was crammed with almost 200,000 fans - an attendance never equalled.

Midway through the second half, with the score at 1-1, the Uruguayan Alcides Gigghia slipped past Bigode on the right wing and shot at goal. Barbosa, expecting him to cross, was caught off guard. The ball hit the back of the net, silencing the crowd and giving an unexpected victory to Uruguay.

It was a national humiliation. Not only had they lost to their local rivals, but they had lost at home in a purpose-built stadium whose vastness was supposed to underline the nation's footballing greatness. Brazil had to wait another eight years before they eventually won a World Cup.

Barbosa was made the scapegoat. His career never recovered and he carried the weight of the blame for the rest of his life. "Under Brazilian law the maximum sentence is 30 years. But my imprisonment has been for 50 years," he commented on his 79th birthday, a fortnight ago.

Barbosa was never allowed to forget the match, which showed an ugly side to Brazil's passion for football. He told a documentary that the saddest moment of his life was not Gigghia's goal, but a comment he overheard at a market 20 years later. A woman pointed at him and said to the boy with her: "Look at him, son. He is the man that made all of Brazil cry."

Even fellow professionals were unable to forgive him. When, in 1993, he went to visit the training camp where Brazil was preparing for the 1994 World Cup, he was not allowed to meet the players. One of the coaches, the eternally superstitious Mario Zagallo, said that Barbosa might bring bad luck to the team.

One sportswriter wrote that he was the victim of the largest injustice in footballing history. "If I didn't learn to stop getting annoyed when people spoke of the goal, I'd be in jail or in the cemetery by now," said Barbosa recently. "People forget that in [the World Cups of] 1974 and 1978 there were worse humiliations. And what about the embarrassment of France in 1988? But people still prefer to talk about 1950."

Barbosa was born in Campinas, in the south-eastern state of São Paulo. After playing for local teams he was transferred to Vasco da Gama in Rio, where he stayed for 14 years. He was the first black goalkeeper to have a solid career in the national squad. The colour of his skin is thought by many to have been a decisive factor in the antipathy felt towards him - in 1950, Brazilian football had not grown out of its racist past.

Barbosa retired from football at the age of 42. He worked in administration at the Maracanã for more than two decades. When he retired from his second career he moved to Praia Grande, on the São Paulo coast. His wife of 50 years, Clotilde, died of bone marrow cancer in 1997 and he struggled to make ends meet until Vasco da Gama heard of his situation and gave him £700 a month, which meant that he could rent his own flat.

He lived on his own, had no children and was not in contact with his few relatives. After the death of Clotilde he had been helped out by a friend, Teresa Borba. She said: "He even cried on my shoulder. Until the end he used to always say: 'I'm not guilty. There were 11 of us.'"

 Moacir Barbosa, goalkeeper, born March 27 1921; died April 7 2000

webTitle: Peru's presidential race will require a run-off

fields.headline: Peru's presidential race will require a run-off
fields.trailText: Official results from Sunday's election showed President Alberto Fujimori fell just shy of the majority needed to avoid a run-off for an unprecedented third term, setting the stage for a showdown with international economist Alejandro Toledo.
fields.body:
Official results from Sunday's election showed President Alberto Fujimori fell just shy of the majority needed to avoid a run-off for an unprecedented third term, setting the stage for a showdown with international economist Alejandro Toledo.

Officials said Wednesday that after counting 97.68% of Sunday's ballots, Fujimori had 49.84% compared to 40.31% for Toledo.

Jose Portillo, head of the office in charge of the count, said the most the vote could change at this point was 0.05%. That means the most Fujimori could end up with is 49.89%. Thousands of Toledo's followers who were gathered in the Plaza de San Martin in downtown Lima broke into wild cheers when they heard the news.

A runoff election will be scheduled for late May or early June.

Throughout the campaign and Sunday's vote, international election monitors had sharply criticised Fujimori's government for using dirty tricks and intimidation to ensure another five years in power.

On Sunday, exit polls and unofficial tallies by independent monitors had indicated he would not reach the 50% plus one vote needed to avoid a runoff.

In Washington, the Clinton administration and Congress warned the 61-year-old leader that it would question the legitimacy of the ballot if he won in a first round and that Peru could face political and economic sanctions.
