fields.headline: Weblife: recipe sites
fields.standfirst: John O'Mahony gets a taste for browsing for food
fields.trailText: John O'Mahony gets a taste for browsing for food
fields.body:
Back when the CD-rom was being heralded as the saviour of the digital universe, someone presented me with a copy of US television chef Julia Child's multimedia cookbook, Home Cooking With Master Chefs.

By any standard, this was a spectacular piece of culinary engineering, with video tutorials from such notable chefs as Patrick Clark and Jacques Pepin, touting the latest tips on attaining the perfect lobster thermidor or chocolate souffle as well as, in one case, a handy S&M approach to trussing a chicken that might have troubled Houdini.

All this was complemented by Child's curiously inspiring grandmotherly warble: "The art of cooking is indeed a noble hobby," she gurgled every time the disc slipped into the player.

Now that the information CD-rom has largely been consigned to the dustbin of history, it is the duty of the web to take over where Child left off. For the average, budding net-epicure, the ideal place to start would be Soar, the Searchable Online Archive of Recipes, which boasts a staggering 67,087 different dishes from which to choose.

Though the site is nothing much to look at, and the basic courier font recipes look as if they have been hand-typed on a faulty Smith-Corona, there is a mind-boggling range including Australian, Burmese, Chinese, Tibetan, Czech, Venezuelan and Eskimo.

The descriptions of the ingredients and preparation, all supplied by users of this "recipe ring", are lovingly detailed. "I'm in the process of making it even as I type," gushes the creator of Doro Wat, an Ethiopian stew, "and it's real good so far."

There is even a humorous section on Extraterrestrial and Bizarre Menus that manages to be vaguely humorous. "Cut elephant into bite-size pieces," says the recipe for elephant stew. "Cook over kerosene fire at 450 degrees for about four weeks, or until golden brown. Serves 3,800."

Soar's more upmarket cousin is www.allrecipes.com, a tasteful, slick and well-designed site with some wonderful bells and whistles such as a "my recipe box", where users can store their favourites as well as a "recipe exchange" notice-board where you can post requests for particular menus.

The recipes themselves are an infinity away from Soar's crude list format, with a button for switching between American imperial and metric measurements and a facility for printing full A4 pages or on kitchen-friendly cue cards.

The site also caters for those needing special diets. It includes 227 recipes for vegetarians (highlights include smoky eggplant and yoghurt salad and cornucopia chilli) 137 for vegans (who can really pig out on bramblewood blackberry pie and bittersweet banana pudding) as well as sections for gluten free, sugar free and even diabetic dietary requirements.

There is also a whole set of linked sub-sites catering for special occasions and needs: www.christmasrecipe.com, www.thanksgivingrecipe.com, www.souprecipe.com and many more.

Of the other culinary megasites, the most notable is the superbly designed www.e-cuisines.com which includes an extremely accurate facility to calculate the calories in any meal. TV and radio cook Betty Crocker offers a revolutionary "what's on hand" section: punch in the meagre ingredients of your cupboard and the site will match these to a suitable dish (one egg and a pint of milk produced an astonishing 24 choices) as well as RealAudio streaming editions of Betty's radio programme.

The Cook's Thesaurus at www.switcheroo.com is an ingenious idea that allows you to find viable substitutes for missing ingredients.

Lovers of Asian food should try a natty little new-age site called www.asiarecipe.com (currently under reconstruction) which proclaims "Think Peace" from every page and offers choices from regions as diverse as Laos, Mongolia and Turkmenistan. Just plain lovers can plump for the Santesson collection of Aphrodisiac dishes at www.santesson.com/recept/aphrlist.ht with offerings such as fennel soup, "amorous" pesto and the inevitable candied violets.

Finally, those who like cooking without effort can go for the cheap and cheerful www.everydaycook.com which includes a glossary for the total beginner. "To boil," runs one definition, "heating liquid, which causes a constant production of bubbles that rise and break the surface."

Despite the diversity on offer, though, I'm still not quite sure that these glorified online cookbooks quite match up to the multimedia possibilities of Julia and her good old CD-rom. Bandwidth limitations simply don't allow for online tutorials and vital illustrated tips that can really transform a meal.

While waiting for this to be remedied, you could do worse than pick up one of the last copies of Home Cooking With Master Chefs from www.cdromshop.com . Head straight for the horseradish-crusted grouper with mashed potatoes. Your dinner parties may never be quite the same again.

webTitle: Ministers told pledge to cut class sizes 'not a good idea'

fields.headline: Ministers told pledge to cut class sizes 'not a good idea'
fields.standfirst:
Education Unlimited
The future of teaching: special report
fields.trailText: Education ministers are being warned by their officials to avoid any temptation to woo voters with an expensive election pledge of a further substantial cut in class sizes.
fields.body:
Education ministers are being warned by their officials to avoid any temptation to woo voters with an expensive election pledge of a further substantial cut in class sizes.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, said yesterday that he would shortly achieve a 1997 manifesto promise that classes for five, six and seven-year-olds would be a maximum of 30. Numbers in oversized classes fell from 485,000 in January 1998 to 177,000 at the start of this year, and are set to fall below 50,000 in September. Mr Blunkett said the pledge would be 100% delivered by September 2001.

Ministers are likely to come under pressure from parents and teachers to extend the policy by setting maximum class sizes for older children, particularly in junior schools where 38% of pupils aged eight to 11 are in classes of more than 30.

But officials are understood to be advising that this would be a costly and prescriptive mistake. They think heads and governors should have discretion as to whether extra funding over the next few years should be channelled into smaller classes or other measures to raise standards. That view was reflected yesterday by Estelle Morris, the school standards minister, when she said small classes mattered most in the first three years of compulsory education.

"We are not about to announce lower class size targets for key stage one (children five to seven) or the same targets for key stage two (eight-11). Because it matters more in key stage one, our approach has always been different -more prescriptive and ring-fenced money. It has never been our intention to do that anywhere else in the system."

Sources said the remarks were not meant as a comment on the next manifesto. But they were welcomed as such by David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers.

"We are not calling for junior pupils or secondary students to be subject to an infant-style class reduction programme. But we are urging the government to give heads additional cash so they are free to spend it on teachers and reduce their class sizes," he said.

The government is spending £620m over five years to implement the manifesto pledge for five to seven-year-olds. It estimates the cost of cutting all classes to a maximum of 25 for all ages in primary and secondary schools would be £3bn.

Ministers said yesterday's figures disproved the allegations that infant class sizes were being cut at the expense of eight-11-year-old pupils. Over the past year numbers in this age group in classes over 30 fell from 835,000 (39%) to 814,000 (38%).

The appointment of more classroom assistants helped to reduce the average adult-pupil ratio in classes of eight-11-year-olds from 22.5 to 21.7. But the number of secondary pupils in classes of more than 30 increased from 313,000 (10.8%) to 334,000 (11.3%).

Phil Willis, the Liberal Democrat education spokesman, said that average secondary classes were now larger than at any time since 1979.

John Dunford, of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "These children did not benefit from smaller classes in primary schools and now they are again disadvantaged in secondary schools. From September class sizes will increase considerably in sixth forms, since additional funding for post-16 reforms is not reaching schools."

webTitle: Blunkett offers review of stress on 7-year-olds

fields.headline: Blunkett offers review of stress on 7-year-olds
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government yesterday offered to review the testing of seven-year-olds in response to concern among parents that children are suffering from unacceptable stress.
fields.body:
The government yesterday offered to review the testing of seven-year-olds in response to concern among parents that children are suffering from unacceptable stress.

David Blunkett, education and employment secretary, said he would "seriously consider" changing the system if it could be shown that the complaints were true.

His offer came in answer to criticism from the father of a seven-year-old on BBC Radio 4's Today programme. Ian Anderson said: "It seems a lot of time is being used in school, because there is so much pressure on the teachers to get good scores in the tests, simply preparing children for the tests, and that is time that could be better used in other ways."

Mr Blunkett said: "If we could show that the assessment was actually putting children at seven under pressure in the way you are describing across the country, and we could not organise for teachers to be able to do it as part of the normal class work without putting [pupils] under test conditions, then I would very seriously consider changing it."

He also appeared to suggest that over-anxious parents were to blame for heaping stress on their children.

Sources in the education department later played down the remarks, suggesting that testing procedures for seven-year-olds should not pressure children if they were applied properly. Not all the children in the class were assessed on the same day, and teachers were supposed to check pupils' spelling and arithmetic during normal classroom activities.

"If parents find that is not happening in schools they should talk to the head. If they are still worried we are happy to make approaches to those schools," said Estelle Morris, school standards minister.

Later Mr Anderson, from Guildford, Surrey, said the problem started before the day of the tests. His seven-year-old had been bringing home work that, he said, was "clearly designed" to prepare for the English assessment.

Nick Tate, chief executive of the qualifications and curriculum authority, which administers the tests, denied that they were stressful - according to "the evidence that we have accumulated".

He added: "Teachers tell us that the flexibility they've got to administer the tests at a time to suit them does not make them stressful.

"It is hard to imagine an assessment situation which is more like the normal classroom situation."

John Dunford, the general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "Mr Blunkett's response is very welcome. But I think it would be useful to have some independent evaluation of the stress caused by tests for all age groups."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, added: "I think it is significant that we are now getting a backlash from parents."

Meanwhile, NASUWT members are threatening to work fewer hours if teachers' bureacratic workload is not reduced.

On the eve of the union's annual conference, Mr de Gruchy said a unilateral limit could be in place by the autumn if alternative strategies failed. The action will depend on the result of a ballot.

The leadership will urge members to back action, short of strikes, "to reduce workload and bureaucracy and eventually establish an overall limit on the amount of time a teacher can be required to deliver".

Mr de Gruchy said teachers were typically working 52 hours a week, despite the government guidelines ordering them not to carry out tasks such as photocopying.

fields.headline: Union urged to scrap Bosman
fields.trailText: The football authorities lobbied the European parliament yesterday to reverse the Bosman ruling, but they hold out little hope of success. "Revision of Bosman is an illusion," said the Uefa secretary general Gerhard Aigner.
fields.body:
The football authorities lobbied the European parliament yesterday to reverse the Bosman ruling, but they hold out little hope of success. "Revision of Bosman is an illusion," said the Uefa secretary general Gerhard Aigner.

A joint Fifa and Uefa delegation is in Strasbourg to call on the European Union to exempt sports from EU rules on the free movement of labour.

Sir Alex Ferguson is part of the delegation, but the manager of the European champions appears less committed to reform than his fellow delegates. He refused to blame Bosman for the game's lack of "long-term" planning. "The fundamentals of soccer are wrong," he said.

fields.headline: Dial-a-fortune
fields.standfirst: Gordon Brown is making piles of cash says  Victor Keegan . And it's all coming from mobile phones
fields.trailText: The auction of radio spectrum for the next generation of mobile phones - which by last night had raised a staggering £18bn for the Treasury - might look like the 21st century's equivalent of the philosopher's stone. But it is more interesting than turning base metals into gold. It is creating vast wealth from nothing at all - because the space occupied by the frequencies that companies are bidding for doesn't exist until it starts being used. It is not only the biggest privatisation and the biggest online auction, making the US company eBay look like a corner shop. It is quite possibly the biggest example of "value added" ever recorded. The eventual proceeds could be well over £20bn. And the proceeds all belong to us.
fields.body:
The auction of radio spectrum for the next generation of mobile phones - which by last night had raised a staggering £18bn for the Treasury - might look like the 21st century's equivalent of the philosopher's stone. But it is more interesting than turning base metals into gold. It is creating vast wealth from nothing at all - because the space occupied by the frequencies that companies are bidding for doesn't exist until it starts being used. It is not only the biggest privatisation and the biggest online auction, making the US company eBay look like a corner shop. It is quite possibly the biggest example of "value added" ever recorded. The eventual proceeds could be well over £20bn. And the proceeds all belong to us.

Forget the physics, just look at the arithmetic. The auction is being held for spectrum to be used by the so-called third generation (3G) phones - and other mobile devices - that will have the capacity to transmit good quality moving pictures and be permanently connected to the internet. This market is expected to be worth $200bn within a few years and could become the biggest consumer market ever.

That's why the biggest players - like Vodafone and BT - are betting their shirts and more. They may not be able to afford to bid such crazy prices, but they also can't afford not to - that would leave the crown jewels with the companies' deadly competitors. The biggest and most expensive of the five licences on offer reached over £4.5bn yesterday when Vodafone posted its latest bid. The auction will carry on, through a sequence of faxed bids to the Radiocommunications Agency's HQ in London's Docklands, until no further bids are received.

This is serious money. Gordon Brown's budget made a provision of less than £3bn for the proceeds. So £15bn of the revenue so far accrued - 50% of which has to be paid over immediately - is pure windfall profit for the taxpayer. This compares with the peak yield from North Sea oil of £11.5bn in 1985/86. The extra earnings are equivalent to a 7p reduction in income tax for a year or a huge infrastructural refurbishment, including new hospitals all over the country and a spanking refurbishment for London's creaking underground system.

It could all end in tears, as a similar auction in the US did last year when winners defaulted on their payments, forcing a rerun which only pulled in 10% of the $4bn bid the first time round. Even if bidders in the UK's auction don't default, the huge amount spent on bids could undermine the government's long-term aim of having mass, affordable access to the internet. Mobile devices are vying with interactive television to be the main deliverer of the internet to virtually everyone - but the prices Vodafone and BT will have to charge to recoup their investment may put mobile telephony out of reach of the ordinary citizen. This is the same government, remember, that is so keen on mass access to the web that it is pressurising the telephone companies to provide free, unmetered access (apart from a monthly charge). It is not easy to see how successful bidders, having paid £4bn to £5bn for a licence and another £2bn to £3bn in construction costs, will be able to offer cheap access to consumers and good profits to shareholders.

Except that this is all about game theory. The people who dreamed up the mechanism of the auction and the participants are all up to their eyes in it. The outcome of the auction depends not only on what you as a bidder might do, but also on the actions of other players who will be making their own calculations about what you are planning.

BT could, for instance, be deliberately bidding up licence B in order to make Vodafone pay an unreasonably high amount, before switching to one of the cheaper licences in the hope that it will be more competitive as a result. Vodafone may think it has a vested interest in having expensive licences, in the hope that some of the the other companies a few years hence will overstretch themselves. This would leave Vodafone, already the word's biggest mobile operator, to clean up as others drop out of the market.

At last night's prices Vodafone was paying the equivalent of around £200 for every adult in the country. If 25% of them sign up to Vodafone this works out at £800 per customer, even before the company builds the infrastructure and the phones.

Yet even this looks cheap against the $12,400 (£7,850) that Vodafone paid to capture each new customer when it bid $183bn for the German telephony company Mannesman in February. That was a paper bid in the sense that it was using the very high value of its own shares to make the bid rather than paying cash, as it will have to in this bid.

B T and Vodafone are in any case almost compelled to go right to the line in this auction because of the consequences they will face if they don't. If Britain's biggest wireless operator (Vodafone) or the country's biggest fixed-line operator fail to get a third generation licence in their domestic markets, the effect on their share prices could be so catastrophic as to make the prices they are paying for the licences seem very small beer.

The $65,000 question - or rather the £18bn one - is what to do with the boodle. Unfortunately, Gordon Brown's hands are glued into his pockets. He is already sitting on a budget surplus of up to $15bn, which he can't easily spend without igniting City fears about economic overheating and forcing the Bank of England to put Britain's already high interest rates up to even higher levels.

Spending on hospitals and railways doesn't have as big an inflationary impact as cutting taxes (which would be spent on consumer items rather than capital goods) but it would still upset the City, even if it spent in areas of high unemployment where the inflationary risks were lowest.

But we can dream. The money involved is so huge - and the timescale of decisionmaking so long - that it would be worth the slight inflationary risk in order to breathe life into Britain's crumbling railways, schools, hospitals and sports facilities. Maybe the question of distribution should itself be decided by a different kind of online auction in which members of the public stake their preferences, on a specially created website, as to how the money should be spent.

The most symmetrical solution would be for the proceeds of this digital auction to be used to provide as many people as possible with an incentive to get speedy and affordable access to the internet by subsidising the take-up of digital television and the next generation of mobile phones. This would have big knock-on effects on the rest of the economy. It would improve education and accelerate the use of the new technologies thereby enabling Britain to take a lead in the burgeoning area of mobile commerce in the same way that the US did with e-commerce.

At the very least, this would avoid the worst scenario likely to emerge from the current orgy of bidding for mobile phone licences - that by making high speed access to the internet too expensive for ordinary people it will widen, not narrow, the digital divide that Tony Blair is so concerned about.

fields.headline: Byers cleared on Rover
fields.standfirst:
Demands for help grow as manufacturing industries head for crisisNew Labour in power: special report
Rover in crisis: special report
Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, will be cleared today of keeping Rover workers in the dark about BMW's plan to sell its Longbridge plant when a report by MPs is published against a backdrop of mounting problems in Britain's ailing manufacturing industries.
fields.byline: Michael White, Kevin Maguire  and Nick Bannister
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, will be cleared today of keeping Rover workers in the dark about BMW's plan to sell its Longbridge plant when a report by MPs is published against a backdrop of mounting problems in Britain's ailing manufacturing industries.

Supporters of car makers and the shipbuilding and coal industries yesterday demanded Whitehall intervention to help them survive. Labour MPs and union leaders demanding government intervention to save manufacturing jobs had earlier extracted a promise from the prime minister that a decision on £240m worth of military ferry orders, which could go to Germany, would be made "not just on the best commercial grounds".

Mr Byers's immediate future will be bolstered when a Commons select committee clears him of knowing in advance about BMW's intentions or doctoring key minutes of talks with the company to save his skin, while accepting mistakes were made in the department of trade and industry.

The select committee, chaired by Labour's Martin O'Neill, will acquit Mr Byers of altering documents in his running row with BMW to defend himself from charges of inactivity as the German car maker panicked in February over mounting losses at Rover - up to £1bn more than expected this year - which threatened to destroy the parent company's own independence.

Mr Byers, who meets shipyard leaders today, will be relieved the trade and industry committee found that BMW's strategy changed fundamentally at the end of February once it realised, two weeks before its agm, that it faced £250m losses for each quarter of this year, instead of the budgeted £150m loss.

The BMW board had always been divided over buying Rover. MPs on the committee will criticise BMW's failure to consult Rover employees and call for workers to be given the right to more information.

"BMW made a cock-up of how they handled it. No one thinks they played fair with the workforce," said a leading member of the select committee.

"But we don't think there were proper signals given to anyone that they were heading for a terminal position."

Rover is not represented on BMW's supervisory board and union officials had to rely on their German counterparts for details of the company's plans. Mr Blair has consistently opposed European Commission proposals to extend consultation rights.

Unions' concern that the rough ride manufacturing is suffering could develop into a full blown crisis is growing. In the shipbuilding industry, John Reid, the Scottish secretary, is in dispute with Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, over a Ministry of Defence order for roll-on, roll-off ferries desperately needed by yards on the Clyde and Tyne, as well as in Belfast.

British shipbuilders risk being undercut - allegedly with cheap East European labour and supplies - from yards in northern Germany, MPs told Mr Blair at question time. Their anger was fuelled by a remark attributed to Mr Hoon that "metal-bashing is no longer a vital national asset".

Mr Blair, Gordon Brown and their cabinet colleagues are sensitive to charges that their championing of the new information age economies has made them insensitive to manufacturing, which still employs around 4m people, including large chunks of the Labour core vote vital to the government's electoral prospects.

But last night senior ministers refused to back calls for more "industry friendly" policies on interest rates and the pound.

Repeating the line used by Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, in Bradford this week, they warned that those policies - or joining the euro - would provide only short-term relief.

Ministers are also wrestling with a fresh crisis in the coal industry as private owner RJB Mining threatens to shut pits in Northumberland and Nottinghamshire unless it gets £73m in state aid.

The emotional as well as employment fallout from closing the collieries in Labour's heartlands would trigger infighting.

Mr Byers, who must also decide whether to lift or keep a two-year-old moratorium on building new gas-fired power stations, is believed to be doubtful about the value of pumping millions of pounds into the coal industry.

But if the aid plea is rejected, MPs in mining areas plan to contrast the government's willingness to hand BMW £152m to invest in Rover with its treatment of coal.

Car industry union leaders fly to Munich today to ask their European counterparts to put pressure on BMW not to sign a deal with the venture capitalists, Alchemy, before considering ex-Rover excutive John Towers's alternative plan.

fields.headline: Battle of the browsers II
fields.standfirst: While Microsoft reels from its trial, Netscape has launched a web browser.  Neil McIntosh  looks at the new battle for domination of the net
fields.trailText: While Microsoft reels from its trial, Netscape has launched a web browser. Neil McIntosh looks at the new battle for domination of the net
fields.body:
The company many like to paint as the internet's David finally got its slingshot working again last week. Netscape, once synonymous with the web and the internet boom, unveiled its latest web browser a day after Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson delivered his damning findings of law against the internet's Goliath - Microsoft.

The new software, Netscape 6, got a mixed welcome: while its speed and small download size won praise, it was criticised for being buggy - although this was only a "preview" release ahead of the final version to be launched in the second half of this year. However, Steve Case, AOL's chief executive, proudly announced that the old Netscape magic was back.

The greater significance was that this was Netscape's first major release in almost two years, during which time the company's market share was overtaken by Microsoft's Internet Explorer, and Netscape was subsumed into AOL. Microsoft's conduct towards Netscape was at the centre of the case against the Redmond company.

Officially, Netscape denies the timing of the release had anything to do with the court findings being published but was always intended to coincide with a large trade show in Los Angeles. Its defence is supported by the problems in managing the "open-source" collaboration between voluntary programmers who wrote a large portion of the new browser.

But as a former Netscape executive said last week to the Wall Street Journal: "It wouldn't help AOL to come out with a revolutionary new browser right as the trial is considering how the Netscape browser is being defeated by Microsoft's anti-competitive practices."

Jim Hammerly, vice president of AOL's Netscape Browser division, says the court case did have some bearing on the new launch, but only in terms of the practicalities of getting the product to consumers, rather than courtroom tactics.

"One of the reasons Netscape has been quiet for a long time is because we had been prohibited from participating with many of our partners in distribution," he says, referring to contracts which bound PC makers to using both Microsoft's Windows and the company's Internet Explorer. "Over the last few months we have announced major new partnerships with manufacturers to embed Netscape 6 on new machines. So that will give consumers the choice of which browser to use. We see ourselves re-emerging in that market."

But can the company really compete against Microsoft, even when it is hamstrung by its ongoing legal battle? Hammerly says that Netscape has no targets for attempting to claw back market share in the desktop PC arena. Instead, the emerging new markets of internet devices such as TV set-top boxes and internet-enabled mobile devices will provide the greatest opportunities for Netscape - and AOL.

"Looking forward, there is the new class of internet appliances for the home and busi ness. Many of these devices are Linux based, and Netscape 6 has 100% performance on that operating system, as it does on Windows and Macintosh.

"We have a lot of partners who are porting this technology to additional platforms and many of these smaller devices, and wireless devices, are major growth areas."

But while it has been proved that Netscape was crunched by the might of Microsoft, this is no longer the David versus Goliath battle that net old timers - and Microsoft's many enemies - like to pretend.

Netscape's parent company, AOL, sees its browser agreement with Microsoft expire later this year, shortly after the final version of Netscape 6 is due to ship. AOL is being coy about its relationship with Microsoft, saying only that it would like to maintain its prominent position on the out-of-the-box Windows screen, given in return for making Internet Explorer the exclusive AOL browser.

But Microsoft's once iron rule over its desktop may wane after the US courts findings against it, and AOL has been busy forming its own partnerships with large PC makers like Gateway which could make it less dependent on its Redmond rival. At the very least, should it decide to, AOL could then put Netscape on the desktops of its 16 million users worldwide, almost overnight. That kind of power makes this battle very much Goliath versus Goliath.

fields.headline: Britain seeks neutral envoy
fields.standfirst:
Foreign Office looks for a heavyweight African leader to mediate on land reform, elections and economic relations

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office was working behind the scenes yesterday to find a neutral mediator to try to resolve with President Robert Mugabe the many issues that threaten to destabilise Zimbabwe.
fields.body:
The Foreign Office was working behind the scenes yesterday to find a neutral mediator to try to resolve with President Robert Mugabe the many issues that threaten to destabilise Zimbabwe.

It sees an emissary from a country other than Britain as having more chance of success, given the strained relations between London and Harare.

Top of the list is the Nigerian president, Olusegun Obasanjo, who helped bring about the talks between Robin Cook and Mr Mugabe at the European Union-African summit in Cairo earlier this month. He is regarded as having the necessary credibility in the region.

The Foreign Office is playing down its initiative, fearful that Mr Mugabe will reject any plan originating in London. But a source said: "There is a possibility of someone from the region going to discuss the wider problems."

He stressed that it was at an early stage, but added: "We have been talking with people in the region."

Nelson Mandela has been ruled out because of his poor personal relationship with Mr Mugabe. The two exchanged insults when Mr Mandela was president of South Africa.

Another possibility, Kenneth Kaunda, Zambia's founding president and now opposition leader, has also been ruled out, partly because he is seen as too old.

The issues to be tackled go much further than the conflict over land.

The Foreign Office is still hoping that Mr Mugabe will send a delegation to London to discuss land reform, but it is looking less and less likely.

The mediator's role will be to try to find a compromise on land reform, discuss how the election promised for next month will be carried out and whether international monitors will be allowed, and try to help the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund restore normal relations with Zimbabwe.

webTitle: Farm workers bear brunt of occupations

fields.headline: Farm workers bear brunt of occupations
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Gladman T. waited for a week after the first squatters moved in before he fashioned a dozen wooden stakes, walked to a far corner of the farm he has worked on for most of his adult life, and pegged out a claim to a small piece of land.
fields.body:
Gladman T. waited for a week after the first squatters moved in before he fashioned a dozen wooden stakes, walked to a far corner of the farm he has worked on for most of his adult life, and pegged out a claim to a small piece of land.

"When the war veterans first came I didn't think they would be allowed to stay. But they are still there and they say they are going to redistribute all the land. I have lived on this farm for 35 years. If they take over I won't have any job, so I have to make sure I have some of the land."

In the confrontation between Zimbabwe's white farmers and the poor blacks who have occupied about 1,000 farms, the real victims are the hundreds of thousands of farm labourers who are threatened with the loss of their jobs and homes.

They are also bearing the brunt of the violence.Only 10 white farmers have been seriously injured, but more than 100 of their workers have been taken to hospital. And while very few farmers have been driven from their houses, hundreds of labourers and their families have been forced from the accommodation that comes with the job.

John Robertson, a Harare economist, estimates that many more labourers stand to lose their jobs than Zimbabweans are likely to benefit from the land redistribution.

"Many of these workers do not have communal lands to go to. If they are dispossessed of their jobs they will be competing for work in a market that has been incredibly unsuccessful since independence at generating new jobs. They stand to lose everything if they are forced off the land."

fields.headline: A man in the middle
fields.standfirst:
Mediation could defuse Zimbabwe crisis

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The idea, currently under discussion in Whitehall, of inviting a neutral figure to mediate the dispute between Britain and Zimbabwe, should be pursued as a matter of urgency. Robin Cook told the Commons on Tuesday that the government was hoping "to find someone who can connect with President Mugabe and speak to him with respect and authority".
fields.body:
The idea, currently under discussion in Whitehall, of inviting a neutral figure to mediate the dispute between Britain and Zimbabwe, should be pursued as a matter of urgency. Robin Cook told the Commons on Tuesday that the government was hoping "to find someone who can connect with President Mugabe and speak to him with respect and authority". One such person may be Nigeria's President Olusegun Obasanjo, who has established impressive democratic credentials since ending 15 years of military rule last year. Mr Obasanjo helped organise the foreign secretary's meeting with Mr Mugabe at the recent EU-Africa summit in Cairo. Other regional figures are also being considered for the role.

From the British perspective, third-party mediation could help achieve Mr Cook's three, EU-backed demands: free, internationally monitored elections; an end to the farm occupations; and respect for the law, especially the rights of government opponents. Mr Mugabe promised Mr Cook in Cairo that elections would be held next month - but despite dissolving parliament, he has not so far set a date. The farm occupations are escalating amid increasing violence. And the Zanu-PF government has refused to enforce the law to protect farmers and demonstrators while taking arbitrary new powers to seize land without compensation. With the situation deteriorating, Mr Cook knows he has an obligation to do more. But with bilateral relations at an all-time low, he needs help.

An independent mediator would, in theory, be able to offer Mr Mugabe a good deal in return for sticking to the democratic path. New British and US funding for a properly managed land reform programme is available. There is the prospect of renewed assistance from the IMF and World Bank, which broke with Zimbabwe last year. Emergency bilateral or multilateral loans might also be forthcoming, to alleviate the immediate fuel and power crisis and stave off a bank collapse which is likely if this year's vital tobacco crop does not reach market. But all this would have to be contingent on Mr Mugabe first meeting Britain's three demands. There is, of course, no guarantee that Mr Mugabe, who is plainly putting his own interests before Zimbabwe's, will see reason. But somebody has to take responsibility, even if he will not. Given the current, dangerous impasse, a genuinely impartial mediation effort could hardly make matters any worse.

webTitle: Bank deal could save rural POs

fields.headline: Bank deal could save rural POs
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The Post Office is within weeks of a signing a £200m deal with high street banks in a desperate attempt to prevent a stampede of closures in rural villages and inner cities, according to directors.
fields.body:
The Post Office is within weeks of a signing a £200m deal with high street banks in a desperate attempt to prevent a stampede of closures in rural villages and inner cities, according to directors.

If the Post Office fails to strike the deal, as many as 8,000 post offices - including 900 in Yorkshire and 250 on Merseyside - face closure, according to internal figures placed in the Commons library.

As many as 877 post offices face threat of closure in Wales and 875 in Scotland.

The closures stem directly from the government's decision to automate pension and benefit payments direct to claimants, so depriving the 8,000 independently run post offices of more than 40% of their income.

Automation, due to save the government a minimum of £400m, is due to start in 2003 and end in 2005.

But local post office managers are already voting with their feet by closing, adding to the sense that rural communities are losing their commercial lifeblood.

Tony Blair yesterday came under severe pressure in the Commons over the threat of mass post office closures as Tory leader William Hague accused him of meaningless reassurances.

The Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy called for the £400m-plus savings to be ploughed back.

But Stuart Sweetman, group managing director of retail banking services, told the all party community banking group on Monday that the Post Office was within weeks of signing a deal with 12 high street banks under which local post offices would provide banking for those without bank accounts. There are thought to be more than 3m people without bank accounts.

Mr Sweetman, according to Labour MP Desmond Browne, who attended the meeting, said that the service would provide the post offices with £200m of extra income, replacing nearly half the revenue likely to be lost as a result of introduction of automated benefit.

In the Commons, the industry secretary, Stephen Byers, said he would be tabling a much trailed amendment next Monday at the report stage of the post offices services bill, which would allow the government to subsidise the network.

He said that this amendment would set up a financial scheme to ensure that essential services could still be delivered through a nationwide network of local post offices.

The Commons exchanges came on the day sub-postmasters submitted a 3m-strong petition protesting at the rise of closures.

However, the shadow industry secretary, Angela Browning, said the sub-postmasters will lose a significant chunk of their income without the slightest idea of how the loss would be made up.

"It's past five to midnight as far as the post offices are concerned," she said.

The Post Office figures show that in northern England, 494 post offices depend for more than 40% of their income on benefit payments.

On Merseyside, 210 of the 304 post offices were likely to close, the figures suggest.

And in Peter Mandelson's constituency of Hartlepool, 14 out of 19 post offices depend on benefits for more than 40% of their income, the figures show.

fields.headline: Scientists defend clone research
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: Limited human cloning research must be allowed if the breakthrough represented by Dolly the sheep is to benefit people, the scientists who created her said yesterday.
fields.body:
Limited human cloning research must be allowed if the breakthrough represented by Dolly the sheep is to benefit people, the scientists who created her said yesterday.

The declaration, coming after a similar call by the Nuffield Council on bioethics, increases pressure on the government to lift its ban on early stage human cloning.

A committee led by England's chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, is due to make a recommendation on the ban to the government in the next few weeks.

Yesterday Simon Best, who heads a commercial offshoot of the Scottish institute which cloned Dolly in 1997, said: "This is cutting edge science in the UK. It's an area where the UK does lead in certain respects, and if the government isn't prepared to take the lead on this, it will send very unfortunate signals to the British scientific community."

Dr Best was in London to present the case for lifting the ban on behalf of the BioIndustry Association, a lobby group for Britain's burgeoning biotechnology firms.

Early stage human cloning, known as "therapeutic cloning" or "cell nuclear replacement", uses the same technique as that used to create Dolly - putting the nucleus of a cloning cell into a hollowed-out donor egg - but would not be used to create a human being or foetus.

Scientists say they would use the few cells making up a microscopic cloned human embryo to understand how to "reprogramme" human cells to to turn into another type of cell.

This knowledge, they hope, would be used to make replacement cells to treat human diseases - nerve cells for Parkinson's disease or spinal cord injury, skin cells for burns, bone cells for osteoporosis and skeletal muscle cells for muscular dystrophy.

Another related ban scientists hope will soon be lifted is that on research on embryos left after women have had IVF treatment for infertility. These are another potential source of the prized "stem cells", human cells with the potential to turn into any type of specialised cell.

"The long-term objective is to produce replacement cells which are compatible with patients," said Ian Wilmut, head of the team which created Dolly.

fields.headline: The cost of free speech
fields.standfirst:
England's libel laws are still rotten

The David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: Much praise has deservedly been heaped upon the bewigged head of Mr Justice Gray for his reasoned judgment in the case which David Irving so ill-advisedly launched against Deborah Lipstadt and Penguin Books. The legal process exposed Irving for what he is: an unpleasant racist who perverted history to malign ends
fields.body:
Much praise has deservedly been heaped upon the bewigged head of Mr Justice Gray for his reasoned judgment in the case which David Irving so ill-advisedly launched against Deborah Lipstadt and Penguin Books. The legal process exposed Irving for what he is: an unpleasant racist who perverted history to malign ends. But pause a while, before the case becomes mythologised as a result for the law of libel in assuring the triumph of good over evil. Penguin ran up bills of well over £2m in the course of defending Prof Lipstadt's right to express an opinion about Irving's peculiar view of the Holocaust. Thanks to the generosity and resilience of Jewish backers, both here and in the US, they will not have to meet the full cost. It is unlikely they will see much of Irving's money, any more than the Guardian has yet to see a penny of Jonathan Aitken's money. Free speech can be very expensive.

Our sister paper, the Observer, was also sued by Irving, for an article by the writer Gitta Sereny which also discussed his historical methodology. That action was paused while the Penguin action went ahead - but not before the Observer spent about £600,000 amassing the necessary evidence to counter Irving's action. We assume even Irving would not have the nerve or ability to continue the Observer case. But dropping it would simply leave the paper stranded somewhere in the queue of Irving's creditors.

English libel law - with its reversed burden of proof and limited qualified privilege - provides poor protection for writers and publications wishing to tackle difficult but important subjects. It is a scandal that Penguin's and the Observer's defence of their writers should have cost the best part of £3m. Irving - like Aitken before him - was foolish in his choice of adversary, for neither defendant flinched. But our libel laws present a formidable weapon against free speech to those who use them malignly.

webTitle: Beaten Irving vows to fight attempts to seize home

fields.headline: Beaten Irving vows to fight attempts to seize home
fields.standfirst: The David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: Disgraced author David Irving said yesterday that he would resist attempts to seize his home to pay for the £2.5m cost of his failed libel case.
fields.body:
Disgraced author David Irving said yesterday that he would resist attempts to seize his home to pay for the £2.5m cost of his failed libel case.

Lawyers for the winners, Penguin books and Deborah Lipstadt, an American academic, believe that the maximum they may be able to recover will be £100,000, a fraction of their bill.

Mr Irving had sued over a book by Professor Lipstadt which labelled him a Holocaust denier. On Tuesday the high court found against him, describing him as an anti-semite who had falsified history. Lawyers for Penguin said it was almost certain the firm would seize Mr Irving's home, a flat in Mayfair, central London, estimated to be worth up to £1m. Mr Irving, 62, has lived there for 32 years, sharing it with his partner, Bente, and their daughter Jessica, six. He said: "Undoubtedly they will come for their pound of flesh, but will find I'm made of British beef. I've always suspected they were into money and gold, with a capital G."

Within the next month the court will be asked to grant an interim costs order of £500,000. Mr Irving is believed to be already in financial trouble: his home has five mortgages on it, according to land registry records.

Mark Bateman, a solicitor for Penguin Books UK, said: "He knew what the consequences would be - professional and financial ruin - and he bought that on himself. He doesn't deserve an element of compassion. I can't see how we won't get his house. He can argue he has to live somewhere, but he doesn't have to live in a £750,000 flat in Mayfair. If we make him bankrupt, his assets will be our assets."

Mr Irving claimed well wishers had donated more than £300,000 to a fighting fund. Mr Bateman said the backers could also be pursued. "If they were considered to be maintaining the legal action, then we'd go after them. But I reckon he's been given small amounts by fruitcakes. I would reckon the sum we recover would be under £100,000."

Mr Irving said he would return to the high court in 10 days to pursue a libel action against Guardian Newspapers Limited, over an article in the Observer.

His next big pay day will be a "real history" conference he is organising in Cincinnati in September. Up to 400 people will pay $340. A spokeswoman for the US embassy in London said he would not have a problem entering due to the case: "We have freedom of speech, so it will not jeopardise him being given a visa."

fields.headline: Moscow aims for Stalin's heights
fields.standfirst: A skyscraper scheme for the capital finds its inspiration in the communist leader's grandiose towersRussia: special report
fields.trailText: The Moscow skyline is about to be transformed by a building programme which could give it many as 60 new skyscrapers inspired by the Stalin tower blocks which currently dominate it.
fields.body:
The Moscow skyline is about to be transformed by a building programme which could give it many as 60 new skyscrapers inspired by the Stalin tower blocks which currently dominate it.

Work has just begun on the first, an updated version of the Stalinist original, and sites have been allocated for the next six. Moscow city council has given permission for another 53 in the next 15 years.

When Joseph Stalin ordered the construction of Moscow's seven showpiece skyscrapers - grandiose structures characterised by their wedding-cake silhouettes - just after the second world war he was determined to prove that Russia could keep up with the west in terms of architectural extravagance and innovation.

"We've won the war and are recognised the world over as the glorious victors. We must be ready for an influx of foreign visitors," he is quoted as saying. "What will happen if they walk around Moscow and find no skyscrapers? They will make unfavourable comparisons with capitalist cities."

The new project is part of the mayor Yury Luzhkov's dream of seeing the city regenerated as a rival to western European capitals.

Stalin's neo-gothic blocks form a ring in the centre of Moscow; Luzhkov's skyscrapers are designed to form a new ring just beyond the centre. "Every one of the 60 buildings will be an original adornment to Moscow," he said as the first stone was laid.

The luxurious high-ceilinged flats in the original skyscrapers were handed out to favoured members of the party nomenklatura, but the new ones are intended for another brand of elite. The developer behind the project, Konti, hope that Russia's "newly emerging upper-middle classes" will be prepared to pay over the odds "to secure themselves a prestigious address with panoramic views over Moscow".

The first 43-floor block will have underground parking, a shopping centre, restaurants, and possibly a nightclub, 10 minutes' walk from the city centre on the edge of the green expanse of Victory Park.

Konti is keen to emphasise the "ecologically clean environment" - fresh air is a valuable commodity in Moscow.

By Russian standards the flats will not be cheap: an average-sized two-room flat will cost about £57,000 - a price even Konti concedes is expensive, even though the land on which the blocks are to be built has been given to it by the city council.

Much of the £12.5m profit the firm expects to make on each block will go back to the council and be channelled towards renovating Moscow's crumbling "Krushchev blocks" - the identical five-storey shoe-box-like buildings put up by Stalin's successor in the 60s to house the capital's booming population, which are in urgent need of repair.

Western investors are being courted by the developer, but if they prove unforthcoming Konti will not start work on the second block until the money from the sale of the 444 flats and offices in the first building is banked.

The idea of launching such a grandiose scheme when Russia's economic situation remains unstable has caused some controversy. Difficult and expensive to build, skyscrapers are usually preferred only when land is scarce and exorbitantly expensive, which is not the case in Moscow.

There is no building company in Moscow with the necessary expertise, and much of the work on the higher levels will be contracted out to foreign companies.

Alexander Shchetinin of Konti said the grand scale of the project was designed with urban regeneration in mind.

"This is more than just a commercial programme, it is a social project too. We want to make the blocks focal points for the surrounding areas."

Each block will be slightly different, but there will be a stylistic unity to the project, he said. "It won't have the pomposity of the original Stalin buildings, but every block will be reminiscent of the original series, recreated in a modern style."

The architecture critic Grigory Revzin said that with estimated prices approximately twice the Moscow average, he was doubtful whether enough people would be attracted to buy skyscraper flats.

"These blocks are being developed as prestigious living spaces. But research into the reality of housing people in skyscrapers shows that psychologically it's very hard: you never see the ground, it's like living in an aeroplane."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 An extraordinary transformation appears to have taken place deep in the soul of Alastair Campbell. The playground bully facade kept up by Ali since his boss became prime minister has been replaced by a gentler figure. Where once Ali would cuss and swear at journalists, now he jokes, slaps backs and takes them out to dinner. Is he now at ease with his masculinity? Or is it the TV cameras following him around for Michael Cockerell's new home movie (provisional title: Alastair Campbell - Faust Among Equals)? My colleague Kate Morris rings the Downing Street press office to ask why Ali's being so polite. "You're the Guardian Diary aren't you?" says a No 10 press officer. Er, we were just wondering if the change in Alastair... "Are you calling from the Diary?"... yes - was due to him being followed around by a documentary crew? "Alastair Campbell acts as a spokesman for the prime minister and we are the press office for No 10. We do not act as spokespeople for Alastair Campbell, so I can't help you." So, the prime minister's official spokesman has no official spokesman? How ... sad.

 It's official - David Irving is pro-Nazi. Now, here's a cracking joke: since David denied the Holocaust, perhaps he'll also deny the result of his libel trial? When you've picked yourself off the floor you can enjoy exactly the same gag again in cartoons on the front page of yesterday's Daily Telegraph, page six of the Daily Mail, page 21 of the Daily Mirror, and the front page of The Times. Hats off to the diversity of the British press!

 Electoral problems of an unusual kind for Philip Gould, Tony Blair's unbogus focus-groupie. Standing in the parent governor elections at Camden School for Girls, Phil's manifesto read: "I work in politics and I am a strategic advisor to Tony Blair and to the government." So modest, from one of the five progenitors of New Labour. "It has been a central mission in my life to help improve state education," wrote the boyish pollster. "I would like you to vote for me, but above all I would like you to vote." Charming. Alas for Phil the parents took him at his word and voted - for someone else. Phil obviously failed to connect with the crucial ABC1 swing voters in key marginals.

 Feel sorry for foxes that get ripped alive by hounds? You shouldn't, because it's not that bad, according to Dr Douglas Wise, a veterinary academic and lecturer at Cambridge University. Dr Wise (representing the Countryside Alliance, believe it or not!) told the inquiry into hunting with dogs this week: "It sounds pretty ghastly to be eaten alive but, thank goodness, it probably isn't as ghastly as one might believe."

 It's painful to report, but Mr Tony Blair has been fibbing again. In declaring his support for Frank Dobson yesterday, Mr Tony said the electoral college system that nominated Dobbo was "precisely" the same as the one that elected himself as leader. Precisely? Tony - and I say this more in sorrow than in anger - how many times must we remind you: when you were elected, affiliated organisations that didn't ballot their members weren't allowed to participate. But poor old Dobbo won the mayoral nomination thanks to votes from the AEEU and the Co-op Society, neither of which balloted their members. If they had balloted, Frank wouldn't have won the nomination. And that's why people call it a stitch-up.

 And now some results from the Washington Post's Merge-Matics book competition, where readers are invited to combine the works of two well-known authors into one, and write a suitable blurb. Second runner-up this year was Machiavelli's The Little Prince - "Antoine de Saint-Exupery's classic children's tale as presented by Machiavelli. The whimsy of human nature is embodied in many delightful and intriguing characters, all of whom are executed."

webTitle: ICL shifts focus ahead of float

fields.headline: ICL shifts focus ahead of float
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: ICL, the Fujitsu-owned information technology company, is to spin-off a number of units and shift focus towards e-business services ahead of its planned £5bn flotation later this year.
fields.body:
ICL, the Fujitsu-owned information technology company, is to spin-off a number of units and shift focus towards e-business services ahead of its planned £5bn flotation later this year.

The e-learning business Knowledge Pool is to be listed in London and on Nasdaq in June or July, with Finnish unit ICL Data Oy aiming for a Helsinki listing around the same time.

The moves, combined with the closure of ICL's trade distribution business and a 3i-backed management buyout of its Spares Logistics division, are expected to raise several hundred million pounds which will be ploughed back into e-business services and an internet incubator fund.

"A line has been drawn in the sand," said Keith Todd, the chief executive. "We have had to clear our past in some areas and will now live in an e-future. These moves will unlock value in the group and allow significant reinvestment opportunities."

In November, ICL said it would invest £100m in e-business expansion. The latest strategic shift will place ICL in direct competition with IBM, Unisys and Cap Gemini, heavy investors in e-business services..

The company will be divided into three new areas - innovation, applications and infrastructure - and its 22,000 workers based in 40 countries retrained in e-business skills at the rate of around 3,000 a year.

In 1999 ICL's e-business revenues were £160m, double the previous year. Total group revenues in the year to March 1999 were £2.74bn with pre-tax profits of £64.5m.

Mr Todd refused to give firm details on ICL's flotation plans but expected around 25% of the shares to be offered to the public before the end of the year.

He insisted that the flotation plans would proceed regardless of the current market volatility for hi-tech stocks.

Asked how much the sale might raise, when turbulent market conditions have seen some hi-tech initial public offerings founder, he said only: "That is a very interesting question."

Knowledge Pool has a turnover of some £55m and makes a profit of £5m, Mr Todd said, while ICL Data Oy is valued at around £840m.

The incubator will focus on creating companies that can support e-commerce customers and then floating them. "I would not expect to spin out the entire incubator unit, but over the years ahead there will be a number of spin-outs," Mr Todd added.

ICL e-business's customers include Thomas Cook, First Direct, BBC Worldwide and the Lord Chancellor's department. Yesterday it announced further contracts with mySAP in Britain, Affinity Internet Holdings and night clubs group Ministry of Sound.

ICL's e-business service spans new media design, consultancy and systems implementation. It also manages e-infrastructure services on behalf of clients.

ICL was listed on the stock market until 1985 when it was taken over by STC. Fujitsu of Japan bought the company in the early 1990s.

webTitle: Wall St Journal in European push

fields.headline: Wall St Journal in European push
fields.trailText: The Wall Street Journal plans to pour millions of pounds into a marketing push for its online service in Europe after yesterday disclosing that subscriber numbers to WSJ.com grew by 55% to 438,000 over the past 12 months.
fields.body:
The Wall Street Journal plans to pour millions of pounds into a marketing push for its online service in Europe after yesterday disclosing that subscriber numbers to WSJ.com grew by 55% to 438,000 over the past 12 months.

The drive to build the online brand comes on top of the £40m relaunch of the Journal's print version in Europe in February.

The newspaper's circulation in Europe has grown to 91,000 from 84,000 on the back of the relaunch, but use of the internet service outside the US remains small. Currently just 4% of online subscribers to WSJ.com are in Europe.

The online edition of the Journal, launched in April 1996, is one of only a handful of news-based services on the internet to charge subscription fees - $29 (£18) a year for subscribers to the newspaper and $59 for others.

The front page of the website has been reconfigured for European users and parent company Dow Jones is doubling the size of the team of journalists in London to increase local content. It also has access to content from the company's news wire operation. Advertising and direct marketing support will launch in the autumn.

"Most of the growth in WSJ.com is still coming from the US but it doesn't have to be that way," said Peter Grieff, who runs the London news operation. "The print edition has clearly been very successful in Europe and online will complement that growth.

"We remain committed to the subscription model because it clearly works. It also means we can charge more for advertising."

FT.com, its chief rival in Europe, has followed the more conventional model of free access in the hope of building enough advertising and e-commerce revenues to build a viable business.

In the first quarter of 2000, WSJ.com recorded revenues of $11.5m split equally between subscription fees and advertising.

Dow Jones has set targets to raise the combined subscriber base of both its online and newspapers around the world to 3m by 2003 - up from 2.44m at present. Only one-third of online users also subscribe to the newspaper.

"In the US, people automatically type in WSJ for financial news," said Grieff. "In Europe we have more of a job. The FT is a formidable rival but we are well positioned to compete."

webTitle: Car importer takes £7m in two weeks

fields.headline: Car importer takes £7m in two weeks
fields.trailText: British carbuyers' anger at being charged more than their European neighbours was graphically illustrated yesterday when a website that helps customers to import cars from the continent said it has taken £7m of orders in the past two weeks.
fields.body:
British carbuyers' anger at being charged more than their European neighbours was graphically illustrated yesterday when a website that helps customers to import cars from the continent said it has taken £7m of orders in the past two weeks.

Totalise Eurekar, a Leeds-based division of internet service provider Totalise, offers savings of up to 40% on UK prices. It said it had taken more than 400 orders since the end of March.

"The interest in our offer has been phenomenal and with all the publicity on the issue of car prices we are attracting more and more customers," said Peter Gregory, the chief executive. "The average UK dealer sells two cars every day. On that basis we will have sold more than a year's quota in just four weeks."

Mr Gregory expected Totalise to sell more than £100m of cars before the year end.

The figures were released two days after the competition commission said motorists were being overcharged by an average £1,100 for each new car. The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, has pledged new measures to stimulate competition and bring down prices.

Totalise acts as an intermediary scouring recognised European dealers for the best prices. It handles VAT and administrative issues on behalf of the consumer and delivers to the customer's door. Green Flag motoring assistance inspects each car before it has been delivered.

Totalise's success contrasts with that of Vauxhall. The manufacturer offered special versions of its models for sale over the net for £1,000 less than usual, yet sold only 250 cars despite a high-profile advertising campaign.

webTitle: Cancer patient's fury at doctor who 'wrote her off on hospital's death ward'

fields.headline: Cancer patient's fury at doctor who 'wrote her off on hospital's death ward'
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: A woman yesterday told of her horror at discovering that hospital doctors had decided not to resuscitate her.
fields.body:
A woman yesterday told of her horror at discovering that hospital doctors had decided not to resuscitate her.

Jill Baker, 67, who has stomach cancer, only found out after she left hospital that the words, "inappropriate for resuscitation", had been written on her hospital notes. Neither she nor her husband had been asked for their views. She said she was "written off" by a doctor who never met her. But today, nine months later, she is enjoying a good quality of life.

Campaigners said the case highlighted the way older people face discrimination from "ageist" doctors taking "end of life" decisions without the permission of patients.

Mrs Baker, was admitted to Portsmouth's St Mary's hospital last July after she developed septicaemia. She discharged herself because she was unhappy with her care and then demanded to see her hospital notes. A doctor had written: "In view of the underlying diagnosis (cancer), in the event of cardiac arrest or stroke, resuscitation would be inappropriate." The note also said "Do not ring 555" - the hospital's resuscitation number.

"I was absolutely horrified. They were going to let me die,' said Mrs Baker. "My husband and I only have each other left. I can't get it out of my mind - this doctor was playing with my life. Before I was admitted people said the ward was called the death ward and after my experience I believe it."

A spokesman for Age Concern said: "It is dreadful. It highlights the fact that elderly people are not getting the care they are entitled to." The charity is calling for a government inquiry into the treatment of elderly people in the NHS.

A spokeswoman for St Mary's hospital said the doctor involved no longer worked for the hospital. Mrs Baker's complaints were being dealt with.

fields.trailText: The railway's most feisty champion is rail regulator Tom Winsor, but yesterday he appeared to run into trouble with a government watchdog when he was criticised for not being tough enough on Railtrack.
fields.body:
The railway's most feisty champion is rail regulator Tom Winsor, but yesterday he appeared to run into trouble with a government watchdog when he was criticised for not being tough enough on Railtrack.

The snapping hound was the illustrious National Audit Office. But surely it was making some mistake in attacking him. After all, Tom Winsor is the man who, since he took charge of the Office of Rail Regulation last July, has at last taken on the track and station maintenance company. He has reduced Railtrack's double figure share price to around £7 and earnt the opprobrium of its chief executive, Gerald Corbett.

In fact the NAO report reaches back to 1994, reflecting the conduct of the regulator's office over the past six years. These were lost years, it might be said, when Railtrack enjoyed a far cosier relationship with the regulator than it does today.

The NAO report reflects what Mr Winsor discovered when he took over the reins - the worst infrastructure since before privatisation, an increasing number of broken rails, and poor performance at Railtrack. (A relatively mild winter has helped Railtrack to start turning this around.)

Within the next year, Mr Winsor will almost certainly be forcing Railtrack to remedy the NAO criticisms, for example, giving a more realistic explanation of the supposed £5.8bn cost of upgrading the west coast main line, the most expensive rail project in Europe.

But in a speech last night, Mr Winsor highlighted an equally thorny issue, the relationship between his office and the Strategic Rail Authority, a politically accountable body bringing in more than £1.5bn of government funding into the rail industry to buy services. The graphic shows the architecture of the industry. The absence of an arrow between the authority and the regulator is telling.

Chaired by the architect of the Channel tunnel, Sir Alastair Morton, the SRA and Mr Winsor have enjoyed an uneasy partnership. Sir Alastair has objected to what he regards as Mr Winsor's over-exuberant approach to his job, while the regulator believes that the SRA should put a new strategy for the industry at the top of its list.

When the government's transport legislation is enacted in the summer, Mr Winsor's consumer portfolio will disappear. It will be down to the SRA to report on complaints from passengers and whether the industry's telephone booking number is working efficiently. Can the SRA do it as well as an independent regulator?

The restructured and privatised rail industry is very much a partnership between public and private sectors. The SRA is the public partner in this relationship, buying services, negotiating contracts and injecting funds. In that role it has to be politically accountable. The rail regulator is very different, checked and balanced, akin to the regimes established in telecommunications, gas, electricity and water.

Regulation, Mr Winsor says, is an important part of a model of industrial reorganisation which has been exported by Britain to many other countries, and it works. Investors and lenders not only want it, they need it. While remaining committed to working with the SRA, he is clearly worried that the handover of his responsibility for promoting the interests of passengers may be affected. Some of Mr Winsor's critics in the industry - and there are some who resent the interference of the legally precise Scotsman - say this is just the regulator protecting a diminishing empire. But the industry needs someone as tough and dedicated to rail as Mr Winsor has been in his nine months in the job.

On the other hand, the SRA is a johnny come lately. Pushed into a siding by John Prescott after he lost a battle with Downing Street over the introduction of his big transport bill in 1998, the SRA will only be officially launched in the summer. Until then it remains a "shadow".

Chairman Sir Alastair Morton is an impressive man who was handpicked by John Prescott after giving much needed advice to the government on how to handle the debacle of the Channel tunnel rail link project two years ago. He is alert and wants to get things done quickly. Indeed, there is the political imperative of the next election for him to demonstrate that the SRA has began to grapple with the industry and is turning it round, with new franchises and new money.

Mr Prescott is bearing this out with a huge cash injection into the industry, but Sir Alastair cannot promise quick results. How can he transform the railway overnight and turn it into a model for the rest of the world?

Sir Alastair's other problem is that he is in a part-time, two-and-a-half day a week job, even though his hours are much longer. At a time of so much change, and with an increase of 25% in passenger usage, the industry requires a full-time leader.

Unfortunately, Sir Alastair is not well. He is putting in far more time than he is required to but his illness is not helping matters. This has led to suggestions that he may resign if he cannot get his way on a continuing government subsidy for the industry and some of the impressive improvement schemes now under consideration - including double-decker trains running into Waterloo and a new fast track on the east coat main line between London and Edinburgh.

In an industry sadly lacking in leadership, the man best suited to replace Sir Alastair would be energetic, full-time and utterly committed.
