fields.headline: Enoch Powell was expelled for this kind of demagoguery
fields.standfirst:
Hague gropes for election issues and comes up with a reckless formulaTories in opposition: special report
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The Tories are a party in deep trouble. A year from now they will be fighting an election they know they cannot win. Mr Hague, doubtless reluctant to face this with unblinking clarity, at least understands the need for damage limitation. He has made extraordinarily little headway against a government which is far from perfect, and he needs to find something to say that people might start listening to. He is getting desperate to win a few seats. He needs an issue. And he thinks he may have found it.
fields.body:
The Tories are a party in deep trouble. A year from now they will be fighting an election they know they cannot win. Mr Hague, doubtless reluctant to face this with unblinking clarity, at least understands the need for damage limitation. He has made extraordinarily little headway against a government which is far from perfect, and he needs to find something to say that people might start listening to. He is getting desperate to win a few seats. He needs an issue. And he thinks he may have found it.

Asylum, moreover, is not something he has dredged up from the gutter. It's a problem amenable to the most solemn grandiloquence. Mr Hague has decided he has "an absolute duty" to talk about it. This is the sonorous defiance he holds out against those who criticise some of the things his people have said. The numbers of asylum seekers, more than 70,000 in 1999, create, he claims, a national crisis, which demands his dutiful attention. So he won't be silenced by the namby-pambies, brave fellow. The definitive speech is being worked on, for delivery next week.

Mr Hague is right about some of this. Requests for asylum have multiplied in recent years, stirred by the turmoil in the Balkans and the overflow from it across central Europe. A lot of human crises have landed on our soil, together with a fair number of people whose way of addressing these crises is to exploit them as cover for their own trickery and deceit, and thereby make their own claim to a right to be here. An exceedingly messy situation has developed. It imposes big burdens on certain counties, like Kent, and creates administrative challenges to the government which the Home Office, starting with its defective computers, has been incompetent at meeting.

All this is meat for legitimate criticism. Though the numbers are less than 0.1 per cent of the population of one of the half-dozen richest countries in the world, there's an oppositionist job to be done against Jack Straw's Home Office, just as there is against David Blunkett's DfEE or any other department. Except that asylum raises more delicate matters than primary school class-sizes. Argument about it easily touches a racist nerve. It is sensitive stuff. Xenophobia is waiting to be aroused, alongside mundane disputes about who will make good the budget of Kent social services.

Stirring up hatred of people, as a people or group or class or generally blocked-out enemy, is the risk. Words need to be used with care, and always accompanied by constructive proposals about how the social problem, if it is a problem, might practically be diminished. But rising portentously to the very toes of his absolute duty, Mr Hague has respected none of these sensitivities. There is a terrible recklessness, to put it no lower, about the words his party bandies about. Its manifesto for the local elections touches every button. "Labour has made this country a soft touch for the organised asylum racketeers who are flooding the country with bogus asylum seekers," it says. That translates: asylum is ipso facto a racket, aliens are taking over Britain, every one of them is a fraudster until proved otherwise. All that's missing is the Tiber flowing with blood.

For we've been here before. The only difference between Enoch Powell's philippic in 1968 against the migrant masses whose numbers were destroying the British nation, and Mr Hague's demagogic caricature of asylum in 2000, is that whereas Powell was expelled from the shadow cabinet for saying what he said, today's shadow cabinet has made his political strategy their own. Ann Widdecombe, Hague's blustering ally in this matter, finds it perfectly respectable to list each of the mild pro-immigrant measures Labour has taken since 1997 as part of her anti-asylum indictment, without ever referring to the causes of the increased demand. As far as the Tory party is concerned, the Kosovo war never happened and Balkan, let alone Somali or Rwandan or Nigerian or Colombian, tragedies do not exist - though Rhodesia looks like being an exception.

A screen of respectability sometimes covers Mr Hague's own words. There are references to the need to protect "genuine" asylum-seekers from the rest. But here is authentic bogusness, the genuine bogus article, addressed to a party which in its present incarnation shows no interest in asylum-seekers of any kind, the genuine any more than the deceiving. Any such refinement would complicate the political message, now delivered into the local elections, that the Tories alone can be relied on to take a harsh line against the flooding influx of racketeering aliens.

The Home Secretary's own line has not always been sympathetic, or straight. On Monday he traded insults with Ms Widdecombe as to which party could proudly claim to spend less money on asylum-seekers, which one had scandalously dabbled in amnesties, whether Labour or the Tories could be reliably the tougher. But his department is doing practical things, especially by recruiting and training more adjudicators to speed up the testing of each asylum case, the only way Britain can meet its obligations in international law and human decency. The government has slowly improved the system, with results that do not reinforce the stereotypes of the Tories and their press. Last year nearly half the asylum seekers whose cases reached a judge were allowed, after due process, to remain.

Meanwhile, the Conservatives are all mouth, foaming mouth. It is a repugnant spectacle. The high-flown way to look at it might be as an expression of the party's existential crisis. After all, its ground as a party of the centre-right has been purloined. Many of the issues that made it centrist belong to the other side. It now experiences an intractable conflict between globalisation and nationalism. It is supposed to be a free market party, but free markets these days destroy national borders. People as well as capital are on the move. The high-ground analysis of Mr Hague's attitude to asylum could offer him some sympathy. Perhaps he's a man in pain, searching for a new rightist identity and driven towards a kind of nationalist protectionism that sits uncomfortably with the economic philosophy he is supposed to believe in.

But let's not be too kind. The only pain he's aware of is the probability of being routed. Something more basic is at work. The absolute duty to speak must, of course, have its day. With numbers swelling, and the department emerging from a period of chaos, a veneer of earnestness is available to the Tories. Behind it, though, there's a fluttering of uncontrollable excitement. At last an issue to make British blood run fast and cold. Never mind delicacy. Never mind truth. William has found something that will be pleasing to his own masses, and perhaps appealing to the outer edge of people who didn't vote Conservative in 1997. For the months are moving forward, and the polls are not. Let the prophet Enoch come in from the wilderness. It has come, I'm afraid, to that dismal epitaph.

fields.headline: 'Disreputable' Tories accused in refugees row
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special reportRefugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The bitter inter-party row over the increase in asylum seekers spilled over into the Commons last night when the home secretary,  Jack Straw, accused the Tories of using wholly inappropriate and inflammatory language over the increase in claimants.
fields.body:
The bitter inter-party row over the increase in asylum seekers spilled over into the Commons last night when the home secretary, Jack Straw, accused the Tories of using wholly inappropriate and inflammatory language over the increase in claimants.

During a debate on refugees, he pointed to Tory election literature and remarks by Tory MPs falsely suggesting that some local council taxpayers were going to have to pay as much as £180 each to fund asylum seekers. "To use the issue of asylum to play the race card is a disreputable act of any party and those who are attempting to do it should stop doing it," Mr Straw said.

The Conservative attack on the government's asylum policies was defeated by 351 votes to 134, majority of 217.

The Tory home affairs spokesman, David Lidington - deputising for Ann Widdecombe, who had a throat infection - said the attorney general, Lord Williams, had used exactly the same language as the Conservatives. Mr Lidington said the British people felt "real anger and resentment" at the government's immigration policy.

He said that in the three years since the government took office the number of people claiming asylum in the UK had more than doubled. In 1996, it was 26,640, compared to 71,160 last year. The backlog of applications awaiting a decision had almost doubled in the same time to 102,870 at the end of 1999.

He said: "The truth is that the crisis over asylum policy is now arousing real anger and resentment among our constituents. They are angry at the transparent abuse of this country's long tradition of giving asylum to genuine refugees." Voters were indignant "when they see our system for handling asylum overwhelmed by bogus applications from people who are intent on evading our immigration controls".

Mr Lidington urged an increased use of detention so that when applicants were refused the right to remain they could be easily tracked down.

Mr Straw blamed the crisis on the failure of the previous administration to increase processing staff, as well as the rise in international political crisises, including Kosovo.

He said he had been forced to revise the Conservative government's legislation which continued social security cash payments for those who applied at port of entry but denied them to those who applied in the country. Mr Straw also attacked the Tories for refusing to support his measure to fine lorry drivers who were found guilty of wilfully bringing in illegal immigrants. The previous Tory government had failed to negotiate a proper flexible deal on the return of illegal immigrants within the EU, he added.

The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, said it was "absolutely ridiculous" to suggest that the growth in the number of people seeking asylum in this country was anything to do with the actions of host countries.

Mr Hughes said the leadership of the Tory party had behaved "disgracefully" and "deserved to be condemned" because they "don't just seek to pander to prejudice, they positively misrepresent facts in order to be able to do that"

The Labour former minister Gerald Kaufman launched stinging attacks on both the Tory party and recent comments of independent London mayoral candidate Ken Livingstone. Mr Kaufman said his parents were provided with sanctuary in Britain after fleeing eastern Europe before most of their families were "slaughtered" in the Holocaust. "Therefore I want to say how bitterly I resent the cheap remarks of Ken Livingstone in likening capitalism to what the Gestapo and Hitler did to the Jews, the homosexuals and all the other people who were murdered by the Nazis," he said. "Such a person is not fit to stand for public office let alone to be elected to public office."

fields.headline: IMF overcomes siege mentality
fields.standfirst: Washington insiders are optimistic about the world economy's vital signs
fields.trailText: From the outside, the International Monetary Fund looks like an institution under siege. Streets are blocked off, the police barricades are up and security is tight. In the aftermath of the riots in Seattle four months ago, the authorities are taking no chances.
fields.body:
From the outside, the International Monetary Fund looks like an institution under siege. Streets are blocked off, the police barricades are up and security is tight. In the aftermath of the riots in Seattle four months ago, the authorities are taking no chances.

On the inside, however, the mood is cheery, almost upbeat. Its biannual world economic outlook, released yesterday, shows that recovery from the dark days of late 1998 has been rapid and robust.

To be sure, the IMF has some well-warranted words of caution, particularly about the durability of the US boom and the continued ill-health of Japan, but it has been pleasantly surprised by what has happened since the Russian debt default took the global economy to the brink 20 months ago.

"Global economic and financial conditions have improved dramatically during the past year," the report says. "The effects of the recent financial crises may be felt for some time, but the emerging economies in Asia have for the most part staged a strong V-shaped recovery, and the transition countries and Latin America have begun to recover from the subsequent turbulence that particularly affected Russia and Brazil."

As a result, the IMF has revised upward its prediction for global growth last year from 2.9% to 3.3% and is forecasting expansion of 4.2% this year, 0.8 percentage points higher than it pencilled in last autumn.

But, while the rich west and parts of Asia and Latin America are doing well, the IMF admits that "progress in raising real incomes and alleviating poverty has been disappointingly slow in many developing countries, and the relative gap between the richest and poorest countries has continued to widen".

Unprecedented growth in the US economy has once again been the main factor behind the upward revision to the IMF's forecasts, but all the other Group of Seven industrial countries bar Japan - Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada - are also now expected to perform more strongly than expected six months ago.

"The impressive expansion in the United States is now the longest on record and the outlook has also improved for Europe. The Japanese recovery, however, remains tentative and fragile."

Following the recession in 1998, the Asian tigers have sprung back to life, according to the IMF. Growth in the newly industrialised Asian economies is put at 7.7% in 1999, 2.5% higher than projected in the last economic outlook report, with expansion of 6.6% expected this year.

However, the IMF says the world economy is not yet out of the woods, stressing that its main concern is the series of economic and financial imbalances that have been building for years.

First, it is worried about the "lopsided" pattern of growth among the three main trading blocs, with the US current account in record deficit and persistently large surpluses in Japan. The IMF - and the US treasury secretary, Larry Summers - believe Europe and Japan now need to grow faster, allowing the US to slow to a more sustainable pace.

Second, the IMF is anxious about the "seemingly significant misalignments of several key currencies relative to what would be consistent with medium-term fundamentals, notably the strength of the dollar relative to the euro".

Combined with the large external imbalances, there remains "a risk of sudden changes in market sentiment, associated shifts in capital flows, and potentially disruptive realignments of exchange rates".

Finally, the IMF adds its voice to those concerned about the level of stock market valuations around the world. "These may be justified in part by investors' favourable assessments of the impact of new technologies, but they may also reflect unrealistic expectations of future earnings growth that have been nour ished by the now record long expansion in the US."

The IMF's economic counsellor, Michael Mussa, said: "It would be a mistake for the Federal Reserve to tighten monetary policy so much that it crushes the economy without hard evidence that inflationary pressures are picking up."

But he warned that further increases in interest rates would be needed to avoid a hard landing. "Further monetary policy tightening is anticipated and is needed and will happen."

The review adds that the decision to flood the global economy with liquidity during the financial crisis of 1997-98 helped fuel demand for financial assets in many countries.

"Experience shows that such asset price inflation can be particularly destabilising because it may encourage households and businesses to over-consume and over-invest, and because of the danger that the financial system may become vulnerable to an eventual downward correction in asset prices."

The IMF accepts that it has been voicing these concerns for some time and that it might be tempting to conclude that they are not really a problem at all. "Such a view has more than a few adherents, and could be correct, but if it is wrong such complacency could have severe consequences."

webTitle: Far left groupuscules rise from the dead

fields.headline: Far left groupuscules rise from the dead
fields.trailText: I was very interested to read Paul Foot's affectionate obituary of Tony Cliff, the International Marxist. But one thing I was sorry not to learn was why exactly this remarkable man, born Ygael Gluckstein, changed his name to something far more suitable for a high-school letter-sweater crooner of the 1950s.
fields.body:
I was very interested to read Paul Foot's affectionate obituary of Tony Cliff, the International Marxist. But one thing I was sorry not to learn was why exactly this remarkable man, born Ygael Gluckstein, changed his name to something far more suitable for a high-school letter-sweater crooner of the 1950s.

I can understand why right-wing Jews change their names, especially in politics: they are ashamed of being immigrants, and they want to fit in. But I am always very puzzled when left-wing Jews do the same. Surely we would regard a black who tried to "pass" as white or an Asian who tried to pass for English (see the Kaphoors from Goodness Gracious Me) as laughable at best, and rather craven and creepy at worst.

Or was it simply, as with so many anti-Israeli Jews, just a simple case of self-loathing.
Julie Burchill
Brighton

 I must say I was most disappointed at the nit-picking sectarian tone of Bill Martin's letter (April 12) about Paul Foot's obituary of Tony Cliff (April 11). While it is true that the left social revolutionaries used the term "state capitalist" to describe post-revolutionary Russia it was merely a label without any serious theoretical content.

Lenin's usage of the term was also descriptive of a particular policy (the New Economic Policy) rather than a serious theoretically worked out position. What Tony Cliff did with the concept (more strictly "bureaucratic state capitalism") was to provide a theoretically argued descrip tion of the Russian economy that showed that the fundamental dynamic of the economy (accumulation) was in no way different from the dynamic of capitalism described by Marx and developed by his successors. This had not been done by any of the people using the term earlier.
Einde O'Callaghan
Chemnitz, Germany einde.ocallaghan@planet- interkom

 What a surprise. Paul Foot writes an obituary for Tony Cliff and straight away someone from another far left groupuscule starts arguing with him. Might this give us a tiny clue as to why no party to the left of Labour has made any progress?
Paul Steeples
London
paul.steeples@iudti.org.uk

fields.headline: Playing tag
fields.trailText: So satellite tracking technology may be used to control truanting teenagers (Report, April 10). Just think about the effect on children's literature.
fields.body:
So satellite tracking technology may be used to control truanting teenagers (Report, April 10). Just think about the effect on children's literature. The adventures of Tom Sawyer would consist largely of him whitewashing the fence. We may not know exactly "what Katy did" but we would know where she did it. William Brown might as well have stayed in bed all day. Of course, there could be problems dealing with the children in Narnia ("last seen in a wardrobe"). Growing up is about taking risks, making mistakes and learning from the experiences. Electronic prisons may promote teenagers' safety, but at the detriment to their development into moral beings, choosing how to behave rather than being compelled to.
Michael Rutherford
Newcastle upon Tyne

webTitle: Revolt looms in Lords over financial watchdog

fields.headline: Revolt looms in Lords over financial watchdog
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The government is braced for further confrontation in the Lords tonight as Conservative and Liberal Democrat opposition join forces to tighten controls over the new post of financial services watchdog.
fields.body:
The government is braced for further confrontation in the Lords tonight as Conservative and Liberal Democrat opposition join forces to tighten controls over the new post of financial services watchdog.

Though opposition peers echo widespread praise in the City for Howard Davies, the man who will become both chairman and chief executive of the financial services authority (FSA), they believe the two roles should be split - if not now, then later.

The proposed structure has been moulded too much in Mr Davies's image, they suggest. If crossbench peers back them, as seems likely, and ministers do not back down on key points they face their 11th Lords defeat this year.

The row came as Tories warned that the government is in danger of facing a "legislative bottleneck" in the Lords, with major bills piling up for scrutiny. Their leader in the upper house, Lord Strathclyde, forecast that ministers would be hard pushed in the months ahead to meet their deadlines.

Tory peers have fallen in behind the Lib Dems to back a raft of amendments to the financial services and markets bill, which will bring the powers of the present assortment of nine financial regulators under a single authority.

They believe the FSA will not be sufficiently accountable to consumers, parliament or to City institutions.

But the row over the FSA bill - already much amended in the Commons - is now bound up with the growing assertiveness of the half-reformed Lords and their impatience with the mounting backlog of bills, many of them in constant need of amendment.

Yesterday senior Tories called for a month's delay on the financial services bill, claiming that City leaders want more time to consider late government amendments of which there have already been 500.

The treasury minister in charge, Melanie Johnson, is warning them not to play "political games".

However, even she is signalling concessions to strengthen consumer protection.

Lib Dem peer Lord Newby, who is leading moves to reform the legislation during its Lords report stage, warned last night: "At the moment the FSA has huge powers which are not sufficiently moderated, either by its own structures or by the extent to which it has to be accountable to parliament or consumers."

Because of concerns over Mr Davies's role, opponents argue that his job should be split into two to improve accountability.

They want a new consumer panel within the FSA to have more power to force the authority to take notice of its recommendations, as well as an annual report to parliament.

Opposition front bench treasury spokesman, Lord Saatchi, said leading City figures were concerned over the financial services bill.

"They feel as we do, that it's impossible to judge this bill properly in the round when you are dealing with so many individual amendments at such a late stage and they have asked for a month's pause," he said.

fields.headline: A Labour of love
fields.trailText: I was amazed to read Ronald Williams's letter about undelivered Labour party leaflets in Runcorn (April 10).They are still being printed!
fields.body:
I was amazed to read Ronald Williams's letter about undelivered Labour party leaflets in Runcorn (April 10).They are still being printed! Perhaps Mr Williams is unaware of the millions of pounds this government is investing in Runcorn through the single regeneration budget, the new deal for schools etc. Labour is working in Runcorn and our workers are as enthusiastic as ever.
Stan Hill
Halton, Cheshire Stan.Hill@halton-borough.gov.uk

 Peter Manwaring asserts there will be no real alternative "come the next election" (Letters, April 12). As my father knows full well, a Labour party sensitive to the needs of the poor as opposed to the business community would be a genuine alternative.
Rob Manwaring
London

 David McKie (April 6) rightly emphasises the importance of the army to the Aldershot. But he is wrong to suggest that this is about to change. There is and will continue to be a considerable army presence in the home of the British army. That is why we are investing in new facilities in the town, for example the new army recreation centre which will be opened in July.
Nick Gurr
Ministry of Defence

 Ian Williams asks (Letters, April 8) "where is the Countryside Alliance?" as Barclays closes rural branches. The alliance has publicly condemned the move, which will cost rural jobs and will further penalise rural people. The alliance has also been playing its full part to save another threatened service, by supporting and participating in the Save the Post Office demonstration and rally in London yesterday. We will continue to campaign on both fronts.
Nigel Henson
Countryside Alliance

fields.headline: No kidding
fields.trailText: Will Tony Blair's paternity leave encourage others to take (and allow) the same? Now he has described his plans (Chastened Blair, April 10), I hope nobody will emulate him.
fields.body:
Will Tony Blair's paternity leave encourage others to take (and allow) the same? Now he has described his plans (Chastened Blair, April 10), I hope nobody will emulate him. He will "spend more time with Cherie when the kid is born to help out". But the point of paternity leave isn't helping women who are mothering; it is fathering: men having the time and space and socially approved opportunity to make their own vital relationship with a brand new baby - hmm, sorry, "kid".

I also hope neither firms nor (self-) important employees will copy the "work a shorter day" version of paternity leave. Nobody is irreplaceable at work; nobody can be replaced in getting to know a new baby. So working a shorter day says "the job is more important". The paternity leave we need encourages fathers to put new children first for a while; a temporary priority that will last for life rather than through the next promotion - or election.
Dr Penelope Leach
President, National Child Minding Association

fields.headline: Estates of the realm
fields.standfirst: Good plan, but it will need big money
fields.trailText: For up to three-quarters of their income they depend on public handouts. Unemployment climbs to 30%. Six out of 10 of their children are poor. They lack for banks, shops and transport. Crime is rife, skills lacking. The Social Exclusion Unit (SEU) yesterday painted a lurid picture of our deprived neighbourhoods, 3,000 of them, concentration camps in the midst of civilised society, nests of failure surrounded by general success.
fields.body:
For up to three-quarters of their income they depend on public handouts. Unemployment climbs to 30%. Six out of 10 of their children are poor. They lack for banks, shops and transport. Crime is rife, skills lacking. The Social Exclusion Unit (SEU) yesterday painted a lurid picture of our deprived neighbourhoods, 3,000 of them, concentration camps in the midst of civilised society, nests of failure surrounded by general success. It is a portrait made all the more compelling by its vintage. Compare the SEU's with the output of the Community Development Programme in the late 60s or work done for environment secretary Peter Shore in the mid-70s - or Kenneth Clarke's short-lived urban task force in the late 80s. Public policy and private enterprise have combined over the years to create social sinks, as we have known for ages. High theory is out of fashion; pragmatism rules. But still it would have been interesting to have had some speculation to leaven this formidable enumeration exercise: do these estates and the inequalities they house fulfil some perverse function in our economic system?

Yesterday the accent was rightly positive. After their obligatory photocall in east London, John Prescott and Hilary Armstrong recalled the array of "area-based" initiatives which the Blair government has already introduced, though not without overlap. Then they reeled off a long list of proposed new targets and pledges. In themselves most are spot on. Jobs and human development are the focus. These are what make communities, not the physical condition of housing, which policy used to focus on. The government says estate dwellers must "own" the new policies. Indeed: places that are done to rather than do are unlikely to become the hotspots of enterprise and self-help the plan envisages.

But there are two large questions which no amount of practical goodwill for social improvement can wish away. One is money. Spots of cash, little increments, bolted-on budgets - these have been tried before and do not work. If these estates are the acme of deprivation, the broad flows of money for schooling, social care, policing, skills training and job creation have to be bent in their direction. That means, and why whisper it, radical redistribution. It means middle, home-owning, future-oriented England doing with a little less or paying a little more. Virtually every recommendation made yesterday means extra - more teachers, better incentives to businesses to stay or set up in deprived areas. It is an open secret in Whitehall that the prime minister's pledges on health have squeezed what is left in the estimates for social spending. If the promises about joining up and prioritisation mean anything, they imply reserving a bigger slice of the money for the estates. Not that "joining up", that great cry of the Blair years, has yet been much of a success. Watch the coming scramble over which department will house the projected neighbourhood unit inside Whitehall.

And that raises a second great issue unresolved in the SEU report. John Prescott more than once used this phrase: we are going to set tough new performance targets ... for schooling, job creation, policing. But tight, tough targets have been the bane of Blairite social policy. What room do they leave for local initiative, for the social and economic entrepreneurship which is such a vital ingredient in the recovery package? The government's anxiety for results is widely shared. But after putting more money in, will Whitehall back off and tolerate the mistakes that will undoubtedly accompany the success stories?

fields.headline: Why this bill must succeed
fields.trailText: Your call for Britain to lead the way by ratifying the statute of the international criminal court is very welcome (Leader, April 10). The government has repeatedly stated that it is in favour of ratifying the statute at the earliest opportunity.
fields.body:
Your call for Britain to lead the way by ratifying the statute of the international criminal court is very welcome (Leader, April 10). The government has repeatedly stated that it is in favour of ratifying the statute at the earliest opportunity. A draft bill is expected in the summer with legislation promised for the Queen's Speech in November. However, with a possible general election as early as next spring, this timetable is worryingly tight.

You mentioned that the US opposes the creation of the court. In fact the US is considering introducing a new bill to prevent its own military personnel, officials and politicians from facing justice for any war crimes committed in the future. Even more dramatically, the bill authorises the president to free "United States military personnel and certain other persons held captive by or on behalf of the international criminal court" and "to use all means necessary and appropriate" to this end.

fields.headline: Irving: the debate simmers on
fields.trailText: As a non-Jew I find David Irving's remarks (Irving: consigned to history as a racist liar, April 12) deeply offensive. His assertion that "if the British soldiers on the beaches of Normandy in 1944 could look forward to see what England has become, they would not have bothered", is breathtakingly obscene.
fields.body:
As a non-Jew I find David Irving's remarks (Irving: consigned to history as a racist liar, April 12) deeply offensive. His assertion that "if the British soldiers on the beaches of Normandy in 1944 could look forward to see what England has become, they would not have bothered", is breathtakingly obscene. My late father fought in the war to rid Europe of fascism. He witnessed the results of the extermination of Jews in concentration camps. Such was the profound effect of what he saw, he never talked about it. It was only after his death that I learnt from my mother the full horror of what he had seen. What a waste of such an intelligent mind that Irving should feel it necessary to recast history in such a twisted way.
Robert Minton-Taylor
Cononley, N Yorks

 The outcome of David Irving's abortive libel action is not merely a victory for Deborah Lipstadt. It is also a victory for the victims of the Holocaust, against such insidious attempts to trivialise and marginalise the 20th century's greatest crime.
Nigel Baldwin
Portsmouth N.Baldwin@btinternet.com

 Presumably Irving will now deny that he lost the case.
Tom Freeman
Sheffield

 The particular vileness of Irving's offence was to increase the suffering of the survivors of the Holocaust by denying that suffering existed. Unfortunately, one kind of Holocaust denial will continue. It continues every time the totemic number of 6m is used. That figure excludes socialists, communists, homosexuals, the disabled and Gypsies - all denied, as Irving tried to deny for the Jews, the final dignity of a clearly recorded place in history. How large is the final figure? Does any one know?

The overarching evil idea behind Nazism was the belief they had the right to cleanse the world of any group they hated. As a life-long socialist of the kind the Nazis would have called communist, my fate in Nazi Germany would have been no different from my Jewish friends. When are "my people" going to get their memorial - in recorded history, if nowhere else?
Jeff Wells,
London
Jeff.Wells@mencap.org.uk

 You claim Mr Justice Gray's decision means "Irving can no longer call himself a historian" (History's verdict on Holocaust upheld, April 11). This sentiment makes a nonsense of the historian's craft, a craft where theoretical relativism has had some success in challenging old-fashioned positivist assumptions. Undoubtedly, many of Irving's conclusions are opportunistic and consciously biased, but there is the theoretical point that, with no recorded source showing Hitler's authorisation of the Holocaust, a certain degree of caution must be made. People angered by Irving should counter-argue rather than dogmatically condemn and financially cripple him, which just enforces this stubborn English mentality of a true and narrative history from above that is protected by the courts.
N Robinson
Loughton, Essex
NickTheSticks@hotmail.com

 So "Irving was motivated by a desire to present events in a manner consistent with his own ideological beliefs". Such a lack of objectivity is,of course, unheard of in sociology.
Prof Keith Dixon
Simon Fraser University, Canada

 Your condemnation of Irving seems excessive. Is he not entitled to ask for proof? May he not ask why Jews are hated? Did Hitler do nothing right? There is an unfortunate similarity between press headlines and Nazi propaganda in the common intent to silence. If it is wrong to attend assemblies of "right-wing" humans, then I plead guilty to attending Tory activist gatherings to hear shocking views comparable to Irving's.

Anti-semitism, xenophobia, sexism, etc are all evils to be fought, but making a living or a lifestyle out of attacking a selected prejudice leads directly to McCarthy-style scenes, which Irving can reasonably claim to have endured. Waving arms in triumph outside the high court is no longer, if it ever was, proof of fair play or justice. Scapegoating never solved anything. Constant action to correct injustice across the board is the one and only solution.
Bill Abbotts
Foxton, Cambs
mail@cambridgeiq.com

 The judgment has revealed the historian to be a cynical manipulator of historical information. His views are distasteful, extreme and offensive to the vast majority. But this does not excuse the disgraceful behaviour of those outside the court who threw eggs at Mr Irving.The crimes of the Nazis were far from unique. The mass murder carried out in the name of international communism surpassed even the evil of Hitler. We must not allow communist sympathisers and apologists to brand their form of extremism as purely anti-Nazi. Hard-line extremists, whether of the right or left, are cynical manipulators of the truth.
Chris Kelly
Wolverhampton
chrisdkelly@hotmail.com

 Goethe stated that "I do not know myself, and God forbid that I should". Unfortunately this will never be a tangible concern for Irving.
Mike Evans
Liverpool

fields.headline: Soldiers held after brawls
fields.standfirst:
Nato disputes Macedonian claims over drunken clashes in Skopje

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: As many as 30 US soldiers on leave from Kosovo were taken into custody in the Macedonian capital Skopje yesterday after drunken clashes with local police, the country's interior ministry claimed.
fields.body:
As many as 30 US soldiers on leave from Kosovo were taken into custody in the Macedonian capital Skopje yesterday after drunken clashes with local police, the country's interior ministry claimed.

Both Nato and the US military confirmed there had been three separate incidents involving American troops in Skopje but insisted that only five servicemen had been temporarily detained by Macedonian police. They were later turned over to US military authorities.

One US military source suggested that in at least two of the clashes the US soldiers had not initiated violence but had reacted after being provoked. In one incident, according to an official, "an American soldier was spat on by a Macedonian; the soldier reacted to that and was detained by Macedonian police".

In another incident, two American soldiers tried to prevent a Macedonian from stealing the belongings of one of the them. In the third incident, "four soldiers at a restaurant were in some type of verbal altercation with the staff at the restaurant and possibly police". All four soldiers were detained, the official confirmed.

"The Macedonians elected to not exercise legal jurisdiction on the soldiers and return them to US military authorities," he said, dismissing the report of 30 soldiers being detained as a "fabrication".

But a Macedonian interior ministry statement said the soldiers, members of Nato-led peacekeeping troops, had been detained in connection with "indecent behaviour, violation of public order, harassment of citizens and a fight involving a policeman". Some were drunk, the statement said.

Speaking in Skopje for K-For, the peacekeeping force in Kosovo, Captain Andreas Reinecke said the force "deeply regretted" the incidents. A US sergeant who was involved said the trouble had started because the Americans were drunk and loud. "Everyone went out, and the fight started," the sergeant said.

Macedonia serves as the main staging post for international peacekeepers travelling into and out of Kosovo.

Serbian police yesterday blamed foreign intelligence services for an explosion that damaged a branch of the ruling Socialist party in Belgrade.

Colonel Milenko Ercic, head of the Serbian capital's criminal police, said the blast on Tuesday night had been a terrorist act designed to create chaos before an opposition rally on Friday against the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic.

Opposition leaders denied any involvement in the blast and said the explosion had been a set-up by the state, which was trying to raise tension in the lead-up the rally.

Konstantin Testorides is an AP correspondent

webTitle: Euro vote 'lets GM companies off the hook'

fields.headline: Euro vote 'lets GM companies off the hook'
fields.standfirst:
Ruling by MEPs rocks environmental groups
GM food: special report
The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Opponents of genetically modified food were left reeling yesterday after the European parliament ruled that big GM producers, such as Monsanto, should not be held legally responsible if their food turned out to be harmful for humans or the environment.
fields.body:
Opponents of genetically modified food were left reeling yesterday after the European parliament ruled that big GM producers, such as Monsanto, should not be held legally responsible if their food turned out to be harmful for humans or the environment.

In a vote which attracted fierce lobbying from biotechnology companies and environmental groups, MEPs rejected moves to make GM firms liable for their product by 287 votes to 202. The parliament now has far greater powers and has equal decision-making authority with national governments when it comes to certain legislative domains such as GM food.

The Labour MEP David Bowe, who tabled the original liability proposal, said MEPs had let GM corporations off the hook. "They say their products are safe, but today's vote shows they are clearly not prepared to put their money where their mouth is. If GM companies have no confidence in their products' safety, why should European consumers?

"In the face of pressure from industry and opposition from the European commission, GM liability has been kicked into touch once again."

In a further blow to GM activists, MEPs endorsed a system for approving GM products, which is expected to be in place by the end of the year. New GM crops and foodstuffs could be submitted to Brussels for sale in Britain soon afterwards. However, the EU approval process is lengthy.

Worries about GM technology have meant that no new crops have been approved for use in the EU since April 1998, but yesterday's vote effectively breaks that deadlock. Most UK Conservative MEPs voted against liability, arguing that the firms should not be forced to comply with overly harsh regulations. "We believe that the industry should not be in any worse position with regard to liability than any other area of environmental risk," they said in a statement after the vote.

Large GM firms, represented by a lobbying coalition called Europabio, interpreted yesterday's result as a ringing endorsement of GM food. In a press release the group said: "Consumers now can hope to reap the benefits of plant biotechnology soon. The vote is therefore good news for European citizens and for the European bioindustries alike."

Europabio had argued that if GM companies were made legally liable for damage caused by their products they could be saddled with unreasonable costs and a huge amount of red tape. It was adamant yesterday, however, that GM technology was entirely safe. "Safety of products is the overriding consideration." The companies' safety measures should be "more than enough" to satisfy consumers. There was some solace for campaigners yesterday since MEPs agreed in principle to include the GM liability issue in more general plans for environmental liability to be drawn up by 2002.

But such a move cannot come soon enough for green MEPs and environmental groups.

"The whole package is a present to the industry, because it will do nothing to reduce public mistrust and will increase the pressure for local initiatives to keep out GMOs," the German Green Hiltrut Breyer predicted.

Friends of the Earth said MEPs had failed Europe's citizens. "Consumers should know that when they buy GMO products they are dealing with companies which don't accept responsibility for potential damage caused by their products," said spokesman Dan Leskien.

EU governments, including Britain, have already approved a new authorisation procedure for GMOs - far stricter than its predecessor, which attracted widespread criticism from GM firms and green groups.

Now a licence for a GM product will last 10 years only. The US, the world's biggest grower of GM crops and the base of many GM firms, has been pressing the EU to get a new system up and running.

 Biotech companies are exaggerating the health benefits of GM foods in an effort to reverse the tide of opposition, a report said yesterday.

It argued that fighting poverty, improving education and sanitation and encouraging consumption of more fruit, vegetables, eggs and cheese would do more to improve nutrition of people in developing countries than the arrival of GM rice and other crops.

Its authors, Sue Dibb of the Food Commission campaign group and Sue Mayer of GeneWatch UK, said claims of benefits for consumers in the industrialised world were also "much hyped" when there was little evidence that even new non-GM "functional foods", such as bio-yogurts, bread with fish oil or soft drinks with added fibre, did much to improve health.

GM soya and maize is already used in many processed foods, but the report, Biotech - the next generation, said new developments in GM crops were still aimed at making food manufacture easier or cheaper, through use of GM oils to make chocolate or margarine, or ingredients in animal feed, cosmetics and biodegradable products.

Ms Dibb said the industry was making "a desperate attempt to reverse its failing fortunes". Dr Mayer said the new foods "may pose safety risks that the current system is unable to deal with".

Greenpeace: Genetic Engineering
Friends of the Earth: GM Food

Food for our Future

fields.headline: Court releases Israel's Lebanese hostages
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Thirteen Lebanese prisoners, kidnapped and held by Israel to trade for the release of a missing airman, are to be freed after years in isolation, following a landmark decision by the supreme court yesterday.
fields.body:
Thirteen Lebanese prisoners, kidnapped and held by Israel to trade for the release of a missing airman, are to be freed after years in isolation, following a landmark decision by the supreme court yesterday.

"This means that the Israeli state can not hold hostages, even for such an important aim as returning the missing navigator Ron Arad," said Zvi Rish, the Lebanese detainees' lawyer. "Even though the end is important it cannot justify all the means."

The verdict - the product of a nine-year legal battle - is the latest in a series of recent rulings which suggest that the Israeli judicial system is trying to adjust to the social changes under way since the Oslo peace accords in 1993.

Last month the court issued a decision enabling an Arab couple to buy a house in a Jewish town. Late last year it banned torture by the intelligence services.

Israel kidnapped two dozen Lebanese, holding some of them virtually incommunicado for as long as 14 years, after Mr Arad was captured alive by Amal militiamen when his plane was shot down over Lebanon in 1986. Since then, theyhave been seen in public only once, during an Israeli television interview. They were denied meat for the first 10 years of their detention because Israel refused to have it ritually slaughtered.

Following yesterday's ruling, 13 detainees are to be freed by Monday and returned to Lebanon, a prison spokesman said. Although the most prominent captives, the Shia Muslim spiritual leader Sheikh Obeid and the Amal militia leader Mustafa Dirani, will not be among them, Mr Rish said he hoped the verdict could pave the way for their eventual release.

Last month Mr Dirani filed a suit for 6m shekels (£1m) in damages, claiming that he was raped by his interrogators in the month after his abduction. His nephew, said by Israeli doctors to be suffering from schizophrenia, was released last week. Five others were released in December as a goodwill gesture at the start of peace talks with Syria, which have since collapsed.

The 6-3 ruling by an extended panel of the court in a closed session overturns a 1997 decision that the detention was lawful. Mr Rish said yesterday that he owed his victory to the remorse of the chief of the supreme court, Aharon Barak, for that decision.

"Chief Justice Barak has changed his mind and in the verdict he is saying bravely that since that verdict three years ago he could not stop thinking about it. Over and over, he thought about that mistake, and now he has the courage to admit he was wrong."

But the verdict was condemned by Mr Arad's mother as a "betrayal" of her son, and by a senior army officer, who said the kidnappings were seen at the time as an effective way of security the officer's release.

fields.headline: EU attacks 'paranoid' UK press
fields.standfirst: Nine-page report names and shames papers guilty of distortionsThe European Commission: special report The European Commission press watch report
fields.trailText: The European commission yesterday launched a fight-back against the British press for its "jingoistic" and "paranoid" reporting of Brussels which has contributed to growing demands for Britain to withdraw from Europe.
fields.body:
The European commission yesterday launched a fight-back against the British press for its "jingoistic" and "paranoid" reporting of Brussels which has contributed to growing demands for Britain to withdraw from Europe.

Exasperated by the refusal of the Press Complaints Commission to upbraid newspapers for "distorted" reporting, the commission published a nine-page report that named and shamed the worst offenders.

The list is topped by the Mirror for a report in February which likened officials who implement EU directives to Nazi collaborators. The Daily Mail came second with a report that accused the EU of funding IRA arms dumps.

"These stories demonstrate nothing more than paranoia," Geoffrey Martin, head of the European commission's London office, said yesterday.

Mr Martin reeled off a series of examples to prove that British newspapers deliberately misled their readers in an attempt to portray the EU as a "foreign body trying to impose its will on a hapless and helpless" Britain.

In a section headed "mythomania", the Express is ridiculed for suggesting that Brussels wanted to ban the "great British toilet". The report points out that there is no such European rule, merely new safety guidelines that will give British people a chance to buy European-style lavatories.

The Sunday Times and Independent on Sunday are also rebuked for reports that Brussels had ordered London to provide theatre-goers with more leg-room and was preparing to harmonise the size of condoms. The newspaper's reports referred to the European standardisation committee, which is not an EU body.

Mr Martin said yesterday he had been driven to compile his report because newspapers had repeatedly refused to print corrections and the PCC was unwilling to reprimand newspapers for inaccuracies.

"No one objects to the right of political opponents of the EU to argue their strongly held views," Mr Martin said. "But democrats everywhere know that commentary based on disingenuous assumptions demands correction or at least a right of reply. This is increasingly difficult to achieve."

He said the distorted reporting of Brussels had created "deep-seated" ignorance about Europe which had led to a marked increase in support for British withdrawal.

The commission's report is the latest example of how pro-Europeans have started to hit back at Eurosceptics who have dominated arguments over the EU for the past decade. The Britain in Europe pressure group has a Millbank-style rapid rebuttal unit and Downing Street rounded on the press last month for trivialising the Lisbon summit at which British led moves to liberalise EU markets.

One pro-European Labour MP, who believes that most British press reports about the EU "qualify for the Booker prize", said the commission's report was a mistake. Denis MacShane, the MP for Rotherham, said: "The EU should let its accomplishments speak for themselves."

Mr MacShane, an aide to the foreign secretary, said papers should follow the example of their continental counterparts, which are critical without lapsing into "gross distortions". "Look at the way Libération in France destroyed the career of the French commissioner, Edith Cresson," he said.

Eurosceptic newspapers last night dismissed the report. The Sun's veteran political editor, Trevor Kavanagh, said: "We are sceptical because we regard the EU as corrupt and anti-democratic. It is therefore difficult to see how we can simply accept decisions on issues like taxation without severely criticising them."

webTitle: 'We are black men. That means we make babies'

fields.headline: 'We are black men. That means we make babies'
fields.standfirst: They're known as 'baby fathers' - black men who have children with more than one partner. But while some white women lust after them, many black women have had enough.  Yasmin Alibhai-Brown reports
fields.trailText: They're known as 'baby fathers' - black men who have children with more than one partner. But while some white women lust after them, many black women have had enough.
fields.body:
This has been an extraordinary week for Patrick Augustus. His autobiographical novel Baby Fathers has been optioned by the BBC. It is a bold move because the theme - young black men who have children with a number of women and wear this as a badge of honour - is usually left well alone by anxious white liberals and radical anti-racists who are always wary of "encouraging" racism.

The deal is worth nearly £1m and Augustus, himself a father of five, is delighted if a little bemused. He is your proud, black, urban man with all those subversive traits that are irresistible to many women and deeply threatening to white men. Last winter he brought another baby father, Victor, to talk to me about his children for a book I am writing.

There was, said a weary Victor, the problem of the new black woman who no longer indulges men like him: "They're changing, man. Three strikes and you're out. They want their BMW man who will come home bringing flowers, a happy-ever-after life. Most black men can't provide this."

Patrick, a local hero among south London lads, believes that men who womanise are victims of circumstance and of wily women who know exactly how to exert power using their sexuality: "There is a lot of animosity between black men and black women today. Black men reject intelligent black women and go with young girls who look up to them. You know, give them comfort because it is hard being a black man. Sad to say, what starts as a dance or a flirtation, ends up as a baby. And let me tell you, there are a number of men who never agreed to be fathers. It was the girls who decided and who went ahead."

This may well be the case sometimes. But again and again and again? What about personal responsibility, what about restraint? And the boasting which we have both heard from baby fathers about their big and small babies? Is this not living down to the worst stereotypes of black men?

Yes and no, says Paul, 23, a computer programmer who "visits" three baby mothers at the moment, two black and one white: "Yes we are doing what society expects. Just like Darcus [Howe] once said. We are black men, that means we make babies all the time. I try to buy them nice things and I would break anyone who tried to harm my kids. But try to go inside our heads. We are kept out of everything. The one place we know we can win, where the white man is no good, is in bed. This is where we can be kings. That is what I thought when I was young. All my children were born before I was 21."

It is essential not to see this only as a "black" problem. Young white men have as many partners and children. All around us there are black fathers and partners - Sir Herman Ouseley, Paul Boateng and a host of others - who are role models for all of society. Writing in Black British Feminism, the academic Tracey Reynolds rightly criticises the dangerously simplistic way this subject has been dealt with in the media, but you only have to read the Voice to see that it is now perceived as a major area of concern.

The 1991 census recorded that 49% of Afro-Caribbean families are headed by a lone mother compared with 14% in the general population. Some are high achievers who have made the decision to go it alone, partly because they cannot find the man and relationship they want. These are self-determining baby mothers rather than gullible victims of baby fathers.

Others are lone mothers as a result of death, divorce and other "normal" events. But a substantial number are young, poor and emotionally vulnerable. But even these women do seem to be getting more sussed.

Sadie, 19, has two children by two men who are friends: "I am stupid. I thought they were the coolest guys, and I was so lucky. They were great dancers and they look at you and you melt. But now I just want to look after my boys. I don't want them to grow up like their dads - all talk and nothing else."

Donna, finally decided to throw out Wayne, the father of her child and another by her arch rival in school, Aimee: "I think Aimee and I both had babies as a competition for a man who was never worth it. Then he started beating me up and said he would go off to her if I complained. And just to keep face I said nothing. Now some third woman is expecting his child. I will not let him near my child."

A number of other women have multiple partners themselves so that they are not dependent on the good will of one baby father. Patrick despises such women: "They want one man to fix the house, another for sex, one to take them partying. They use children as weapons and I have seen men crying over the way they are treated."

He has started a pressure group for men struggling against women who are becoming a little too much like baby fathers themselves. White baby mothers are, I think, less trouble. I spent an evening with a group of them recently and they were indeed desperate to be understanding. They talked about the effects of slavery on black men, and explained how it was possible to live with betrayal and double-standards. Lust was high on the list.

As Susie, 20, put it: "White men are boring and safe. A lot of white girls think black men have great bodies, like D'Angelo, and we want to have their babies because they are so beautiful. I like a cool, tough guy, you know."

Yet, according to research in progress by sociologist Ravinder Barn, these beautiful babies of white mothers are increasingly ending up in care mainly because the women find it so hard to cope. These women are isolated, disapproved of by both black and white communities, often abused. If they find a white partner, new problems can arise with the child and the baby father. Many do not want their children to go, but feel they have no option.

There may still be some women willing to oblige, but even Patrick now accepts that the good old days seem to be coming to an end for the baby father. He is worried, though, that his fame and fortune will make him a victim of an ambitious baby mother instead.

 Who Do We Think We Are? by Yasmin Alibhai-Brown is published by Penguin on April 27 at £19.99.

fields.headline: Cautious Bush courts gay vote
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The Republican presidential candidate, George W Bush, risks alienating his party's powerful moral conservative wing by meeting gay activists in Texas today. The meeting is part of an attempt by Mr Bush to rebuild bridges with traditionally pro-Democratic minorities before this year's presidential election.
fields.body:
The Republican presidential candidate, George W Bush, risks alienating his party's powerful moral conservative wing by meeting gay activists in Texas today. The meeting is part of an attempt by Mr Bush to rebuild bridges with traditionally pro-Democratic minorities before this year's presidential election.

Until now, Mr Bush has seemed to go out of his way not to court the gay vote, which accounts for 4-5% of the electorate. But after this year's primary contest, in which he concentrated on winning traditional conservative support to capture his party's nomination, the meeting marks a cautious attempt to reach out to more liberal voters.

His campaign team is treading carefully in advance of the meeting, anxious not to offer the anti-gay Reform party candidate, Pat Buchanan, a chance to make this a campaign issue. The get-together is being billed as a discussion of common ground on issues such as education, health care and tax.

"I welcome all people to my team," Mr Bush said. "I'm looking forward to the meeting."

In the past he has refused to meet Republican gay activists and has been evasive about whether he would appoint openly gay men and women to positions in his administration. He told a radio interviewer that he thought openly gay people would not share his conservative views. Nor has he promised to maintain the federal non-discrimination policy on the employment of gays.

Asked last year whether he would emulate his party rival for the nomination, John McCain, and meet representatives of the Log Cabin Republicans, an 11,000-strong gay rights pressure group, Mr Bush replied: "Probably not".

Leaders of the Log Cabin group have been excluded from today's meeting, organised by a gay PR executive in Washington whose brother is a Bush fundraiser. About a dozen gay and lesbian people are expected to attend, including a Bush campaign official.

In 1992 Bill Clinton took 87% of gay votes when he defeated President George Bush. Recent surveys have shown a steady Democrat lead of two-to-one among gays.

Liberal Republicans such as the New York mayor Rudolph Giuliani and the New Jersey governor Christine Todd Whitman - a possible Bush vice-presidential nominee - are among the few party members who are prominent supporters of gay rights.

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.trailText: Quotes of the week.
fields.body:
"When women ask why there aren't more funny women around, I say, you have to start writing for yourself. I blame the women who sit at dinner parties just listening to men telling their stories. Why is that? Why do we only feel confident when we are in the powder room together?"

Comedian Doon Mackichan of Smack the Pony, Observer.

"I tried to kill her. I put a cushion on her face. I'd been trying to sleep for ages - I finally snapped."

Raymond Bentley, who put a cushion over his wife's face and a hand around her neck and pleaded guilty to causing her actual bodily harm.

"I have never tried HRT, I have always done it the natural way. I've been a personal trainer for 25 years and I've been natural. Having a facelift is natural. It's just a little tuck and help. A subtle procedure I call it. It was a natural progression for me."

Angie Best, George Best's ex-wife on the meaning of the word natural, Sun

"The major plus of being in a soap opera on the radio is that appearance doesn't matter... When I was bigger, I was always forced into stereotypical TV roles. In one drama, every scene saw me stuffing my face with doughnuts. As a large person I knew this wasn't realistic and that fat people hate to scoff food in front of others. I understand why so many actresses have eating disorders - there is such pressure in the media. Being in the Archers I escape that to a degree."

Lucy Davis who plays Hayley in the Archers, Woman's Journal

"What? Marriage? Lousy. I want my own way too much."

Ann Widdecombe's response to being asked whether she would have been good at marriage, Evening Standard

"Frank Dobson sometimes tells me a good one but I can never remember them! My current favourite: what do toilet bowls, birthdays and the clitoris have in common? Men miss them."

Mo Mowlam, Independent

"When I see pictures of me then, it makes me so sad. I look so miserable, haunted - like a rabbit caught in the headlights. It was such a confusing time because I was being pushed and pulled in both directions - held up for my looks and, at the same time, condemned for them."

Jodie Kidd reflects on past speculation that she was suffering from anorexia, Elle

fields.headline: Next please
fields.standfirst: A university student complained this week that if you're not a bimbo or a bloke, you're doomed as an actor.  Anita Chaudhuri isn't surprised
fields.trailText: A university student complained this week that if you're not a bimbo or a bloke, you're doomed as an actor.  Anita Chaudhuri isn't surprised
fields.body:
It was with a wry smile that I read about the plight of Cambridge student Jennifer Tuckett, the 20-year-old who claims she has been discriminated against by that strong-hold of male supremacy on campus, the student drama society.

No doubt she turned up for the first auditions with dreams of becoming the next Emma Thompson or Tilda Swinton, both of whom made their stage debuts at the same university. Alas, in her first role she had to strip to her underwear for the farce Noises Off. To her dismay, other productions hardly had any roles at all for women. "I felt that I was being passed off as a blonde bimbo," she complained. "Everything was so male-dominated and incredibly intimidating. All the writers and directors are male, and all the best parts were going to men."

Now, I'm sure that she is not going to thank me for pointing this out, but it strikes me that she is one of the lucky ones. When I was a drama student at Glasgow University some years ago, I would have given anything to have been passed off as a fluffy blonde. Then at least I might have been invited to audition for something more glamorous than the assistant stage manager on Coriolanus or the lead in an all-woman production of Alfred Jarry's Ubu Roi (I got the part, but no one knew it was me as I was wearing an enormous pantomime mask). Fortunately, my heart was never set on a theatre career, but many of my female contemporaries went on to devote their entire academic career to the ritual humiliation of being turned down for auditions. "Sorry, you don't look remotely doll-like," snapped the director of The Doll's House to a skinny, punky-haired friend of mine who begged to be considered. And after graduation it was super-confident boys such as Orphans-director and actor Peter Mullan who went on to achieve fame and fortune, while the girls vanished into the mists of backstage obscurity.

It's a sad fact that student drama groups tend to attract only two types of people - the intimidating male director who drones on endlessly about sending off his CV to the director's course at the Bristol Old Vic and the impossibly pretty girl who can't act but can cry on demand (usually when the director threatens to chuck her). Somehow, these two manage to assemble a cast around them. The question is whether, in a professional context, things get any better.

Vicky Featherstone, director of Paines Plough, a theatre company which showcases new writing, believes that the criteria on which new actresses are judged is having a detrimental effect on film and theatre as a whole. "A lot of women are put off ever going into the profession because they know they will be judged on issues such as body image and the way they photograph rather than their acting ability," she says. When Featherstone herself was a student at Manchester University she initially wanted to be an actress. "But I changed my mind when I realised what was involved. Now, in my position as a director, I'm aware that actresses are in a vulnerable position and I do take that responsibility quite seriously. Even then, I have to battle with myself not to second-guess whom the audience might find attractive - I try to focus on who will be best for the part."

Featherstone lays much of the blame with drama schools' selection process. "Often, selection panels try to compile a perfect theatre company out of any given year, so there will be a predominance of men because there are more parts for them and they will choose a couple of big-busted funny girls and a couple of Juliet lookalikes," she says. "There are new theatre companies breaking the mould. But if you look at the RSC or the National, they stick to an aesthetic ideal."

Actress Saffron Burrows believes that acting comes naturally to women, because for much of our lives we have to pretend to be more confident than we are. "Most actresses say they have no idea how they got there, that they're winging it," she says. "Every single casting decision is based on appearance, whatever your gender. For women, it becomes harsher as you become older and then there's a complete disparity between men and women and what is deemed attractive. In films it is much more vulgar, because the casting decisions are made by the money men."

Jennifer Tuckett, meanwhile, thinks she has found a solution to counteract the exclusion. She has just set up a women's theatre club, Vanya Women Productions, and already has a play in production entitled the Sex Files. Men are being allowed to audition, but it remains to be seen whether they will be allowed to keep their clothes on.

Then at least I might have been invited to audition for something more glamorous than the assistant stage manager on Coriolanus or the lead in an all-woman production of Alfred Jarry's Ubu Roi (I got the part, but no one knew it was me as I was wearing an enormous pantomime mask). Fortunately, my heart was never set on a theatre career, but many of my female contemporaries went on to devote their entire academic career to the ritual humiliation of being turned down for auditions. "Sorry, you don't look remotely doll-like," snapped the director of The Doll's House to a skinny, punky-haired friend of mine who begged to be considered. And after graduation it was super-confident boys such as Orphans-director and actor Peter Mullan who went on to achieve fame and fortune, while the girls vanished into the mists of backstage obscurity. It's a sad fact that student drama groups tend to attract only two types of people - the intimidating male director who drones on endlessly about sending off his CV to the director's course at the Bristol Old Vic and the impossibly pretty girl who can't act but can cry on demand (usually when the director threatens to chuck her). Somehow, these two manage to assemble a cast around them. The question is whether, in a professional context, things get any better. Vicky Featherstone, director of Paines Plough, a theatre company which showcases new writing, believes that the criteria on which new actresses are judged is having a detrimental effect on film and theatre as a whole. "A lot of women are put off ever going into the profession because they know they will be judged on issues such as body image and the way they photograph rather than their acting ability," she says. When Featherstone herself was a student at Manchester University she initially wanted to be an actress. "But I changed my mind when I realised what was involved. Now, in my position as a director, I'm aware that actresses are in a vulnerable position and I do take that responsibility quite seriously. Even then, I have to battle with myself not to second-guess whom the audience might find attractive - I try to focus on who will be best for the part." Featherstone lays much of the blame with drama schools' selection process. "Often, selection panels try to compile a perfect theatre company out of any given year, so there will be a predominance of men because there are more parts for them and they will choose a couple of big-busted funny girls and a couple of Juliet lookalikes," she says. "There are new theatre companies breaking the mould. But if you look at the RSC or the National, they stick to an aesthetic ideal." Actress Saffron Burrows believes that acting comes naturally to women, because for much of our lives we have to pretend to be more confident than we are. "Most actresses say they have no idea how they got there, that they're winging it," she says. "Every single casting decision is based on appearance, whatever your gender. For women, it becomes harsher as you become older and then there's a complete disparity between men and women and what is deemed attractive. In films it is much more vulgar, because the casting decisions are made by the money men." Jennifer Tuckett, meanwhile, thinks she has found a solution to counteract the exclusion. She has just set up a women's theatre club, Vanya Women Productions, and already has a play in production entitled the Sex Files. Men are being allowed to audition, but it remains to be seen whether they will be allowed to keep their clothes on.

webTitle: Feng shui sows seeds of conflict

fields.headline: Feng shui sows seeds of conflict
fields.trailText: A father and son yesterday resigned from their jobs as tomato growers claiming that the introduction of feng shui to boost the harvest   clashed with their religious beliefs.
fields.body:
A father and son yesterday resigned from their jobs as tomato growers claiming that the introduction of feng shui to boost the harvest clashed with their religious beliefs.

Martin Kelly, 45, and his 20-year-old son Paul-Martin Kelly, who are both Baptists, said they could no longer work at Arreton Valley nursery on the Isle of Wight.

"I'm not working for a farm that openly claims that it relies on a power other than God," Mr Kelly said yesterday. "The only power that I believe in is the power of God. I pushed aside money worries and have put my faith in God. It put me in conflict with my faith. I would not be able to sleep at night.

"It was a no win situation because no matter how hard anyone works, any success would be put down to the power of feng shui and it negates the efforts of the workforce."

A British Tomato Growers' Association spokeswoman said the ancient oriental art of feng shui had nothing to do with religion and everything to do with nature.

"We were surprised they decided to leave and would be extremely surprised if any other growers decided to leave," she added.

The feng shui policy, used in conjunction with a swarm of bees to help pollinate the plants, was introduced earlier this week by Tomato Growers' Association members.

A team of experts skilled in the Chinese art visited glasshouses across the country, advising on the siting of the hives for the 2.5m bumblebees imported from Belgium and Holland.

webTitle: Labour looks for Gore campaign for tax tips

fields.headline: Labour looks for Gore campaign for tax tips
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power: special report
The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Labour has started to build links with the Al Gore presidential campaign, hoping at the general election to mirror his plan to paint George Bush as a rightwinger with tax figures that fail to add up.
fields.body:
Labour has started to build links with the Al Gore presidential campaign, hoping at the general election to mirror his plan to paint George Bush as a rightwinger with tax figures that fail to add up.

Labour has settled on winning a historic second term in government by pushing the public perception of William Hague to the right, by seeking to cost ruthlessly his spending pledges and then counter them with his promise to cut taxes as a proportion of GDP.

Members of the Downing Street policy unit this week met with leading members of the Gore campaign staff.

Tony Blair's office is also said to be in regular contact with Bob Shrum, one of the vice president's most senior advisors.

Mr Shrum has told Labour that Mr Gore was starting to pull ahead of Mr Bush by using campaign techniques to pain him as a rightwing extremist, and that the Gore briefing room was repeatedly portraying the Bush tax-and-spend promises as being incredible.

The Gore campaign cited a Wall Street Journal report that Bush "is carrying an extra burden: he must find the money to pay for health initiatives while also pushing for a big tax cut".

The briefing continued by saying that Bush was pushing a $2.1 trillion tax giveaway that exceeded the projected available budget surplus by nearly $1 trillion, according to an independent study by the Citizens for Tax Justice.

Labour believes that the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, will be unable to pull out of the Conservatives' tax guarantee made by Mr Hague, when he promised to reduce the overall burden of tax as a proportion of GDP.

The Treasury is already costing some of the Conservative pledges, including those on health, welfare, education, asylum and defence. It is not clear whether Labour will use civil servants to make the costings, although such a practice was used in the past by the Conservatives.

Amongst the Labour figures who have travelled to the US in recent months are Philip Gould, the party's pollster and strategist, who was one of the architects of the 1997 victory and is also a long term ally of the Clinton Democrats. He is already drawing up the dividing lines on which Labour would prefer to fight the election, expected to be next spring.

Douglas Alexander, the Paisley South MP and a close ally of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, has also been to the US. Mr Brown is leading the team forming Labour's campaign strategy, while Peter Mandelson is to be responsbile for its detailed implementation.

Mr Mandelson, despite his duties as Northern Ireland secretary, has already found time to make his presence felt at Millbank, the party headquarters. Millbank's official chief, the party's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, is also expected to go to the Democrat party's convention in the summer.

Shaun Woodward, the Witney MP who defected from the Tories last summer and masterminded the Tories' 1992 general election campaign, also visited the Gore campaign in February and is due to make another visit next month. Mr Woodward is being asked to advise Mr Brown and Mr Mandelson on how to fight rightwing populist tax campaigns.

At a day long Cabinet meeting recently, Labour agreed that it should not make the mistake of retreating to its heartlands vote, insisting that the middle class/working class coalition that won the 1997 election needs to be retained.

However, the party has agreed to alter some of the rhetoric and try to shed its so called "control freak" image. At one point party strategists even considered a further move of headquarters and leaving Millbank, which is something of a symbol of control freakery.
