fields.headline: Weapons lost from army base
fields.trailText: Detectives were last night investigating the disappearance of weapons from an army base at Larkhill, Wiltshire, after a routine check yesterday showed more than 30 guns to be missing.
fields.body:
Detectives were last night investigating the disappearance of weapons from an army base at Larkhill, Wiltshire, after a routine check yesterday showed more than 30 guns to be missing.

The Ministry of Defence said 19 9mm Browning pistols, 13 shotguns and three starter pistols were missing from the 14 Regiment Royal Artillery base at Larkhill.

The weapons are thought to have disappeared during the night, but an MoD spokesman was unable to comment on whether there had been a break-in at the armoury. He said the matter was being investigated by the police and army's special investigation branch.

Some of the shotguns were privately owned by base personnel. "There's no ammunition missing, but obviously it is important that we establish the whereabouts of the weapons as soon as we can."

webTitle: Rare antelope slaughtered for fashion shawls

fields.headline: Rare antelope slaughtered for fashion shawls
fields.trailText: The population of a rare Tibetan antelope was severely hit by poachers who slaughtered them and then smuggled luxury shawls made from their hair to a shop in London, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The population of a rare Tibetan antelope was severely hit by poachers who slaughtered them and then smuggled luxury shawls made from their hair to a shop in London, a court heard yesterday.

More than 1,000 chiru antelope, representing up to 2% of the species' population, were killed to make 138 shahtoosh shawls for the Renaissance Corporation, an Indian company which has a crafts shop in central London. The firm pleaded guilty to trading goods from an endangered species.

Horseferry Road magistrates' court heard how the shawls were discovered after the Metropolitan police received a call from the wildlife department of the Indian police in November 1996. The Indian police had intercepted an consignment of the shawls in Delhi which were on their way to the London shop.

Shawls worth more than £353,000 were found at the shop, with price tags varying between £640 and £13,000.

Shahtoosh, which means "king of wools" in Persian, can only be collected by skinning the chiru antelope, which lives in Tibet and China's hilly north western regions of Xinjiang and Qinghai.

The chiru has been listed as an endangered species under the convention for international trade of endangered species since 1975. Britain is one of the signatories to the Cites convention and trade of chiru has been illegal here since 1979.

The Renaissance Corporation changed hands in March 1998. Peter Binning, representing the new Indian based owners, told the court they were prepared to accept responsibility for the shop's illegal importing activities.

Officers from the Metropolitan police's wildlife unit said last night they were satisfied with the outcome of the three year investigation.

The Renaissance Corporation was fined £1,500 for illegal importing plus £350 costs and the shawls will be confiscated to be burned by the Met.

fields.headline: £200,000 for model who lost leg
fields.trailText: Sir Paul McCartney's new girlfriend Heather Mills is to receive £200,000 damages for the accident involving a police motorcycle in which she lost a leg, Scotland Yard confirmed last night.
fields.body:
Sir Paul McCartney's new girlfriend Heather Mills is to receive £200,000 damages for the accident involving a police motorcycle in which she lost a leg, Scotland Yard confirmed last night.

The 32-year-old former model, whose relationship with Sir Paul was made public last month, lost her left leg in a road accident in 1993.

Following a report in the Mirror newspaper, a Scotland Yard spokeswoman said: "An out of court settlement was made... without any admission of liability."

Ms Mills, from Washington, Tyne and Wear, had been a swimwear model until she lost a leg below the knee when a police motorcycle hit her as she crossed a road in London. The officer was cleared by magistrates of driving carelessly.

She battled back to health and devoted much of her time to helping others with similar disabilities and promoting fund-raising efforts for landmine victims.

Her relationship with Sir Paul, 57, began after they met through their charity work over a year ago.

Ms Mills told the Mirror: "I would never have sued, but the officer launched a damages suit against me so I had no choice."

webTitle: Easter eggs poor value for money

fields.headline: Easter eggs poor value for money
fields.trailText: Excessive packaging is cutting the value for money to be had from Easter eggs, according to trading standards officers.
fields.body:
Excessive packaging is cutting the value for money to be had from Easter eggs, according to trading standards officers.

Confectionery companies were charging up to six times more per 100g of chocolate for Easter eggs than for ordinary chocolate bars, the officers from Brent council in London found from a survey of at 33 Easter eggs to examine the ratio between weight and packaging. The eggs ranged from 99p to £12.99, with net weights from 65g to 970g.

The results, to be shown on BBC1's Watchdog programme, found the most expensive egg per 100g to be Marks & Spencer's £4.99 Flower Egg, which works out at £2.70 per 100g, compared with 46p for the average bar of chocolate. The packaging provided 44% of the M&S egg's total weight.

Even the cheapest egg per 100g, Nestle's Smarties egg, was still 81p for that weight.

M&S, however, also produced the egg with the least amount of packaging: the 200g milk chocolate egg with truffles. It was wrapped in foil that provided only 8% of total weight, but the egg broke in transit from the store.

Packaging accounted for 21% of the weight of the £2.99 Quality Street egg and the £9.99 Mars egg. Packaging on a 200g chocolate bar weighs only 2% of the total, and on a box of Terry's All Gold it registers only 15%.

Comparing the weight per egg with volume of the box, the officers found a King Size Mars egg offered only 1g of chocolate for every 36 cubic cm of packaging.

Trading standards officer Steve Playle said the award, if there was one, for a best value egg would go to the 105g Nestle Smarties egg, which had one of the lowest percentages of packaging, was the least deceptive and had the lowest unit price.

A European directive required all packaging to be kept to a minimum, he said."Excessive packaging uses up valuable resources in its manufacture and costs extra money to be disposed of."

fields.headline: Options open on looted art
fields.trailText: The government will today promise to give "very serious" consideration to any recommendations for the return of art looted by the Nazis from Jewish owners. But it will stop short of promising legislation to allow the restitution of paintings from British national collections.
fields.body:
The government will today promise to give "very serious" consideration to any recommendations for the return of art looted by the Nazis from Jewish owners. But it will stop short of promising legislation to allow the restitution of paintings from British national collections.

Arts minister Alan Howarth reveals in the Guardian today that he will be recommending a range of possible resolutions of claims to his newly appointed advisory committee on looted art.

These moves include restitution of works of art, financial compensation, or moral recompense by displaying an object's history beside it.

However, Mr Howarth has rejected calls for automatic restitution of the actual looted object. "We do not think it right to prejudge the panel's hearings in this way," he said.

Mr Howarth will be announcing the membership and terms of reference of the spoliation advisory panel in reply to a parliamentary question today.

The preliminary study of the British national collections, published last month, left question marks over the provenance of 350 paintings and sculptures, whose history during the Nazi years cannot be proven beyond doubt.

However, most British national collections are prohibited, by law, from disposing of any works for any reason.

Lord Janner, the Labour peer, and the commission on looted art, are among those who have been demanding a promise from the government that there will be restitution of the objects themselves.

Last night Anne Webber, chairwoman of the commission, was disappointed at the lack of commitment to legislation allowing restitution. "It appears this prodecure will leave Britain completely out of line with the rest of the world," she said.

fields.headline: Curfew on autograph forger
fields.trailText: A man who faked celebrity autographs was yesterday sentenced to six months of weekend curfews.
fields.body:
A man who faked celebrity autographs was yesterday sentenced to six months of weekend curfews.

Paul Wilson, 35, of Bridgham, Norfolk, offered forged signatures of Diana, Princess of Wales, John Lennon and Steve McQueen.

Wilson admitted 12 sample charges of obtaining property by deception by selling forged signatures to mail order customers at Norwich crown court in November.

Judge Paul Downes yesterday ordered him to remain indoors on Saturdays and Sundays between noon and 11pm. The court heard that he had repaid all complainants and that he had debts of more than £15,000. Karim Khalil, defending, said Wilson and his wife were working to clear their debts and that jailing him would be a catastrophe.

Police and trading standards officers began investigating when customers complained that Wilson's firm, Paul Wilson Autographs, had taken their money but sent nothing in return.

Trading standards officers then bought autographed pictures of footballers David Beckham and Michael Owen from Wilson and checked with the players, who said the signatures were forgeries.

webTitle: Five social services taken off list

fields.headline: Five social services taken off list
fields.trailText: Five social services authorities have been taken off the government's "special measures" list after showing improvements in their performance.
fields.body:
Five social services authorities have been taken off the government's "special measures" list after showing improvements in their performance.

John Hutton, the social care minister, said that the five - Buckinghamshire, Bury in Greater Manchester, Kingston upon Hull, Newcastle upon Tyne and Sefton on Merseyside - had achieved changes through the combined determination of councillors, managers and staff. There was "clear evidence" of improvement.

Mr Hutton had announced last November that 17 authorities in England were on special measures, by which they were to be kept under close scrutiny and required to report direct to ministers. Since then, Ealing in west London had become the first to be de-listed.

The 11 authorities remaining on the warning list, on notice that they could lose responsibility for social services unless they improve their performance, are: Barking and Dagenham in east London, Hackney in east London, Hillingdon in west London, Lambeth in south London, Barnsley, Cambridgeshire, Coventry, north-east Lincolnshire, Peterborough, Sheffield and Wirral.

fields.headline: Couple die in 'grudge' house fire
fields.trailText: Detectives are investigating the suspected grudge killing of a couple burned to death in their house less than two months after moving in.
fields.body:
Detectives are investigating the suspected grudge killing of a couple burned to death in their house less than two months after moving in.

Neighbours tried in vain to rescue the young man and woman, who have not been named, but were drive back by intense heat which melted windows.

A man staying at the terraced house and understood to be a friend of the couple is being interviewed by police. He leapt from a window as the fire took hold, and was treated in hospital for smoke inhalation and shock.

West Yorkshire police said that the fire in Normanton, near Wakefield, at 4.40am yesterday appeared to have been started deliberately outside the front door, and they were treating the case as murder. The house had been empty for months before the couple moved in.

fields.headline: Women's jail chief 'taunted by colleagues'
fields.trailText: One of the most senior women in the prison service claimed yesterday that she was humiliated, ignored and nicknamed "the baglady" after upsetting her superiors by campaigning for reforms.
fields.body:
One of the most senior women in the prison service claimed yesterday that she was humiliated, ignored and nicknamed "the baglady" after upsetting her superiors by campaigning for reforms.

Katie Dawson, former head of the women's jail at Risley, Cheshire, told an employment tribunal that she had been sidelined and passed over in favour of less experienced male colleagues when the prison was closed last year.

Mrs Dawson, 56, who had won praise for reaching the top of an often macho profession, said that she was the only member of staff at the women's prison to be left without consultation or advice on what job to do next.

She told the tribunal in Manchester that her role was so marginalised that she was left without an office and was derided as the Risley baglady - or rough sleeper - by junior colleagues.

Mrs Dawson said that her problems had begun on her appointment to head the jail in 1994, after a successful period as a senior governor at Strangeways prison, Manchester.

Her zeal for reform in a complex where 96 women shared one bath, and the lavatories still had urinals from the previous men's prison, had upset the system, she said.

"It was soon evident to me that the conditions afforded to the women were not up to the standards that male prisoners had. It was further obvious there was a lack of HQ strategy to deal with the problems of women's units," she said. She also raised concerns about bullying and violence among women prisoners, partly triggered by the miserable conditions.

Mrs Dawson said that she sensed that the waves she made were worsened by her spare-time novel writing, especially when a publisher accepted a romance based in jail.

The book, published under the pseudonym Maggie Marshall but based on Mrs Dawson's 25 years' experience in the prison service, described a love affair between a priest and a woman prisoner officer. The latter is subsequently taken hostage by a body-building lesbian inmate.

The tribunal heard that Risley's shortcomings were denounced in 1996 by the then chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, who paid a surprise visit to the women's jail.

He commended Mrs Dawson's efforts at reform, but she was moved sideways shortly afterwards to a newly-created position.

When she asked what it involved, she said, she was told: "You will just be there."

She was then passed over for a position as head of custody at the Risley complex, which also includes a men's prison and remand centre, and a younger and less qualified male colleague got the job.

She was persuaded not to go to an industrial tribunal at that stage because of the further embarrassment it would bring to the prison.

"Reforms were also begun," she said. "Most importantly, staffing was made up to levels where at long last inmates could have exercise, which was supposed to have been their statutory right."

But she decided to bring the case when the long-drawn-out death of the prison left her without a proper budget and "working with very demoralised colleagues".

Mrs Dawson, who now works at the Risley complex as head of inmate activities, said: "I am not a troublemaker, a feminist or any type of eccentric. There is discrimination and retaliation within the prison service, both towards inmates and staff.

"There are more male staff than woman, and challenging procedures and equality results in the position I have found myself in."

The hearing continues today.

webTitle: Bill aims to crack down on squatters

fields.headline: Bill aims to crack down on squatters
fields.trailText: Squatters will be stopped in most cases from acquiring ownership of property by occupying it for at least 12 years, under a bill being   drawn up by the government's law reform body.
fields.body:
Squatters will be stopped in most cases from acquiring ownership of property by occupying it for at least 12 years, under a bill being drawn up by the government's law reform body.

The move follows headlines over squatters who have acquired valuable houses and property by "adverse possession" after the owners - in most cases a council - forgot they were living there.

Last July Timothy Ellis, 38, was granted a court declaration that he owned the £200,000 four bedroom house in Brixton, south London, where he had squatted for 16 years. Lambeth council had ordered him out at one stage but then failed to take possession proceedings.

The bill, being drawn up by the law commission with the support of the lord chancellor, would apply to land registered at the land registry, which covers 80% of land in England and Wales. A squatter who wanted to become the property's owner would have to apply to the registry.

It would contact the registered owner who would have the right to object to the squatter's registration as owner. The owner would then be given two years to get the squatter out.

If the owner could not be traced or failed to evict the squatter within the two years, the squatter would be able to apply again and be registered as the new owner.

The bill, to be published later this year, will replace the law on land registration in the biggest project undertaken by the law commission.

The land registry already has a database of registered titles for 15m properties, which can be searched online.

webTitle: Set emotion aside, Noye jury told

fields.headline: Set emotion aside, Noye jury told
fields.trailText: The jury in the trial of Kenneth Noye was urged yesterday to set emotion aside and acquit him of murdering Stephen Cameron in a road rage attack solely on the evidence presented to the Old Bailey court.
fields.body:
The jury in the trial of Kenneth Noye was urged yesterday to set emotion aside and acquit him of murdering Stephen Cameron in a road rage attack solely on the evidence presented to the Old Bailey court.

Stephen Batten QC, defending, told jurors in his closing speech that they had to think of Noye as a "Mr Smith of whom you and the public have never heard".

He added: "It is not that you owe a debt to Kenneth Noye, but you owe a duty to the public you represent. Our society requires all trials to be fair. This one is no different." Jurors should base their decision on the evidence "and absolutely nothing else".

Noye, 52, denies murdering Mr Cameron, 21, at the Swanley interchange of the M25 on May 19, 1996, claiming that he stabbed him in self-defence because he had flown at him in a "wild rage".

The court heard that Noye fled the country after the incident because he feared he would not get a fair trial. Giving evidence, Noye admitted being sentenced to 14 years for dishonestly handling gold taken in the Brink's-Mat bullion robbery of 1983.

The court was also told that he was acquitted of murdering Detective Constable John Fordham, an undercover officer he found hiding in the grounds of his house 15 years ago. His defence then was that he was acting in self-defence.

Mr Batten told jurors they had heard evidence consistent with Noye's contention that he stabbed Mr Cameron only to defend himself.

Mr Justice Latham, summing up, said the jury must concentrate on what was happening when Noye stabbed his victim. "If you are satisfied he was not acting in the honest belief it was necessary, but it was in retaliation or to carry on a fight, the use of the knife was unlawful."

If the jury concluded that use of the knife was instinctive, and that Noye did not intend to cause serious injury but risked causing some harm, they could return a verdict of manslaughter. If they believed Noye was provoked, he would be guilty of manslaughter by reason of provocation.

The jury is due to retire to consider its verdict today.

fields.headline: Spotting tumours a decade early
fields.trailText: Breast cancer in some women might be detectable a decade before tumours become obvious, Merseyside scientists claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Breast cancer in some women might be detectable a decade before tumours become obvious, Merseyside scientists claimed yesterday.

A team from the University of Liverpool and Clatterbridge hospital in the Wirral said oestrogen receptor cells in the breasts of some women began to behave abnormally long before cancer began to develop.

Receptors cells are designed to handle the traffic in hormones and other proteins that keep people active and sentient.

"It has long been recognised that breast cancer may take a considerable time to form," said John Sloane, who led the team. "It is also understood that the female hormone oestrogen is closely linked to the disease.

"Perhaps something happens in their breast to make it unduly sensitive to the effects of normal oestrogen. We discovered that at an early stage, sometimes 10 or 15 years before the cancer develops, the oestrogen receptor cell, instead of behaving normally to make other cells divide, in fact divides itself, and this excessive division can lead to breast cancer."

Early detection increases the chance of a cure. Teams round the world are seeking ways to detect cancer formation in its first moments. Some hope to harness astronomical techniques to "spot" unusual cell behaviour. Others are experimenting with changes evident in blood tests, or using microwave "radar" systems to spot tiny tumours. The Merseyside group now have to confirm that early abnormalities are indeed a sign of cancers to come.

"There is very strong evidence that normal breast cells do not change into cancers in one step but pass through a series of intermediate stages," said Professor Sloane. "This research could eventually enable the progression of the disease to be intercepted."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
£1.2m for twin's birth injury
A 25-year-old woman who suffered severe brain damage during birth when doctors failed to realise she was one of twins was yesterday awarded £1,250,000 agreed compensation at the high court. Justine Lewis, of Wolverhampton, suffered oxygen starvation during her delivery at New Cross hospital in August 1974. Wolverhampton health authority had previously admitted medical staff were negligent.
fields.body:
£1.2m for twin's birth injury
A 25-year-old woman who suffered severe brain damage during birth when doctors failed to realise she was one of twins was yesterday awarded £1,250,000 agreed compensation at the high court. Justine Lewis, of Wolverhampton, suffered oxygen starvation during her delivery at New Cross hospital in August 1974. Wolverhampton health authority had previously admitted medical staff were negligent.

Dead baby found in bag
Police were last night hunting the mother of a new- born baby whose body was found in a carrier bag on a verge at a Gloucester housing estate. Police fear the child's mother needs medical attention.

Bank scam forces review
Lloyds TSB yesterday said it had tightened up procedures after four gang members were jailed for a total of 10 years for stealing cash from banks after getting hold of rubbish destined for shredding. They used the confidential waste to assume the identity of real people and take out cash, Hove crown court in Sussex heard. The gang netted around £35,000 over 18 months from banks, mainly Lloyds, across the south.

Queen to play host to Putin
The Queen will meet Russian president Vladimir Putin during his official visit to Britain next week. Mr Putin and his wife, Lyudmila, will be received at Windsor castle on Monday afternoon. Human rights campaigners had called for him to be refused an audience because of Russia's conflict with Chechnya.

Girl escapes as car hits house
A 10-year-old girl escaped with minor injuries yesterday when a car careered through her bedroom wall as she slept, missing her by feet. Molly Boyle went home from hospital after treatment. The car driver, who had to be cut free after his vehicle hit the bungalow in Yalding, Kent, suffered multiple injuries.

Humour a lesson of life
A sense of humour is not inherited but has to be learned, researchers from St Thomas's hospital in central London report in New Scientist today. They were surprised to find no genetic link as most personality traits are at least partly determined by genes.

webTitle: Anti-drugs drive on film and TV has 'feeble impact'

fields.headline: Anti-drugs drive on film and TV has 'feeble impact'
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Anti-drugs messages in television and film have little effect because young people do not regard media representations of drug use as credible, according to research published today.
fields.body:
Anti-drugs messages in television and film have little effect because young people do not regard media representations of drug use as credible, according to research published today.

Demonising the effects of drugs lessens the impact of any negative message, the report found. Instead of taking their cue from TV and film, which only has a "feeble" impact, viewers are influenced far more by the activities of their friends and peer group, the broadcasting standards commission survey shows.

Representations of drug use should be more realistic, the commission said, while at the same time pointing out the risks and not glamourising illegal substances.

Lord Holme, the commission's chairman, said drug workers believed that broadcasters should not "instruct" on how to use the most dangerous drugs. But he added: "It is also clear that whilst broadcasting is a less significant influence for good or ill than is sometimes believed, if it is to play an effective part in the fight against drug abuse then its portrayals must be realistic."

The commission's researchers questioned 170 people aged between 11 and 35, most of whom had taken drugs. The researchers found that people tended to be introduced to drugs through friends and associates, rather than TV, which was a "feeble" influence. "It is talking to friends about what it feels like that generates curiosity, not TV and film."

Professionals who worked with drug users said that anti-drugs messages would carry far more weight if they were more realistic. There was no point in showing a character dying after taking one ecstasy tablet because thousands took ecstasy every weekend and suffered no ill effects. "These respondents wanted more honesty - an end to what they perceived as a sustained effort to demonise drugs," the report said.

webTitle: Scientists warn on high vitamin intake

fields.headline: Scientists warn on high vitamin intake
fields.trailText: High doses of vitamins, which some people take in the belief that they will improve their health or ward off disease, can be harmful, a distinguished American scientific body said yesterday.
fields.body:
High doses of vitamins, which some people take in the belief that they will improve their health or ward off disease, can be harmful, a distinguished American scientific body said yesterday.

For the first time, upper limits have been recommended by the dietary experts for the intake of vitamin C and the mineral selenium.

Their guidance will be controversial in Britain where a powerful campaign mounted by health food companies and consumers in 1998 led to the government shelving proposals to put limits on vitamin B6 consumption.

Vitamins are antioxidants, which are believed by many to reduce the chances of suffering cancer, heart disease, diabetes, Alzheimer's and other illnesses by mopping up damaging molecules called free radicals.

The US national academy of sciences panel looked at the evidence for the effectiveness of four of the most popular antioxidants, vitamins C and E, selenium, and beta carotene, which is turned into vitamin A in the body. It concluded there was nothing in the scientific literature to suggest that high doses of these supplements could protect against illness.

Excess beta carotene, in particular, was known to increase the risk of cancer in some people, especially smokers. The panel set no limits for beta carotene, holding the view that it should not be taken at all other than by people with a vitamin A deficiency.

Many people take high doses of vitamin C to ward off colds. But the experts said the scientific evidence was "not consistent or specific enough" to warrant a recommended intake for this purpose.

On the other hand, there have been suggestions that excessive vitamin C could be damaging. A study published two years ago by Leicester University, funded by the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, suggested that high doses of vitamin C could lead to cancer and rheumatoid arthritis.

"A fine balance exists that may be disrupted in favour of oxidants (oxidative stress), giving rise to an accumulation of biomolecular damage, which in turn may play a role in major diseases such as cancer, rheumatoid arthritis and atherosclerosis," said the study, published in Nature magazine.

A British advisory group reviewing vitamin dose levels in the wake of the B6 controversy is expected to take account of the American recommendations.

The group, set up by Maff last year, is due to report to the new food standards agency in April 2001 with its own upper limit guidelines.

The food standards agency, which has now taken over responsibility for food supplements from Maff, played down the suggestion that vitamins could have harmful effects.

A spokesman said: "There's a lot of information around that suggests some supplements may be harmful if used to excess, but it remains to be seen whether that is actually proven. The jury is still out in many cases.

"Generally the advice is that if you eat a balanced diet you don't need supplements unless you are deficient in some way."

The American experts said eating five servings of fruit and vegetables a day would provide the recommended vitamin C levels, while the chief source of vitamin E should be food such as nuts, seeds, liver and leafy green vegetables.

Good sources of selenium included seafood, liver, meat and grains; pre-formed vitamin A was found in liver, fish oil, egg yolk, milk and butter; and beta carotene in dark green leafy vegetables such as spinach, carrots, tomatoes and apricots.

The panel's recommended daily intakes were: vitamin C, men 90 milligrams, women 75 milligrams; vitamin E, 15 milligrams; selenium, 55 micrograms.

webTitle: Sculpture on the end of a cocktail stick

fields.headline: Sculpture on the end of a cocktail stick
fields.trailText: Willard Wigan, the undisputed Michelangelo of the cocktail stick (and a Manchester United fan), unveiled his latest creation yesterday: Victoria, Brooklyn and David Beckham, with a match head for comparison.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
It is the kind of thing that could drive an artist to absinthe: you spend hours, literally not breathing, carving the flowing locks of your subject onto an almost invisible sliver of wood - and, as soon as you finish, he cuts his hair.

Willard Wigan, the undisputed Michelangelo of the cocktail stick (and a Manchester United fan), unveiled his latest creation yesterday: Victoria, Brooklyn and David Beckham, with a match head for comparison.

He has trained himself to stand without breathing for up to three minutes, and has been known to work for 24 hours without a break: he keeps a convenient container nearby to cater for the calls of nature.

The cocktail sticks are held in a clamp and he holds his body immobile except for the hand holding a scalpel: at critical points he works between heart beats. At the end of a session he frequently has to force apart the locked fingers that hold the scalpel.

It took seven days to carve the Beckham family, and then the footballer went to the hairdresser's. "I was gutted," Mr Wigan said yesterday. He took a breath, set to again, and shaved the head.

The artist, from Birmingham, earns a living sculpting conventional-size figures. He suffers from dyslexia and had a disastrous time in formal education - and began his microscopic career with secret caricatures of his teachers, "because they made me feel so small".

The Impossible Microworld, as the Bath exhibition is called, was a tourist attraction in Jersey, featuring a Spanish artist whose Venus with Mirror by Velazquez painted on a shirt button remains a star of the show. His fame has eclipsed the originals, and his polar bear, balanced on a grain of sugar, is everybody's favourite.

"We find it very touching that, since we opened, we have had literally dozens of teachers, bringing groups of children with dyslexia, just to show them what somebody like them can achieve," Mr Watts said.

fields.headline: Blade runners
fields.standfirst: Park police get their skates on
fields.trailText: Dangerous skaters or mobile robbers beware: the Royal Parks constabulary has enlisted a team of roller blading bobbies to keep order in London's Hyde Park and Kensington Gardens.
fields.body:
Dangerous skaters or mobile robbers beware: the Royal Parks constabulary has enlisted a team of roller blading bobbies to keep order in London's Hyde Park and Kensington Gardens.

The four PCs, Ken Hynd Stacey Loader, Angie Greneski and Janice Jarvis, have been kitted out with quick-release skates that allow them to speed around but can be removed to chase suspects across uneven ground.

Traditional uniform has also been ditched in favour of fashionable black combat trousers, blue sweatshirts and safety pads, finished off with a distinctive checkered helmet.

Tom Corby, spokesman for the royal parks agency, said: "If an old lady walking her chihuahua sees a panzer division of skaters coming towards her, she's obviously going to be spooked, so the officers will be there to regulate the flow, make sure skaters stick to the park rules and skate in designated areas."

Officers are versed in park rules that forbid skaters skating backwards, performing tricks, and exceeding the parks' 15 mph limit.

A spate of accidents in recent years - in 1995 a collision with a roller blader left a 26-year-old cyclist dead, while a horse frightened by a roller blader threw its female mount, blinding her in one eye - led to the agency adopting a code segregating skaters from pedestrians.

webTitle: Gang guilty of bridge plunge murder

fields.headline: Gang guilty of bridge plunge murder
fields.trailText: A gang which included a 14-year-old boy and a 16-year-old girl was yesterday convicted of murdering a student who was beaten unconscious and thrown off a central London footbridge into the Thames.
fields.body:
A gang which included a 14-year-old boy and a 16-year-old girl was yesterday convicted of murdering a student who was beaten unconscious and thrown off a central London footbridge into the Thames.

The older members of the gang, which included three homeless men, face life in prison for the attack on Timothy Baxter, 24, who drowned after he was manhandled into the river 40ft below.

His friend Gabriel Cornish, 25, was also beaten and thrown into the river but was rescued from the fast-moving waters by passers-by.

Mr Baxter, a law student from London, and Mr Cornish, a music student, were attacked in June last year as they returned home from a night out in central London.

The court heard that their six attackers - who were all either homeless or mixed with rough sleepers around Leicester Square - had attempted to rob the two students and had punched, kicked and stamped on their heads until they became unconscious.

After throwing them into the river the gang laughed and joked about whether their bodies would float before two of the gang went on to attack and rob a third victim.

Sonni Reid, 20, John Riches, 22, Cameron Cyrus, 18, all of no fixed abode, and a 16-year-old girl and two teenage boys now aged 15 and 17, who cannot be named for legal reasons, were all convicted of murdering Mr Baxter and attempting to murder Mr Cornish.

The 17-year-old youth burst into tears while the other defendants held their heads in their hands as the jury forewoman returned the verdicts. The jury of six men and six women had taken eight hours to complete their deliberations after the 10-week trial.

Judge Anne Goddard QC adjourned sentencing until next month, but the adult defendants all face mandatory life sentences, while the juveniles face indefinite youth custody.

Reid and Riches were also found guilty of attempting to rob both men of a silver bracelet, a rucksack and a skateboard. Riches and the 17-year-old were convicted of causing actual bodily harm in the attack on the third victim.

The two students were returning home at 4am on June 18 last year when three of the defendants - Reid, Riches, and the 17-year-old, then 16 - approached and tried to rob them.

As the youngest boy repeatedly threatened to throw Mr Cornish into the river, the two victims spotted three other people coming towards them from the north bank. The men begged for help only to realise that the three were members of the same gang, who then joined in the attack.

The two-month trial, attended every day by Mr Baxter's parents, heard how both the victims were savagely beaten and hurled over the 4ft railings of Hungerford footbridge.

Mr Cornish regained consciousness as he drifted in the fast-flowing current. He was rescued after passers-by heard his cries for help. But an intensive police search failed to find Mr Baxter and his body was washed up the next day near his home in the Oxo Tower.

Mr Cornish, who spent two weeks in hospital, broke down in court as he gave a moving account of his ordeal. Nigel Sweeney, prosecuting, told the jury that the six accused did nothing to help their victims once they were in the water.

webTitle: BA goes back to the future in ad for £600m relaunch

fields.headline: BA goes back to the future in ad for £600m relaunch
fields.trailText: Famous faces as diverse as Jerry Hall and Winston Churchill are to help BA restore its tarnished image, in one of the most expensive television advertisements in British television history.
fields.body:
Famous faces as diverse as Jerry Hall and Winston Churchill are to help BA restore its tarnished image, in one of the most expensive television advertisements in British television history.

After the departure of its chief executive, multi-million pound losses and a collapse in its share price, the airline badly needs a public relations boost. To accompany a £600m relaunch, it is spending what industry insiders say is an extraordinary amount of money on its new commercial.

BA dismissed reports that the budget for the 60-second film had reached £2.25m as exaggeration, but confirmed that it had set aside a substantial amount of money for the campaign. A standard commercial, shot over three days, would cost about £150,000.

BA has also dropped the "world's favourite airline" tag in favour of the slogan "21st century travel". The film shows a small girl wandering through an airport which, as she walks, changes from a 30s style building into the present day. Computer techniques superimpose faces from the 20th century into the crowds - figures such as Gandhi, Salvador Dali and Churchill all make a brief appearance. Live celebrities include the model Jerry Hall and Liverpool footballer Michael Owen. The US writer, PJ O'Rourke, who made fun of the British reserve in the last BA campaign, makes a cameo appearance.

Bob Ayling, BA's former chief executive, who left last month, is said to have sanctioned the advert before Christmas. The commercial, created by the agency M&C Saatchi, was shot in five days last month at studios in west London and features a cast of hundreds. The latest virtual reality techniques are said to have been used in what has been described as a "huge production number featuring the kitchen sink and more".

BA said the campaign accompanied a relaunch of the airline's services.

Concorde is being refurbished, beds are being introduced in business class, a new international class is being introduced between economy and business and television screens are being installed in the back of economy class seats. "It is part of a campaign to support our biggest ever investment in services," an airline spokeswoman said yesterday. "It links our heritage to our future."

Claire Beale, of the advertising industry magazine Campaign, said the airline had clearly made a significant investment.

BA, she said, had a tradition of big-budget advertising - it was responsible for the first £1m ad, created by the Chariots of Fire director Hugh Hudson in which thousands of extras formed a smiling face.

"It has set a precedent. You expect a big budget, all-singing all-dancing amazing ad. That is what the brand is about - being the best and being the biggest."

webTitle: Panel to decide on art looted by Nazis

fields.headline: Panel to decide on art looted by Nazis
fields.trailText: The government will today promise to give "very serious" consideration to any recommendations for the return of art looted by the Nazis from Jewish owners. But it will stop short of promising legislation to allow the restitution of paintings from British national collections.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The government will today promise to give "very serious" consideration to any recommendations for the return of art looted by the Nazis from Jewish owners. But it will stop short of promising legislation to allow the restitution of paintings from British national collections.

Arts minister Alan Howarth reveals in the Guardian today that he will be recommending a range of possible resolutions of claims to his newly appointed advisory committee on looted art. These include restitution of the work of art, financial compensation, or moral recompense by displaying the object's history beside it.

However, Mr Howarth has rejected calls for automatic restitution of the actual looted object. "We do not think it right to prejudge the panel's hearings in this way," he said.

Mr Howarth will be announcing the membership and terms of reference of the spoliation advisory panel in reply to a parliamentary question today.

The preliminary study of the British national collections, published last month, left question marks over the provenance of 350 paintings and sculptures, whose history during the Nazi years cannot be proven beyond doubt.

However, most British national collections are prohibited, by law, from disposing of any works for any reason.

The Labour peer Lord Janner, and the Commission on Looted Art, are among those who have been demanding a promise from the government that there will be restitution of the objects themselves.

Last night Anne Webber, chairwoman of the commission, was disappointed at the lack of commitment to legislation allowing restitution. "It appears this prodecure will leave Britain completely out of line with the rest of the world," she said.

webTitle: Parents of 134 babies in contact with TB doctor told of low risk of infection

fields.headline: Parents of 134 babies in contact with TB doctor told of low risk of infection
fields.trailText: Letters were last night sent to the parents of 134 babies who came into contact with a hospital doctor diagnosed as having tuberculosis.
fields.body:
Letters were last night sent to the parents of 134 babies who came into contact with a hospital doctor diagnosed as having tuberculosis.

The doctor, who worked on a neo-natal unit at the Leicester royal infirmary between February and March, is on sick leave and receiving treatment.

Special clinics will be held tomorrow and Monday for parents to take their children to begin a three-month course of antibiotics.

The junior doctor developed a cough and following tests it was revealed she had the pulmonary - or lung - form of the illness.

Nick Naftalin, acting medical director of University Hospitals of Leicester NHS trust, said yesterday: "This doctor has cared for or has checked 134 babies during the six weeks that she worked with us. We recognise that the patient population that this doctor was caring for are particularly vulnerable and we would recognise also the particular anxieties of the parents who already have babies who have been ill."

Philip Monk, consultant in public health, reassured parents that the risks of infection were low.

He said that a process of "contact tracing" had now begun to establish who else the doctor may have potentially passed the illness to. The incubation period for TB is up to 12 weeks.

One mother, Hayley Harvey, who received a letter about her four-week-old son, Layton, said: "I have a five-year-old daughter who has been kissing him. From what I understand TB is spread like a cold. What about her and all the kids at her school?"

Recent reports have said that every year around 400 people in Britain die of TB, which was known as the White Plague during Victorian times.

webTitle: Court bars man from harassing women

fields.headline: Court bars man from harassing women
fields.trailText: A man known as "Special Brew Sid" because of his fondness for extra strong lager was yesterday banned from harassing female passers-by.
fields.body:
A man known as "Special Brew Sid" because of his fondness for extra strong lager was yesterday banned from harassing female passers-by.

Adam Richards, 30, who is a fixture on Lewes High Street in East Sussex and on benches outside the town's crown court, was served with an anti-social behaviour order banning him from intimidating, harassing, touching or insulting women.

It is thought by police to be the first such order relating to offences committed against women in Sussex in a public place. Richards faces a maximum five year prison sentence should he reoffend.

Lewes magistrates acted under the Crime and Disorder Act 1998 after hearing that Richards had a history of unruly behaviour and of harassing women in particular. He has more than 20 public order and alcohol related convictions and last year served a three month prison term for being drunk and disorderly.

His offences include punching a woman train ticket inspector, being found unconscious in the street clutching eight cans of lager and chasing a shop assistant.

Police said Richards, who is unemployed, appears to relish his ability to intimidate women. As well as crude abuse he often shouts bizarre phrases. Last week he was heard crying, "Get off the plane and cook my dinner" at a woman in Lewes.

Inspector Neil Moscrop of Sussex police welcomed the magistrates' verdict which bans Richards from wilfully obstructing females in any public place, abusing and/or insulting them and making non-consensual physical contact.

"There have been about 30 of these orders up and down the country from local authorities to do with unruly tenants making neighbours' lives a misery. But I think this is the first case involving actions specifically against females," he said.

"Richards appears to relish the fact he can act like this against women. We have always dealt with him for offences at the lower end of the scale such as being drunk and disorderly. But the longest sentence he has ever got is only three months which has not shocked him into confronting the fact he has got a problem.

"All other possible courses of action have been exhausted. The public of Lewes clearly needed protection from the behaviour which we ourselves have witnessed."

webTitle: Words of courage, words of protest

fields.headline: Words of courage, words of protest
fields.standfirst: Queen awards George Cross to RUC amid fears for its future and accusations from republicans about its past Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Queen yesterday drew a heavy line under the 78-year-old history of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, conferring the George Cross for valour on a police force which has lost 302 officers to terrorists throughout 30 years of violence, and paving the way for its imminent transformation. There was a sense that nothing would ever be quite the same again.
fields.body:
The Queen yesterday drew a heavy line under the 78-year-old history of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, conferring the George Cross for valour on a police force which has lost 302 officers to terrorists throughout 30 years of violence, and paving the way for its imminent transformation. There was a sense that nothing would ever be quite the same again.

At a sodden and sober Hillsborough Castle in Co Down, 1,500 serving and former officers of the RUC, some terribly handicapped, listened intently as the Queen spoke of the challenges ahead. She was convinced they would maintain the same dedication that she was honouring now in bestowing on them the medal her father George VI struck to mark acts of outstanding bravery during the second world war. At the climax of a brief yet masterly speech, the Queen told them: "Due in no small measure to the bravery and dedication over the years of the men and women of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, Northern Ireland is now a much more peaceful and stable place in which to live. I hope and trust that the emnities of the past can be laid to rest in a way that fully recognises the sacrifices made.

"I know it is clear to you, as it is to me, that there will be challenges to face in the period of change that lies ahead. As you face these challenges, I am confident that you will maintain that sense of duty and dedication which is being honoured today. I know that you will have my support and prayers in the future as the dogged and relentless search for lasting peace continues."

Political expediency

Even as he was heading for home, Tony Blair was confirming in the Commons that Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, would shortly publish legislation to enact EU commissioner Chris Patten's 175 recommendations to modernise the 13,500-strong force, with the primary aim to increase the 8% Catholic representation.

The force's name will be the premier casualty, sparking particular hurt among victims' relatives, many of whom marked gravestones with RUC insignia.

The police family was delighted five months ago at the news that the RUC was to receive the George Cross, especially since it was only once before conferred collectively, to the islanders of Malta in 1942 while they were under German air bombardments. But many thought it smacked of political expediency, coming as it did so soon after the controversial Patten report.

A few invited to yesterday's ceremony stayed away. A Police Federation insider said: "They see the award as a spoonful of sugar to help Patten's medicine go down. They are asking how can the RUC be worthy of the George Cross and not of its name?"

Thelma Johnston, 59, shivering as she sat with her walking stick, summed up the bittersweet mixture of pride at the award and upset at the forthcoming symbolic changes. She said: "As I was laying out my clothes last night, I was wondering if I was coming to a wedding or a funeral. It is a strange feeling."

Her son, David Johnston, 30, a father of two boys, was shot by the IRA in Lurgan, Co Armagh, in June 1997, 34 days before the terror group declared its second ceasefire. His colleague, John Graham, 34, who had three daughters, died alongside him as the north Armagh brigade enjoyed a final lethal outing.

The Queen, in a coat Buckingham Palace emphasised was cinnamon coloured rather than orange, said: "This award is an exceptional recognition of the outstanding contribution made by the RUC to peace in Northern Ireland. It is a singular acknowledgement of the gallantry and courage shown and, in all too many cases, the ultimate sacrifice paid by the members of the constabulary during the past 30 years of terrorism and civil unrest."

The RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, an arch-moderniser, took a similar approach. He was humbled, and, voice cracking, recalled those who had died. Sir Ronnie said: "As a policing service we also look forward to a new and exciting future - a future we seek to build on the wonderful foundations laid by our colleagues past and present."

She had been in training eight days, and was selected as the last in the alphabetic list of the intake of 40.

Ms Wright, who has a son, Rory, 4, said: "It is overwhelming for me. Whatever changes come, we will have to live up to the standards that serving and former officers have set for us."

fields.headline: Stonewall gets £900,000 from lottery
fields.trailText: Stonewall, the gay lobby group, will today be awarded a £900,000 national lottery grant in a move certain to spark fresh controversy over use of "good cause" proceeds from the twice-weekly draw.
fields.body:
Stonewall, the gay lobby group, will today be awarded a £900,000 national lottery grant in a move certain to spark fresh controversy over use of "good cause" proceeds from the twice-weekly draw.

The grant comes at a time when Stonewall is leading support for the government's controversial move to repeal Section 28, which prevents local authorities "promoting" homosexuality in schools, and when argument is continuing over proposals to reduce to 16 the age of homosexual consent.

The National Lottery Charities Board, which is making the grant, says that the award has nothing to do with Section 28 or the age of consent debate. But it is braced for critics to attempt to fuse the three issues.

Lady Brittan, who chairs the board, said last night: "Our aim is to support those at greatest disadvantage in society, and we believe that the lesbian and gay community is as equally disadvantaged as many others."

The grant, one of the biggest made by the board, will be paid over three years to fund a Stonewall project called Citizenship 21.

The project's aims are to challenge prejudice and homophobia, foster institutional change and build links among minority communities.

Citizenship 21 was planned as a response to the campaign of nail-bombings, a year ago, which terrorised gay, black and Asian communities.

The lottery money will fund five workers to lead training workshops on gay and lesbian issues for employers and state agencies. There will also be an awards scheme to encourage development of links among minority groups.

A third strand of the work will be creation of a national databank for use by local lesbian and gay groups as well as organisations such as the police, health authorities and charities.

John Miskelly, who chairs Stonewall, said: "Through this project we hope to achieve some of the things highlighted by Tony Blair and William Hague at the time (of the nail-bombings) - that we should strive for a society where all sections of the community work together to build a society based on greater tolerance and respect for all minorities."

The lottery charities board rode a storm of media and political protest when it first awarded grants to gay groups in the late 1990s. It will point out today that of more than 1,900 grants since last April, worth a total £246m, only 14 have gone to gay, lesbian or bisexual projects at a total cost of £2.8m.

In the same period, groups supporting disabled people have received £80m, projects helping children and young people have received £41m and more than £10m has gone to work aimed at helping elderly people.

Lady Brittan said: "The Citizenship 21 project is an exciting attempt to tackle disadvantage across England by challenging prejudice and ho mophobia. It will also improve our understanding of lesbian and gay issues.

"In the scheme of things this award is very small, but we hope that Stonewall's innovative approach will make a real difference across the country."

Stonewall was founded in 1989 to challenge legal and social discrimination against gay and lesbian people. It has a staff of nine and raises 80% of its regular income from donations and fund-raising.

webTitle: Blair promises to work with London mayor

fields.headline: Blair promises to work with London mayor
fields.standfirst:
PM praises 'courage' of Dobson but avoids tirades against Livingstone as front runner seizes on conciliatory tone

The London mayor: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair yesterday finally joined a platform with Labour's London mayoral hopeful Frank Dobson - now rebranded as plain "Frank" - to endorse him as the "serious candidate", but also promising to abide by the democratic decision of voters and "work with whoever's the mayor".
fields.body:
Tony Blair yesterday finally joined a platform with Labour's London mayoral hopeful Frank Dobson - now rebranded as plain "Frank" - to endorse him as the "serious candidate", but also promising to abide by the democratic decision of voters and "work with whoever's the mayor".

Ending speculation that he was avoiding public appearances with a candidate trailing badly in the polls, the prime minister said his former health secretary's greatest problem had been the focus on how he was selected, rather than what he had to say about crime, jobs, business and transport.

"When you turn to policy, you turn to Frank," whose integrity and courage qualified him for the job, he said.

Mr Blair avoided the kind of personal tirades against front runner Mr Livingstone, which Labour's private polling has shown to be counter-productive. "I am not going back in to the business of attacking Ken Livingstone - everyone knows what I think of him," he said. But while declaring the issue of transport and the future of the underground the "key dividing line" in the campaign, the prime minister refused to say whether he would accept the policy for the tube advocated by whoever wins the election on May 4.

Mr Livingstone and Liberal Democrat Susan Kramer both support a bond-financed public sector option, while Mr Dobson backs the part-privatisation scheme favoured by the government. Conservative Steve Norris wants a full-scale privatisation.

Mr Blair attacked Mr Livingstone's bonds and congestion charge policy as "irresponsible on grounds of cost", and implied that the government's part-privatisation scheme - already part of an act of parliament - would go ahead regardless of whether most Londoners voted for him as mayor.

However, he added: "Of course it matters if a candidate is violently against the private sector and it would make it much more difficult to get the work done in the way we want it".

Mr Blair's spokesman later added: "The government's intention is to proceed with the public-private partnership - we'll see what happens".

But Mr Livingstone seized on the prime minister's more conciliatory tone, welcoming his pledge to "abide by the democratic decision of the people of London. "Tony Blair has moved some way to accepting that if I am elected, the partial privatisaton of the tube will have to be reconsidered," he said.

Mr Blair's aides have in the past few days been making it clear that he is anxious to avoid any early confrontation with Mr Livingstone if the independent favourite does become Britain's first directly elected city mayor.

webTitle: Poor lost ground in Labour's first years

fields.headline: Poor lost ground in Labour's first years
fields.standfirst: Official income data out of date, say ministersNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The government's campaign to end poverty suffered a setback yesterday when official analysis confirmed that the gap between rich and poor widened slightly in Labour's first two years of power.
fields.body:
The government's campaign to end poverty suffered a setback yesterday when official analysis confirmed that the gap between rich and poor widened slightly in Labour's first two years of power.

Ministers were quick to insist that the income data for 1998-99 produced by the office of national statistics was out of date because it did not take into account the extensive reforms of the chancellor, Gordon Brown, including the 10p starter tax rate, the £3.60 national minimum wage and the working families tax credit.

What stirred alarm on the day the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, launched an ambitious neighbourhood renewal programme was the mathematical formula used by statisticians for measuring income distribution: the Gini co-efficient.

It calculates all forms of income, offset by taxes, direct and indirect, and - in the case of the poor - boosted by benefits to create "disposible income".

The ONS analysis confirmed that such income rose in 1998-99 and has been rising since 1995-96. In effect it means that the better off have been pulling further ahead of those in the bottom tenth, or decile, of the income scale after a period in the early 1990s when the divisive trends of the Thatcherite eighties appeared to be easing.

From a rating of 33 in 1995-96 the index rose to 34 in 1996-97, the final full year of John Major's Conservative government. It was stable during Labour's first year in power but rose to 35 in 1998-99. That is its highest rating since 1990, the last year of Margaret Thatcher's premiership. The Treasury and No 10 joined forces to place the report in context. Mr Brown's spokesman pointed to 1.2m children being removed from poverty and 800,000 more people in work, as well as the tax changes aimed at discreetly redistributing cash from the better off to the poorest.

Independent analysts at the Institute for Fiscal Studies confirmed the government's version. "It is hard to pin this on Labour," said one official. But the ONS study helps to explain the feeling among voters which pollsters report: that Labour supporters expected to feel improvement in their lives faster than they have done.

"Our aim is to reduce inequality by extending opportunity. We are getting more power, wealth and opportunity to the poorest in our society," the prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said. "We are doing it most of all by getting those who were on welfare into work."

Ironically, a thriving economy produces more inequalities, especially when wages are rising, because the better off tend to have more jobs in their families than those whom Mr Brown is trying to lure back into the workforce - where, he says, they are needed to help keep the economy growing steadily without skills and labour shortages.

While the figures do not take account of measures introduced since April last year, such as the minimum wage and the working families tax credit, which would be expected to reduce inequality, the Labour leftwinger Lynne Jones, MP for Birmingham Selly Oak, said: "The aim of the government has got to be to close that gap."

fields.headline: Lost in cyberspace
fields.standfirst: The internet's a fast-moving place these days. Too fast for Channel 4, it seems, which chose the week after the biggest high-tech stock crash yet to launch its new series, dotcomedy.  Jacques Peretti  reckons it's too little too late
fields.trailText: The internet's a fast-moving place these days. Too fast for Channel 4, it seems, which chose the week after the biggest high-tech stock crash yet to launch its new series, dotcomedy. Jacques Peretti reckons it's too little too late.
fields.body:
How ironic - or to use web-parlance - "e-ronic". With impeccable timing, Channel 4 launches an internet show the same week that the share price of net companies crashes on the stock market; Bill Gates is told by the US government to break up Microsoft, and confidence in the web plummets to an all-time low.

It's a gift. But from the evidence of the pilot, one suspects none of these stories will be featured on dotcomedy (tomorrow, 11.10pm, Channel 4).

Six months ago, the programme started life with the knowing title of That Internet Show, hastily changed when C4 took a look at the pilot and realised it had little or nothing to do with the internet.

This, however, is what makes dotcomedy interesting. The show is a sign of the times - a moment in the "digital revolution" (remember that?) when analysis of global change is less relevant than downloading a doctored picture of Gail Porter having sex with a donkey.

No one cares about the cardinal net issues any more - freedom; encryption; anonymity, etc. Instead, we've moved into a hands-on era in which people are concerned with playing with the limitations of the technology, and are facing the mundanity of living with the damn thing - whether it be killing time in an office by surfing www.celebrity-morgue.com or using it to buy a cardigan.

By happy coincidence, Gail Porter, one of the unwitting porn stars of the internet, is co-host of dotcomedy, joined by a comedian called Chris Addison (very contemporary in sideburns and safari shirt).

For all its unintentional dumb modernity, the show uses the rather old-fashioned girl/boy flirting presenter team. A concept which The Big Breakfast stuck doggedly to for so many years, and which was first pioneered by the unlikely coupling of Emma Forbes and Andi Peters on Live And Kicking.

In addition to the predictable presenter formula, dotcomedy steadfastedly ignores any of the internet's stylistic innovations, choosing instead traditional items and even a studio guest (on the pilot - rather bizarrely - Sue Cook, who made the mistake of trying to inject a bit of intelligence into the proceedings).

Cook refused to play ball with the presenters' porn-chat, possibly realising that to concentrate on sex is one of the show's errors. MP3, the conduit for accessing free music, recently overtook porn as the subject to receive most hits on the internet. MP3, however, is "geeky", which wouldn't square either with dotcomedy's narrow brief on the net or C4's own self-image as sexy and risqué.

Moreover, dotcomedy, like most late-night TV, fails to overcome the fact that you can't show internet porn on terrestrial telly. Graham Norton side-stepped the problem by focusing on comic chat with the stars of porn sites, but dotcomedy doesn't have such a ruse, and so couldn't deliver the goods and stay the right side of the ITC.

At least dotcomedy is candid about its shallowness. As Addison says: "One in five people surf the net, so what do they get from this deep ocean of technology? Pornography and stupid pictures."

True to his word, the show kicks off with that old favourite of The Clive James Show, Have I Got News For You? and other cutting-edge internet shows - the topical photo gag.

We get to see Bill Clinton's yacht erection (again); a stripping housewife (again); sheep crashing into walls (yup, that one). In short, the stock clips and jokes passed round bored offices for the last couple of years. At the end of the show, the presenters are ironic about how little content there's been for the last half hour, a sarcastic and very modern kind of apology.

Luckily for dotcomedy, the inanity of the show dovetails nicely with the needs of conventional TV entertainment, continually in search of new ways of packaging good old-fashioned post-pub soft-porn TV.

The job of serious net analysis was once done by a show called The Net on BBC2 in the mid-90s, a programme for technophiles hosted by Ben Woolley, axed after a couple of series and never satisfactorily replaced.

In a way, The Net suffered from being too far ahead of the curve, just as dotcomedy suffers from being too far behind it. The show was taken off because it was not dotcomedy enough, just as dotcomedy may eventually get taken off for not being Net enough.

It seems that TV is yet to find a Blairite third way between inpenetrable geek-speak and a no-brain surf. dotcomedy has the misfortune to launch just as web fatigue begins to descend - ennui at interminable dotcom.mentary.

We're now ready for a show which exposes the internet rather than eulogises about it - the fact that you order a book from amazon and you get a CD; that you write a cheque for lastminute.com and it bounces. But that's probably a job for Ann Robinson and Watchdog. Someone who really knows where it's at.

For all its unintentional dumb modernity, the show uses the rather old-fashioned girl/boy flirting presenter team. A concept which The Big Breakfast stuck doggedly to for so many years, and which was first pioneered by the unlikely coupling of Emma Forbes and Andi Peters on Live And Kicking. In addition to the predictable presenter formula, dotcomedy steadfastedly ignores any of the internet's stylistic innovations, choosing instead traditional items and even a studio guest (on the pilot - rather bizarrely - Sue Cook, who made the mistake of trying to inject a bit of intelligence into the proceedings). Cook refused to play ball with the presenters' porn-chat, possibly realising that to concentrate on sex is one of the show's errors. MP3, the conduit for accessing free music, recently overtook porn as the subject to receive most hits on the internet. MP3, however, is "geeky", which wouldn't square either with dotcomedy's narrow brief on the net or C4's own self-image as sexy and risqué. Moreover, dotcomedy, like most late-night TV, fails to overcome the fact that you can't show internet porn on terrestrial telly. Graham Norton side-stepped the problem by focusing on comic chat with the stars of porn sites, but dotcomedy doesn't have such a ruse, and so couldn't deliver the goods and stay the right side of the ITC. At least dotcomedy is candid about its shallowness. As Addison says: "One in five people surf the net, so what do they get from this deep ocean of technology? Pornography and stupid pictures." True to his word, the show kicks off with that old favourite of The Clive James Show, Have I Got News For You? and other cutting-edge internet shows - the topical photo gag. We get to see Bill Clinton's yacht erection (again); a stripping housewife (again); sheep crashing into walls (yup, that one). In short, the stock clips and jokes passed round bored offices for the last couple of years. At the end of the show, the presenters are ironic about how little content there's been for the last half hour, a sarcastic and very modern kind of apology. Luckily for dotcomedy, the inanity of the show dovetails nicely with the needs of conventional TV entertainment, continually in search of new ways of packaging good old-fashioned post-pub soft-porn TV. The job of serious net analysis was once done by a show called The Net on BBC2 in the mid-90s, a programme for technophiles hosted by Ben Woolley, axed after a couple of series and never satisfactorily replaced. In a way, The Net suffered from being too far ahead of the curve, just as dotcomedy suffers from being too far behind it. The show was taken off because it was not dotcomedy enough, just as dotcomedy may eventually get taken off for not being Net enough. It seems that TV is yet to find a Blairite third way between inpenetrable geek-speak and a no-brain surf. dotcomedy has the misfortune to launch just as web fatigue begins to descend - ennui at interminable dotcom.mentary. We're now ready for a show which exposes the internet rather than eulogises about it - the fact that you order a book from amazon and you get a CD; that you write a cheque for lastminute.com and it bounces. But that's probably a job for Ann Robinson and Watchdog. Someone who really knows where it's at.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Crossing Continents | The News Huddlines
fields.body:
Portugal is the stopping-off point for this week's Crossing Continents (Radio 4, 11.0am). With heavily congested, poorly maintained roads and a national love of speed, the country has six times the number of road deaths in Britain, in a population only one-fifth the size. Reporter John Egan meets Manuel Ramos, who since the death of his daughter has been campaigning for better road safety, a shift in culture and more prison sentences for those convicted of dangerous driving. Portugal's delicate relationship to its former colony, East Timor, is also discussed.

The News Huddlines (Radio 2, 9.30pm) celebrates 25 years of topical comedy with Roy Hudd, June Whitfield and co (pictured). Other shows along similar lines have come and gone, but Roy Hudd, aided by, on average, 35 writers per week, has stood firm. The programme has launched generations of sketch writers, and Hudd has fronted every show, except on the occasion he was fog-bound in France.

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Which summer drama will post the biggest ratings?
fields.trailText: Which summer drama will post the biggest ratings?
fields.body:
Hearts And Bones 5/4

Lock, Stock 5/2

Rebus 4/1

Metropolis 6/1

Black Books 6/1

We are, as always, in for some treats this springtime, when a shedload of new scripts written by many new scriptwriters hits our small screens. We asked Ed Nicholson, Ladbrokes' entertainment odds compiler to take a closer look to assess which of them will be the talk of the office.

"Hearts And Bones looks a certainty to do well", says Ed. It's going to take the Beeb back to the gritty subject matter of young adults learning about life. "As ever, it revolves around personal relationships and boasts an attractive, as well as a tremendous, cast. But it's the consistency that will prove the most important ingredient of all", adds Ed.

More surprising, however, is ITV's walk down the risky path with Metropolis, a sophisticated new drama that follows the lives and loves of six university friends struggling to find themselves. Plots will include dope-smoking dropouts, violent car crashes and the dirty world of Westminster politics.

"For those of you who like dark mysterious anti-heroes, then the forthcoming Rebus is for you. Following in the footsteps of Robbie Coltrane and Cracker, detective Rebus will be played by John Hannah. He cleans up his own dysfunctional life as well as the streets of Edinburgh."

Channel 4's big hope is the small-screen adaptation of Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels flick from a couple of years ago. There will be new characters and new original stories.

"Because the first story is also written by Guy Ritchie, it's certain to have the biggest publicity of the lot. But if it's bad it will die an awful death."

Intelligent humour will be the calling card of the Beeb's Black Books, from the writers of Father Ted and Big Train, with Dylan Moran and Bill Bailey starring. "The plot reminds me of High Fidelity, with the same kind of dysfunctional, characters. It should gain its fair share of the viewers."

fields.headline: Cooking with class
fields.trailText: The Naked Chef | Sex And The City | Inside Story
fields.body:
There was a moment during The Naked Chef (BBC2) when it looked like no one would get fed at all. Jamie - cheeky, scruffy, havin' a larf - was scampering round the streets of London town on the scrounge for prosciutto and wild mushrooms when he got stuck to a window. Outside the wild mushroom shop, he pukka-ed up and kissed the glass. With lips as bee-stung as Jamie's, this was perhaps inadvisable. Indeed, with lips like Jamie's - peachy and full - to kiss anything where a vacuum is likely to result is certain folly. (Eskimos with long tongues don't go around licking icebergs, and for very good reason).

So for a moment, elongated by the tension of whether he'd ever un-sucker himself from the window, Jamie - wicked, largin' it, ubiquitous - hung there, his little Camper-clad feet dan gling beneath him, the engine on his scooter burring an anthem for doomed youth.

The people inside the wild mushroom shop rushed to phone the lovely Jules: "Get round here quick. And bring a palette knife!" - but as quickly as the calamity arose, it dissipated. There was a loud pop and Jamie was free again, free to make his salad and have a larf. Personally, I don't find salad very funny but Jamie assured us that if we ripped up our peaches and tore our mozzarella, it'd be a hoot. He did have a serious point to make however. "It is tempting to buy those bags of salad. I've done it," he warned in tones as if he'd just confessed to being a crack addict. "And it's not worth it." Those bags of rocket and lamb's lettuce are evil. Just say no, kids.

Aside from the "I'm a common Essex lad" cor blimey banter, and all the sliding down the Matthew (banister) in his groovy little pad, The Naked Chef's approach to cooking is sound. Even if the occasions for which Jamie cooks are contrived, they at least provide a context for the dishes and take away the fear which many of us have when the spectre of cooking-for-more-than-two appears.

We can only assume that Carrie Bradshaw from Sex And The City (C4) hasn't encountered Jamie Oliver's brand of can-do cooking. She did make a fondue this week, even ripping up the bread for the slimy Mr Big with whom she is now an item once more, but her heart wasn't in it.

While Miranda's new boyf liked watching porn while they had sex, Samantha fell in with her personal trainer (who practised a bizarre line in pubic topiary) and Charlotte fell out with NYC's power lesbians (the cliterati, if you will), the rest of us wondered what it would be like to have anguish that glamorous. To smoke like Carrie smokes, her stunning features Sabatier-sharp as she sucks hard on the wet tip of a Marlboro Light. It makes you wish they'd hurry up and clone spare body parts so you can get yours replaced when they're all blackened with cancer. Beautiful misery.

Misery that was only too real was the subject of Inside Story (BBC1). Every week in England and Wales, two women are murdered by their partners or ex-partners. In 1995, Loraine Whiting was one of those women, but thanks to this thoughtful documentary, she was transformed from easy-to-ignore statistic into a rounded, vital woman whose life and death was charted by her daughter, mother and family friends.

After suffering 20 years of physical and emotional abuse at the hands of her partner then husband, Len Carter, she packed her belongings into her beloved 2CV and left him. Months later, after her bruises had faded and she finally felt she could leave her new home without fear, Carter found her again and shot her three times in the legs before shooting himself dead. Whiting called an ambulance and told them - 31 times - Carter was dead and waited for the emergency services to arrive. They feared Carter was still alive and left Whiting to bleed to death on her living room carpet for fear of an ambush. Her family blame the police, the police blame Carter, we are left to make our own minds up.

Throughout the programme, and within the seemingly innocuous footage of home videos and the pixels of family photographs, menace lurked. And there was a point when a pub punter voiced surprise at Carter bringing his shotgun into the bar with him. "This isn't gangland London," the bemused man said. "It's a quiet village."

And that is surely the point. Food for thought.
