fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: Messiah | Beatmania | Ridge Racer 64
fields.byline: Andy Bodle,  Greg Howson   and Jack Schofield
fields.body:
Angel from the realms of gory
Messiah PC £39.99 Shiny Entertainment/ Interplay *****
 Power on, CD in. Install. Readme. Intro. Cursors for movement, mouse-click to fire. Yawn. Enter to use, D to crouch. Jump, flap wings once and fly into shoulder blades to possess. Escape for game menu... Hang on: fly into shoulder blades to possess?

What's happening? Something ain't right on earth and God is seriously upset. He sends down Bob, a cherub, who wears a nappy, has wings about as useful as a chicken's and the constitution of a slug (he's also infuriatingly mortal).

Fortunately, Bob has one essential trick: he can take over any body he wishes - if he isn't spotted and splatted first.

While in possession of a body, Bob can do anything that person could normally do: use weapons, operate machinery, take considerably more damage before dying. But if his behaviour deviates noticeably from what is expected, the trigger-happy humans will get suspicious.

This twist makes for gameplay unlike anything else. There's action aplenty if you want it - just walk into a restricted area, or pick a fight with an armed policeman. But there's also a strong puzzle-solving element: how, for example, do you escape from a high-security technical facility? Well, you can enter the body of a cop and blast your way out; possess a scientist and thus obtain security clearance; fly out in angelic form using the high-powered fans in the engine room; or jump into a rat and sneak out through the sewers.

There are distant echoes of other games: the sense of humour is very Duke Nukem and it looks quite a lot like Half-Life. But the gameplay makes Messiah stand out. Sure, there are one or two graphical hiccups, and the difficulty curve seems a lot steeper than in your average action game, but most of that is precisely because this is not your average action game. All other developers and their money-grubbing, more-of-the-same marketing overlords should be stand in a corner with a dunce's hat. (AB)

It's the ace of bass fishing
Beatmania (Playstation) Sega Bass Fishing (Dreamcast) Beatmania (Konami) SBF (Sega) £49.99 Both games ***
 Historically, gaming peripherals have been designed to adhere to the obvious. So we've seen plenty of light guns, steering wheels and flight controllers but precious little in the way of innovation. Beatmania and Sega Bass Fishing are attempting something a little different.

Beatmania, described as a DJ simulator, is best experienced using its keyboard/turntable controller (sold separately). In a similar vein to Parappa the Rapper, the player must match onscreen prompts with the corresponding key press while keeping in time with the tune.

Sounds simple, but nimble digits are a necessity and though the musical styles lean towards dance, it matters little. Beatmania is totally unforgiving, visually unstimulating yet curiously addictive.

The mix of joy and relief when you finally master the current track is reward in itself. But on the day the music dies - or at least when your calloused fingers can take no more - a spot of fishing is recommended. Sega Bass Fishing is a surprisingly engrossing fishing sim, but it's success is based firmly on the use of its fishing rod controller (again, sold separately).

Setting out on the beautifully drawn lake you simply set the bait, cast away and prepare for some strenuous reeling. The built-in vibration adds to the palpable excitement of landing a catch and if you're keen on fishing or at least fancy waving some plastic around the telly, this comes recommended.

Both Beatmania and Sega Bass Fishing are quirky and enjoyable. Just remember to play both with the correct peripheral, as mixing a record or landing a fish is not quite the same with a plain joypad. (GH)

Let's take another run at the ridge
Ridge Racer 64 Nintendo 64 £44.99 Nintendo ****
 Boy racers start here. This N64 game gives a terrific sense of speed while still providing better graphics than the old Sony PlayStation games, Ridge Racer and Ridge Racer Revolution.

If you've played those, or the original Namco arcade machines, there's little new. However, this belated conversion - not by Namco but by Nintendo of America - is still very playable and enjoyable.

The limited capacity of N64 cartridges means there are limitations, particularly the music, the repetitive commentary, and the sound effects. But while the techno sound track will disappoint PlayStation owners, it's pretty good by N64 standards.

Nonetheless, Nintendo has managed to pack in a new form of powerslide, which it calls drifting, for high-speed cornering. (The original techniques are still supported.) There are also two- and four-player modes. The "back from the pub" crowd will be ecstatic.

The main drawback with Ridge Racer has always been the shortage of tracks, and this is still true. There are only three basic tracks, each of which is extended for higher levels, and also available in reversed (mirror image) form. Throw in a couple of extras and you get up to 20, but with not the variety that implies.

There's less of a car shortage, since you can easily add to the original four by winning new ones in one-on-one races. Progress is less a matter of mastering harder tracks than working your way through a series of faster cars. Forget about tweaking extra performance out of them. The emphasis is on arcade-style action, rather than realism.

Well, who wants realism when you can bounce your cars off walls, ram opponents from behind, and still win? (JS)

fields.headline: Little voices
fields.standfirst: Just when you'd got over Furby, worse is to come, reports  Jack Schofield  from Korea
fields.trailText: Just when you'd got over Furby, worse is to come, reports Jack Schofield from Korea
fields.body:
Two thousand American kids are training the next generation of talking toys, the first of which could be out by Christmas. The toys will be based on a small speaker-independent speech recognition system that can recognise and respond to 50 words or phrases (this will rise next year to to 500 phrases). Toys with built-in internet access could follow.

"Things like Furby are not very interactive compared with what we're working on," says Richard Lee, the chief operating officer of Human Interface Worldwide, a small startup based in Seoul, Korea. "Our strategy is to make toys really interactive. We haven't been to any toy fairs yet, but when we do, we're confident our product will blow away everything that is out in the marketplace."

When a child says "I love you," the toy can say "You're my best friend," while the response to "Goodnight" could be "Goodnight, sweet dreams" or whatever. The same question could prompt different responses at different times: it all depends on the scriptwriter, and the programming.

"Smart toys" are believed to have about 5% of a global toy market worth $65bn in 1998, including computer and video games. The potential market for toys with speech recognition is much larger than the $3.25bn that implies. Speech recognition could be added to a wide range of dolls, soft toys and action figures, as well as toy telephones, juke boxes, clocks, voice-controlled video game controllers and other devices.

Many toy sales are driven by characters ranging from Mickey Mouse to South Park, and Lee says that HI Worldwide has signed a "memorandum of understanding with a major US motion picture and TV company" to co-develop toys. The company is also developing "talking Fifa World Cup mascots" for the event in Korea and Japan in 2002.

HI will not make or sell toys. Its strategy is to license characters and use them to develop toys for manufacturers such as Hasbro and Mattel. Examples could include Stuart Little, the talking mouse from Sony's hit movie of the same name, and Nintendo's Pikachu from Pokémon.

"All the characters have their own movies and their own TV series and their own characters and voices, so we'd want Stuart Little or Pikachu or Big Bird to respond in their own voices," says Lee.

The first toys will hold about 60 minutes of voice output. This will increase as flash memory chips get bigger and cheaper.

HI is using speech recognition technology from a Belgian company, Lernout & Hauspie, and was set up in December when it signed an exclusive license to use L&H's technology in toys. It hasn't produced anything yet, but it is developing a speech recognition and voice output system.

This will be implemented using a digital signal processing (DSP) chip, will fit on a 6cm x 4cm circuit board, and should be ready in June. Later the system will be shrunk to a quarter of the size by using a custom Asic (application specific integrated circuit) chip.

Early next year, HI plans to have prototypes using L&H's ASR1800 software to recognise 500 phrases. This version will also support Wap, (wireless application protocol) to access a cutdown version of the web. Smart toys would then be able to work with the internet.

"In principle, you could talk to the toy and the toy could retrieve data wirelessly from the internet and tell it to you," says Lee. "That way you're not dependent on what's in the memory. A child could ask the toy 'Who's the president of the United States?', the toy could find out using real-time internet access and say 'Bill Clinton, didn't you know that?' The toy can help educate them."

The first systems will use English. HI will also offer French, German, Japanese and Korean. Chinese (Cantonese and Mandarin), Spanish and Portuguese will follow.

The speech circuitry is still too big for many toys, but Lee proposes putting it in accessories. "If we can't put it in a Barbie doll we can certainly put it in Barbie's Corvette or Ken's horse, or GI Joe's back-pack or whatever."

HI's modules will be relatively expensive - around $20-$40, depending on volume - but Lee isn't worried about that. Smart toys could sell for five times as much as dumb ones, so the character owners, toy manufacturers and retailers will all benefit. "They have nothing to lose by promoting us: we're giving them the opportunity to make more money," says Lee.

But it may be bad news for parents.

HI is using speech recognition technology from a Belgian company, Lernout & Hauspie, and was set up in December when it signed an exclusive license to use L&H's technology in toys. It hasn't produced anything yet, but it is developing a speech recognition and voice output system. This will be implemented using a digital signal processing (DSP) chip, will fit on a 6cm x 4cm circuit board, and should be ready in June. Later the system will be shrunk to a quarter of the size by using a custom Asic (application specific integrated circuit) chip. Early next year, HI plans to have prototypes using L&H's ASR1800 software to recognise 500 phrases. This version will also support Wap, (wireless application protocol) to access a cutdown version of the web. Smart toys would then be able to work with the internet. "In principle, you could talk to the toy and the toy could retrieve data wirelessly from the internet and tell it to you," says Lee. "That way you're not dependent on what's in the memory. A child could ask the toy 'Who's the president of the United States?', the toy could find out using real-time internet access and say 'Bill Clinton, didn't you know that?' The toy can help educate them." The first systems will use English. HI will also offer French, German, Japanese and Korean. Chinese (Cantonese and Mandarin), Spanish and Portuguese will follow. The speech circuitry is still too big for many toys, but Lee proposes putting it in accessories. "If we can't put it in a Barbie doll we can certainly put it in Barbie's Corvette or Ken's horse, or GI Joe's back-pack or whatever." HI's modules will be relatively expensive - around $20-$40, depending on volume - but Lee isn't worried about that. Smart toys could sell for five times as much as dumb ones, so the character owners, toy manufacturers and retailers will all benefit. "They have nothing to lose by promoting us: we're giving them the opportunity to make more money," says Lee. But it may be bad news for parents.

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst: Everyone is going crazy about Wap phones - but nobody really knows how they will change the world. Does the answer lie in a discarded British computer
fields.trailText: Everyone is going crazy about Wap phones - but nobody really knows how they will change the world. Does the answer lie in a discarded British computer
fields.body:
Britain has a very healthy computer games sector: as Jack Schofield recently pointed out, exports of leisure software exceed those of television programmes or films. Now there may be a number of different reasons why Britain has more game development studios than the rest of Europe put together, but the best one that I've heard is that it's down to the legacy of the Sinclair Spectrum.

In the early 1980s, American teenagers were taking delivery of Apples and IBM PCs, stuffed full of memory, with colour monitors and full-sized keyboards attached. I can well remember the excitement of buying a hard disk drive for my Apple IIe in California back in the mid-1980s.

Meanwhile, their counterparts on this side of the Atlantic were just getting their hands on the Sinclair spectrum. It had a keyboard that you could hardly type on, cassette tapes for storage, a limited display (it was your TV) and a little memory. Not the best possible environment for games development, you might think.

The machine, however, tapped into an incredible dynamic. By giving hundreds of thousands of inquisitive teenagers a machine that they could finally program themselves, no matter how difficult and how frustrating that programming was, the Spectrum unleashed a wave of creativity.

The limited computing environment meant that creativity and ingenuity were channelled into the games themselves and not solely into the presentation. The result was an entire generation skilled at executing novel and creative concepts in resource constrained environments. The beginning of a whole new creative industry was a device with a keyboard that it's difficult to type on, little memory, limited processing power and a display you wouldn't want to look at for any length of time: sounds like a Wap phone to me.

To read the press recently, you'd think that Wap (the wireless application protocol) was a cure for cancer. It's going to transform our lives in incredible ways: we'll be able read the CNN news headlines while waiting for a train at Waterloo, for example.

Wap is certainly an important technology. Gartner Group predicts that 95% of all phones sold in 2004 will be Wap-enabled. Forrester forecasts that at the end of 2003, when European mobile phone penetration will be around 59% overall, internet-enabled mobile phones (which may or may not be Wap phones) will have a 45% penetration. Yet the current Wap frenzy suggests that some organisations are allowing their marketing departments to float free from their technological moorings.

As I heard someone comment a short while ago, marketing departments are crazy about Wap because they don't understand it. It's the first step on the road to a mobile future: it doesn't pretend to be the "internet on your mobile phone". The technology platform of both the handsets and the networks isn't really capable of supporting the functionality required to meet that goal.

Even though (in time) the arrival of high bandwidth networks (eg, GPRS) will alleviate some of the problems, the form factor (and use of) handsets makes the idea of web browsing walking down the street with a Wap phone pretty unattractive.

It might be heretical to say so, but Wap has its limitations. Yet it must be a key element of organisational strategies towards mobile communications, not because it is the end game but because it provides an immediate entry to the world of mobile partnerships, business models, regulation and so on.

The real significance of Wap, however, may be that it will tap into the same dynamic as the Spectrum. Given that just one of the UK mobile operators (BT Cellnet) is planning to put some half a million handsets into the market over the summer, the user pool is set to grow quickly. We will soon be in a situation where a large number of innovative people (with time their hands), who think differently and bring a new approach, will move into an environment that had previously been closed to them.

It may not be as open as the computer games environment was, but there are clear opportunities.

If the Spectrum analogy has anything to it, it means that a new value chain will rapidly come into existence. Wap development studios will be springing up all over the place and vying for the attention of a small number of major "publishers" that dominate the delivery channels (ie, the mobile operators and major Wap portals such as, perhaps, banks).

Who knows? Perhaps a decade from now Britain will have a third of the world market for software development for mobile services and there will be a couple of hundred mobile software development shops up and down the country. They will be staffed by people who can still remember the day when they got their first pre-paid Wap phone, connected to some boring news feed site, then hung up and thought to themselves: "I can do better than that."

fields.headline: Sir Kenneth Allen
fields.standfirst: An old school industrialist with first-hand experience of life on the shop floor, he became an employers' leader and helped found the CBI
fields.trailText: Sir Kenneth Allen, who has died aged 92, was one of the old school of industrialists. He was a talented, creative engineer, more so than in his secondary skill as an accountant, and came from a family of engineers, the Bedford-based engineering group, WH Allen and Sons Ltd, founded by his grandfather. He worked his way from a shop floor apprenticeship with the shipbuilders Harland and Wolff both in Belfast and in Glasgow, and gained first-hand knowledge of the lifestyle, conditions and problems of the men on the shop floor, an experience he never forgot.
fields.body:
Sir Kenneth Allen, who has died aged 92, was one of the old school of industrialists. He was a talented, creative engineer, more so than in his secondary skill as an accountant, and came from a family of engineers, the Bedford-based engineering group, WH Allen and Sons Ltd, founded by his grandfather. He worked his way from a shop floor apprenticeship with the shipbuilders Harland and Wolff both in Belfast and in Glasgow, and gained first-hand knowledge of the lifestyle, conditions and problems of the men on the shop floor, an experience he never forgot.

It enabled him, when he was president of the Engineering Employers' Federation from 1962 to 1964, to establish a special relationship with the trade unions, especially with the late Bill Carron [later Lord Carron], president of the Amalgamated Engineering Union. It was a relationship which paved the way to resolving the outstanding trade union claim of the period - the 40-hour-week.

It is important to recall the industrial/economic climate of the early 60s. The Macmillan government had put the control of inflation, incomes policy, and the resolving of industrial tension at the top of its domestic agenda. Sterling was under serious pressure from early 1961 and Selwyn Lloyd, as chancellor, announced a "pay pause" without any consultation with the unions. It would be "imposed" on the public sector by the government, and he hoped the private sector would pick up the message. Selwyn Lloyd also announced that this would be followed by a "permanent incomes policy".

A National Incomes Commission [Nicky] was set up to police the system, albeit on a voluntary basis. The TUC greeted all this with hostility and many employers, while welcoming some disciplining of the unions, were dubious about its effectiveness. So too, in private, was prime minister Macmillan - forever distrustful of the Treasury. He was always on the lookout for intelligent, socially aware employers to handle a difficult situation with tact and common sense. He found one in Kenneth Allen, who not only presided over the largest and most important single group of employers - the Engineering Employers' Federation - but was also actively involved with the British Employers Confederation, predecessor of today's Confederation of British Industry.

The period when Sir Kenneth Allen - he was knighted in 1961 - became an employers' leader was the beginning of the era of technological transformation of industry and the emergence of a new word, automation. A shorter working week was inescapable - yet it took vision and courage to negotiate the deal which was finally achieved with the engineering unions.

The EEF, which spoke for 4,500 firms, faced a series of strikes, overtime bans and go-slow protests. Kenneth Allen presided over that period with great courage, diplomacy and wisdom. He also saw the need for employers to have a single national voice rather than the three separate bodies then in existence - the Federation of British Industries, British Employers Confederation and National Union of Manufacturers. Allen was a member of a small, then secret, committee planning the birth of the CBI, which finally occurred in 1965. The late John Davies, a friend of Allen, became the first CBI director general, and five years later was to join Edward Heath's 1970 cabinet as industry secretary. Allen became chairman of the CBI's key labour and social affairs committee and remained in that role until 1967.

Kenneth Allen was born in Bedford. His grandfather, William Henry, moved to London and set up his first engineering works on a site that eventually became Waterloo Station. He was bought out by the Southern Railway in 1894 and moved to Bedford, where he established a plant building pumps, engines and steam turbines, first for the navy and then for the embryo aero industry.

Young Kenneth was educated at Westminster School and then went to Neuchatel University in Switzerland to study languages. But the pull of the family engineering business was critical and he was guided into an engineering apprenticeship in the Harland and Wolff shipyard. After a further course in accountancy he was brought back to Bedford to work in the family firm during the 30s.

He became a director in 1937, managing director in 1946, and followed his uncle into the company chairman ship in 1955. He remained chairman until 1970. During the war years, when the Bedford company was wholly absorbed in naval and aircraft work, Kenneth Allen's drive and caring attitude won him enormous respect from the firm's 1,200 workforce. The post-war years were often hard going as international competition began to erode the dominance of traditional British markets, especially in marine engineering. Using his language skills, Allen toured the world to build up new links and began to shift his company toward making equipment for the huge international oil market.

In his later years as chairman he recognised the limitations of a family firm trying to go it alone - so WH Allen and Sons merged with Northern Engineering Industries, which was subsequently taken over by Rolls-Royce. The Allen factory in Bedford survived, specialising in producing high quality diesel engines for Rolls-Royce.

Sir Kenneth Allen inevitably held a wide range of outside appointments, including chairman of the British Internal Combustion Engine Manufacturers Association (1955-57), president of the British Engineers Association (1957-59), chairman of Amalgamated Power Engineering (1968-70), and director of Electrolux (1970-81); he was a freeman of the City of London and liveryman with the Worshipful Company of Shipwrights. He was high sheriff of Bedfordshire in 1957 and a deputy lieutenant from 1978 to 1991.

He married in 1931, Eleanor Mary Eeles, who died in 1990. He is survived by a son and a daughter.

 William Kenneth Gwynne Allen, industrialist, born May 23 1907; died April 4 2000

webTitle: Hormone guru hails 'safe cure' for age's woes

fields.headline: Hormone guru hails 'safe cure' for age's woes
fields.trailText: It may sound like another false trail towards the fountain of youth, but French researchers are convinced that an easily replicated chemical found in male sex hormones gives a youthful glow to the skin of the over-60s, firms up their cracking bones, and restores zest to their love lives.
fields.body:
It may sound like another false trail towards the fountain of youth, but French researchers are convinced that an easily replicated chemical found in male sex hormones gives a youthful glow to the skin of the over-60s, firms up their cracking bones, and restores zest to their love lives.

Etienne-Emile Baulieu, 71, one of France's most eminent hormonal scientists, is so sure of the beneficial effects of dehyroepiandrostrene (DHEA) that he wants it to be made freely available on the European market.

"People from 60 to 80 need only 50mg a day to rejuvenate skin, strengthen bones and augment the parameters of the libido, particularly among women," he says. "There are no side effects."

Sceptics who suspect that he is hyping up the findings of his year-long study in in the hope of making millions may be reassured by the fact that pharmaceutical firms refused to back the study, for fear of undermining an entire dream industry. Nearly all the £1m funding came from the public sector and the research was carried out in public hospitals.

"US firms did not want to sponsor us because DHEA cannot be patented and has been on the market since 1934," Professor Baulieu says. "There is no big money to be made. It is cheap and easily synthetised and is already used by pharmaceutical firms as raw material to make other molecules."

The results of the study by a team of 22 researchers were sent to the American Academy of Sciences, which had been looking for an independent group to research a US phenomenon, the uncontrolled sale of DHEA derivatives.

Products labelled DHEA Ultimate, DHEA Super Hormones and Ultra DHEA have flooded health stores since being registered as a food supplements to escape investigation by the food and drug administration.

"Anybody can use DHEA labels, whether the product contains the substance or not," Prof Baulieu says. "You can buy it by the kilo and there is nothing illegal as it is not a drug. Offers are flooding the internet across the world."

The claim that DHEA is an all-purpose anti-ageing remedy would be illegal in most EU countries, because DHEA's effects are limited, he says.

In Britain it can only be obtained on a doctor's prescription. It is listed as a class C drug, alongside tranquillisers, under the Misuse of Drugs Act, and has been used for medical purposes in the past.

Prof Baulieu says his recommended dose would replace the diminishing level of DHEA present in the human body from adolescence.

"We carried out tests on 280 volunteers, half of whom were given placebos," he said. "They were all in good health, which helped the process of positive effect."

The treatment did not slow down the ageing of arteries, and there was no proof that it improved awareness, memory or immunity to disease. Tests have yet to be carried out on the over eighties.

"The results have not disappointed us and the substance is clearly without danger," Prof Baulieu says.

webTitle: Italy finds new saint as porn actress retreats to her cell

fields.headline: Italy finds new saint as porn actress retreats to her cell
fields.trailText: Italy hailed a new saint yesterday after one of its most famous porn stars vowed to abandon the sex industry and take a spiritual retreat in a convent.
fields.body:
Italy hailed a new saint yesterday after one of its most famous porn stars vowed to abandon the sex industry and take a spiritual retreat in a convent.

Luana Borgia, alias the Duchess of Hard, astounded fans and delighted the righteous by revealing a crisis of conscience.

"I want to change, to turn over a new leaf. I'm tired of this life and I've been thinking of leaving the hard porn scene for a while," said the 30-year-old.

The pressure to sleep with people she did not like had become unbearable so it was time to rediscover who she was, said the star of Restless Presence, Dreams, and The Testament (parts I and II).

She will cloister herself inside San Francesco convent, a 13th century complex in the southern city of Cosenza.

Doubts over her career choice surfaced six years ago but Ms Borgia felt unable to break free. She strove to make certain scenes of Sexual Alchemy educative but her conscience demanded more.

Her resolve strengthened four years ago when she appeared at a concert against football hooliganism - slogan: no to violence, yes to love - and met Father Fedele, a Capuchin priest.

Regular phone conversations ensued and Ms Borgia made fewer films. She donated an ambulance to the Capuchin order's missions in Africa but the breakthrough came in a tearful plea for help.

Father Fedele said: "Her conversion was one of the most beautiful conquests of my priesthood. She is a very good and sweet girl." He was especially pleased that she had also forsaken lucrative appearances at nightclubs.

The actress made the announcement on national television but commentators rejected suspicions that it was a publicity stunt and hailed Ms Borgia as a sincere convert. It was a matter of time before she became a nun.

Almost unheard above the hubub, Ms Borgia insisted she had no desire to become a saint. She was emphatically not renouncing her career, seeking forgiveness or even embracing religion.

"I don't regret anything about my past, but I want to do something else, perhaps cinema and television. I don't have any intention of becoming a nun, as some have insinuated.

"I don't go to mass but I don't think it is necessary to go to mass to offer a testimony of faith."

She wanted to take a break while deciding how to redirect her career and her friend's convent offered tranquillity. Her visit will last 15 days, but in some newspapers it had become an indefinite stay.

fields.headline: Governor sparks Tokyo race row
fields.trailText: The governor of Tokyo, Shintaro Ishihara, claimed yesterday that illegal immigrants had turned part of Japan's capital into a crime-ridden foreign country that even yakuza gangsters were afraid to enter.
fields.body:
The governor of Tokyo, Shintaro Ishihara, claimed yesterday that illegal immigrants had turned part of Japan's capital into a crime-ridden foreign country that even yakuza gangsters were afraid to enter.

The comments are likely to add fresh fuel to a blazing row over racism, which has long been seen in Japan as a problem suffered only by other, less homogeneous countries.

"Crimes by illegal immigrants are rising rapidly," said the governor, who is famed for his outspoken nationalist views. "Japanese people can no longer walk the streets of the Ikebukuro and Shinjuku districts at night. Those places are like other countries. Even the yakuza don't dare to go in."

Mr Ishihara was defending a controversial speech he made last weekend when he warned Japanese troops to prepare for an uprising by foreigners in the aftermath of a major earthquake. For the hundreds of thousands of Chinese and Korean residents, the speech was a frightening throwback to the attitudes of a bloody past.

In the wake of Tokyo's last big earthquake in 1923, Japanese troops and police massacred 6,000 Koreans after an unfounded rumour that they were poisoning well water.

Yesterday, the governor expressed pity for those victims and said he would protect all of the city's residents in a future calamity.

"I would never give an order to kill foreigners," he told the Guardian. But he insisted that illegal immigrants and racial minorities were the main source of danger.

"After the Los Angeles quake, it was ethnic minorities, including blacks and Hispanics, who went looting. The same thing would happen here," he said. "Although some Japanese might take part in riots, the strongest fear is about areas with high levels of illegal immigrants."

The governor's remarks have sparked a furious backlash by China, North Korea and foreigners' groups inside Japan.

"It is a criminal statement that incites xenophobia and discrimination against all foreign residents," said a spokesman for one group of migrant workers.

The group joined a gathering of celebrities and protesters outside the metropolitan government building to demand the resignation of Mr Ishihara.

Government ministers from the conservative Liberal Democratic party (LDP) were more circumspect in their criticism. The new prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, said only that the governor's expression was "inappropriate".

This caution may reflect a feeling in the LDP that the views of Mr Ishihara - a populist who has risen to power by tapping public frustration at Japan's prolonged economic stagnation - are widely held.

More than a hundred people have already telephoned the Tokyo government to express their support for the governor.

Fewer than 1.5% of Japan's 126m citizens are not indigenous, but this is expected to change dramatically in the years ahead.

According to a recent UN study, Japan will need 600,000 immigrant workers by 2050 to make up for low fertility rates and the world's fastest ageing population.

The need for more gaijin (literally, outside people) is disconcerting to many Japanese, who fear a rising wave of crime that is commonly blamed on foreigners, especially illegal immigrants.

Although the government has recognised the need for more foreign workers, debate has not even started on making the necessary social adjustments. There are no laws banning racism. Estate agents openly refuse to rent property to foreigners and several bath houses have banned gaijin .

The problem is barely ever discussed, but inadvertently Mr Ishihara - who insists he is not a racist - has changed all that.

fields.headline: Stink over alleged cheese fraud
fields.trailText: The biggest of France's big cheeses is being investigated for alleged fraud after a two-year inquiry by 140 gendarmes into the manufacture of an internationally-sold camembert called Le Président.
fields.body:
The biggest of France's big cheeses is being investigated for alleged fraud after a two-year inquiry by 140 gendarmes into the manufacture of an internationally-sold camembert called Le Président.

Marcel Urion, the managing director of the Lactalis group, which turns out 1m camemberts a day in its 85 factories, is being questioned by an examining magistrate on suspicion of "falsification and dishonest advertising".

Le Président, consistently voted France's most popular mass-produced cheese, has become the hallmark of Lactalis's £300m a year business, built up over the last two decades in a price-cutting operation that rivals say they cannot follow.

Le President is the best known product of a firm which buys 5bn litres of milk a year before flooding supermarket shelves with everything from UHT milk to pats of butter under dozens of different trade names. But the examining magistrate, Brigitte Demé, says her dossier includes allegations that the price-cutting operation is underpinned by watering down milk and violating EU regulations on quality.

The company's founder, Michel Besnier, was recently asked to resign from the national federation of dairy producers, because, according to an official, "he was not prepared to explain certain of his firm's practices".

Gendarmerie investigators have concentrated on the practice of creaming off proteins in the milk to create a cheap additive for other products, and the alleged use of possibly dangerous sterilising practices in cheese production.

A company official said yesterday that his firm had "standardised" the amount of protein in milk at 29 grams a litre, despite EU directives forbidding the practice, but added that "everybody else does it". The supposedly illegal sterilising procedure was used only for packing material.

Several cooperatives and private firms who believe the firm has been cheating have asked to be associated with an eventual court hearing as civil plaintiffs seeking damages.

webTitle: Pastrana seeks European cash for cocaine war

fields.headline: Pastrana seeks European cash for cocaine war
fields.trailText: The Colombian president, Andres Pastrana, arrived in London yesterday to muster support - and cash - for a £5m strategy to stamp out Colombia's narcotics trade, revive the country's economy and end nearly 40 years of civil war.
fields.body:
The Colombian president, Andres Pastrana, arrived in London yesterday to muster support - and cash - for a £5m strategy to stamp out Colombia's narcotics trade, revive the country's economy and end nearly 40 years of civil war.

While Bill Clinton urges the US senate to agree to £1bn in mostly military aid for Colombia, Mr Pastrana is looking to Europe, Canada and Japan for another £600m towards social development projects in the remote southern regions which produce most of the world's cocaine.

"Plan Colombia" has won enthusiastic support from US officials, but analysts say that other countries may be less willing to back a strategy which could end up fuelling an increasingly savage war.

Mr Pastrana is to meet Tony Blair today - the day before United Nations' Human Rights Commissioner Mary Robinson releases a damning report on Colombia's human rights record.

The annual report, obtained in advance by the Guardian, pins much of the blame for the current humanitarian crisis on the Pastrana government's failure to take effective action against human rights abusers.

According to the UN, 402 massacres occurred in Colombia last year, the majority committed by the far-right paramilitaries.

The report follows equally critical studies from the US state department and the New York-based Human Rights Watch, which accused the Colombian military of tolerating - and sometimes cooperating with - the militias.

Colombian officials and their US supporters say that Plan Colombia will bring peace by rooting out the conditions which breed violence. As well as a counter-drugs strategy, the plan embraces a peace process with leftwing rebels, economic recovery, judicial and political reforms, human rights protection and social investment.

But rebel leaders describe the plan as an excuse to step up counter-insurgency actions.

"Plan Colombia, as we understand it, is no more than a way for hawks in the United States to become more deeply involved in our internal affairs. It's a declaration of war by the United States," said Raul Reyes, a senior commander of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia.

Western diplomats in Bogota confirm that while the military portion of the plan was ready in late 1999, the Colombian government has yet to present a coherent social investment programme. And, they say, few governments will be willing to climb aboard what is perceived as an American project to clean out its backyard.

"Nobody wants to be seen at the tag end of a US plan - particularly when some countries don't agree with the military element," said one diplomat.

The US aid focuses on equipment and training for elite anti-drugs troops who will spearhead a campaign in southern Colombia, the source of over 70% of Colombia's cocaine and a traditional rebel stronghold.

Human rights monitors say that even if coupled to social investment programmes, increased military aid will increase the violence and worsen the plight of Colombia's rural poor.

Last year 288,000 people were driven from their homes by the war, and in private US officials say that as many as 150,00 more could be forced to flee by an anti-drugs offensive in the south.

webTitle: Mosque killings raise tension in Pakistan

fields.headline: Mosque killings raise tension in Pakistan
fields.trailText: Gunmen armed with grenades and automatic weapons attacked a prayer meeting in a rural mosque in Pakistan killing 12 Shia Muslims, including five children, in the worst outbreak of sectarian violence for a year.
fields.body:
Gunmen armed with grenades and automatic weapons attacked a prayer meeting in a rural mosque in Pakistan killing 12 Shia Muslims, including five children, in the worst outbreak of sectarian violence for a year.

Police yesterday arrested the son of the leader of a nearby Sunni Muslim mosque, run by the militant Sipah-i-Sahabah organisation, which has been blamed for the deaths of scores of Shias.

The killings in the village of Malowali, 90 miles northwest of Islamabad, on Tuesday night threaten to reignite sectarian tensions which have claimed hundreds of lives in Pakistan in the past 10 years.

The gunmen cut the telephone lines leading to the remote village before bursting into the mosque, throwing hand grenades and spraying the congregation with bullets. A police officer was among the dead and more than 20 people were injured.

Prayers were being held as part of the Shia holy month of Muharram, which marks the death of the grandson of the prophet Mohammed and culminates in a day of mourning and processions this weekend.

As police searched the damaged mosque blankets soaked in blood still lay on the broken stone floor, where the victims had been kneeling in prayer.

Last week a leading Shia, Waqar Hussain Naqvi, was shot dead in Karachi. His father, Sajid Naqvi, was born in Malowali village, the scene of yesterday's attack, and runs the Tehrik-e-Jaffria movement, which wants Shia Islamic law implemented in Pakistan, even though Shias make up only 20% of the population.

Security had been tightened across Pakistan in advance of the Shia holy month,which has sparked religious tension in the past.

"People will feel insecure attending religious gathering until the killers are arrested," said Sayed Mazhar Gailani, a leader of Tehrik-e-Jaffria.

The rival Sipah-e-Sahabah movement denied involvement and blamed India, as is routinely done for bombings and shootings in Pakistan.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Indonesian boat people drown
fields.body:
Indonesian boat people drown

As many as 220 suspected illegal immigrants whose boat went missing on the way to Australia from Indonesia almost three weeks ago are presumed to have drowned, an Australian immigration official said yesterday.

The immigration minister, Philip Ruddock, said the boat went missing after it left Java on either March 24 or 25 bound for Christmas Island, an Australian territory 220 miles south of Java, and probably experienced bad weather.

Australia has been targeted by a growing tide of illegal immigrants in recent months.
Reuters, Sydney

Man tied to tree for two days

Security forces yesterday freed a Norwegian businessman who had been kidnapped and spent two days tied to a tree in a forest outside Moscow, a police spokesman said.

Two kidnappers dressed as police snatched the man in central Moscow on April 9, the spokesman said.

The foreign ministry in Oslo identified him as 43-year-old Hassan Jadullahvad. Police arrested the kidnappers while delivering a $200,000 (£126,000) ransom yesterday.
AP, Moscow

webTitle: US to atone for denying nuclear ills

fields.headline: US to atone for denying nuclear ills
fields.trailText: After decades of official denial by successive US governments, the Clinton administration publicly acknowledged responsibility yesterday for the diseases contracted by thousands of American workers exposed to radiation when they worked in US nuclear weapons-production factories during the cold war.
fields.body:
After decades of official denial by successive US governments, the Clinton administration publicly acknowledged responsibility yesterday for the diseases contracted by thousands of American workers exposed to radiation when they worked in US nuclear weapons-production factories during the cold war.

"The government is done fighting workers and now we're going to help them," the energy secretary, Bill Richardson, announced as he unveiled details of a multi-million dollar compensation scheme yesterday. "We're reversing the decades-old practice of opposing worker claims and moving forward to do the right thing."

Vowing to "right the wrongs of the past", Mr Richardson's scheme offers lump-sum payments of at least $100,000 (£63,000) to stricken workers, or to their surviving descendants. As an alternative, workers would be allowed to negotiate a package which covers medical costs, lost wages and retraining. The scheme will require Congressional approval before it can be implemented.

Yesterday's announcement follows a breakthrough admission earlier this year by a White House-appointed inquiry team which said for the first time that there was credible evidence that many workers at the plants had contracted lung cancer and other serious conditions from exposure to radiation or toxic chemicals.

More than 600,000 workers produced over 70,000 nuclear weapons during the industry's past 50-plus years. However, only about 3,000 of them, those who can be shown to be suffering from radiation-induced conditions, are expected to qualify for claims.

The diseases most commonly associated with exposure to radiation include certain types of leukaemia, lymphoma, myeloma, bone cancer, breast cancer, thyroid cancer, and stomach, liver and lung cancers.

Yesterday's moves constitute a major about-face for the US government, which has consistently refused to accept responsibility for such illnesses, arguing that the guilt could not be pinned on any one work-related source.

One clear indication of the new approach is the fact that workers will now receive the benefit of the doubt in cases where plant medical records are missing or incomplete. The government will "assume the workers were exposed to the highest amount of radiation associated with the tasks they performed", officials said.

That change is crucial because record-keeping about individual workers' exposure to radiation in the industry, especially in the early years, was poor.

Two of the principal sites where claims will be settled are the US uranium enrichment plants at Paducah, Kentucky, and at Piketon, Ohio, but workers at more than a dozen other sites around the US are expected to file compensation applications.

"Today this administration begins the process of compensating workers for their suffering and becoming an advocate for all contract workers no matter where they worked," the US vice-president, Al Gore, said in a statement.

Officials said yesterday that the scheme would cost the US government around £250m during the first five years, with expenditure beginning to slow down after that as remaining claims were settled.

A new government-created agency, the occupational illness compensation office, will expedite completion of the claims, using independent medical evidence to decide whether applicants' illnesses are work-related.

webTitle: Spy trial puts position of Iran's Jews in jeopardy

fields.headline: Spy trial puts position of Iran's Jews in jeopardy
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: The long-awaited trial of 13 Jews on espionage and related charges begins today, placing Iran under international pressure and prompting fear within Iran's Jewish community that their freedom could be threatened.
fields.body:
The long-awaited trial of 13 Jews on espionage and related charges begins today, placing Iran under international pressure and prompting fear within Iran's Jewish community that their freedom could be threatened.

At least 10 of the accused are charged with spying for Israel. If found guilty, they face lengthy prison terms or even the death penalty. Three may not be charged with espionage.

The leading lawyer Esmail Naseri said: "All are accused of membership in espionage networks or spying for Israel." He implied that some could have unknowingly been part of a network that spied for Israel. If that were the conclusion of the court, the espionage charge would be dropped.

Rahmat Fazam, the father of Ramin, one of the accused, said: "My son did not do anything wrong. He can't even write his name."

The hearings will be closed to the public according to the head of the judiciary in Shiraz, the town in southern Iran where the trial will be held.

Since the case was made public almost a year ago, western governments led by France and the United States have maintained that it is based on trumped-up charges. Jewish groups abroad have voiced outrage, arguing that the accused are innocent and are suffering religious persecution.

Some Iranian Jewish leaders said the suspects were communicating with Israel by fax and email. Any communication with Israel is illegal.

The government has promised a fair trial, while putting foreign governments on notice that their criticism will have no bearing on the verdict. The furore over the case has sparked concern among leaders in Iran's Jewish community, estimated at 35,000, that the religious freedom they have enjoyed since the 1979 revolution might be slipping away.

Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the founder of the Islamic republic, declared that Jews should be protected. Jews trace their roots in Iran back 2,700 years, when Cyrus the Great allowed them to practise their faith.

For 20 years, they have led a secluded life centred on 56 synagogues. The Jewish population in Iran has remained steady and many prosper as doctors, lawyers and traders.

This case has thrust them into the spotlight. Some said they believe Jewish groups abroad, as well as Israeli authorities, have done them a disservice in claiming that the charges were motivated by religious bias. "I don't think [the case] is based on a religious issue because in religious terms we are free," said Eshaq Niknava, deputy head of the Jewish Society in Shiraz.

"The state has given Jews special privileges. The respect we get now is much greater than in the past," he added.

When the suspects were first detained last spring, the case remained a secret. Jewish leaders in Iran and abroad worked behind the scenes with Iranian officials to resolve the matter. Foreign governments also tried to convince Iran to drop the charges.

But once the case was brought out into the open in June, the international response placed Iran in a no-win political situation. If Iran had agreed to drop the charges, the government's judicial system would have been vulnerable to internal criticism.

"The Israelis and their allies forced the matter by going public too soon," said a senior western diplomat in Tehran. "They wanted to show Iran in a bad light and perhaps encourage the remaining Jews to leave."

Under the reforming president Mohammed Khatami, religious minorities from Zoroastrians to Kurds have been granted more rights than ever to practise their religious beliefs and cultural rituals.

Jews earn credit in public schools for Hebrew courses; they are entitled to a representative in parliament. And they are allowed to drink alcohol and produce kosher foods.

"Khatami and his circle are free thinkers and they have allowed social and cultural activities to be more free," said Manuchehr Eliasi, the Jewish MP. "Our life has improved over the last few years."

If Iran had agreed to drop the charges, the government's judicial system would have been vulnerable to internal criticism. "The Israelis and their allies forced the matter by going public too soon," said a senior western diplomat in Tehran. "They wanted to show Iran in a bad light and perhaps encourage the remaining Jews to leave." Under the reforming president Mohammed Khatami, religious minorities from Zoroastrians to Kurds have been granted more rights than ever to practise their religious beliefs and cultural rituals. Jews earn credit in public schools for Hebrew courses; they are entitled to a representative in parliament. And they are allowed to drink alcohol and produce kosher foods. webTitle: US Red Cross backs Red Star of David

fields.headline: US Red Cross backs Red Star of David
fields.trailText: A row over the use of the Star of David as a recognised emblem for humanitarian assistance is threatening to tear apart the International Red Cross and Red Crescent movement, after the American Red Cross froze part of its international funding until the Israeli branch is admitted as a full member.
fields.body:
A row over the use of the Star of David as a recognised emblem for humanitarian assistance is threatening to tear apart the International Red Cross and Red Crescent movement, after the American Red Cross froze part of its international funding until the Israeli branch is admitted as a full member.

Bernardine Healy, the president of the American Red Cross, said the continued exclusion of the Magen David Adom (MDA), Israel's equivalent of a national Red Cross society, was a "fundamental betrayal" of the movement's humanitarian principles.

The US body's freeze on about £3m - a quarter of the International Red Cross's revenue from membership fees - does not affect funding for international operations, or the US government's contribution.

The MDA and Israel have long sought full recognition with US backing. And the American Red Cross has stepped up its campaign in recent weeks. It has enlisted support from the US Congress and will demand the MDA's immediate admission at a two-day meeting that starts in Geneva today.

"The exclusionary nature has become so obvious ... every sovereign nation is present except Israel," Dr Healy said yesterday.

Eleven other national societies are also awaiting membership and three of them, including Eritrea and Kazakhstan, depend on decisions about use of the emblem. The MDA only has observer status in the international humanitarian movement, largely because it insists on using the red Star of David as its symbol; the star is not either of the two emblems - the red cross or red crescent - recognised under the Geneva conventions.

The ICRC argues that formal recognition of the red Star of David would open the door to a proliferation of emblems, undermining their protective value during conflicts.

"[The] ICRC and Federation would like to be the driving force to solve a problem which has lasted for some 50 years, which has not had much operational consequences because pragmatic cooperation has been taking place with the Israeli society ... ," ICRC spokesman Urs Boegli said. "But it is a matter of principle and of concern."

webTitle: US left flexes muscles for year of protest

fields.headline: US left flexes muscles for year of protest
fields.standfirst: A 'big bang' of direct action is being planned as organisers scent victory
fields.trailText: During the massive demonstrations that prevented the opening ceremony of the World Trade Organisation's Seattle meeting last November, one of the protest's main organisers, Mike Dolan, spotted the veteran campaigner and Californian senator Tom Hayden on the streets.
fields.body:
During the massive demonstrations that prevented the opening ceremony of the World Trade Organisation's Seattle meeting last November, one of the protest's main organisers, Mike Dolan, spotted the veteran campaigner and Californian senator Tom Hayden on the streets.

How does this compare, he asked Mr Hayden, with the big anti-Vietnam war demonstrations and the famous disruption of the Democrats' Chicago convention in 1968?

"The difference is," Mr Hayden told him, "you're winning."

With similar protests planned for the International Monetary Fund and World Bank summits in Washington this weekend and the Democratic and Republican conventions in Los Angeles and Philadelphia this summer, the signs are that the US left in its diverse forms is mobilising in ways that have not been seen since the early 70s. Some of them certainly believe they are winning, and that a "big bang" of activism is under way.

Two "shadow conventions" are being planned for LA and Philadelphia to which activists and campaigners are being invited. They will deal with four main topics: poverty, the drugs war and its social effects, campaign financing and the environment. Already the authorities in Philadelphia are moving to prevent any hint of disruption of the convention by stopping organisers from booking halls.

The moves come as students occupy 12 campuses throughout the country in protest at college investment in sweatshop labour, and as the lowest-paid US workers - the janitors who clean offices - take to the streets in strikes that are winning support across the political spectrum.

Mr Dolan, 44, is the deputy director of Global Trade Watch, which was set up to campaign against unfettered free trade. He is a former field director of the California Democratic party who learned his organising skills with the United Farm Workers' Union and was generally accepted to have played the key role of coordinator in Seattle.

He recounted his encounter with Mr Hayden at a small party last weekend in honour of him and Hillary McQuie, of the Direct Action Network, at the LA home of Arianna Huffington, formerly a conservative Republican but now a supporter of radical action, as espoused in her new book, Overthrow the Government.

Mr Dolan, a famously witty speaker whose staff have likened him to a cross between Woody Allen and Lenin, believes that the success of Seattle has created a momentum for radical causes. "There is a vacuum there," he said. "We have to fill it."

The test of how strong the disillusionment with conventional politics is will come at the weekend when thousands are due on the streets of Washington. They will be protesting at the effects of free trade on poorer countries and against the admission of China to the WTO, because of its human rights record and its treatment of Tibet. The slogan is "fair trade, not free trade."

But there is also a recognition that the two party conventions in the summer, which will effectively be coronations for Al Gore and George W Bush, present an opportunity to make use of the thousands of media people who will be present. Mr Dolan envisages a massive non-violent protest in Los Angeles that could close the convention.

While many of the unions were involved in Seattle, there is uncertainty as to how they will want to play the Democrat convention. Mr Gore already has the endorsement of the AFl-CIO, and senior union officials are anxious that the protests should not benefit the Republicans at the expense of the Democrats. At the same time, the AFL-CIO has run television ads against China's admission to the WTO.

Ms Huffington said at the weekend that John McCain, the unsuccessful Republican presidential candidate, and Antonio Villaraigosa, the Democratic speaker of the California assembly who is tipped to be LA's next mayor, had agreed to address the shadow conventions. Homeless people and relatives of those serving lengthy drug sentences are also due to speak.

Marc Cooper, the co-host of last weekend's gathering, a radical journalist and former translator of the late Chilean president Salvador Allende, with whom he worked, described Seattle as "the big bang of activism, spinning off hundreds of individual activists who returned home energised, cranked-up and ready to rumble some more."

Mr Cooper believes the new movement is very different from previous ones. "To the eyes of an old 60s veteran," he said, the organising meetings were "almost painfully democratic and politely orderly."

The political sea-change is reflected in the growing numbers of student bodies which are becoming politically involved. At the last election, only 22% of Americans between the ages of 18 and 24 voted, but the indications are that many of those are now seeking to take part in campaigns against the growing disparity between rich and poor, in the US and abroad.

"There was a lot of cynicism and hopelessness about when I was at school," said Mia Green-Dove, of Hampshire college, one of the thousands of students heading for Washington this weekend. Last year, she was among nearly 10,000 who demonstrated at the School of the Americas in Georgia against its training for soldiers who later committed atrocities in central America.

"There used to be a feeling of, 'Oh, there's nothing we can do about it'," she said. "Now there is a real feeling that we can help to change things."

webTitle: 'Are you awake? It's Paul. He's had a heart attack...'

fields.headline: 'Are you awake? It's Paul. He's had a heart attack...'
fields.standfirst: A year ago,  Matt Foot  was woken in the middle of the night with terrible news. His father, the campaigning journalist and Guardian columnist Paul Foot, had been taken to hospital with a suspected coronary. This is what happened next...
fields.trailText: A year ago,  Matt Foot  was woken in the middle of the night with terrible news. His father, the campaigning journalist and Guardian columnist Paul Foot, had been taken to hospital with a suspected coronary. This is what happened next...
fields.body:
A year ago, on Saturday April 4 1999 - Easter weekend - I was woken by my flatmate at 2.30am. "Clare's on the phone," he said. In my semi-asleep state I was completely confused. I had had a punishing week at work in my job as a trainee solicitor. I imagined Clare to be a custody sergeant calling from a police station for a suspect who needed representation.

But this Clare was my father's partner and my very close friend: "Matt, are you awake?" she said. "It's Paul. He's had a heart attack. He's gone to hospital. It's very serious. Can you come round? I'm really scared."

In shock, I dressed and made the five-minute drive to Clare's and my father's house in Stamford Hill. My five-year-old sister Kate was asleep in bed, so we decided that I should go to the hospital to be with Paul and keep contact with Clare on the office mobile.

I was not really able to cope with the frightening concept of arriving to find my father dead. Driving to the hospital, I was only able to concentrate by blasting out a tape of my flatmate's band, shouting the words. I was shown into the resuscitation unit in the emergency ward. Dad was awake. "Hi Matt," he said, raising his arm. "You shouldn't have come."

It was clear that something was seriously wrong. One of the two doctors standing nearby told me they had given Paul a drug to thin his blood because they thought a clot had caused a heart attack. Now they were not sure. Paul was in serious pain and was getting weaker by the minute. I tried to reassure him, but he seemed to be dying.

I called Clare and we decided that she should come to the hospital, then I drove to her and my father's home and waited for my sister to wake up. At seven o'clock she came downstairs and asked: "Where's mum?" I explained that Dad was not well and had been taken to hospital. She lay with me on the sofa and dozed off to sleep. As I lay there I felt absolutely shattered for this little girl who could lose her father at such a young age.

Clare phoned later that morning: an X-ray had shown that Paul had not suffered a heart attack, but that his aorta was leaking and could burst at any moment. If the aorta ruptured he would die instantly. Paul's only chance was emergency surgery, but we should all prepare ourselves for the worst. He would probably not survive the journey from the Homerton in Hackney to the London Chest Hospital in Bethnal Green, and in any case the blood-thinning drug would make an already risky operation even more dangerous.

I rang my brothers, Tom and John. Tom, only 19, arranged to come and pick me up. My other brother lives in Milan. I woke him up and he booked a flight straight away.

We all made our way to the London Chest Hospital and met Clare in the family waiting room. They had begun operating at 10am. The longer it went on the better, we were told. Five hours later, Mr Wright, the surgeon, appeared. Paul had survived an extraordinary operation, he said. His aorta had ruptured as they opened him up, yet they had managed to complete the procedure. It was obvious that they couldn't believe he had made it.

Mr Wright explained the remaining hurdles and warned that the next 72 hours were critical. First, Paul had to stop bleeding. Mr Wright thought this might take an hour. Second, when - if - Paul regained consciousness, his heart rate and blood pressure would soar and could tear apart the graft to his aorta. Third, they did not know how much damage his brain had sustained from being deprived of oxygen. If all went well, he could live for another 10 years.

After a few hours we went in to see him. It was a shocking sight. He was asleep, with tubes coming out of everywhere, including a horrible thick one from his neck. There were at least three machines attached to him.

It took a torturous 15 hours for the bleeding to stop. The hospital staff thought they would need to operate again, but said that Paul probably would not make it through another bout of surgery. Eventually, after a second sleepless night for us all, it did stop.

The unexpected crises were somehow harder to cope with. First, Paul's kidneys failed. Then he got pneumonia. His legs and left arm appeared to be paralysed. He kept getting fevers, and he still had not regained consciousness.

All the time, the nurses would tweak and tune the various valves attached to the tubes coming out of different parts of Paul's body. The nurses also kept us going. Immediately after the operation, there was a period when Clare could not face seeing Paul. Carl, a nurse who spent days looking after Paul, came out of the hospital and led Clare by the hand from the lawn and into Paul's room.

The lowest point came some two weeks after the operation. We were summoned by the head of the intensive care unit, who told us they believed that Paul was brain damaged and was probably in a persistent vegetative state. My brother John, who until then had been the optimist, the person who kept us going, broke down. We gave up. We wanted to pull the wires out of his body.

Each member of the family coped with this period in a different way. We had been joined in our appalling wait by Paul's sister Sarah, brother-in-law Tim and brother Oliver. My brothers socialised. I drew upon ex-girl friends - we hoped Paul would get better before I ran out of them. We developed a rather sick humour. Meanwhile, bundles of cards were arriving from the strangest assortment of people - women peace campaigners, Tory MPs, trade unionists (including a huge card from the Fire Brigades Union conference delegates), the entire Daily Express City office, socialists, even a government minister.

We spent a lot of time in the waiting room with other families going through similar crises. At times of severe illness, religion appears to take great hold. We had to fight to stop people praying next to Paul's bed - it seemed to make no difference when we told them that he was a committed atheist and that the shock and anger he would feel if he did suddenly wake up to find someone praying over him would probably finish him off.

It took Paul five weeks to regain consciousness, to blink for the first time on request.

No one could tell us how much he would recover. We were sent off to the London Hospital to see Mr Swash, who was to give us the results of various scans. The only doubt seemed to be whether he was paralysed from the chest down or from the waist. We were not surprised or distressed by this news. It was Paul we wanted back, not his legs.

Soon afterwards, he was put in a general ward at the Homerton. For three weeks we waited for an assessment by Dr Greenwood, the neurologist who heads the hospital's rehabilitation unit. Paul drifted in and out of reality. Strange, rambling descriptions of where he had spent the day flowed out of him. Mostly they were parts of the world he had never visited.

One day we wheeled him over to the rehab unit for an assessment, and he suddenly seemed to rejoin us. He knew who we were.

During the tests, Paul showed a phenomenal ability to remember telephone numbers, but he had no idea when he was born or where he was. Then came the physical tests. We were dreading the moment when he would realise his legs could not move. Then Dr Greenwood asked him to wiggle his toes and, to our utter amazement, his right toe moved a millimetre.

Slowly, Paul started to speak and eat and drink. One day, a speech therapist asked him if he could say a couple of sentences and Paul recited the whole of the prologue to Henry V. We were treated to hours of in-depth discussion of his bowel movements.

In July, Paul was moved into the rehab unit and began the slow process of recovery. Freedom came on October 1, when he went home. A few weeks later I took him with his great-uncle Michael to Devon for the funeral of his uncle John. By long tradition we stopped off at a second-hand bookshop at Ashburton. The trip from the car to the bookshop took an inordinate time as the two men competed in a Monty Python ministry of funny walks contest. I think it resulted in a draw.

It is difficult having a well-known dad who is ill. Everyone wants to talk about it and often you do not. Everyone shares their opinion, which often does not match your own. Even now there are times when it drives me mad to hear how "great" his recovery has been. Sometimes I just want my old dad back.

That said, it is a miracle how far Paul has come, and there are two reasons for it.

Firstly, there is the NHS. The expertise and care shown in the ICU at the London Chest Hospital and the rehabilitation unit at the Homerton were second to none. The commitment of the underpaid, overworked staff is incredible and is abused by this government. We will never forget Carl, Joy, Karen, Collette, Mary, Jim and all the other nurses in Homerton's Howard ward.

Secondly, there is my father. His public school and army background makes him determined to beat the odds. He continually berates his legs for not working properly, but the anger he feels is coupled with a feeling of optimism. He has a lot to live for: Clare; his hopeless ambition to play golf again; his half-completed book; his columns for the Guardian and Private Eye; his socialism - he is standing as a candidate for the London Socialist Alliance for the Greater London Assembly; and for our sister, Kate, who we hope will have many more years of fun with her dad.

The expertise and care shown in the ICU at the London Chest Hospital and the rehabilitation unit at the Homerton were second to none. The commitment of the underpaid, overworked staff is incredible and is abused by this government. We will never forget Carl, Joy, Karen, Collette, Mary, Jim and all the other nurses in Homerton's Howard ward. Secondly, there is my father. His public school and army background makes him determined to beat the odds. He continually berates his legs for not working properly, but the anger he feels is coupled with a feeling of optimism. He has a lot to live for: Clare; his hopeless ambition to play golf again; his half-completed book; his columns for the Guardian and Private Eye; his socialism - he is standing as a candidate for the London Socialist Alliance for the Greater London Assembly; and for our sister, Kate, who we hope will have many more years of fun with her dad.

fields.headline: Pyramid selling
fields.standfirst: The shopkeepers are up in arms. The imams have declared a holy war. But Sainsbury's believes its Egyptian venture is a triumph.  Mona Eltahawy  reveals how a supermarket found itself in hot water on the banks of the Nile
fields.trailText: The shopkeepers are up in arms. The imams have declared a holy war. But Sainsbury's believes its Egyptian venture is a triumph.  Mona Eltahawy  reveals how a supermarket found itself in hot water on the banks of the Nile.
fields.body:
Osama El Khouli's shop in south-west Cairo is almost deserted. Its sole customer is not shopping but talking into a telephone. A little girl pops in to buy some ice cream; two men buy cigarettes. "This is the beginning of the end for small supermarkets like us," says Khouli from behind the till. "They are experts in management and in marketing, which are new policies for the Egyptian market. We don't have their expertise or studies. It's very difficult to compete."

Khouli's problem lies 10 minutes' walk away down the Pyramids Road. Sainsbury's opened its first Egyptian branch there a year ago, the first step in an aggressive expansion programme into the Middle East. There are seven Sainsbury's stores in Egypt now, and the company has an 80% holding in a local chain, Edge, whose 100 stores across the country may also eventually be turned into Sainsbury's supermarkets. Its investment in Egypt is estimated to total £92m so far, with another £325m on the way.

It is the success of the company's Egyptian experiment that has led to what is now known as the Sainsbury's fatwa: a religious edict from the imams in the Pyramids Road mosques that has equated shopping at the supermarket with adultery, stealing and drug trafficking.

In fact, the edict is not strictly a fatwa. The declaration of a fatwa in Egypt is the privilege of the country's spiritual guide, or mufti, and not for local imams. Even so, it gives an indication of the depth of the antipathy to Sainsbury's.

"I argued with some of these roaming preachers about their firm belief that Sainsbury's is nothing but the devil's son," says M Ali Ibrahim, the editor of the Egyptian Mail. "Most of them bit my head off, claiming that their campaign against the British-owned stores is part of their holy jihad against infidels."

According to Ibrahim, beleaguered shopkeepers who ran businesses near the Sainsbury's branch on the Pyramids Road asked local preachers to help them. The imams obliged. Worshippers were told that if they bought from the store they would "suffer on the day of judgment".

One preacher told Ibrahim: "Those unbelievers plan to send hundreds of our Muslim retailers to bankruptcy. They aim to force retailers to lay off their employees and close their stores."

Sainsbury's, meanwhile, claims that the "freelance fatwa" has not hurt its booming Egyptian business. "We've heard of the fatwa through the press," says the supermarket chain's spokesperson, Gillian Bridger. "We've not received anything - no death threats, nothing directly to us about this. The stores are trading well and have exceeded our expectations. The fatwa has had no adverse reaction on shopping. We're extremely popular with shoppers. They call us the consumer champion."

The Sainsbury's in Pyramids Road is full of the old familiars - the orange and white logo, Red Label tea and trolleys with toddler seats. Dozens of Sainsbury's employees in their bright orange shirts stand behind tills, packing and carrying goods for customers. Huge posters announce special offers; leaflets are spread around the store explaining Sainsbury's policies and history.

Dr Mohammed Mahmoud Ali is on his fourth shopping trip to Sainsbury's. "I like it a lot," he says. "It's neat, the people are polite. Compared to Egyptian supermarkets there is a big difference in prices, in things such as rice, soap, sugar, meats and canned goods. Many people have left their local supermarkets to shop here. You can see how many people are here."

For decades, Egyptians made do with the local ba'al , where the shopkeeper weighed and priced goods with little worry of competition. These little corner shops were shaken in the 80s with the birth of the supermarket, where you could pick and choose your own goods. The change was part of a greater one overtaking Egypt. A consumer class was growing, fuelled by the more open policies of late president Anwar Sadat and by petro-dollars that Egyptians brought home from jobs in the Gulf.

Not everybody could keep up, and the gap between the haves and have-nots grew. Now, the local shopkeepers' main gripe against Sainsbury's is that, while it is attracting Egypt's wealthier class, its pricing structure is undercutting them at the other end of the market as well. "My husband and I saved up to come here to shop because we heard it was cheaper than the other places," says a woman who standing outside Sainsbury's with a trolley loaded with bags. "We're getting by on government employee salaries, so it makes a difference if we can save."

And for many staples, Sainsbury's prices are indeed different. Its own-brand pasta is at least 2p cheaper per packet than the cheapest equivalent on the local market; it may not sound much, but it is significant in a country where the average civil servant's salary is less than £35 a month. A packet of washing powder is almost 37p cheaper at Sainsbury's.

Egyptian retailers have accused the chain of deliberately selling goods below factory prices. Asked for an explanation, Sainsbury's says: "Our aim in Egypt is to offer good quality products at competitive prices. We see no reason to sell below cost price."

The Sainsbury's saga is about more than angry shopkeepers and their local preacher cohorts. The true target of the fatwa seems to be a concept Egypt has been learning to live with for several years: globalisation.

Reams of newsprint has been devoted to the subject, as Egypt has slowly moved from socialist-style central planning towards a market economy. From the satellite dishes that line the roofs of the City of the Dead, where the capital's poor live side by side with the tombs of their ancestors, to the ubiquitous mobile phone, modern western culture is seeping into Egyptian life. A couple of months ago, the champion of US-oriented globalisation, New York Times columnist Thomas Friedman, was feted in Cairo when he delivered a speech on the key rules for making it in a globalised economy.

In his column in the Egyptian Mail, Ibrahim warned that there is no turning back the clock. "We should learn how to apply the rules of the free market," he wrote. "Sainsbury's will not be the last company to trade in Egypt. Others will arrive to take their shares."

Bridger says Sainsbury's made its move into Egypt because of the country's "political and economic stability, the size of the potential market, a healthy growth rate, favourable investment conditions, and good relations between the Egyptian and British governments".

For Osama El Khouli and his fellow shopkeepers, those favourable investment conditions could mean the end. "We've all been affected by this," he says. "Pray for us."
