fields.headline: No: 1614
fields.standfirst: Oliver Reed
fields.trailText: Oliver Reed.
fields.body:
Occupation: Hellraiser.

Occupation, when not raising hell: Providing financial support to the British brewing industry, brawling, and (occasionally) acting.

But he's dead, isn't he? Emphatically: he keeled over mid-drink in a Maltese bar last May at the age of 61. Ollie, though, wasn't the sort to be detained by petty obstacles like that for long.

I've got a bad feeling about this. Don't worry: further excruciating TV appearances are rather ruled out by his current location, six feet under down the road from his favourite pub in County Cork. Not so his film career, however.

Women in Love II: The Rematch? Nope, but plenty more naked wrestling all the same. Reed died midway through filming Ridley Scott's £70m Roman flick Gladiator, and the studio has spent £2m on computer wizardry to finish his part.

Almost what they spent on Reed's hospitality expenses, at a guess. Steven Spielberg's Dreamworks studio spared no expense, superimposing Reed's alcohol-battered head onto a body double for his role as Proximo for a crucial two minutes' extra footage.

This summer's family movie? "The guys from Spartacus would pass out if they saw this amount of blood and guts," one critic mused.

Not his first premature exit, I seem to recall. Ah, you'll be referring to Channel 4's 1991 After Dark programme, during which Ollie rambled incoherently about fighting dogs, forcibly kissed feminist writer Kate Millett and forced the station to interrupt broadcasting, before sheepishly asking "do you want me to leave?" and wandering off.

Not to be confused with: Bela Lugosi (who died while filming Ed Wood's Plan 9 From Outer Space, to be replaced by a local chiropodist); Brandon Lee (whose role in The Crow was taken by a computer when he kicked the bucket mid-shoot).

Do say: "What a wonderful posthumous salute to a tragically wasted talent."

Don't say: "If only they'd made all his other films using electronic simulations, he'd never have had to leave the pub at all."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.body:
A column on page 21, April 5, said that Barclays would be closing up to 4,000 bank branches. Barclays has fewer than 2,000 branches and was due last week to shut 172 of them.

Matthew Taylor, the Liberal Democrats' Treasury spokesman, was quoted on page 4, April 10, as saying of the chancellor's tax plans: "Gordon Brown pretends he is Robin Hood. But he is more like the Sheriff of Nottingham with his policies hitting the poor or women." The Sheriff of Nottingham, Mike Whittall, notes that charitable fund-raising is among the core functions of his office. He and the Lord Mayor are currently helping the NSPCC's Full Stop campaign against child abuse, and - for women - the Millennium Millions drive by Nottingham City Hospital to establish a breast-cancer treatment centre in the West Midlands.

Writing about the theft from Bletchley Park, Buckinghamshire, of an Enigma code encryption machine, page 3, April 3, we described the device's former owner, the Abwehr, as "German SS intelligence". The Abwehr was German military intelligence.

fields.headline: JJB bounces back after troubles
fields.standfirst: Sports retailer fares well in battle agains supermarket chains
fields.trailText: Sports retailer JJB bounced back from its problems of 1999 yesterday with better-than-expected profits and strong recent sales figures.
fields.body:
Sports retailer JJB bounced back from its problems of 1999 yesterday with better-than-expected profits and strong recent sales figures.

The group, which ran into problems last year after acquiring rival retailer Sports Division and then struggling to put stock on the shelves, unveiled full-year profits up from £43.2m to £71.0m on sales up from £373m to £614m.

It also reported a bumper start to the new year, with like-for-like sales, which exclude the impact of new selling space, up 27% in February and March.

The huge increase was partly due to last year's figures being so poor, but also the result of JJB's four week "Let JJB pay your VAT" promotional campaign which was designed to reinforce the retailers' image as a value retailer.

The company is facing intensifying competition from the big supermarkets, especially Asda and Tesco. But finance director David Greenwood said JJB has a big advantage over the grocers because the big sports brands prefer to see their goods in specialist outlets.

He said Nike, Adidas, and Reebok "firmly believe that their future lies with the sports trade. They don't want to be selling all their shoes and clothing alongside baked beans."

Nevertheless JJB conceded that its margins are suffering because of its aggressive pricing strategy, and the admission prompted the shares to fall back, although they recovered later in the day to close up 14p at 580p. Last year, at the height of the Sports Division problems, they slumped to 380p.

JJB's strategy is to concentrate on opening new out-of-town superstores and closing down smaller high street outlets. The group plans to open 26 new superstores this year and has also been experimenting with health clubs and soccer domes, which include six-a-side soccer pitches.

It currently has three such outlets - which have a superstore alongside - and plans three more this year. Elsewhere on the High Street, fashion designer and retailer Ted Baker - one of the few companies to escape the carnage in the retail sector last year - unveiled sales up 34% to £37m and annual profits ahead 18% at £8m.

The company warned that its profits growth would now be constrained by the cash it was pumping into expansion, and the shares lost 1p to 485p.

fields.headline: Allianz 'will not force Dresdner breakup'
fields.trailText: Allianz, the Munich-based insurer, yesterday ruled out breaking up Germany's Dresdner Bank and said it had not had any offers for its 21.7% stake in the bank.
fields.body:
Allianz, the Munich-based insurer, yesterday ruled out breaking up Germany's Dresdner Bank and said it had not had any offers for its 21.7% stake in the bank.

Allianz was said to be furious over the failure of the planned merger of Dresdner and Deutsche Bank, which would have given the insurer a big stake in their combined retail outlets.

But yesterday Allianz's chief financial officer Paul Achleitner said that although Allianz was disappointed, "the question of a break-up of Dresdner is a non-issue, it is not on the agenda".

The merger fell through be cause the two sides could not agree what to do with Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, Dresdner's investment banking arm.

Dresdner is now regarded as being open to a takeover bid, but Mr Achleitner appeared to rule out one much canvassed option - a merger with HypoVereinsbank, another bank in which the insurance group has a substantial stake.

"I assume he [HypoVereinsbank chief Albrecht Schmidt] would not welcome such talks, and we cannot make something happen that managements don't want," he said.

Sources say Gerd Haeusler, the chairman of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, is to resign from Dresdner Bank following the collapse of the planned merger.

fields.headline: Watchdog might need a leash
fields.standfirst: Wariness about FSA is justified
fields.trailText: Wariness about FSA is justified | Brown roasted
fields.body:
Today, huffing and puffing, the financial services and markets bill arrives at the report stage. It has taken two years and 1,450 amendments to get this far. If the Conservatives have their way, another 150 amendments will be lurking in the Lords.

Amid the sound and fury of the legislative process there is a danger that the real purpose of the bill is being obscured. Yet that purpose is straightforward enough. The regulatory system put in place in 1987 did not work and had to be replaced.

With the benefit of hindsight it is easy to say that a system based on nine regulators was too cumbersome, too inflexible, with too much overlap. The question now is whether a single regulator with a desire to be flexible will be more successful.

The financial services authority is making many of the right noises. It wants to be a robust watchdog at the retail end of the spectrum while adopting a more sophisticated, risk-based approach to the professional sector where practitioners usually reckon they can look after themselves and worry more about cost than protection.

Critics worry that the FSA will be too powerful, armed with statutory immunity as well as a panoply of roles, from investigator to executioner. They are concerned, too, that the new regime permits but does not insist that the roles of FSA chairman and chief executive be divided.

In some eyes the new regime will be too expensive/heavy handed; driving business out of London, although the rate businesses are still setting up in the City suggests that such concerns are not (yet) affecting decisions on location.

For its part, the FSA argues that it will be neither unaccountable nor overmighty, that the new legislation contains provisions which will make the organisation justify its actions and offer those who think they have been wronged by it the means of redress.

The snag is that drawing up legislation to regulate financial markets is like writing military manuals: the focus tends towards battles of the past. By the time practitioners have learnt the rules, the world - especially that of financial markets - has moved on, providing practitioners with new risks and the potential for unforeseen abuses. At least the FSA is honest enough to acknowledge it cannot run a "no failures" regime.

On balance the FSA probably needs the wide powers envisaged to cope with the challenges ahead. But because, parliament eventually permitting, it will have such wide powers and because the proof of its effectiveness can only be proved by experience, Don Cruickshank's idea that the workings of the regime need future review, and not too future at that, deserves consideration.

Brown roasted

Every school swot knows the feeling: praised to the skies, week in, week out, until one day unfairly accused of doing something wrong and bracketed with all the bad boys and girls.

Gordon Brown found himself in this uncomfortable position yesterday. The chancellor has got so used to being told he is a good boy by the International Monetary Fund and being lavished with gold stars for his handling of the economy that it came as a bit of a shock to be told off by teacher.

The IMF view is that Mr Brown's Budget last month should have done more to take pressure off interest rates and the pound. Instead of riding to the rescue of the ailing NHS, the chancellor should have squirrelled away the huge budget surplus built up last year. This is the sort of thing the dunces of the global economy go in for, not its top performers.

The reaction from the Treasury was one of injured innocence, straight out of the "but, sir" textbook. All that the chancellor has done is spend some of the surplus that nobody - including the IMF - expected him to have. Even allowing for the extra dosh to keep hospitals afloat, fiscal policy is much tighter than seemed imaginable at the time of the pre-Budget report in November.

Mr Brown has cause to feel aggrieved. In a purist sense, the Fund is right. Fiscal policy is now looser than it would have been had the Budget not happened. But much of the improvement in the public finances has been locked in rather than spent. The notion that the chancellor is playing fast and loose with the public finances is ludicrous.

Nor is there any evidence that the Bank of England has been so terrified by the chancellor's act of fiscal juvenile delinquency that it is preparing to push up interest rates. It has known the details of the Budget at the past two meetings of the monetary policy committee and done nothing.

Even good boys sometimes need to let their hair down, and Mr Brown could not simply bank the entire fiscal surplus at a time when the NHS was bleeding dry. Moreover, the extra spending will look a lot cleverer in a year's time if the economy starts to slow. As it probably will.
fields.bodyText: Today, huffing and puffing, the financial services and markets bill arrives at the report stage. It has taken two years and 1,450 amendments to get this far. If the Conservatives have their way, another 150 amendments will be lurking in the Lords. Amid the sound and fury of the legislative process there is a danger that the real purpose of the bill is being obscured. Yet that purpose is straightforward enough. The regulatory system put in place in 1987 did not work and had to be replaced. With the benefit of hindsight it is easy to say that a system based on nine regulators was too cumbersome, too inflexible, with too much overlap. The question now is whether a single regulator with a desire to be flexible will be more successful. The financial services authority is making many of the right noises. It wants to be a robust watchdog at the retail end of the spectrum while adopting a more sophisticated, risk-based approach to the professional sector where practitioners usually reckon they can look after themselves and worry more about cost than protection. Critics worry that the FSA will be too powerful, armed with statutory immunity as well as a panoply of roles, from investigator to executioner. They are concerned, too, that the new regime permits but does not insist that the roles of FSA chairman and chief executive be divided. In some eyes the new regime will be too expensive/heavy handed; driving business out of London, although the rate businesses are still setting up in the City suggests that such concerns are not (yet) affecting decisions on location. For its part, the FSA argues that it will be neither unaccountable nor overmighty, that the new legislation contains provisions which will make the organisation justify its actions and offer those who think they have been wronged by it the means of redress. The snag is that drawing up legislation to regulate financial markets is like writing military manuals: the focus tends towards battles of the past. By the time practitioners have learnt the rules, the world - especially that of financial markets - has moved on, providing practitioners with new risks and the potential for unforeseen abuses. At least the FSA is honest enough to acknowledge it cannot run a "no failures" regime. On balance the FSA probably needs the wide powers envisaged to cope with the challenges ahead. But because, parliament eventually permitting, it will have such wide powers and because the proof of its effectiveness can only be proved by experience, Don Cruickshank's idea that the workings of the regime need future review, and not too future at that, deserves consideration. Brown roasted Every school swot knows the feeling: praised to the skies, week in, week out, until one day unfairly accused of doing something wrong and bracketed with all the bad boys and girls. Gordon Brown found himself in this uncomfortable position yesterday. The chancellor has got so used to being told he is a good boy by the International Monetary Fund and being lavished with gold stars for his handling of the economy that it came as a bit of a shock to be told off by teacher. The IMF view is that Mr Brown's Budget last month should have done more to take pressure off interest rates and the pound. Instead of riding to the rescue of the ailing NHS, the chancellor should have squirrelled away the huge budget surplus built up last year. This is the sort of thing the dunces of the global economy go in for, not its top performers. The reaction from the Treasury was one of injured innocence, straight out of the "but, sir" textbook. All that the chancellor has done is spend some of the surplus that nobody - including the IMF - expected him to have. Even allowing for the extra dosh to keep hospitals afloat, fiscal policy is much tighter than seemed imaginable at the time of the pre-Budget report in November. Mr Brown has cause to feel aggrieved. In a purist sense, the Fund is right. Fiscal policy is now looser than it would have been had the Budget not happened. But much of the improvement in the public finances has been locked in rather than spent. The notion that the chancellor is playing fast and loose with the public finances is ludicrous. Nor is there any evidence that the Bank of England has been so terrified by the chancellor's act of fiscal juvenile delinquency that it is preparing to push up interest rates. It has known the details of the Budget at the past two meetings of the monetary policy committee and done nothing. Even good boys sometimes need to let their hair down, and Mr Brown could not simply bank the entire fiscal surplus at a time when the NHS was bleeding dry. Moreover, the extra spending will look a lot cleverer in a year's time if the economy starts to slow. As it probably will.

fields.headline: Third generation bids top £18bn
fields.trailText: Bids for third generation mobile phone licences topped £18.4bn yesterday, with signs that Vodafone may have won the biggest licence available to incumbent operators.
fields.body:
Bids for third generation mobile phone licences topped £18.4bn yesterday, with signs that Vodafone may have won the biggest licence available to incumbent operators.

Vodafone's £4.55bn bid for licence B remained unchallenged for several rounds of the government's auction yesterday as rival BT Cellnet switched its focus to licence C with an offer of £3.28bn.

Canada's TIW bid £3.9bn for licence A, which is reserved for a new operator. TIW is up against Telefonica of Spain and Amsterdam-listed Worldcom. NTL Mobile bid £3.3bn for licence D and Orange, which is to be demerged from Vodafone, offered £3.35bn for licence E.

Industry experts yesterday predicted that it could take 20 years for operators to recoup their investment into the next generation mobile phones.

The five winners will need to spend a total of at least £12bn to roll out networks for the new licences.

Close Brothers Technology Group, a division of Close Brothers investment bank, does not expect the adoption of third generation phones to rise above 34% of the population by the end of this decade.

"Assuming the number of new subscribers added annually begins to level out after this point, average revenues per user would need to be between £100 and £200 a month if some of the operators are to see any kind of return on investment within the first 15 years," said Paul Lewington, an analyst at the bank.

To compensate, operators would be forced to make deals with other service providers.

"They'll be looking to add substantial value to their basic services through providing content and commerce-based offerings like mobile portals, e-commerce sites and directories," he said.

webTitle: Strike threat over Rolls-Royce job cuts

fields.headline: Strike threat over Rolls-Royce job cuts
fields.trailText: Union leaders are planning to ask Rolls-Royce workers to vote for a strike ballot in an effort to save 2,000 jobs at the aerospace group's UK plants.
fields.body:
Union leaders are planning to ask Rolls-Royce workers to vote for a strike ballot in an effort to save 2,000 jobs at the aerospace group's UK plants.

Workers at the group's civil aviation plant at Hillington, Glasgow, have already approved a strike ballot, and a mass meeting at the group's main Derby works on Tuesday will be asked to approve a similar move.

A company spokesman admitted jobs were being cut and said that compulsory redundancies had not been ruled out. But he said most of the cuts would be achieved through natural wastage or voluntary redundancy.

A spokesman for the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union said the aerospace group had deliberately avoided giving a group-wide figure for job losses to avoid bad publicity.

However, union calculations based on redundancy notices issues by local plants showed that 2,000 jobs were at risk at a time when the group had a record £11.5bn order book.

"All plants are working flat out and there is overtime in abundance at many sites," the union spokesman said.

"Staff at Rolls-Royce fear that people are being let go, and that the company is going to have to bring in contractors at lower salaries and with no job security to fulfil the order book."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Nasdaq tumbles
fields.body:
Nasdaq tumbles

The Nasdaq stock market, the benchmark for US technology companies, fell 23% from its month-old peak at one point yesterday amid continued fears that e-companies are overvalued. By midday New York time the Nasdaq composite index had lost 5% in a few hours to trade below 4,000. The fall, after a volatile two weeks, brought the index into official bear market territory with a decline of more than 20%. A fall in Microsoft, until recently the largest component of Nasdaq, was blamed for some of the sell-off yesterday. Shares in the world's largest software company fell almost 3% at one stage.

Capital rethink on Border bid

Capital Radio was last night considering whether to make a counter offer for Border Television after Scottish Radio Holdings on Tuesday raised its offer for the company to £141m. Border directors, who flew to London yesterday, are understood to have had contact with both Scottish Radio and Capital. Scottish Radio's renewed bid was at £12.75 a share in cash or five new shares for every six in Border - at yesterday's close worth £12.91.

Canal looks at Murdoch deal

Pierre Lescure, chairman of French pay TV group Canal-Plus said yesterday that it would make sense for his company to cooperate with Rupert Murdoch's planned digital television platform Platco. However Lescure excluded a shareholding link between Canal-Plus and Platco. "The platform does not yet exist, but it makes sense for us to cooperate; we are perfectly complementary in geographical terms," he said.

Reuters glitch hits City

Many City firms were left without share prices for up to two hours yesterday after Reuters, the media group, suffered technical glitches. The problem was unconnected to the one last week when a failed Reuters feed prevented the FTSE 100 index being calculated for several hours or the stock exchange problem which prevented the market opening last Wednesday. Reuters said yesterday's problem had arisen as a result of surge in "traffic" over its network.

Early start for euro coins

Several euro zone countries are considering issuing euro coins to citizens in the second half of December 2001, ahead of the formal introduction of euro notes and coins in January 2002, the European Central Bank has said. The advance issuing of euro-denominated notes to the public has been excluded, though. Member states aim to ensure that all cash transactions can be made in euros within a fortnight of January 1, 2002, and ideally want dual circulation of national currencies and euro notes and coins to last between four weeks and two months.

fields.headline: Bookham Technology
fields.trailText: The rocketing price of Bookham Technology's shares saw one of its largest shareholders, Enterprise Capital Trust, dump its 29.9% stake in the group and take a profit of at least £11.7m.
fields.body:
The rocketing price of Bookham Technology's shares saw one of its largest shareholders, Enterprise Capital Trust, dump its 29.9% stake in the group and take a profit of at least £11.7m.

The sale came as Bookham shares soared to £33.50 during the day, valuing it at £3.9bn. At those levels it would have been bigger than British Airways and Freeserve. But the shares finished the session up 87p £25.50, compared with the offer price of £10 apiece when the company listed yesterday.

The Oxfordshire-based company still boasts US technology giants Cisco Systems, the networks group, and Intel, the chip makers, as shareholders.

David Cumming, an investment director at Standard Life Assurance, confirmed that the fund had sold a portion of its Bookham allocation.

"Bookham is a good company and it's being valued as a high growth company."

However, he said that there was a risk that Bookham, like other hi-tech growth stocks, could fall, as long-term growth prospects were already in the share price.

Enterprise Capital, which pocketed at least £11.7m on its investment, had agreed not to dispose more than 30% of its holding.

Bookham 's popularity has stemmed from its 10-year trading history, a claim many of its technology and dot.com cousins cannot make.

Bookham, which is also listed on New York's Nasdaq exchange, has a technology which slashes the costs in manufacturing fibre optic components on silicon chips. It has set itself apart from its competitors which have relied on manually assembled devices.

Bookham's revenues are expected to grow at a compound annual rate of 260% between 1999 and 2001, from £3.5m to £161m, according to Goldman Sachs which is co-ordinating the float.

However, like so many companies in the technology sector, it is loss-making and is forecast to move into the black only in 2001.

webTitle: The deadheads finally sell out to big business

fields.headline: The deadheads finally sell out to big business
fields.trailText: Men of a certain age can often find solace in the words of the Grateful Dead and Ben Cohen, half of the team behind Ben & Jerry's Homemade, proved no exception yesterday. Explaining why he had decided to sell his socially responsible group to Unilever, he quoted a line about "seeing the light" from the song Scarlet Begonias.
fields.body:
Men of a certain age can often find solace in the words of the Grateful Dead and Ben Cohen, half of the team behind Ben & Jerry's Homemade, proved no exception yesterday. Explaining why he had decided to sell his socially responsible group to Unilever, he quoted a line about "seeing the light" from the song Scarlet Begonias.

Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield, the two friends who founded an ice cream phenomena in a converted gas station in 1978, will receive about $49m (£31m) for their 15% stake.

The two men control about 45% of Ben & Jerry's voting shares and may continue to be involved with the company on an independent board of directors. Mr Greenfield, however, is not expected to be as closely involved as his partner because he is apparently unhappy about the company becoming a Unilever subsidiary.

Mr Cohen said Unilever was contractually obliged to increase socially beneficial activities as a percentage of Ben & Jerry's sales each year. It must also continue to buy hormone-free milk from local dairies, retain Ben & Jerry's staff and continue to pay 7.5% of pre-tax profits to the company's charity.

After four months and several takeover offers, Mr Cohen and the board had finally ceded control to the sort of multinational they had long campaigned against.

But in doing so, they appear to have extracted promises from Unilever to maintain the sort of socially responsible practices that encourage consumers to pay extra for with names like Cherry Garcia.

webTitle: Unilever gorges on ice cream and slimming foods

fields.headline: Unilever gorges on ice cream and slimming foods
fields.trailText: The Unilever consumer products group yesterday splashed out £1.6bn on two big US brand names - one which piles on the pounds and a second which helps overweight consumers fight the flab.
fields.byline: Julia Finch  and Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
The Unilever consumer products group yesterday splashed out £1.6bn on two big US brand names - one which piles on the pounds and a second which helps overweight consumers fight the flab.

The Anglo-Dutch food and toiletries group is buying the Ben & Jerry's ice cream empire - whose range includes flavours like Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough and Chubby Hubby - for £200m. At the same time the group is handing over £1.4bn for the SlimFast meal replacement business.

Vermont-based Ben & Jerry's, which was founded in 1978, has built a reputation for "caring capitalism". It hands over some 7.5% of it profits each year to fund social and environmental projects. But the group made it clear it was open to offers earlier this year and Unilever - whose ice cream business already includes brands like Magnum, Solero and Carte d'Or - is paying $43.60 a share to take control. The shares had been changing hands at some $35 and the bid is more than analysts had expected.

A rival consortium - including Anita Roddick, founder of the Body Shop and an active environmental campaigner - which had wanted to nurture Ben & Jerry's reputation recently withdrew its offer, leaving the field clear.

Unilever's joint chairmen, Antony Burgmans and Niall Fitzgerald, said they intended to retain the ice-cream maker's caring, sharing image. "Ben & Jerry's is an incredibly strong brand name with a unique consumer message," they said in a statement. "We are determined to nurture its commitment to community values."

Last year Ben & Jerry's posted sales of $237m, with 90% in the US.

Unilever is undergoing a restructuring which will see 1,200 of its 1,600 brands axed, including Pear's soap and Timotei shampoo.

The company is moving in on the diet business with its purchase of Florida-based Slimfast, a private company whose sales topped $600m last year. "Weight management" products are the fastest growing sector of the food market in the US, where 55% of the population is overweight and up to 25% can be classed as obese. Slimfast has 45% of the market.

Unilever's shares climbed 19p to 431p.

fields.headline: Clark plans float ballot
fields.trailText: C&J Clark, the shoemaker which ranks as one of Britain's biggest privately owned companies, will ballot shareholders on a stock market flotation of the 177 year-old firm in the autumn. Seven years ago, a row over selling out threatened to tear apart the Clark family.
fields.body:
C&J Clark, the shoemaker which ranks as one of Britain's biggest privately owned companies, will ballot shareholders on a stock market flotation of the 177 year-old firm in the autumn. Seven years ago, a row over selling out threatened to tear apart the Clark family.

Tim Parker, the chief executive brought in by the Quaker family to help restructure the business, said yesterday that investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort Benson was advising the firm, but any move to the market would depend on the views of the Clark family, 400 of whom speak for about 70% of the shares.

The move comes amid an extraordinary recovery in Clark's fortunes. Jobs have been slashed and factories closed, changing the face of Street in Somerset, where a third of the population used to work for the shoemaker. The company yesterday reported record profits for the third year running, with operating profits up from £42.5m to £50.4m on turnover up 6% at £779m.

It has been helped by Clarks Originals, drawing on classic designs from the 1970s and 80s, becoming hip again, having been spotted on the feet of pop stars. Sales in the US and Japan are said to be soaring, while in the UK the company accounts for around 10% of the men's shoe market, almost 13% of women's and nearly 30% of the children's market.

"We are powering ahead in most of the markets we operate in," Mr Parker said, adding that the company was considering acquisitions.

Seven years ago the story was different. Sales had been hit by imports of shoes, particularly from India. Berisford International, a conglomerate run by financial alchemist Alan Bowkett, offered £240m for the business, hoping that younger members of the Clark family - and those suffering from Lloyd's of London losses - would be keen to turn their inheritance into cash.

But Shoes - Shareholders Opposed to Enforced Sales - campaigned successfully for the principles of founder James Clark, such as family harmony, modest salaries and long-term company planning.

webTitle: Seattle-style protests are misguided, says Brown

fields.headline: Seattle-style protests are misguided, says Brown
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday delivered a robust defence of the world's financial system against attacks from anti-globalisation protesters amassing in Washington for a Seattle-style rally. The chancellor suggested they are misguided enemies of the poor.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday delivered a robust defence of the world's financial system against attacks from anti-globalisation protesters amassing in Washington for a Seattle-style rally. The chancellor suggested they are misguided enemies of the poor.

In an interview with the Guardian on the eve of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank spring meetings, the chancellor said the two institutions, which some protesters want dismantled, were an essential part of the battle against global poverty.

"I think people should recognise that the way forward is to make the international institutions work better rather than launch a campaign simply against their existence," Mr Brown said.

The chancellor, who chairs the IMF's policy-making committee, said the 54-year-old institution had a crucial role to play in policing the global financial system, ensuring instability did not disrupt growth in developing countries - an essential element of poverty reduction.

The challenge was to create a "virtuous circle" of debt relief for the poorest countries, poverty reduction and economic growth.

With all G7 countries now in favour of 100% relief on their bilateral debts from the world's poorest countries, Mr Brown said one of the main issues of the spring meetings was how to maintain the momentum of the highly indebted poor countries initiative (HIPC).

His recent proposal for a joint IMF/World Bank committee to drive HIPC forward had now been agreed and 10 countries would soon receive debt relief.

Revealing that the treasury has "quietly" given the IMF an extra $43m in recent weeks, he said the funding needed for relieving the debt owed to multilateral institutions was falling into place.

The chancellor, who chairs the IMF's policy-making committee, said the 54-year-old institution had a crucial role to play in policing the global financial system, ensuring instability did not disrupt growth in developing countries - an essential element of poverty reduction. The challenge was to create a "virtuous circle" of debt relief for the poorest countries, poverty reduction and economic growth. With all G7 countries now in favour of 100% relief on their bilateral debts from the world's poorest countries, Mr Brown said one of the main issues of the spring meetings was how to maintain the momentum of the highly indebted poor countries initiative (HIPC). His recent proposal for a joint IMF/World Bank committee to drive HIPC forward had now been agreed and 10 countries would soon receive debt relief. fields.headline: Stagecoach takes a wrong turn
fields.trailText: It has not been a smooth ride this year for transport group Stagecoach. Once the darling of the stock market, it raised a bundle of cash cash from the market last year - by placing shares priced at 154p to fund acquisitions.
fields.body:
It has not been a smooth ride this year for transport group Stagecoach. Once the darling of the stock market, it raised a bundle of cash cash from the market last year - by placing shares priced at 154p to fund acquisitions.

Those days are long gone. Shares in Stagecoach Holdings fell on the day by 10%, down from 70p to 63p.

This was in spite of a meeting with analysts, which Stagecoach's new chief executive, Keith Cochrane, had designed to convince the City that its fortunes were improving.

Last week the stock almost halved in price after a profit warning and news that Stagecoach had sold its Porterbrook train leasing operation to Abbey National for £250m less than had been expected.

Analysts said Stagecoach faced an uphill struggle to overcome problems with its US bus business, while its bus and rail divisions were not growing quickly enough.

Prudential Bache analyst Howard Wheeldon said that the Coach USA business, which was acquired last year, was years away from meeting its cost of capital. "It's a sorry tale of woe."

Steven Bowen, at SG Securities, said Stagecoach had admitted that the company was six months behind in terms of its restructuring programme. "The view now seems to be that the management really need to improve themselves."

Mr Cochrane's meeting with analysts was called so that he could talk through the Porterbrook sale and current trading. But analysts said the meeting had not been reassuring and had highlighted the severity of the group's troubles, including higher insurance rates and fuel costs for its US bus business.

Analysts have been worried for some time about the rapid expansion of Stagecoach abroad, arguing that the company has overstretched itself without proper investigation of what has been happening on the ground.

They believe that other transport companies such as National Express, which have followed Stagecoach into America will be looking anxiously over their shoulders in case they suddenly encounter similar problems.

One analyst said: "It looks as though some of the American deals have been made too much on the golf course without proper investigation."

The only positive development for Stagecoach this week has been the announcement that it was allowed to join its partner Virgin Trains to bid for the Great Western rail franchise when it comes up for renewal.

Together, Stagecoach and Virgin could eventually be the dominant partners on Britain's fast inter-city rail services.

fields.headline: Provenance: bloodstained
fields.standfirst: Nazi loot may have ended up in our galleries. Today arts minister  Alan Howarth announces steps to restore it
fields.trailText: The David Irving case has confronted us anew with the ultimate horror of the Holocaust and the corruptions of latter-day denial. In the meantime, the government is acting to secure justice in respect of abuses, not to be compared with the gas chambers but nonetheless evil and requiring remedy: the looting of works of art in the Nazi era.
fields.body:
The David Irving case has confronted us anew with the ultimate horror of the Holocaust and the corruptions of latter-day denial. In the meantime, the government is acting to secure justice in respect of abuses, not to be compared with the gas chambers but nonetheless evil and requiring remedy: the looting of works of art in the Nazi era.

A conference in Washington two years ago resulted in a commitment to identify art looted from the Jewish people from 1933-1945. This govern ment signed up to it and we asked the directors of our national museums and galleries to carry out an audit of their collections to find out whether they contain items with gaps in their provenance between these years.

"Dubious provenance", of course, covers a broad spectrum: everything from defective record-keeping and misunderstanding on one side, to deception and theft on the other. That the period in question coincided with the darkest decade in European history only increases the possibility of questionable provenance.

Goodwill and painstaking work resulted in the publication, six weeks ago, of preliminary findings. They were extensively reported and, as is the way with these things, a certain amount of sensationalism crept in: "Nazi shadow hanging over 350 works of art", read one headline. In fact, the museums and galleries were simply announcing findings about uncertain provenance. It does not follow that because there is a gap in the recorded history of a particular item it must have been looted. Indeed, so far only one item from any of our national collections - A View of Hampton Court by Jan Griffier - is the subject of a claim from the family that formerly owned it.

This is not altogether surprising. These crimes were not committed in Britain. Even so, the government is determined that justice should be done in any cases where a work of art that is shown to have been looted is in a public collection. To this end, we are setting up a Spoliation Advisory Panel and I will be announcing its membership and terms of reference today. The task of the eminent members of the panel will be to examine cases brought to it by claimants and make recommendations as to what will be a just solution case by case.

The panel, however, will not be a tribunal. Both the claimant and the trustees of the item in question will still be able to seek justice through the courts. But the services of the panel will be available, free of charge, to the parties, and we hope that all concerned can in this way be spared the cost and the anguish of going to court. The panel will be able to consider cases arising anywhere in the UK. It will also be available to assist where an item claimed may be in private possession.

I do not envy the task of those who will serve on the panel. They will have to make recommendations on matters that remain horribly painful to the families who may have suffered, among other unspeakable things during the Nazi period, the looting of cherished and valuable family possessions. Moreover, it may well not be a straightforward matter to identify just solutions. Whatever wrongs were done in the Nazi era, works of art held in our public collections were - we should start by assuming - acquired in good faith and have probably been held for the public benefit for considerable periods.

Later today I will publish terms of reference that contemplate a range of possible remedies for the panel to recommend - including restitution of the work of art, financial compensation and moral recompense through the display of an account of the relevant history.

Some have asked the government to stipulate that there should be a presumption, if not a requirement, that restitution of the object should be automatic if it is shown to have been looted. Although we well understand the strength of feeling that has led to this view, we do not think it right to prejudge the panel's hearings in this way.

It is, moreover, the case that some of the major national museums and galleries in this country are prevented by law from disposing of items in their collections in anything other than narrowly limited circumstances. Restitution may well require legislation. The panel is empowered not only to advise claimants and the holding collections, but also the government itself. I want to make it crystal clear that, if the panel recommend restitution - and both claimant and present owner accept the judgment - the government will take the panel's recommendation very seriously indeed. Our commitment to right these historic wrongs should not be doubted.

We will give most careful consideration to any recommendations that the panel may make to the government itself. There would be no point in having the panel if we did not allow it to reach its own carefully considered conclusions on these matters. Just as there were different circumstances in which works came to be lost, ranging from outright robbery to forced sale at artificially low value, so there should be the option of different potential solutions.

I believe that what we are doing here is a good thing. Great wrongs have been committed in the past, and by this means we will do what we can in our time to redress these wrongs.

fields.headline: 'Cancer link' to nuclear plants
fields.standfirst: Britain's nuclear industry: special report
fields.trailText: Women living downwind of mudflats which contain discharges from Hinkley Point nuclear power plants in Somerset have double the chance of getting breast cancer, according to research being published today.
fields.body:
Women living downwind of mudflats which contain discharges from Hinkley Point nuclear power plants in Somerset have double the chance of getting breast cancer, according to research being published today.

The findings, which controversially associate the steady rise in breast cancer with radioactive discharges, mirror research done in the 1980s which showed that people under 25 living in the same area were more likely to contract leukaemia.

The study by the Green Audit organisation was funded by anti-nuclear organisations and made possible by the release for the first time of ward by ward details of causes of death between 1995 and 1998.

Data from 103 wards was examined, and distance from the mudflats and greater exposure to land-blown particles of radioactive matter from Hinkley Point show a statistically significant excess risk of dying of breast cancer. The worst affected area was Burnham North, directly downwind of the mudflats and the power station. National statistics show 8.7 cases could be expected and 17 deaths were reported. Low lying areas and river valleys where such contamination might be brought in on the tide also showed an excess, the report says.

The theory is that the discharges from the power station lodge in 50 square kilometres of the mudflats and dry out at low tide. They can be blow in on the prevailing wind or during storms in sea spray that penetrates well inland. Women living further inland and on the coast above 200 metres and away from the source of the particles had a below average chance of suffering breast cancer.

The findings by Chris Busby, Paul Dorfman and Helen Rowe from Aberystwyth are part of a series of investigations into the relationships between nuclear discharges, intertidal mudflats and cancer. There were similar findings in north Wales in Bangor, Llandudno and Conwy, where radioactivity from Sellafield is blown inshore from the mudflats. Michael Meacher, the environment minister, ordered an investigation into the findings but so far there have been no further results.

Dr Busby's report says that in the past 15 years leukaemia clusters have been found in the vicinity of all three nuclear reprocessing plants - Sellafield, Dounreay in Scotland and La Hague in France - and other nuclear stations using man-made radioactive substances. The one thing all the sites have in common is that they routinely discharge significant quantities of man-made radioisotopes to the air, river or sea, under government licences, the report says.

A previous study at Hinkley Point done by Cameron Borrie, the chief medical officer of Somerset, concluded that after the nuclear station opened in 1964 there was a statistically significant increase in the rates of leukaemia and non-Hodgkin's lymphoma among under 25-year-olds living in a 12.5 kilometre radius. Cases more than doubled in the first five years of the plant's opening.

Attempts by researchers to follow up these studies by using ward data have been rebuffed by the authorities on the grounds that the data was confidential, but the new office for national statistics makes information publicly available.

Dr Busby said: "Our conclusion is that the discharges may contribute to the risk of breast cancer but there may be some other explanation. The argument that possible causes should not be investigated because information is confidential is no longer supportable."

Jim Duffy, a member of the Stop Hinkley Campaign which partly funded the research, said: "These are very worrying findings and reinforce our view that the discharges have to stop."

British Nuclear Fuels, which runs Hinkley, rejected Dr Busby's findings yesterday. The company said he was a well known anti-nuclear activist and his previous research could not be trusted.

fields.headline: The Very Rev Derrick Walters
fields.standfirst: As dean of Liverpool he built a housing development next to his cathedral
fields.trailText: As dean of Liverpool at a crucial period in the city's history, Derrick Walters, who has died aged 68, had the vision to see how the great Anglican cathedral and the position of its dean could be deployed for the good of the whole community.
fields.body:
As dean of Liverpool at a crucial period in the city's history, Derrick Walters, who has died aged 68, had the vision to see how the great Anglican cathedral and the position of its dean could be deployed for the good of the whole community.

Born in Swansea, the son of a shop steward - from whom he derived his concern for social justice - Walters was educated at Gowerton boys' grammar school and the London School of Economics. After briefly considering a stage career, in 1957 he entered ordination training at Ripon Hall, Oxford. Then came a curacy in Swansea, and in 1962 Walters migrated to England, where two incumbencies in industrial areas were followed by his appointment in 1974 as diocesan missioner in the Salisbury diocese. The rural composition of Wiltshire and Dorset contrasted with the settings in which he had hitherto worked, but for nine years he threw himself into the promotion of the Church's mission in country parishes. His sharp mind and incisive insights were welcomed at the meetings of the bishop's staff; and he developed a penchant for information technology.

In 1983, he was summoned to Liverpool, to succeed Edward Patey as dean. A lesser spirit might well have been daunted both by the vastness of Giles Gilbert Scott's cathedral and by the condition of Liverpool at the time. But Walters, supported by his superb wife Joan, whose radical convictions matched his own, had a clear vision of what could be brought about both within the cathedral and beyond its walls. He blew into the cathedral like a rushing, mighty wind. He enhanced the worship and the music and developed its facilities, giving it a refectory and a shop and making it attractive as a conference venue. He was concerned deeply with its spiritual dimension. He did not pursue his wider projects to the detriment of his primary responsibility.

But Walters could not be confined by the cathedral walls. His theology was based on the kingdom of God, and that drove his commitment to the city of Liverpool as a whole and the conditions of its citizens' lives. He was fortunate to have in David Sheppard a bishop who shared his priorities. When Walters came to the cathedral, there was an expanse of derelict land adjacent to it. He saw his chance and embarked upon what were to become major schemes of development. The waste land was transformed, with the building of Queen's Walk and the John Moores University media studies block, which was named the Dean Walters Building in his honour. There was also the creation of housing for students, for cathedral clergy and staff and, most important of all, public housing. This last was his contribution to the effort to reinstate inner-city living in Liverpool. It was calculated that Walters was associated with developments worth, in total, some £230m.

By any standards, it was an enormous achievement. How did he do it? He saw that the prominence of the cathedral gave its dean some real power. He had great charm and great powers of persuasion, and so was able to draw others to follow his vision and to cooperate in a creative way for the common good. While some saw him as an ecclesiastical entrepreneur, those who worked closely with him soon became aware that his promotion of development sprang from deep theological convictions and that God was at the centre for him.

Beyond any doubt, he left his mark upon many areas of the life of both cathedral and city, which was recognised by the award of an OBE in 1994. His final years were beset by a prolonged struggle against cancer. By a great exertion of will, and with the aid of two sticks, he managed to install James Jones as Bishop of Liverpool in 1999, his last act in the cathedral. His final days were marked by great serenity and by much gentleness and kindness to those around him. He will long be remembered and honoured in Liverpool and in the hearts of his many friends.

He is survived by his wife and two sons.

• Rhys Derrick Chamberlain Walters, priest, born 10 March 1932; died 5 April 2000

fields.headline: Weah makes a bigger splash
fields.trailText: Chelsea 2 -1 Coventry
fields.body:
At last Chelsea have realised the importance of winning the bread-and-butter matches. Their victory overCoventry City in a soggy sandwich of a game here may have come too late to pose a threat to Manchester United, yet it will keep alive their hopes of reaching next season's Champions League by finishing in the top three.

Last night's win has taken Gianluca Vialli's team above Arsenal to fourth placein the Premiership, where they pose the biggest threat to faltering Leeds United's hopes of a bronze. Watching Chelsea fall behind but then recover to master Coventry and the rainsoaked conditions, it was hard to understand how they had dropped recent home points to Southampton and Everton.

Coventry went ahead through Gary McAllister and held their lead until half-time. The arrival of George Weah early in the second half did much to turn the game around for Chelsea, who scored twice in five minutes.

Having reached the FA Cup final four days after establishing a 3-1 lead over Barcelona in the Champions League quarter-finals they had to focus again on securing second or third place in the Premiership.

On paper it looked a simple task. Chelsea had not lost in the league for 15 games and Coventry had not won away in the Premiership for a year.

Naturally Vialli rotated his team; six changes at Wembley, five last night. Yet with surface water splashing around the players' ankles this was no occasion for niceties. After 18 minutes, though, Coventry took the lead with an outstanding goal.

Having broken up a Chelsea move deep in his own half, Colin Hendry brought the ball forward and laid it out to Whelan on the right . Whelan exchanged passes with McAllister and Hendry stepped over his low centre to allow it to reach McAllis ter, who drove the ball low past Ed de Goey.

Four minutes later Tore Andre Flo shot over with only Magnus Hedman to beat and then Hendry's covering tackle thwarted Gianfranco Zola.

The ball's tendency to hold up on a saturated pitch did nothing for Chelsea's passing game and although Gustavo Poyet ended the first half with a shot which flew just wide the Uruguayan, suffering from a chill, went off early in the second. Cold comfort for Chelsea, but Vialli's substitutions changed everything.

Poyet and Flo gave way to Gabriele Ambrosetti and Weah. Within minutes Weah set up Ambrosetti for the cross which the Liberian met with a flick of the head, the ball bouncing into the net off Hendry.

Another five minutes and Jon Harley's pass found Weah clear and onside. He drew Hedman off his line and slipped the ball to Zola, who fired into a gaping net.

Once Coventry fell behind they showed little sign of getting back and Chelsea several times came close to increasing their lead, an offside flag denying Zola.

Vialli made Jody Morris captain, explaining that the 21-year-old midfielder needed the experience as he would surely be given the armband eventually.

Last night's win has taken Gianluca Vialli's team above Arsenal to fourth placein the Premiership, where they pose the biggest threat to faltering Leeds United's hopes of a bronze. Watching Chelsea fall behind but then recover to master Coventry and the rainsoaked conditions, it was hard to understand how they had dropped recent home points to Southampton and Everton. Coventry went ahead through Gary McAllister and held their lead until half-time. The arrival of George Weah early in the second half did much to turn the game around for Chelsea, who scored twice in five minutes. Having reached the FA Cup final four days after establishing a 3-1 lead over Barcelona in the Champions League quarter-finals they had to focus again on securing second or third place in the Premiership. On paper it looked a simple task. Chelsea had not lost in the league for 15 games and Coventry had not won away in the Premiership for a year. Naturally Vialli rotated his team; six changes at Wembley, five last night. Yet with surface water splashing around the players' ankles this was no occasion for niceties. After 18 minutes, though, Coventry took the lead with an outstanding goal. Having broken up a Chelsea move deep in his own half, Colin Hendry brought the ball forward and laid it out to Whelan on the right . Whelan exchanged passes with McAllister and Hendry stepped over his low centre to allow it to reach McAllis ter, who drove the ball low past Ed de Goey. Four minutes later Tore Andre Flo shot over with only Magnus Hedman to beat and then Hendry's covering tackle thwarted Gianfranco Zola. The ball's tendency to hold up on a saturated pitch did nothing for Chelsea's passing game and although Gustavo Poyet ended the first half with a shot which flew just wide the Uruguayan, suffering from a chill, went off early in the second. Cold comfort for Chelsea, but Vialli's substitutions changed everything. Poyet and Flo gave way to Gabriele Ambrosetti and Weah. Within minutes Weah set up Ambrosetti for the cross which the Liberian met with a flick of the head, the ball bouncing into the net off Hendry. Another five minutes and Jon Harley's pass found Weah clear and onside. He drew Hedman off his line and slipped the ball to Zola, who fired into a gaping net. Once Coventry fell behind they showed little sign of getting back and Chelsea several times came close to increasing their lead, an offside flag denying Zola. Vialli made Jody Morris captain, explaining that the 21-year-old midfielder needed the experience as he would surely be given the armband eventually.
fields.bylineHtml: David Lacey at Stamford Bridge

webTitle: Police say new tape nails Cronje

fields.headline: Police say new tape nails Cronje
fields.standfirst:
Game in danger of losing its respect
Inquiry to look into controversial England Test
fields.trailText: Police in India last night said that a "crucial" piece of evidence in their investigation into Hansie Cronje, the disgraced former South Africa captain, had not yet been translated from Afrikaans.
fields.body:
Police in India last night said that a "crucial" piece of evidence in their investigation into Hansie Cronje, the disgraced former South Africa captain, had not yet been translated from Afrikaans.

Detectives revealed the existence of a tape-recording of a conversation apparently between Cronje and a mysterious South African middleman.

The same middleman was also said to have been phoned several times by Sanjay Chawla, the London-based bookmaker who allegedly paid Cronje money during last month's one-day series between India and South Africa.

"We are sure that when we get what's in the conversation it could be clinching," said one police source. "Their talks are of far-reaching significance."

The calls to the unidentified middleman were allegedly made on March 8 by both Chawla and Cronje from the Taj Regency hotel in Cochin, the day before the first one-day international was played.

Detectives, who are now trying to hire an Afrikaans translator, have amassed almost 40 pages of damning evidence against Cronje after three weeks of phone-tapping.

Yesterday Kishen Kumar, a failed Bollywood actor also implicated in the match-rigging scandal, arose unshaven from his Delhi hospital bed to deny any wrongdoing.

Kumar, whom police accuse of raising tens of thousands of pounds to bribe players, admitted that he had been good friends with Chawla since childhood. But he insisted: "Friendship is not a crime. I have done nothing wrong. There is nothing to hide."

Kumar collapsed on Saturday with chest pains shortly after being named by Rajesh Kalra, an associate of Chawla's who was arrested last week as part of the police investigation. Kalra is due to appear in court today.

Kumar told reporters he had been the victim of underworld threats from Indian mafia dons based in Dubai who had burned down his Bombay shop.

KK Paul, the head of the crime branch of Delhi police, yesterday dismissed reports that the money paid to Cronje had been deposited into an anonymous bank account in the Cayman Islands. "This is [just] speculation," he said.

The police chief hinted that more arrests would follow shortly, and said he was confident that the evidence obtained against Cronje would stand up in court.

"Why did he create this drama saying it was all rubbish? If all this was rubbish, there was no need for him to confess." The Cronje tapes remain in a locked police safe.

The South African authorities yesterday pledged to cooperate fully with Indian detectives, though the fact that there is no extradition treaty between the countries makes it less likely that Cronje will ever face trial in India to answer charges of cheating, fraud and criminal conspiracy.

webTitle: Game in danger of losing its respect

fields.headline: Game in danger of losing its respect
fields.standfirst:
ICC under fire for failure to launch worldwide match-fixing inquiry
Police say new tape nails Cronje
Inquiry to look into controversial England Test
fields.trailText: The International Cricket Council's decision not to hold a worldwide investigation into match-fixing in the wake of the Hansie Cronje affair yesterday drew widespread criticism.
fields.body:
The International Cricket Council's decision not to hold a worldwide investigation into match-fixing in the wake of the Hansie Cronje affair yesterday drew widespread criticism.

The former Pakistan captain Imran Khan said that without such an investigation the game would "lose the respect it has earned in a hundred years. The future of the game is at stake".

Tim May, the former Australian Test off-spinner and now chief executive of the Australian players' union, also attacked the game's governing body for failing to react decisively after events in 1994 when Australian players were offered, and refused, money to distort match results.

"Given that this is six years down the track, it's pretty easy to say that cricket has not done a very good job," said May.

May's Australian team-mates Mark Waugh and Shane Warne were subsequently found to have accepted money for providing pitch and weather information - which is much what Cronje has so far admitted to - and were fined by their own cricket board, which kept the matter under wraps for almost two years.

The ICC, though sanctioning an inquiry by the South African government and the United Cricket Board of South Africa in the Cronje affair, says that a worldwide investigation conducted by itself would be unwieldy. Each case, it says, has to be treated on its merits.

The former chairman of the Australian Cricket Board, Malcolm Gray, who will succeed Jagmohan Dalmiya as ICC president in July, conceded that the council's role in dealing with match-fixing had not been all it should, and stressed that leadership was urgently needed from the game's administrators if irreparable harm was not to be done.

"If the public believes what Cronje has done is normal then it will turn away from the sport," he said yesterday. He added that the ICC had introduced a series of regulations at last year's meeting in Christchurch which would combat betting.

"I think the procedures currently in place are adequate or as adequate as they can be," he continued. "We must be ever vigilant and do everything within our powers to stamp out anything of this nature."

Dalmiya insists that the ICC will take all possible steps to eradicate corruption from cricket, although Gray says its code of conduct commission - set up last year under the chairmanship of the British lawyer Lord Griffiths when the ICC discovered it was powerless to enforce regulations in the face of legal attack - is unlikely to be called into play here.

"The news concerning Hansie Cronje is a very big shock to everyone in world cricket," said Dalmiya. "His admission and the other allegations made by the police in India require immediate and thorough investigation and the ICC awaits an early outcome."

Dalmiya is to hold urgent talks in Bombay with the president of the Indian cricket board to establish a strategy for dealing with the threat posed to the game by illegal bookmaking in that country.

Cronje, along with four other South African cricketers, has been charged by the Delhi police with fraud, conspiracy and deceiving and defrauding paying spectators, after investigations into Indian businessmen. The police say they have incriminating taped evidence of Cronje in conversation with a bookmaker during South Africa's recent tour of India.

Common belief is that there will be much more for Cronje to answer when the police present their case, and the South African authorities have already set up their own investigation. President Thabo Mbeki has insisted on a judicial inquiry, to be conducted by Justice Albie Sachs, South Africa's representative on the ICC's code of conduct commission. It is the Sachs connection which has apparently persuaded the ICC to approve the South African inquiry and not instigate another of its own as might seem appropriate.

South Africa is already counting the cost of Cronje's admission, with Standard Bank, one of the main cricket sponsors there, hinting that it will find it difficult to renew its support if the UCB does not resolve the issue satisfactorily.

webTitle: Cronje inquiry to look into controversial England Test

fields.headline: Cronje inquiry to look into controversial England Test
fields.standfirst:
Game in danger of losing its respect
Police say new tape nails Cronje
fields.trailText: England's remarkable Test match victory over South Africa at Centurion last January will be examined by the independent commission of inquiry yesterday set up to investigate allegations of match-fixing by Hansie Cronje.
fields.byline: David Hopps  and  Andy Capostagno  in Durban
fields.body:
England's remarkable Test match victory over South Africa at Centurion last January will be examined by the independent commission of inquiry yesterday set up to investigate allegations of match-fixing by Hansie Cronje.

The revelation came as South Africa's deputy foreign affairs minister Aziz Pahad said his government would co-operate fully with the Indian authorities alleging match-fixing by Cronje. "The government does not have any intention to protect or prejudice any suspect," Pahad said, raising the possibility that Cronje may be forced to give evidence in court in India.

The cricket board's communications director Bronwyn Wilkinson announced that the role of the sacked captain on "the last day of the Centurion Park Test would be covered in the inquiry as well as any other major points of suspicion".

The Test ended in high drama after three days had been washed out. At Cronje's suggestion both captains forfeited an innings to make it possible to avoid a draw. England won by two wickets.

The joint initiative by the board and the South African government confirming the immediate setting up of a commission of inquiry into Cronje's admission that he took between $10,000 and $15,000 from a bookmaker will allay concerns over the threatened desertion of sponsors that could bring financial chaos and undermine their black and Asian development programme.

Standard Bank, sponsors of the one-day side, and the team sponsors, South African Breweries, promised there would be no hasty decisions. But the bank's group marketing director, John Bryant, insisted that the company would "terminate the sponsorship if the affair is not resolved satisfactorily".

That is likely to mean nothing less than a life ban from cricket for Cronje, irrespective of whether his assertion that he has never succumbed to match-rigging, but merely "played along" with his contacts, survives further scrutiny.

Cronje, who could expect to double his cricket earnings of £75,000 a year with endorsements and speaking engagements, has suffered immediate financial repercussions.

The South African restaurant chain Spur Steak Ranches announced yesterday that it had ended its advertising contract with Cronje.

Cronje faces charges of conspiracy, cheating and fraud in India, following allegations from Delhi police that bugged telephone conversations had uncovered a betting scam during the recent one-day series between India and South Africa. But any extradition requests from India will not be considered until South Africa's independent commission of inquiry makes its judgment, Pahad said yesterday.

Placards strung on lamp-posts for the Johannesburg Star captured the sentiments of a nation shaken by Cronje's deception. "Shame," said the headline above a picture of Cronje hanging his head. "Hansie: A nation betrayed."

But Cronje's confession of partial involvement ensured that the response was not entirely hostile. Even yesterday, many South Africans preferred to believe that he had done nothing improper to influence the course of a match.

Support was most striking from within religious groups, where Cronje's reference to his "religious convictions," and his dark-night-of-the-soul confession to a church minister had encouraged many to call for his forgiveness.

webTitle: Three held as police say race attack bogus

fields.headline: Three held as police say race attack bogus
fields.trailText:
Detectives investigating an alleged racist attack in which a 17-year-old youth claimed he was set on fire by a racist gang
   in Berinsfield, Oxfordshire, said last night the attack never took place.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating an alleged racist attack in which a 17-year-old youth claimed he was set on fire by a racist gang in Berinsfield, Oxfordshire, said last night the attack never took place.

Chris Barton, 17, a mixed race youth, said four white men had sprayed him with petrol then set fire to him with lighters after racially taunting him in the early hours of last Friday morning. He suffered superficial burns to his face and hands.

Last night, however, a Thames Valley police spokesman said they were now of the opinion a racist attack never occurred.

"Thames Valley Police treated the case seriously and committed a large number of detectives and one of their four senior investigating officers," the spokesman said.

"All the detectives worked in a highly professional manner and for long hours and are now of the opinion that a racist attack never occurred."

As a result of the investigation two men aged 41 and 37 and a youth aged 17 have been arrested on conspiracy to commit criminal deception.

"All three were arrested on Wednesday morning and are being questioned about various matters," the police spokesman said.

After the attack last week Mr Barton appeared in the press talking about his ordeal. He said he had pulled off his jumper, which was on fire, to avoid more serious burns.

He said then: "I don't want to remember it. It has scared me too much.

"I was frightened when the police came around and showed me the burnt jumper I had been wearing. I never want to see that jumper again. I try to keep myself to myself. We don't know anyone around here."

At the time of the attack residents in Berinsfield, a predominantly white, working class village 12 miles south of Oxford, expressed their shock that such an attack had taken place.

Debbie Waine, 33, whose house overlooked the supposed scene of the attack, said: "People are pretty shaken up. Yes, we have gangs of boys going around in cars pretending to be big and we have fights like you do everywhere but nothing like this."

The Thames Valley police spokesman said: "We would like to reassure all the people in Berinsfield and members of ethnic minority communities in Oxfordshire that this racist attack did not occur."

fields.headline: Off the scrapheap
fields.standfirst: Brixton Breakers was a rubbish-strewn, rat-infested junkyard in south London, over-run by bikers and drug dealers. So how did this squalid patch of land become the cradle of the most exciting new art movement in recent years? Continuing his week-long series on Britart,  Gordon Burn  heads for Minet Road
fields.trailText: Brixton Breakers was a rubbish-strewn, rat-infested junkyard in south London, over-run by bikers and drug dealers. So how did this squalid patch of land become the cradle of the most exciting new art movement in recent years? Continuing his week-long series on Britart, Gordon Burn heads for Minet Road.
fields.body:
There's romantic squalor, the nostalgie de la boue kind of squalor: Soutine and Modigliani in their shitpile in Montmartre in the first world war, pawning their clothes for rotgut wine and ether and opium; Francis Bacon shuffling around among the rag-piles in his mews studio in south Kensington, living like a poor man with lots of money. There's picturesque squalor. Champagne and mousetraps. And then there's squalor that transcends the merely squalid.

Brixton Breakers fitted into the last category. Oh, it was brutal. It was a breakers yard in London SW9 that did exactly what it said it did on the board by the gate: it broke things; bent and totally totalled them. Mostly these were cars connected to some insurance fiddle, stripped and crushed and cubed. They also did re-spray jobs on stolen cars ("hot motors"). And that wasn't the half of it.

They dealt drugs in the Breakers at night, hooded figures in the dark; and some nights had all-night, yard-style parties. Booma-booma-booma. Gerry, the guy who ran it, was a biker, and other bikers from his gang or chapter or whatever would zoom over and hang out. Gerry's clothes were black with sump oil; they were slick and ebonised. His nails were black, and his eyelids and scalp. The artists speculated on whether the chairs in his house were also like that, and his cups, and his children.

Gerry had a sidekick called Chico. Chico wore a greasy mac and bred puppies and was dubbed by the tabloids The Most Evil Man in Britain. He ran a puppy farm in Brixton Breakers, right in among the totalled Toyotas and hot motors. Feral dogs. Now and again, he'd throw them a bootful of raw chicken. Oh, man. Sometimes the feral dogs would escape from their compound and set about people - chase and bare their teeth at the artists.

People using the alley down the right side of the yard were particularly susceptible. This was the way to the studios. It was a rat-run, pitted and cratered. The craters were full of oil and ooze. The rats came to feed on the heaps of crap dumped at the top of the alley by the fly-tippers. Heels of bread and stiletto shoes and burst mattresses. Rats the size of cats. It was bleak and cold and weird. With all this going for it, naturally it was going to attract some of the best artists and finest sensibilities of their generation.

Damien Hirst made all his formaldehyde pieces at Minet Road: the cows, the lamb, the bulls' heads, the pig. He did the spots there and the giant spin paintings with the mad Minet Road titles: "Beautiful, cheap, shitty, too easy, anyone can do one, big, motor-driven, roto-heaven, corrupt, trashy, bad art, shite, motivating, captivating, over the sofa, celebrating painting." Marcus Harvey made one of the most powerful and notorious paintings of the 90s there - his billboard-size portrait of Myra Hindley daubed in childrens' hands.

And after the artists came the collectors, dragging their Lobb and Gucci through the mire, braving the verbals. "Oy, where'd you get your driving licence, on a milk carton?" It became a compulsory stop-over on the international collectors' circuit. People came with chauffeurs. David Bowie came to fling paint on a spin painting with Damien. You wouldn't leave your car to go round the corner for a coffee. There were muggings. A woman artist was mugged twice, both times in the morning. It was scary.

Daniel Coombs spent six weeks clearing car parts out of a space behind Brixton Breakers with Richard Clegg, another former student from the painting school at the Royal College in London. Clegg had always been a bit iconoclastic. He'd been the singer with an anarcho-punk band called Monkey Island and had wrecked the floor of the gallery at the college with a degree show piece made from 2,500 bars of Sunshine soap and cataracts of sump-oil. So he fitted right in.

Coombs, though, had stuck to conventional painting. In 1994, the year before he moved into Minet Road, he'd sold a group of surreal Bauhaus-meets-Butthead canvases to Charles Saatchi. In 1996, Coombs was in Young British Artists 6 at the Saatchi Gallery and then saw his work being shoehorned into the new art movement Saatchi tried to launch just last year: New Neurotic Realism.

But the very particular circumstances at Minet Road soon got to him. It was a wart of land and a jumble of old clapped-out buildings in the middle of a modern council estate; the last remaining trace of a life that had once been lived there. He stopped making paintings and started making assemblages from the rubbish heaped outside the studio door instead.

"It felt like a quite alien environment, in a way," he says. "I felt alien and isolated, and didn't quite know what was happening at first. I found it hard to use a brush and do sensitive paintings. But the strangeness of the place drew us together more. It made us all take quite a hard attitude to our work. It made us want to do something quite brutal. Everybody who produced beautiful work there was influenced by the surroundings. Marcus [Harvey] definitely. He was just starting the Myra piece when I moved in, and I remember being impressed by this giant canvas laid out on scaffolding. It was exciting to think of Damien Hirst making his stuff there. If somebody produces something really outstanding, it gives you an impetus to compete with them."

In his book, The Conditions of Success, the former director of the Tate, Sir Alan Bowness, puts forward the view that most truly original new work is the result of group activity: "I do not believe that any great art has been produced in a non-competitive situation: on the contrary it is the fiercely competitive environment in which the young artist finds himself that drives him to excel... Pollock, Rothko, Newman, Still and de Kooning were all linked together in friendship and rivalry. A post-expressionist generation of distinction - Johns, Lichtenstein, Rauschenberg, Warhol - was to follow them. Artists who emerge from such a situation do not have a consistency of style... but there is a consistency of purpose. They want to get to the top."

Daniel Coombs, Richard Clegg and their contemporaries from the Royal College who followed them to Brixton - Ian Dawson, Martin Westwood, Chantal Joffe - were the second tribe to colonise Minet Road.
